headline: Officer Charged in Fatal Shooting of a Black Man in a California Walmart
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Stun Guns', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Police']
abstract: The Alameda County district attorney said an officer used “unreasonable” deadly force in a confrontation that lasted less than 40 seconds.
lead_paragraph: A California police officer was charged on Wednesday with felony manslaughter for fatally shooting a Black man inside a Walmart in April in a swift confrontation that the district attorney said displayed an unreasonable use of deadly force.

headline: 2020 U.S. Open: What to Watch on Thursday
abstract: A star-studded day at Arthur Ashe Stadium will feature Sofia Kenin, Dominic Thiem, Serena Williams, and Andy Murray in their second-round matchups.
lead_paragraph: How to watch: From noon to 11 p.m., Eastern time, on ESPN, and from 7 to 9 p.m. on ESPN2; streaming on the ESPN app.

headline: Naomi Osaka Is Steadfast in Winning, and Her Message
keywords: ['Tennis', 'United States Open (Tennis)', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Black People', 'Blacks']
abstract: After some upsets elsewhere, Osaka has asserted herself as the clear favorite in the top half of the United States Open women’s singles draw.
lead_paragraph: Through two matches at the United States Open, Naomi Osaka is staying on message.

headline: In Spain, Nightlife Is More Important Than Schools
abstract: The country needs an education revolution.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — Soccer, beaches, bullfights and discos. Spain’s priorities for reopening its economy after months of confinement read like a declaration of the government’s vision for the country. Just days before the school year begins, our politicians have finally decided to tackle what they seem to consider least urgent: the education of millions of students.

headline: Cattle Ship Capsizes Off Japan, Leaving Dozens of Crew Members Missing
abstract: Only one member of the crew was known to have survived. Nearly 6,000 cows were on the carrier, which had been bound for China.
lead_paragraph: The cargo ship, longer than a soccer field, lost an engine as it traversed choppy seas off the coast of Japan. Then a wave flooded its deck in the dark of night, according to a survivor, forcing the vessel to list at a precarious angle.

headline: ‘Love, Guaranteed’ Review: Swiping Left on Online Dating
abstract: Rachael Leigh Cook stars in this rom-com about a lawyer and her charming new client who wants to sue a dating website for falsely promising love.
lead_paragraph: Online dating is put on trial in “Love, Guaranteed,” a featherweight romantic comedy streaming on Netflix. Set in autumnal Seattle, the film follows the lawyer Susan Whitaker (Rachael Leigh Cook) who works doggedly, though often pro bono, causing her boutique firm’s bills to pile up. Cue the coffee cart meet-cute with Nick Evans (Damon Wayans Jr.), a deep-pocketed bachelor who also happens to be a prospective client; he hopes to sue a dating website for its empty promise of love.

headline: This Vertical Farm Was Born in the Pandemic. Sales Are Up.
abstract: The Vegetable Co. sits in a shipping container on the edge of a Malaysian parking lot. It’s one of many small farms around the world selling directly to consumers.
lead_paragraph: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia — The setup of the two friends’ agricultural venture was unusual. Their farm sat next to a gas station, inside a shipping container where the plants grew in vertically stacked shelves. And the timing of their first sales — during the early days of Malaysia’s coronavirus outbreak — seemed less than ideal.

headline: They Wanted Some Private Outdoor Space in Williamsburg. But Where Is the Best Place to Find It?
abstract: For their first purchase together, a couple searched their old Brooklyn neighborhood for a little fresh air — and maybe a second bedroom. Which of these options would you choose?
lead_paragraph: For their first purchase together, a couple searched their old Brooklyn neighborhood for a little fresh air — and maybe a second bedroom. Which of these options would you choose?

headline: Happy 100th Best-Seller Week to ‘Between the World and Me’
abstract: Ta-Nehisi Coates wasn’t thinking about how many books he was going to sell. He was focused on saying what he needed to say.
lead_paragraph: CENTURY CLUB A book that stays on the best-seller list for 100 weeks is as deserving of respect and admiration as a human being who makes it to triple digits. On the current hardcover fiction and nonfiction lists, only two titles have reached this impressive milestone — “Where the Crawdads Sing,” by Delia Owens (104 weeks), and “Educated,” by Tara Westover (132 weeks).

headline: Following My Instincts Back to South Dakota
abstract: Reporting experience at a previous job told me that I should check out the Sturgis Motorcycle Rally this year.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: Mulan, a Most Adaptable Heroine: There’s a Version for Every Era
abstract: Is she a novice or a skilled fighter? Does she end up a blushing bride or does she kill herself? The legend of the female warrior has morphed greatly over some 1,500 years.
lead_paragraph: When rumors of a live-action, nonmusical version of “Mulan” began to trickle out a few years ago, many hard-core fans of the 1998 Disney original groused. No big musical numbers and soaring ballads? No Mushu, the wisecracking dragon, or Li Shang, the movie’s clearly conflicted love interest? No “Reflection”? Many felt that the filmmakers were being unfaithful to the Mulan legend — or at least to Disney’s own version of it.

headline: Goodbye to Lord & Taylor, and the Way We Used to Shop
abstract: I haven’t shopped there in years. But I’m sad to lose another place to gather, and linger, with friends.
lead_paragraph: It’s finally the end for Lord & Taylor. After limping along since its Fifth Avenue flagship closed in 2019, the nearly 200-year-old department store chain announced last week that it will close all its locations. The store meant different things to different people: jobs for its workers, dignified clothing for those who passed through its doors to get a special item, glamour for those who bought luxuries there and elitism for those who couldn’t afford it.

headline: What a 16-Year-Old Learned in Three Months of Portland Protests
keywords: ['George Floyd Protests (2020)', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Black Lives Matter Movement']
abstract: Last summer was all about dance team and teen parties. But after she watched George Floyd’s death in a video on her phone, Daria Allen’s world drastically changed.
lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Ore. — Last summer, it seemed like everyone in Portland was turning 15. Daria Allen’s neighborhood buzzed with a steady hum of quinceañeras and parties. She joined a dance team, and signed up for extra dance classes at a local studio.

headline: Is ‘American Carnage’ Campaign Gold?
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Politics and Government', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Civil Rights Movement (1954-68)']
abstract: What is the political fallout of urban violence? And is the media just buying into it?
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to “The Argument” from your mobile device:

headline: Why an Eviction Ban Alone Won’t Prevent a Housing Crisis
keywords: ['Landlords', 'Evictions', 'Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: Renters receive more relief, but there’s a looming problem for landlords, especially those who own just a few properties.
lead_paragraph: As an eviction crisis has seemed increasingly likely this summer, everyone in the housing market has made the same plea to Washington: Send money — lots of it — that would keep renters in their homes and landlords afloat.

headline: A Quaker School Promoted Liberal Values. Then Its Teachers Unionized.
keywords: ['Private and Sectarian Schools', 'Education (K-12)', 'Organized Labor', 'Quakers', 'Teachers and School Employees']
abstract: Brooklyn Friends, a private school, is trying to dissolve a faculty and staff members’ union.
lead_paragraph: Last spring, Dan Magaziner’s 8-year-old son learned about “changemakers” in his social-studies class at Brooklyn Friends, a private Quaker school in Brooklyn known for its progressive teachings and emphasis on social justice.

headline: How Trump Is Using Westchester to Stir Up Suburban Fears
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Affordable Housing', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Discrimination', 'Suburbs', 'Segregation and Desegregation', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Fair Housing Act (1968)']
abstract: In an appeal to racism among white voters, the president says that Democrats tried to ruin Westchester County, N.Y., through fair housing policies.
lead_paragraph: President Trump on Monday asserted that his Democratic rival, Joseph R. Biden Jr., wants to “destroy” the “American dream” by filling the suburbs with low-income housing projects.

headline: Savor Summer Longer With This Cherry Tomato Pasta
abstract: This simple recipe provides a burst of sunshine any time of year.
lead_paragraph: Separated from perfection by nothing more than a pinch of salt, ripe tomatoes inspire a very particular type of summer joy. In the last few weeks of the season, many of us consume them ravenously, as if storing sunshine for the cold months ahead.

headline: How Libraries Can Save the 2020 Election
keywords: ['Absentee Voting', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Libraries and Librarians', 'Presidential Election of 2020']
abstract: They are among our last trusted institutions. Expanding early voting at local branches may be our best hope for a trusted outcome.
lead_paragraph: As states rush to adapt their election systems amid the coronavirus pandemic, officials estimate that 80 million Americans plan to vote by mail this fall, twice as many as in 2016. Because of Postmaster General Louis DeJoy’s decision to remove or cripple key components of America’s mail system just weeks before Election Day and President Trump’s open efforts to discredit mail-in voting, millions are worried their ballots won’t be counted in time, or even counted at all.

headline: How Do You Open an Interactive Museum in a Pandemic? Very Carefully
abstract: Curators of the new Makeup Museum had to completely rethink their first exhibition.
lead_paragraph: New York’s first Makeup Museum, an immersive, interactive concept focusing on touch and experimentation, was slated to open in May. Its premiere exhibition, “Pink Jungle: 1950s Makeup in America,” would encourage visitors to take part in experiences like mixing their own makeup or indulging in facials modeled on the ones given to Marilyn Monroe and Greta Garbo. Artifacts of that halcyon era, like elaborate compacts or rhinestone-studded lipstick cases, would be available for handling.

headline: Why ‘Rent,’ the Movie, Was My Gateway Musical
abstract: It was a flop, but the film adaptation of the Broadway smash turned me on to theater. And those starving artists made me want to make art too.
lead_paragraph: To think: There was a point in my life when I didn’t know all the words to “Seasons of Love” — or hadn’t even heard of it at all.

headline: A Law-and-Order Push by Trump, but Little Change in Biden’s Lead
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Republican National Convention', 'Criminal Justice']
abstract: The president’s effort to reframe the election at the convention hasn’t helped his standing much, according to a big wave of polls.
lead_paragraph: Despite the spotlight of the Republican convention and the unrest in Portland, Ore., and Kenosha, Wis., a big wave of new polls Wednesday showed that President Trump continues to trail Joe Biden by a significant margin both nationwide and in the critical battleground states.

headline: In Act of Heresy, N.R.A.’s Former No. 2 Calls for Gun Control
keywords: ['Gun Control', 'Firearms', 'School Shootings and Armed Attacks', 'Books and Literature', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A new book from a controversial former executive accuses the National Rifle Association of “appealing to the paranoia and darkest side of our members.”
lead_paragraph: The National Rifle Association’s former second-in-command is breaking with the group’s orthodoxy and calling for universal background checks and so-called red flag laws in a new book assailing the organization as more focused on money and internal intrigue than the Second Amendment, while thwarting constructive dialogue on gun violence.

headline: I’m Doomsday Prepping for the End of Democracy
keywords: ['Republican National Convention', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Rumors and Misinformation', 'Democracy (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: Even if Trump loses, there’s no guarantee we’ll make it to the other side.
lead_paragraph: My wife, Helen, and I got into a quarrel the other day about how to plan for America’s bleak future. Our family needs to replace an aging car, but I’ve been hesitant, wary of making any new financial commitments as the nation accelerates into the teeth of political chaos or cataclysm. What if, after the election, we need to make a run for it? Why squander spare cash on a new car?

headline: We Didn’t Want to Co-Parent a Puppy
keywords: ['Parenting', 'Divorce, Separations and Annulments', 'Anxiety and Stress', 'Dogs', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)']
abstract: Getting a pandemic puppy seemed like a bad idea for a blended family. Until we did it.
lead_paragraph: Even as a child, I never wanted a dog. When I was a longtime single through my 20s, a friend once asked me who I’d rather be with: a partner who had a dog or a partner who had a cat. I said, “a kid.”

headline: Doesn’t Feel Like a Recession? You Should Be Paying More in Taxes
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Budgets and Budgeting', 'Taxation', 'Recession and Depression', 'States (US)', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'E-Learning', 'Income Inequality', 'Income Tax']
abstract: It’s not only the right thing to do, it’s good economics.
lead_paragraph: As the coronavirus pandemic — and Congress’s undersize response — wreaks havoc throughout the economy, tax receipts are cratering. This means that state and local governments are facing enormous revenue shortfalls at the exact time they are dealing with large additional demands. So far, states and localities have responded by slashing spending and jobs, with 1.5 million public-sector workers laid off by the end of June.

headline: Is Virtual Burning Man the Internet’s Ultimate Test?
keywords: ['Burning Man Festival', 'Virtual Reality (Computers)', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Deserts', 'Social Media', 'Creativity', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Festivals']
abstract: The cyberdelic extravaganza is online for the first time because of the pandemic. But maybe that’s not as strange as it might seem.
lead_paragraph: What makes Burning Man so special to those who attend — the cliché among the faithful is “life-changing” — is an intense experience of self-awareness.

headline: Windjamming in the Bay
abstract: With the virus lingering and modified lockdowns still in effect, San Franciscans can still get an adrenaline rush watching kitesurfing daredevils catch air off Crissy Field.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — It is the beachfront version of a double black diamond ski slope, smack in the middle of this major American city, framed by the San Francisco skyline and fog-wreathed Golden Gate Bridge. Playing out against this backdrop most weekdays in summer is a scene so hair-raising as to seem unreal: dozens of board riders pulled by kites across the bay at speeds of up to 40 miles an hour, the boards themselves attached to hydrofoils engineered to lift them above the surface, making it seem as though the riders are suspended between water and sky.

headline: Marian Wright Edelman Steps Down, and a New Generation Takes Over
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Nonprofit Organizations', 'Philanthropy', 'Children and Childhood', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'George Floyd Protests (2020)', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Black People', 'Blacks']
abstract: A Ferguson activist will lead the Children’s Defense Fund at a time when an impassioned civil rights movement is challenging racial injustice.
lead_paragraph: Marian Wright Edelman, 81, took to the streets this summer, joining millions of people around the country in protesting police brutality after the killing of George Floyd.

headline: Waves of Russian and Emirati Flights Fuel Libyan War, U.N. Finds
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Arms Trade', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'Mercenaries and Private Military Contractors', 'International Relations']
abstract: A confidential report sent to the Security Council details extensive breaches of the international arms embargo on Libya by eight countries since the beginning of the year.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — As war raged in Libya last winter, a dozen world leaders gathered in Berlin to talk peace. The contradictions surrounding the conference were no secret: Many of the global leaders who pledged to end foreign meddling in Libya’s conflict were themselves fueling it.

headline: Glamping for First-Timers
keywords: ['Content Type: Service', 'Camps and Camping', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)']
abstract: A novice camper needed a vacation. What are the options during the summer of Covid-19?
lead_paragraph: I’ve never been an outdoorswoman. Though I’m from Texas, spent pivotal teenage years in Kentucky and grew up around hunters and farmers, there’s a difference between spending time outside and living, cooking and sleeping with nature.

headline: The Whitney Reopens With 3 Powerhouse Shows
abstract: When the museum closed in March, it was showing Agnes Pelton’s paintings and Mexico’s great muralists. Thankfully, these works are still up on the walls.
lead_paragraph: The Whitney Museum of American Art is reopening on Thursday, with new safety guidelines that will require visitors to purchase timed tickets in advance. By the time the museum announced its closure in March, our critics had reviewed two remarkable shows: the first New York museum exhibition of the still-mysterious painter Agnes Pelton; and a grand retrospective of the Mexican muralists Diego Rivera, José Clemente Orozco and David Alfaro Siqueiros.

headline: Its Electric Grid Under Strain, California Turns to Batteries
keywords: ['Batteries', 'Power Failures and Blackouts', 'Electric Light and Power', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Solar Energy', 'Wind Power', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Natural Gas']
abstract: When demand exceeded supply in a recent heat wave, electricity stored at businesses and even homes was called into service. With proper management, batteries could have made up for an offline gas plant.
lead_paragraph: Last month as a heat wave slammed California, state regulators sent an email to a group of energy executives pleading for help. “Please consider this an urgent inquiry on behalf of the state,” the message said.

headline: A Turtle With a Permanent Smile Was Brought Back From Near Extinction
keywords: ['your-feed-science', 'Endangered and Extinct Species', 'Conservation of Resources', 'Turtles and Tortoises']
abstract: Scientists have rebuilt the population of Burmese roofed turtles to nearly 1,000 individuals and counting.
lead_paragraph: Conservationists are not known for delivering a lot of good news. But in the Burmese roofed turtle — a giant Asian river turtle whose bug-eyed face is naturally set in a goofy grin — they have cause for celebration. Just 20 years ago, the species was presumed extinct. But after rediscovering a handful of surviving animals, scientists have grown the population to nearly 1,000 animals in captivity, some of which have been successfully released into the wild in Myanmar over the past five years.

headline: Pull Out of the Kentucky Derby? Pressure on a Black Owner Mounts
keywords: ['Horse Racing', 'Kentucky Derby', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'George Floyd Protests (2020)', 'Jockeys, Drivers and Trainers', 'Discrimination', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: Greg Harbut, the rare Black owner of a horse in America’s biggest race, says the predominantly white sport must change. But at a moment of social unrest, others question why he is racing at all.
lead_paragraph: In any other year, Greg Harbut would be enjoying the achievement of a lifetime. On Saturday, he will watch his horse Necker Island enter the starting gate for the 146th running of the Kentucky Derby, a moment of pride for a family that over the generations has built its success in the thoroughbred business.

headline: ‘Just Because I Have a Car Doesn’t Mean I Have Enough Money to Buy Food’
keywords: ['Food Insecurity', 'Food Banks and Pantries', 'Diet and Nutrition', 'Unemployment', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: The economic strain of the coronavirus pandemic has more Americans turning to food banks and charity for help feeding their families.
lead_paragraph: LAKESIDE, Calif. — This is America: a family crammed in a minivan driving mile after mile across San Diego County, first to one food giveaway and then to another and then to more.

headline: Santas have Covid concerns, too: How retailers are preparing for the holidays.
abstract: It’s early to be thinking about holiday shopping, unless you are a retailer. In which case it may be all you can think about.
lead_paragraph: It’s early to be thinking about holiday shopping, unless you are a retailer. In which case it may be all you can think about.

headline: Japan’s convenience store chains are told to stop pushing 24-hour schedules.
abstract: Japanese convenience store owners who have been fighting for a break from their grueling 24-hour, 365-day-a-year operations may be closer to shorter opening hours.
lead_paragraph: Japanese convenience store owners who have been fighting for a break from their grueling 24-hour, 365-day-a-year operations may be closer to shorter opening hours.

headline: Trump Vaccine Chief Casts Doubt on Coronavirus Vaccine by Election Day
abstract: Just as Thailand reached 100 days without a new local case, it found one. The New York Times surveyed more than 1,500 colleges and found that over two-thirds had reported at least one case.
lead_paragraph: This briefing has ended. Read live coronavirus updates here.

headline: Businessman Acquitted in Murder of Jan Kuciak, Journalist in Slovakia
abstract: Marian Kocner was acquitted of ordering the 2018 killing of an investigative journalist that set off anticorruption protests.
lead_paragraph: PEZINOK, Slovakia — After eight months of a closely watched trial, Marian Kocner — once one of Slovakia’s most powerful and well-connected businessmen — was acquitted on Thursday of ordering the murder of an investigative journalist who had threatened to expose a web of corruption involving the nation’s political and corporate elites and organized crime.

headline: N.Y.C. Surpasses 1,000 Shootings Before Labor Day
abstract: The city recorded 242 shootings last month, more than twice as many as in August 2019.

abstract: Hong Kong’s most combative media tycoon, the highest-profile figure arrested under the city’s new security law, discusses his quest for freedom.

headline: Endurance Racing With Cars That Belong in a Demolition Derby
abstract: Autos worth $500 or less have competed for 15 years in a circuslike race called 24 Hours of Lemons. Now electric vehicles have been invited, with no limit on spending.
lead_paragraph: Start with a $500 car. Cheaper is fine, but no higher. Then decorate it outrageously. Maybe with a giant rubber ducky, or a flying pig. Now put it on a racetrack with scores of other half-broken art-cars — and drive it fast as hell for 14 and a half hours.

headline: A Smooth Election
abstract: And what else you need to know today.
lead_paragraph: It really is possible to conduct a smooth election during a pandemic.

headline: Bloomberg Gives Big to Black Medical Schools
abstract: The billionaire is making a $100 million donation to four institutions in an effort to improve the health and wealth of Black communities.
lead_paragraph: Want this delivered to your inbox each morning? Sign up here.

headline: ‘Measure for Measure’ Review: Rising by Sin in Melbourne
abstract: A forbidden love affair causes havoc in Paul Ireland’s ponderous update of Shakespeare’s play.
lead_paragraph: Racism, revenge and a cross-cultural romance compete for screen time in Paul Ireland’s “Measure for Measure,” a dolorous reimagining of Shakespeare’s play set in and around a tower block in Melbourne, Australia.

headline: ‘Critical Thinking’ Review: All the Right Moves
abstract: John Leguizamo directs and stars in this warmhearted drama about underprivileged teenagers who enter a national chess championship.
lead_paragraph: Whether championing math, poetry, or just how to be a decent human being, the inspirational teacher is as familiar to movie audiences as the class stoner. “Critical Thinking” does little to detach itself from genre cliché; yet this heartfelt drama about a rough-and-tumble group of high-schoolers who claw their way to a national chess tournament has a sweetness that softens its flaws.

headline: ‘Feels Good Man’ Review: The Evolution of a Poisonous Frog
keywords: ['Documentary Films and Programs', 'Cartoons and Cartoonists', 'Whites', 'Right-Wing Extremism and Alt-Right']
abstract: A new documentary looks at how the cartoonist Matt Furie’s creation Pepe the Frog became a symbol of hate.
lead_paragraph: As the documentary “Feels Good Man” tells it, when the cartoonist Matt Furie learned that his comic character Pepe the Frog had become an internet meme, he decided not to enforce his copyright. “I’m like an artist, so I don’t like suing other artists,” he explains. Initially, the meme seemed harmless, but Pepe evolved into symbol of white nationalism, anti-Semitism and violence. When Jeremy Blackburn, a computer scientist, shows Furie data that suggest that Pepe has become an “entry point to radicalization,” he asks Furie if he feels “any personal responsibility.”

headline: What All the New Polls Mean for Biden
abstract: The race still has a clear leader, but could be tightening: This is your morning tip sheet.
lead_paragraph: Biden’s still ahead — and with cash to burn. It’s Thursday, and this is your politics tip sheet. Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.

headline: Facebook Moves to Limit Election Chaos in November
keywords: ['Rumors and Misinformation', 'Political Advertising', 'Online Advertising', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Social Media', 'Corporate Social Responsibility', 'Cyberwarfare and Defense', 'Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates']
abstract: The social network said it would block new political ads in late October, among other measures, to reduce misinformation and interference.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Facebook on Thursday moved to clamp down on any confusion about the November election on its service, rolling out a sweeping set of changes to try to limit voter misinformation and prevent interference from President Trump and other politicians.

headline: The Joy of Just Good Enough Theater
abstract: Most plays aren’t masterpieces. As audiences in Paris emerge from lockdown and return to normal, there’s comfort in seeing a show that may not be great, but isn’t bad, either.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — In times of crisis, we want theater to be powerful, hard-hitting, relevant — even more so now, when artists in many countries have to justify why audiences should be allowed to gather and watch them perform.

headline: Michael Bloomberg to Give $100 Million to Historically Black Medical Schools
abstract: The billionaire’s gift is meant to ease students’ debts and free them to serve in needy communities.
lead_paragraph: In the midst of the pandemic, Michael R. Bloomberg is focusing on a unique way to improve the health of Black communities: by giving money to Black students studying to become doctors.

headline: Homeland Security blocked warnings of a Russian campaign against Biden.
abstract: The department’s leaders declined to publish a memo describing Russian attempts to question Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s health, prompting new scrutiny of political influence at the department.
lead_paragraph: The Department of Homeland Security has declined to publish a July 9 intelligence document that warns of Russian attempts to denigrate Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s mental health, prompting new scrutiny of political influence at the department.

headline: Trump moves to cut federal funding from Democratic cities.
abstract: The president directed officials to identify “anarchist jurisdictions” and move to withhold funds as he tries to build his campaign around the unrest that has accompanied racial justice protests.
lead_paragraph: President Trump has directed federal officials to find ways to cut funding to a string of cities controlled by Democrats, citing violence amid protests against systemic racism in policing, a move that threatens billions of dollars for many of the country’s largest urban hubs as the president makes the unrest a centerpiece of his re-election campaign.

headline: As he questions his opponent’s health, Trump finds his own under scrutiny.
abstract: The president denied he had “mini-strokes” at the time of a mysterious trip to the hospital last year. But he raised more questions when he could not keep his explanations for that visit straight.
lead_paragraph: For much of his life, President Trump has promoted himself as a virtual superman who has endless energy, needs little sleep, rarely gets sick and excelled at sports in his youth. As he once dictated in a statement put out in the name of an agreeable doctor, he is “the healthiest individual ever elected to the presidency.”

headline: An internal Census Bureau document lends weight to worries of a hasty 2020 count.
abstract: The Trump administration prompted a barrage of complaints last month when it ordered the Census Bureau to wrap up the counting portion of the 2020 census  by Sept. 30 instead of Oct. 31. The administration ordered the speedup to ensure the delivery of population figures — used to determine congressional districts — by Dec. 31, before President Trump’s term ends.
lead_paragraph: The Trump administration prompted a barrage of complaints last month when it ordered the Census Bureau to wrap up the counting portion of the 2020 census  by Sept. 30 instead of Oct. 31. The administration ordered the speedup to ensure the delivery of population figures — used to determine congressional districts — by Dec. 31, before President Trump’s term ends.

headline: After being used to spread disinformation, Facebook seeks to limit election chaos.
abstract: Facebook moved on Thursday to clamp down on confusion about the November election on its service, rolling out a series of changes to limit voter misinformation and prevent interference from President Trump and other politicians.
lead_paragraph: Facebook moved on Thursday to clamp down on confusion about the November election on its service, rolling out a series of changes to limit voter misinformation and prevent interference from President Trump and other politicians.

headline: ‘He Was the Perfect Pro’: Tom Seaver’s Senses Made Him a Baseball Great
abstract: Seaver, who died Monday at age 75, was recalled as a masterly pitcher who defined the Mets for a generation and belongs in the pantheon of the game’s giants.
lead_paragraph: The most fitting way to celebrate the life of Tom Seaver, the greatest Met of all, is with a wine glass in one hand and a baseball in the other. Seaver, who died on Monday at 75 years old from complications of Lewy body dementia and Covid-19, spent his retirement running a California vineyard. He was better known as a master pitching craftsman who felt the game in his bones.

headline: One Man’s Plea to His City Council: Rename Boneless Wings
abstract: “Nothing about boneless chicken wings actually comes from the wing of a chicken,” he told the Lincoln, Neb., council. “We’ve been living a lie for far too long.”
lead_paragraph: The City Council meeting on Monday in Lincoln, Neb., started like many others: a library board appointment, applications to sell liquor, questions to the parks department about trenching and boring.

headline: Efforts to Channel Protests Into More Votes Face Challenges in Kenosha
keywords: ['Black People', 'Blacks', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Black Lives Matter Movement']
abstract: Some Black residents of Kenosha, upended by the police shooting of Jacob Blake, weren’t convinced that an election would solve the problem.
lead_paragraph: KENOSHA, Wis. — Gerald Holmes, a forklift operator from Kenosha, Wis., was so passionate about the importance of the election four years ago that he drove people without rides to the polls. But this year, Mr. Holmes says he is not even planning to vote himself.

headline: After six months, she hopes unemployment pay is behind her.
abstract: Karen Kent hopes this will be the last week she will have to file a jobless claim. A cafeteria worker at a high school in Pennington, N.J., Ms. Kent, 47, was laid off in early March when the pandemic hit and schools closed.
lead_paragraph: Karen Kent hopes this will be the last week she will have to file a jobless claim. A cafeteria worker at a high school in Pennington, N.J., Ms. Kent, 47, was laid off in early March when the pandemic hit and schools closed.

headline: Can We Talk to Our ‘Blue Lives Matter’ Neighbors About Black Lives Matter?
abstract: A reader wants to know whether her son’s lawn sign crossed a line, and if she should take things further.
lead_paragraph: My husband, our tween son and I moved into a new house at the beginning of the year. We didn’t meet our neighbors before the pandemic hit; we still haven’t. After the horrible police shooting of Jacob Blake last week, our son made a beautiful Black Lives Matter poster and asked if he could display it on our lawn. We were proud to! A few days later, our neighbors seemed to respond with a Blue Lives Matter sign on their lawn. It hurts our hearts when we see it. Were we wrong to put up our son’s lawn sign? Can we talk to the neighbors about theirs?

abstract: To live in New Smyrna Beach, Fla., is to know sharks and forget fear.
lead_paragraph: On a surf outing a few years ago, as I paddled out to the sandbar, I felt something rough and solid brush against my leg. A shadow larger than my shortboard passed in the turquoise water below.

headline: What’s With All the No-Fee Apartments in New York City?
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Real Estate Brokers']
abstract: As rents fall and vacancies climb, the fees charged by brokers are being waived more often.
lead_paragraph: The share of no-fee rental listings in New York City is rising, with 75 to 85 percent of all listings in Manhattan and Brooklyn eschewing broker’s fees during the month of August. That’s a substantial increase from about 50 percent in pre-pandemic January, according to data provided by TextLuke.com, a service that scans apartment listings and makes recommendations based on a user’s requests and responses.

headline: A smooth Massachusetts election could also be a cautionary tale.
abstract: Election experts said that Tuesday’s primary offered a mix of smart policies and harsh deadlines, and that the state benefited from not having a highly charged political atmosphere.
lead_paragraph: Aside from a Kennedy losing, election night in Massachusetts on Tuesday felt almost normal.

headline: Steve Nash, a Coaching Newcomer, Will Take Charge of the Nets
abstract: Nash, a two-time M.V.P. as a player, is believed to have been chosen in part because of the rapport he has established with Kevin Durant.
lead_paragraph: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla. — The Nets made a stunning move Thursday to fill their coaching vacancy by hiring Steve Nash, the Hall of Fame point guard and two-time N.B.A. Most Valuable Player Award winner, despite Nash’s lack of coaching experience.

headline: Dwayne Johnson Tests Positive for Coronavirus, Urging Fans to Wear Masks
abstract: The actor and former wrestler known as the Rock said on Instagram that his entire family had tested positive. “It has nothing to do with politics,” he said. “Wear your mask.”
lead_paragraph: Dwayne Johnson, the actor and former wrestler known as the Rock, announced on Instagram on Wednesday that he and his family had recently tested positive for the coronavirus.

headline: What Does Everyone See in Jesse Plemons?
abstract: After a slew of supporting roles in Oscar contenders by major directors, he is taking the lead in a new Charlie Kaufman film. His goal is to never deliver a false moment.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Jesse Plemons had never felt so lost. It was early March 2019, just a few days before he was supposed to shoot Charlie Kaufman’s “I’m Thinking of Ending Things,” and Plemons still had two questions that he dared not ask of his director.

headline: Jazz Has Always Been Protest Music. Can It Meet This Moment?
abstract: Over the past 50 years, the music has become entrenched in academic institutions. As a result, it’s often inaccessible to, and disconnected from, many of the very people who created it: young Black Americans.
lead_paragraph: If the Black Lives Matter movement has an anthem, it’s probably Kendrick Lamar’s “Alright.” Five years after its release, it’s still chanted en masse by demonstrators and blasted from car stereos at protests, fluttering in the air like a liberation flag.

headline: Up Is Down in This Fun Physics Experiment
abstract: The liquid levitates, and a boat floats along its bottom side.
lead_paragraph: Sail beneath a levitating sea — upside down?

headline: One Family Has Delivered the Mail by Boat for 115 Years. Is This the Last?
keywords: ['Postal Service and Post Offices', 'Boats and Boating', 'Family Business', 'Summer (Season)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: Since 1905, four generations of Quinns have delivered letters, packages and passengers to the islands of Penobscot Bay. A lost summer could sink the tradition.
lead_paragraph: HANCOCK COUNTY, MAINE — In blinding fog, an aging boat called the TM 2 zigzagged through the Cricket Hole, a shallow reef in Maine’s Penobscot Bay. The ocean’s calm surface concealed a maze of unseen ledges, around which the TM 2’s captain, Karl Osterby, cut a tight course. The boat soon approached an aluminum dock on Great Spruce Head Island, where a man in shorts and rubber boots awaited.

headline: Afghan Peace Talks Set to Begin as Prisoner Swap Is Nearly Done
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Peace Process', 'Prisoners of War', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Afghan officials say that the last of thousands of Taliban prisoners are set to be freed, and that talks with the insurgents in Qatar will start soon.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The Afghan government said that a repeatedly stalled prisoner swap with the Taliban had largely been completed on Thursday, potentially removing the final hurdle for direct negotiations with the insurgents to end the country’s long war.

headline: Our 2020-21 Writing Curriculum for Middle and High School
abstract: A flexible, seven-unit program based on the real-world writing found in newspapers, from editorials and reviews to personal narratives and informational essays.
lead_paragraph: Our 2019-20 Writing Curriculum is one of the most popular new features we’ve ever run on this site, so, of course, we’re back with a 2020-21 version — one we hope is useful whether you’re teaching in person, online, indoors, outdoors, in a pod, as a homeschool, or in some hybrid of a few of these.

headline: Webinar Series: Teach Writing With The New York Times
abstract: From September to May, we’re hosting seven free webinars to help teachers use our prompts, mentor texts and contests to teach everything from argument and narrative writing to informational essays and podcast scripts.
lead_paragraph: When schools around the world went remote last spring, we tried to help. From late March to early May, we hosted nine webinars, and over 4,000 teachers, parents and students signed up. We were no experts: Up until that point we had hosted only nine public webinars in total over the previous two years. But the response was enthusiastic, and we were thrilled to get to know so many talented educators and share ideas live.

headline: Tom Seaver’s Shining Star
abstract: A reader tips his cap to the longtime Mets pitching great, who died on Monday.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Rising Shingles Cases in Adults Put Unvaccinated Children at Risk
keywords: ['Shingles (Disease)', 'Clinical Trials', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'Children and Childhood', 'Chicken Pox', 'Parenting', 'Research', 'Rumors and Misinformation', 'Herpes Viruses']
abstract: Parents who get shingles can experience debilitating symptoms and pass the chickenpox virus to their children. So why can’t they have the vaccine?
lead_paragraph: The death of a 30-year-old Texas man made headlines in July when he got infected with the coronavirus after attending a “Covid-19 party.” According to the chief medical officer at Methodist Hospital in San Antonio, the man said he attended a gathering with an infected person to test whether the coronavirus was real and to gain immunity from it.

headline: Andy Murray and Kim Clijsters Picked a Brutal Year for a Comeback
abstract: Injury, retirement and then the coronavirus kept the former stars away from the game. Thrust back into a Grand Slam, they had no time to catch up before facing stiff competition.
lead_paragraph: Andy Murray’s reward for his stunning five-set comeback in the first round of the United States Open was a showdown Thursday night with one of the most talented young players in the world. Felix Auger-Aliassime, a 20-year-old from Canada, may be the sport’s next big thing, a player with speed, power, explosiveness and the deft touch of a natural shotmaker.

headline: ‘Mulan’ Review: A Flower Blooms in Adversity (and Kicks Butt)
abstract: In Niki Caro and Disney’s live-action version of the ancient story, a young woman rides off to war and discovers herself.
lead_paragraph: Feet flying, Mulan enters her new movie with speed and wit. She’s a tyke when she first appears, chasing a protesting chicken. When it takes flight, so does Mulan, by scampering over roofs and all but dancing in the air. The bird is one of the few things that elude her during this otherwise less-than-buoyant epic, which tracks Mulan as she transforms from an unruly daughter into a masculinized warrior in the name of family, nation and those twinned imperial powers called China and Disney.

headline: English Premier League Terminates China TV Agreement Amid Dispute
abstract: The world’s most-watched sports league said it had canceled its biggest overseas broadcast deal, worth over $700 million. It was already facing heavy costs from coronavirus disruption.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The English Premier League, already facing mounting losses because of the continued impact of the coronavirus crisis on soccer and other sporting events, announced on Thursday that it had canceled its most lucrative overseas broadcast contract after it was unable to resolve a dispute with its Chinese partner.

headline: How a Praying Mantis Says ‘Boo!’
abstract: A study of startle displays hints at why provoked creatures have such a wide range of reactions.
lead_paragraph: From a distance, the dead leaf praying mantis resembles its namesake: brown, crispy and still. Inch a little closer and it looks the same. But go even closer — too close — and a transformation occurs. The mantis whirls around, spreads its black-patterned wings and puts its arms behind its head in a pose reminiscent of Edvard Munch’s “The Scream,” showing off shocking red undersides.

headline: Embracing Sexual Identity, These Graphic Novels Burst With Life
keywords: ['Black People', 'Blacks', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Comic Books and Strips', 'Cartoons and Cartoonists']
abstract: In her Graphic Content column, Hillary Chute looks at a reissue of Howard Cruse’s classic “Stuck Rubber Baby” and a new set of tarot cards for the future.
lead_paragraph: Howard Cruse’s STUCK RUBBER BABY (First Second, $24.99), a graphic novel about racial violence and gay subculture in the South of the early 1960s, is immediately fascinating — and disturbing. The first page offers, on either side of the title, an image of the Kennedys, and a racist Southern protest (“Race Mixers Go Back North”). The narrator-protagonist, Toland Polk — whose adult face looms large as a backdrop, and whose gaze meets our own — then recalls the dead bodies he saw that had “stuck” in his mind as a kid. The second page takes up the 1955 picture, published in Jet, of the murdered Emmett Till in his coffin — a “gross” image a friend shows Toland, which “permanently blew a fuse” for him.

headline: A Study in the Subtleties of Northern Rhône Terroirs
abstract: What does a comparison of three bottles from different appellations reveal? Conclusive proof of the power of place is hard to determine.
lead_paragraph: This month we’re going to try something a little different.

headline: Finding the Heart of Zinfandel
abstract: Debating authenticity in wine is often pointless, especially with New World wines. That leaves more options for producers, who are free to surprise.
lead_paragraph: The comment from Preston G. of San Francisco seemed dismissive and definitive. Over the last month, as this column has been exploring zinfandels that were a step back from the popular over-the-top blockbuster style, he wrote: “Restrained is not authentic to the variety.”

headline: A Canadian Poet Channels a 7th-Century Scottish Hermit
abstract: In “The Caiplie Caves,” Karen Solie invents a voice for St. Ethernan, who lived over a thousand years ago and retreated to solitude on the coast of Fife.
lead_paragraph: THE CAIPLIE CAVESBy Karen Solie

keywords: ['Rumors and Misinformation', 'Conspiracy Theories', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Republican National Convention']
abstract: From business competition in New York to President Barack Obama’s birthplace to mail-in voting, President Trump’s goal has been to undermine the opposition and leave people uncertain about what to believe.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump leaned forward in his chair in the Capitol Hill hearing room, tossed aside his prepared remarks as too “boring” and told lawmakers on an October day in 1993 that granting gaming licenses to Native American reservations in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut — a threat to Mr. Trump’s own casinos — would be a big mistake.

abstract: One state learned the hard way that technology won’t get us out of this pandemic. But it can help.

keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: President Trump is said to have spoken privately for years about withdrawing from the alliance, a move that critics say would be a major victory for Russia.
lead_paragraph: For nearly four years, President Trump has publicly railed against the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, angrily demanding that its members pay more for Europe’s collective defense. In private, Mr. Trump has gone further — speaking repeatedly about withdrawing altogether from the 71-year-old military alliance, according to those familiar with the conversations.

headline: Dr. Seymour Schwartz, Who Wrote the Book on Surgery, Dies at 92
abstract: His name is synonymous with his field: He was a founding editor of “Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery,” a seminal textbook for medical students.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Seymour Schwartz, an eminent surgeon and prolific polymath who was the founding editor of the 1,800-page surgery textbook, first published in 1969, that became a bible for medical students, died on Aug. 28 in St. Louis. He was 92.

headline: Pfizer Expects Vaccine Results by End of October
abstract: Pfizer’s chief executive, Dr. Albert Bourla, said the drug-making company is in a “very advanced stage” and should know by the end of October whether the coronavirus vaccine they are developing is safe and effective.
lead_paragraph: Pfizer’s chief executive, Dr. Albert Bourla, said the drug-making company is in a “very advanced stage” and should know by the end of October whether the coronavirus vaccine they are developing is safe and effective.

headline: Stiffing Workers on Wages Grows Worse With Recession
keywords: ['Wages and Salaries', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Minimum Wage', 'Recession and Depression', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: New research shows that minimum-wage violations spike as low-paid workers become more vulnerable and less inclined to complain.
lead_paragraph: Fredy Moreno had been working as a house painter for a few weeks in March when he began to suspect that his boss had no intention of paying him. “He told me that he was going to pay me on a certain date, then moved that date,” Mr. Moreno said through an interpreter. “Then he made an excuse — that he’s in the hospital.”

headline: Pinterest reins in advertising related to political terms.
abstract: Pinterest said on Thursday that it was taking further steps to clamp down on political misinformation on its site.
lead_paragraph: Pinterest said on Thursday that it was taking further steps to clamp down on political misinformation on its site.

headline: ‘Black Love’ Keeps It Simple: Honesty, Not Antics
abstract: The documentary-style reality series maintains its focus on Black lives and relationships while avoiding typical reality TV stunts.
lead_paragraph: In an episode from 2018, the actor Glynn Turman sat on a sofa with his arm draped affectionately around his wife, Jo-An, as the two recounted their experiences together for the documentary series “Black Love.” Amid talk of marriage, children and a meet-cute at Roscoe’s House of Chicken and Waffles, Turman paused to broaden the conversation with an impassioned plea.

headline: The Biden campaign enlists two former players to blame the Trump administration for the lack of Big Ten football.
abstract: A key part of the Biden campaign’s message has been that the nation is continuing to suffer from the Trump administration’s failure to tame the coronavirus outbreak. Joseph R. Biden Jr. pressed the point himself this week with a speech faulting President Trump for the inability of most schools to reopen safely, and on Thursday the campaign took aim at another disrupted American tradition: Big Ten football.
lead_paragraph: A key part of the Biden campaign’s message has been that the nation is continuing to suffer from the Trump administration’s failure to tame the coronavirus outbreak. Joseph R. headline: 7 Things to Do on Labor Day Weekend
keywords: ['Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Music', 'Theater', 'Archives and Records', 'Bard Music Festival', 'Comedy and Humor', 'Classical Music', 'Dancing', 'Jazz', 'Next Wave Festival', 'Pop and Rock Music', 'Festivals', 'DanceAfrica (Dance Festival)', 'Children and Childhood']
abstract: How can you get your cultural fix when many arts institutions remain closed? Our writers offer suggestions for what to listen to and watch.
lead_paragraph: In the recently released video “A Marvelous Night at the Apollo,” members of the team behind the Season 3 finale of “The Marvelous Mrs. Maisel” discuss the making of the episode, “A Jewish Girl Walks Into the Apollo …” The show’s creator, Amy Sherman-Palladino, describes it as a love letter to the Apollo Theater and reveals a personal connection: Her father, the comedian Don Sherman, opened for Dinah Washington at the storied Harlem institution. Washington advised Sherman to drop his act and just joke with the crowd about working with her.

headline: Ready to Try an Ozu Film? Watch These Two Family Tales.
abstract: The Japanese master specialized in portraits of generational conflict. “The Only Son” and “Early Summer” exemplify many of the qualities that make his work so important.
lead_paragraph: Gateway Movies offers ways to begin exploring directors, genres and topics in film by examining a few streaming movies.

headline: The Terrible Cost of Presidential Racism
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Discrimination', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Women and Girls', 'Cold War Era', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: Recently declassified White House tapes reveal how President Nixon’s racism and misogyny led him to ignore the genocidal violence of the Pakistani military in what is today Bangladesh.
lead_paragraph: As Americans grapple with problems of racism and power, a newly declassified trove of White House tapes provides startling evidence of the bigotry voiced by President Richard M. Nixon and Henry Kissinger, his national security adviser.

headline: Unemployment Claims Show Layoffs Continue to Batter Economy
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Unemployment Insurance', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Unemployment', 'States (US)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)']
abstract: Progress in restoring lost jobs has become more challenging. “It’s pretty bad at this stage in the crisis,” one economist said.
lead_paragraph: More than five months after the coronavirus pandemic began throttling the economy, layoffs remain widespread, the government reported Thursday, the latest sign of the labor market’s painstakingly slow recovery.

headline: Russia Spins Alternative Theories in Poisoning of Navalny
abstract: As they have in the past when Russia was accused of misconduct, officials and state media commentators responded to news of a nerve agent attack with an array of improbable explanations.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — To the German chancellor, Angela Merkel, what befell the Russian opposition leader, Aleksei A. Navalny, was alarmingly simple: He was poisoned with a weapons-grade nerve agent in an attempted murder.

headline: Babies Born at High Altitudes May Be Smaller
abstract: Beginning as low as 500 meters, the higher the altitude, the shorter the babies’ length at birth and the slower their growth up to 5 years old.
lead_paragraph: Living at high altitudes may be associated with giving birth to smaller babies who grow more slowly through childhood.

headline: Justice Dept. Plans to File Antitrust Charges Against Google in Coming Weeks
keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Online Advertising', 'Search Engines', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Attorneys General', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The attorney general is said to have set a deadline over the objections of career lawyers who say they need more time to build the case.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department plans to bring an antitrust case against Google as soon as this month, after Attorney General William P. Barr overruled career lawyers who said they needed more time to build a strong case against one of the world’s wealthiest, most formidable technology companies, according to five people briefed on internal department conversations.

headline: Excess Weight May Increase Your Risk of Dementia
abstract: Overweight people were about 30 percent more likely to develop dementia.
lead_paragraph: Being overweight may be linked to an increased risk for dementia.

headline: Siah Armajani, Sculptor of Communal Spaces, Dies at 81
abstract: “I am interested in the nobility of usefulness,” Mr. Armajani said. He kept a low profile, but his public installations garnered wide influence.
lead_paragraph: Siah Armajani, an Iranian-born American artist whose architecturally scaled, politically inflected public sculptures have been internationally influential even as he kept a low profile in the art world, died on Aug. 27 at his home in Minneapolis, where he had lived and worked for 60 years. He was 81.

headline: What Was Your Gateway Musical?
abstract: Our critic confesses she discovered musicals via the widely panned film adaptation of “Rent,” a flop. We want to hear from readers: What was your first favorite?
lead_paragraph: When it was released in 2005, critics were not particularly kind to the film adaptation of “Rent.” The New York Times called it “occasionally silly, often melodramatic and never subtle.”

headline: Navalny Poisoning Raises Pressure on Merkel to Cancel Russian Pipeline
keywords: ['Pipelines', 'Natural Gas', 'Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations', 'Poisoning and Poisons', 'Politics and Government', 'International Relations', 'United States International Relations']

lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany has long defended her decision to go ahead with an $11 billion Russian gas pipeline, sticking to her position that politics and business should remain separate.

headline: 10 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: It’s been 75 years since the end of World War II, and this week we offer a stack of books on the subject — from detailed accounts of the war’s origins (by Roger Moorhouse and Benjamin Carter Hett) to a biography tracing Hitler’s downfall (by the German historian Volker Ullrich) to considerations of the atom bomb and the victory in Japan (by Lesley M. M. Blume and Ian W. Toll). There’s a novel about a German soldier, and a history of the attack that played a little-known role in the development of chemotherapy.

headline: 7 Police Officers Suspended as a Black Man’s Suffocation Roils Rochester
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Black Lives Matter Movement']

lead_paragraph: ROCHESTER, N.Y. — Seven Rochester police officers were suspended on Thursday in the suffocation of a Black man as he was being detained in March, although the mayor and senior state officials faced escalating questions about why more than five months passed before action was taken.

keywords: ['Voter Fraud (Election Fraud)', 'Absentee Voting', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: They say he is sowing confusion about systems that already have robust checks against fraud.
lead_paragraph: By encouraging North Carolina voters to test the integrity of the elections system by casting both mail and in-person ballots, and repeating some of the same claims in a series of tweets and a speech on Thursday, President Trump seemed to mimic a cynical slogan originating in 20th Century machine politics: Vote early and often.

headline: Mark Zuckerberg Is the Most Powerful Unelected Man in America
keywords: ['Social Media', 'News and News Media', 'Rumors and Misinformation', 'Political Advertising', 'Presidential Election of 2020']
abstract: Facebook is too big for democracy.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, Facebook’s chief executive, Mark Zuckerberg, announced the company’s “New Steps to Protect the U.S. Elections.” They include blocking new political ads in the week leading up to Election Day and attaching labels to posts containing misinformation, specifically related to the coronavirus and posts from politicians declaring victory before all the results are counted.

headline: Robert Pattinson Tests Positive for Coronavirus, Halting ‘Batman’ Production
abstract: Work on the film first shut down in March because of the pandemic, which has staggered the entertainment industry.
lead_paragraph: Just days after filming resumed on “The Batman” at studios outside London, it shut down again after the film’s star, Robert Pattinson, tested positive for the coronavirus, according to two people with knowledge of the production.

headline: Congress Must Be Clear: No Doctored Videos
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct']
abstract: A congressman posted a manipulated video. That ought to be taken seriously.

headline: Student Charged in Cyberattacks at Miami-Dade Schools

headline: Memphis Grizzlies Guard Ja Morant Named Rookie of the Year
abstract: Morant, who was the No. 2 pick in last year’s draft, beat out Zion Williamson of the New Orleans Pelicans, who went No. 1.

headline: A Few Students Threw Parties. Now an Entire SUNY Campus Is Shut Down.
abstract: More than 500 State University of New York, Oneonta, students tested positive for the coronavirus less than two weeks after classes began.

headline: Biden, in Kenosha, Makes Case for Healing and Unity, Not Division
keywords: ['Black People', 'Blacks', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'George Floyd Protests (2020)', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Discrimination']
abstract: Two days after President Trump traveled to Wisconsin to focus attention on violence and disorder, Joe Biden sought to strike a drastically different tone, repudiating the president’s divisive approach to matters of racial injustice.
lead_paragraph: KENOSHA, Wis. — Drawing a sharp contrast with President Trump, Joseph R. Biden Jr. on Thursday aligned himself strongly and sympathetically with protesters of racial injustice and with Black voters during an afternoon of raw interactions with people still grappling with the police shooting of Jacob Blake.

headline: Netanyahu Privately Condoned U.S. Plan to Sell Arms to U.A.E., Officials Say
keywords: ['Arms Trade', 'Military Aircraft', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The package being pushed by the Trump White House — which could shift the military balance in the Middle East — includes an electronic warfare plane, the EA-18G Growler.

lead_paragraph: On the evening of Nov. 3, Americans settle nervously in front of their screens to await elections results. In the early hours Donald Trump seems to be having an excellent night. Counting the votes cast at polling places, Trump is winning Pennsylvania, Wisconsin and Michigan.

abstract: George Washington University said it was looking into a blog post written under the name of Jessica A. Krug detailing a long history of deception about her racial identity.

headline: The Rockets’ Small-Ball Strategy Gets a Big Test Against the Lakers
abstract: Houston has fared well since an in-season shift in strategy to use P.J. Tucker, who is 6-foot-5, at center. But will that work against LeBron James and Anthony Davis?
lead_paragraph: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla. — The experiment was formalized on Feb. 6. In a crowded hallway at Staples Center, a couple of hours before his team would face the Los Angeles Lakers and 34 days before the N.B.A. season would be suspended because of the coronavirus pandemic, Houston Rockets Coach Mike D’Antoni announced that he was going small.

headline: ‘They Killed a Son’: Family of Black Man Who Was Suffocated Speaks Out
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'George Floyd Protests (2020)']

lead_paragraph: Seven police officers were suspended and there were protests in Rochester, N.Y., over the death of Daniel Prude, who suffocated after officers put a hood over his head during a mental health call in March.

headline: A Name That Rings a Bell
abstract: This is Brian Thomas’s 10th New York Times Crossword, so you should be familiar with him by now.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — By the time some people work their way up to solving the themeless Friday and Saturday crosswords, they seem to have made an interesting leap from not being so sure they are ready for a tough challenge to the alarmingly confident “Bring it on, (Will) Shortz! And make it really hard this time!” I see comments here on Wordplay and on social media — particularly on Crossword Twitter, a fascinating microcosm of the solving universe — that suggest that the puzzle was so easy for them that they were forced to solve it blindfolded and standing on their heads in order to make it feel challenging.

headline: Corrections: Sept. 4, 2020
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, Sept. 4, 2020.
lead_paragraph: An article on Thursday about the Democrats’ efforts to plan a response to a scenario in which President Trump declares his own election victory prematurely misstated the number of states that do not allow mail-in ballots to be processed before Election Day. It is 11, not 12; New Hampshire changed its rules this year to allow some processing.

headline: As Others Condemn Putin Critic’s Poisoning, Trump Just Wants to ‘Get Along’
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2020']
abstract: At a rally on Thursday, President Trump did not mention the dissident Aleksei A. Navalny, or warnings that Moscow is trying to interfere with the election. When news reports mention Russia, he said, “I just turn it off.”
lead_paragraph: President Trump on Thursday reiterated his desire to “get along” with Moscow despite an international uproar over the poisoning of the Russian dissident Aleksei A. Navalny with a deadly nerve agent, saying that when the subject of Russia appears on the news, he turns it off.

keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Antifa Movement (US)', 'George Floyd Protests (2020)', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Right-Wing Extremism and Alt-Right']

lead_paragraph: LACEY, Wash. — Law enforcement agents shot and killed an antifa supporter on Thursday as they moved to arrest him in the fatal shooting of a right-wing activist who was part of a pro-Trump caravan in Portland, Ore., officials said.

keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Beggars', 'Whites', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Hate Crimes']
abstract: A Black victim’s family seeks a federal investigation into how the police have handled a shooting after a confrontation with a white man.
lead_paragraph: A white man charged with second-degree murder in the fatal shooting of an unarmed Black man who had been panhandling in a Trader Joe’s parking lot in Louisiana was released on bail on Thursday, intensifying calls from the victim’s family to investigate the killing as a hate crime.

headline: Once Up 3-1, the Islanders Now Face a Game 7
abstract: The top-seeded Philadelphia Flyers won their third game of the series after regulation, this time in double overtime, to fend off elimination.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — The Islanders have squandered two opportunities to knock off the top-seeded Philadelphia Flyers and put their mark on franchise history, but they have one final chance on Saturday.

headline: ‘You Should Break Up With Me’
keywords: ['Love (Emotion)', 'Dating and Relationships', 'Colon and Colorectal Cancer', 'Diabetes', 'Widows and Widowers']
abstract: Life can be fleeting. She wanted to make sure he knew the risks of connection.
lead_paragraph: My husband, Amal, used to spend a lot of time in helicopters, his bow tie peeking out of his flight suit. This was in Baltimore, where he and I were pediatricians. Amal worked in a hospital’s intensive care unit, and part of his job was flying with very sick children who needed to be transferred by air. When I expressed worry about him doing this, he would point out that more people die in cars than helicopters.

headline: Expert Picks: Who Will Win the Kentucky Derby
keywords: ['Horse Racing', 'Kentucky Derby', 'Jockeys, Drivers and Trainers', 'Triple Crown (Horse Racing)']
abstract: Joe Drape and Melissa Hoppert weigh in on the contenders for the 146th running of the Kentucky Derby.
lead_paragraph: The horses for the 146th running of the Kentucky Derby, which was moved to Saturday from May 2 and will have no spectators present because of the coronavirus pandemic, are listed in order of post position, with comments by Joe Drape and Melissa Hoppert of The New York Times. The morning-line odds were set by Mike Battaglia of Churchill Downs.

lead_paragraph: How to watch: From noon to 7 p.m., Eastern time, on ESPN, and from 7 to 11 p.m. on ESPN2; streaming on the ESPN app.

abstract: Organizers, concerned at the state of the pandemic in South Florida, put off the event until next year.
lead_paragraph: Citing the toll of the coronavirus pandemic in South Florida, the organizers of the Art Basel Miami Beach fair — which each year attracts the global stars of the art world — said on Wednesday that they were canceling this year’s event, which had been scheduled for December.

keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'Culture (Arts)', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Shoes and Boots', 'Comedy and Humor', 'Book Trade and Publishing', 'Theater', 'Art', 'Security and Warning Systems']

lead_paragraph: This Labor Day Weekend is unlike any other in recent memory: Broadway and most of the city’s live performance venues have been closed for nearly six months; museums have only recently begun to reopen; and unemployment reached alarming levels in April.

keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Veterans', 'Cemeteries', 'Prisoners of War', 'Funerals and Memorials', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government']

lead_paragraph: Georgetown, from the air, looks as if it shouldn’t exist: a scattering of buildings, swallowed up in the vast landscape of scored earth and trees.
