headline: New in Paperback: ‘The Travelers’ and ‘On Fire’
abstract: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
lead_paragraph: STATE: A Team, a Triumph, a Transformation, by Melissa Isaacson. (Agate, 320 pp., $17.) According to our reviewer, Juliet Macur, the “most engaging character” in this sports journalist’s memoir about playing on her (state-championship-winning) high school basketball team in the late 1970s, thanks to Title IX, is the team’s first coach. A supportive gym teacher “seemingly stuck” on feminine sterotypes, she directed her players on the bench to sip water out of Dixie cups rather than drink from bottles like the boys.

headline: A One-Word Answer to the Scattergories Card
abstract: Isaac Jonathan Pomeraniec met Danielle Chelminsky online and quickly got lost in their own “little world.”
lead_paragraph: When Dr. Isaac Jonathan Pomeraniec met Danielle Chelminsky online in July 2018,  he was working at the University of Virginia Medical Center in Charlottesville, Va. He was not expected in Washington until the start of 2019, as part of a seven-year joint residency program between the University of Virginia and the National Institutes of Health, where Dr. Pomeraniec is now a fifth-year resident in neurosurgery.

headline: When My Dad Turned Off the Internet
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Parenting', 'Quarantines', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Families and Family Life', 'Teenagers and Adolescence']
abstract: I’m 16. When my parents were my age, they didn’t have the internet and they didn’t have a pandemic.
lead_paragraph: The pandemic tension in my house reached its peak this summer the night my dad switched off the Wi-Fi. He claimed that “You spend too much time on your phones and not enough time with the family! I never had the internet when I was your age; we used to play on the streets.”

headline: More in Common Than It Seemed on Paper
abstract: After connecting online, Jessica Frogge and Dr. Saif Rathore discovered their similarities were far more profound.
lead_paragraph: Jessica Frogge and Dr. Saif Rathore didn’t initially seem to have much in common. She is Irish Catholic and grew up on the family farm outside Chicago. He is a naturalized citizen who is Muslim, was born in Pakistan and raised in Toronto, Canada’s biggest city.

headline: Teachers Find a Snow-Day Snack at Safeway
abstract: Mackenzie Brown and Weston Kulvete can’t forget the snowstorm that whitened much of the East Coast four years ago. That’s when their romance began.
lead_paragraph: A snowstorm had blanketed much of the East Coast in December 2016, including Baltimore, where Mackenzie Brown, on a snow day from her work was an assistant special education teacher at Kennedy Krieger Institute, took a Facebook break.

headline: The Pandemic of Work-From-Home Injuries
keywords: ['Ergonomics', 'Telecommuting', 'Chairs', 'Computer Monitors', 'Text Messaging', 'Laptop Computers', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Content Type: Service']
abstract: Chiropractors report a surge in problems as millions of workers have spent months clacking away on sofas and beds and awkward kitchen counters.
lead_paragraph: Elizabeth Cuthrell, a Manhattan-based film producer, used to work in an ergonomic office space: comfortable desk chair, monitor at eye level, external keyboard. Then came Covid-19. During stay-at-home she worked on a laptop from a wicker chair, or sometimes on a couch with “cushions like marshmallows.” A month later she felt pain in her neck, wrist and shoulders that sent her to a chiropractor.

headline: TikTok Bid Highlights Oracle’s Public Embrace of Trump
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Mobile Applications', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The tech giant stands out in Silicon Valley for its close ties to the administration, which must bless any deal for the social media app.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In March, when the Trump administration ordered up a study enabling the widespread release of the malaria drug hydroxychloroquine to treat Covid-19, one of the first questions the director of a government research agency that would oversee the trial asked was: “Who has talked with Oracle?”

headline: Uber Is Hurting Drivers Like Me in Its Legal Fight in California
keywords: ['Car Services and Livery Cabs', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Taxicabs and Taxicab Drivers', 'Freelancing, Self-Employment and Independent Contracting', 'Chauffeurs and Drivers', 'Living Wage']
abstract: We’re in limbo as the ride-hailing company spends millions fighting a new state law.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — I love to drive. Before Uber, I was a car service owner-operator for 10 years and got a thrill out of meeting new people while making my way around San Francisco, a place I’ve called home for over 30 years. I drove my black Mercedes sedan full-time five to six days a week, and counted myself lucky. When my wife died in 2011, I stopped, taking time to grieve.

headline: Taking Their Love From AIM to IRL
abstract: During high school, Kaitlyn O’Hagan and Rohaan Menon would message each other late into the night, but it would be eight more years before they fell in love.
lead_paragraph: Kaitlyn O’Hagan, 28, and Rohaan Menon, 29, spent the summer of 2007 messaging each other on AOL’s instant messaging service, AIM. They were rising juniors at Stuyvesant High School in Manhattan, and were in the same friend group at the end of their sophomore year. But when school started again in the fall, “nothing really came of it,” said Ms. O’Hagan, who is a doctoral student and research assistant at the N.Y.U. Wagner School of Public Service.

headline: Can Pools Help to Deter Crime?
keywords: ['Swimming Pools', 'Politics and Government', 'Crime and Criminals', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)']
abstract: The pandemic has limited access to public pools in New York this summer — and violence has soared.
lead_paragraph: In August of 1969, New York mayor John V. Lindsay flew by helicopter to the Bronx to commemorate the opening of two new municipal pools, each of them appointed with murals and built with great investments of hope. He used the occasion to announce that many more pools were planned for the city. Pool construction had lagged in New York since the Depression, when the Works Progress Administration oversaw the creation of some of the most impressive recreational facilities ever built in the country. Lindsay was committing to a new period of aquatic innovation.

headline: The Trouble With Empathy
abstract: Can we really be taught to feel each other’s pain?
lead_paragraph: When my daughter started remote kindergarten last month, the schedule sent to parents included more than reading, math, art and other traditional subjects. She’ll also have sessions devoted to “social and emotional learning.” Themes range from listening skills and reading nonverbal cues to how to spot and defuse bullying.

headline: I Study Corporate Welfare. Even I Was Shocked by This Cronyism.
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Conflicts of Interest', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists']
abstract: A privately owned entity created by the Export-Import Bank allows its customers to also be its owners.
lead_paragraph: Right under the nose of a president who promised to drain the swamp, one of the government’s shadiest handouts to large banks and big companies looks like it will be renewed for another 25 years. It will not get adequate oversight and congressional review. All it will take is the approval of two out of three U.S. Export-Import Bank directors, who are political appointees.

headline: The Inanity of Zoom School Suspensions
abstract: Disciplinary action is often needless and discriminatory. The patchwork of in-person and virtual schooling is making things worse.
lead_paragraph: I’m going to be honest: I didn’t know what I was doing.

headline: N.B.A.’s Head Coaching Diversity Under Scrutiny as Vacancies Loom
keywords: ['Basketball', 'Coaches and Managers', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Discrimination', 'Hiring and Promotion', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: Steve Nash, who is white, landed a head coaching job this week despite his inexperience, renewing discussions about how few posts are filled by Black people in a league where most players are Black.
lead_paragraph: The splashy, surprising hire of Steve Nash as the Nets’ head coach is sure to galvanize the team’s fan base, with a roster headlined by Kevin Durant and Kyrie Irving primed to immediately compete for a championship.

headline: From Long-Distance Running to Long-Distance Love
abstract: Anthony Tran and Sean Theriault, who met while training for the Boston Marathon in 2002, haven’t stopped running together since.
lead_paragraph: Anthony Bristol Tran likes to imagine how he might have met Sean Michael Theriault. His alternate version tells of a kinetic encounter: Dr. Tran, a serious runner, sees a dashing, hazel-eyed man go past him during a marathon. Their eyes catch. A gaze is held just a moment too long. And then, just like that, those hazels disappear up the track.

headline: ‘Mulan’ 1998: A Moment of Joy and Anxiety for Asian-American Viewers
abstract: Though the original Disney movie was culturally significant, it came out in a film era when people of color were routinely tokenized.
lead_paragraph: Disney’s new live-action “Mulan” is coming at a time when the entertainment world is still feeling tremors from the success of “Crazy Rich Asians” and “Parasite.” It was a very different landscape when the animated “Mulan” debuted in 1998: American audiences were far less used to the presence of Asians onscreen and many Asian-American moviegoers felt less comfortable with depictions of themselves.

headline: The Conspiracist in Chief Will Save Us All
keywords: ['QAnon', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Conspiracy Theories', 'Fringe Groups and Movements', 'Social Media', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Republicans have a QAnon problem, which means the rest of America does too.
lead_paragraph: Conspiratorial thinking is an elemental part of American political life, one that stretches back to before the founding of the United States.

headline: Spectators Are Not Allowed at the U.S. Open. Except These Lucky Few.
abstract: Baristas, court attendants and other employees are enjoying an odd perk this year: Access to the matches, without the crowds.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. Open is usually a crowded, raucous and very New York affair. Local luminaries like Alec Baldwin, Spike Lee and Katie Couric sit courtside, while corporate bigwigs swill cocktails in exclusive boxes over Arthur Ashe Stadium, and laser-focused tennis fans, arriving via a packed subway, watch from the nosebleeds above.

headline: Tom Seaver Was Great Even When the Mets Weren’t
abstract: When Seaver was on the mound for the Mets, at least, he seemed immune to whatever the crisis du jour in Queens was at the time.
lead_paragraph: In early April 1983, with Tom Seaver back on the Mets after a six-year exile, I went to see him pitch the season opener at Shea Stadium. My father, as was often the case, came with me. We had been rooting for the Mets, together, since their inaugural season in 1962, and we did not have much to show for our two decades of shatterproof loyalty.

headline: Nothing Happens When Women Are Raped in Nigeria
abstract: The pain of women and girls simply isn’t a big deal.
lead_paragraph: LAGOS, Nigeria — In May, hundreds of thousands of people around the world became familiar with the slight smile of a young student named Uwa Omozuwa. She was studying in a church, working toward a degree in microbiology, when she was violently raped. Within days, she had died from the brutal injuries inflicted by her attacker.

headline: There Is No Route to the White House Without Latino Voters
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Hispanic-Americans', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: Republicans and Democrats alike seem to rediscover us every four years, then forget about us. It is called the Christopher Columbus syndrome.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Every four years, without fail, the two mainstream political parties try to win over Latino voters for their respective presidential candidates. The reason is clear: There is no route to the White House without the support of Latinos.

headline: As Some New Yorkers Flee, Others Move Closer to the Office
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Transit Systems', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Subways', 'Commuting']
abstract: For workers who are required to be on-site, fear of public transportation has spurred a wave of demand for homes within walking distance of their jobs.
lead_paragraph: From her East Village walk-up, Jessica Fine used to take the subway to her job as a physician assistant on the Upper East Side. When the pandemic began, she switched to Citi Bike for the three-mile commute.

headline: ‘Voting Is My Healing’: Inside a Push to Turn Out 100,000 Crime Survivors
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Voting and Voters', 'Crime and Criminals', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: For all that narratives about crime shape American politics, survivors are rarely at the center of the conversation, if they are heard at all. A campaign called #HealTheVote is trying to change that.
lead_paragraph: Eris Eady, a project organizer at the Alliance for Safety and Justice, began a Zoom call this week with a request to the hundreds of participants: Tell us why, or for whom, you are here.

headline: How Layshia Clarendon, Athlete and Activist, Spends Sundays
abstract: The New York Liberty guard has worked all summer in Florida as part of the W.N.B.A.’s experiment isolating in a bubble.
lead_paragraph: Last February, Layshia Clarendon was preparing to move from Oakland, Calif., to Brooklyn to play basketball for the W.N.B.A.’s New York Liberty.

headline: The Shows Must Go On. But They Aren’t the Same Without You.
keywords: ['Television', 'Comedy and Humor', 'Pop and Rock Music', 'Social Media', 'Stadiums and Arenas', 'Athletics and Sports', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Ratings (Audience Measurement)', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)']
abstract: The sudden absence of live audiences has upended the worlds of sports, comedy and politics. What do we lose when the crowd doesn’t show?
lead_paragraph: They used to arrive before dawn. Hundreds of them came to scream and leap and wave posters scrawled with the names of their hometowns as they vied to be caught on camera among the “Today” show crowd. “People dream about coming to 30 Rockefeller Plaza,” Hoda Kotb, the show’s co-anchor, told me recently over Zoom after a show. But for the last several months, Kotb has heard the eerie sound of her own footsteps as she heads into the studio and slips behind the anchor desk, where she perches at a socially distanced remove from her co-stars and broadcasts in front of a ghostly plaza. One morning, she spied some movement outside the window — it was a nurse in scrubs, lugging a rolling suitcase — and Kotb was so hungry for a taste of audience connection, “I literally held my phone number on a white piece of paper to the glass,” she said. “I was like, ‘Call me and tell me where you’re from!’”

headline: Hand in Hand in Central Park
abstract: David Guggenheim and Michael Bosworth hit it off right away, but their dogs needed a little more time. Long walks in the early morning helped all of them bond.
lead_paragraph: When David Adam Guggenheim stretched out his hand to greet Michael Scott Bosworth in February 2017, the handshake cemented what he already knew from their long conversations.

headline: You Know That Apartment Next Door?
abstract: Gopal Narsimhamurthy was so certain he and Megha Jain were meant to be together that he traveled 3,000 miles one way for dates and bought a place adjoining hers.
lead_paragraph: When Megha Jain said that Gopal Narsimhamurthy is “completely unlike any man I have ever met,” she was speaking about the man whom she met in June 2018. He was the man who took 15 round-trip flights — from Dublin, where he lived at the time, to New York, where she lived — during a 14-month period of long-distance dating.

headline: When the Story Line Is This Easy, You Just Know
abstract: Monica Clark, a lawyer who penned a novel about love without “struggle,” found that her real life love story with Will Jones, a TV reporter in Chicago, followed suit.
lead_paragraph: Will Ryan Jones had some time to kill before attending a party hosted by the Cameroon Embassy in Washington, so he asked Monica Marie Clark if he could tag along with her to her friend’s birthday party.

headline: Bar and Medical Exam Delays Keep Graduates in Limbo
keywords: ['Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'ACCREDITATION', 'Legal Profession', 'Graduate Schools and Students', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: Many recent graduates can’t practice their professions without passing a licensing exam, but those tests have been disrupted for months by the coronavirus pandemic.
lead_paragraph: John Molera thought the anxiety of taking the bar exam was over after he finished his test in late July. Then, a few hours later, he got an email from a classmate: One of the roughly 30 people sitting in the room with him for the past two days — where Mr. Molera recalled many people lifting masks for snacks and water breaks — had the coronavirus.

headline: Here Are 20 Shows to Watch This Fall
abstract: Thanks to the coronavirus shutdown, the networks’ fall schedules are packed with reality competitions and recycled shows. But there are still as many intriguing offerings as ever this season.
lead_paragraph: In recent years, the fall television season had been the last bastion of the broadcast networks. Then came Covid-19. With production barely restarting, the network comedies and dramas that usually fill the fall season are mostly absent this year, replaced by reality competitions, true-crime anthologies and recycled shows making their “broadcast premieres.”

headline: Instagram Is Coming for Your Sock Drawer
abstract: The Home Edit won over Khloé Kardashian and Gwyneth Paltrow with a particular style of home organization. Now a new Netflix show will showcase its high aspirations and “low bar” ethos.
lead_paragraph: Khloé Kardashian’s color-coded hair-extension closet might sound like some kind of art installation about late-stage capitalism, but it’s actually a thing that exists in Kardashian’s Los Angeles home, and it’s exactly what it sounds like: a carpeted room dedicated entirely to 50 or so clip-in extensions arranged on uniform black hangers in order of lightest to darkest, beginning with a sheet of bleached-out, nearly white strands and culminating in a swatch of strawberry-tinged almost brown.

headline: The 22-Year-Old Coordinating Protests in Belarus, From a Small Office in Poland
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Social Media', 'Voter Fraud (Election Fraud)']
abstract: Stepan Svetlov hasn’t set foot in Belarus for two years. But his social media profile is now a lodestar for demonstrators back home.
lead_paragraph: WARSAW — Stepan Svetlov’s computer sits on a desk in Warsaw, nearly 300 miles from Minsk, the capital of Belarus. But when Belarusians poured into the streets in the hours and days after President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko fraudulently claimed a re-election victory on Aug. 9, it was thanks in no small part to Mr. Svetlov, 22, and his computer.

headline: They’re Stuck at Home, So They’re Making Home a Sanctuary
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Home Repairs and Improvements', 'Quarantines', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Telecommuting']
abstract: With few places to go or reasons to spend, those lucky enough to be employed remotely are upgrading their surroundings. The impulse comes with guilt.
lead_paragraph: In March, the threadbare couch in the living room was merely an annoyance, but Megan Barney, a book publicist in Cambridge, Mass., was not ready to spend hundreds of dollars to replace it.

headline: A Secret Diary Chronicled the ‘Satanic World’ That Was Dachau
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Concentration Camps', 'World War II (1939-45)', 'Diaries', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: For two years, a prisoner in the German concentration camp kept a journal that would later be used to convict those who had persecuted him and killed his fellow prisoners.
lead_paragraph: The final article from “Beyond the World War II We Know,” a series by The Times that documents lesser-known stories from the war, remembers Edgar Kupfer-Koberwitz, a prisoner at Dachau who secretly documented everything he observed in the concentration camp in a diary, which he then buried until the American liberation.

headline: To Many Travelers, 2020 Was the Summer of 1965
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Summer (Season)', 'Road Trips', 'Recreational Vehicles', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Camps and Camping']
abstract: Driving over flying. Domestic destinations. Though the conditions and causes were different, certain midcentury travel preferences experienced a revival this year.
lead_paragraph: Last year, Amanda Morgan watched a production of “My Fair Lady” at the Sydney Opera House, drove from Queenstown to Christchurch on New Zealand’s South Island, roamed through lavender fields in Provence and spent a week in Mykonos. She celebrated Christmas in Amsterdam and New Year’s Eve in Paris.

headline: N.Y.C. Cut 40,000 Youth Jobs When They Were Needed Most
abstract: “I wasn’t doing this for video games,” said one participant in the Summer Youth Employment Program, whose budget was slashed because of the pandemic. For those who didn’t get a slot, it was yet another letdown in an uncertain year.
lead_paragraph: When Laisha Gonzalez de Peña landed an office job at a Washington Heights day camp last summer, she knew the money would help her with household expenses and college tuition. What she didn’t expect was how she, a recent immigrant who was shy and legally blind from lupus, would also find the confidence to open up about her life during chats with the young campers.

headline: How the Green New Deal Saved a Senator’s Career
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Green New Deal', 'Elections, Senate', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Youth', 'Social Media', 'Environment']
abstract: There are lessons here for Joe Biden.
lead_paragraph: Senator Ed Markey, the Massachusetts Democrat who recently warded off a primary challenge from a Kennedy scion, probably saved his career by authoring the Green New Deal resolution with Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez of New York last year.

headline: Oracle’s embrace of Trump goes beyond its bid for TikTok.
abstract: In March, when the Trump administration ordered up a study enabling the widespread release of the malaria drug hydroxychloroquine to treat Covid-19, one of the first questions the director of a government research agency that would oversee the trial asked was: “Who has talked with Oracle?”

abstract: Usually, players have much more time to gear up to play in the long matches demanded by the Grand Slam tournaments.
lead_paragraph: It is an unprecedented situation: a United States Open with no spectators in a strictly controlled environment with competitors and their teams unable to venture beyond the tennis venue and their lodging.

headline: Trump’s advice to vote twice gives state elections officials new headaches.
abstract: President Trump’s call for people to test the integrity of the elections system by trying to vote both by mail and in person has created new headaches for state election officials, who are already dealing with the formidable task of holding an election during a pandemic.

headline: At a rally, Trump says he wants to ‘get along’ with Russia, despite the Navalny poisoning.
abstract: President Trump on Thursday reiterated his desire to “get along” with Moscow despite an international uproar over the poisoning of the Russian dissident Aleksei A. Navalny with a deadly nerve agent, saying that when the subject of Russia appears on the news, he turns it off.
lead_paragraph: President Trump on Thursday reiterated his desire to “get along” with Moscow despite an international uproar over the poisoning of the Russian dissident Aleksei A. Navalny with a deadly nerve agent, saying that when the subject of Russia appears on the news, he turns it off.

headline: Inside a push to get 100,000 crime survivors to vote.
abstract: For all that narratives about crime shape American politics, survivors are rarely centered in the conversation, if they are heard at all. A campaign called #HealTheVote is trying to change that.
lead_paragraph: Eris Eady, a project organizer at the Alliance for Safety and Justice, began a Zoom call this week with a request to the hundreds of participants: Tell us why, or for whom, you are here.

headline: Biden says, ‘win or lose, I’m going to go down fighting’ for racial equality.
abstract: Two days after President Trump traveled to Wisconsin to focus attention on violence and disorder, Joe Biden sought to strike a drastically different tone, repudiating the president’s divisive approach to matters of racial injustice.
lead_paragraph: Drawing a sharp contrast with President Trump, Joseph R. Biden Jr. on Thursday aligned himself strongly and sympathetically with protesters of racial injustice and with Black voters during an afternoon of raw interactions with people in Kenosha, Wis., who are still grappling with the police shooting of Jacob Blake.

headline: Jake Auchincloss wins the Massachusetts primary for Joe Kennedy’s House seat.
abstract: Jake Auchincloss, a moderate Democrat and local city councilor who was a registered Republican as recently as President Barack Obama’s second term, has won Tuesday’s nine-way Democratic primary in Massachusetts’s Fourth Congressional District to become the likely successor to the outgoing Representative Joseph P. Kennedy III.

headline: In Kenosha this week, the contrast between Trump and Biden was strong.
abstract: KENOSHA, Wis. — The usual campaign-friendly stops were spurned. There was no grilled bratwurst or Wisconsin frozen custard to eat for the cameras. The candidates’ motorcades did not pull over at Tenuta’s Deli, a 70-year-old local institution whose walls are lined with the obligatory framed photographs of visiting politicians.

headline: Tips on Spending the Money in College Savings Accounts
keywords: ['529 Savings Plans', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Financial Aid (Education)', 'Content Type: Service', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Personal Finances']
abstract: Funds in 529 plans grow tax free and can be withdrawn tax free if they’re spent on eligible education expenses. But there is some fine print.
lead_paragraph: You’ve put aside money for college in a 529 account for years. Now it’s time to start withdrawing funds to pay the higher-education bills. What’s the best way to do that?

headline: The Manhattan Home of an Iranian Princess Finally Sells
abstract: The seven-story brick and limestone mansion at 29 Beekman Place was bought by a real estate company for $11.5 million, a fraction of its original asking price.
lead_paragraph: The Midtown mansion that was a longtime home of Princess Ashraf Pahlavi, twin sister of Iran’s last shah, finally closed in August after several years on the market and some legal wrangling. The sale price was $11.5 million, a hefty discount from its nearly $50 million initial price tag.

headline: Weighing Pandemic Risks When Donating to Colleges
abstract: A charitable gift annuity is a way to ensure regular income while also leaving a donation behind, but the coronavirus is squeezing some previously solvent schools.
lead_paragraph: Many colleges and universities are struggling to reopen safely and offer in-person classes during the pandemic. At risk is not just the health and safety of their students, faculty and staff, but in many cases the financial viability of the institutions themselves if they have to go to remote learning, which could prompt students and their families to demand reductions.

headline: Even as people return to work, more find that layoffs are permanent.
abstract: One sign of how the economic crisis is evolving: Back in April, nearly 80 percent of unemployed workers reported being on temporary layoff or furlough. In August, that figure had fallen to less than half.
lead_paragraph: One sign of how the economic crisis is evolving: Back in April, nearly 80 percent of unemployed workers reported being on temporary layoff or furlough. In August, that figure had fallen to less than half.

headline: Variations on a Lead
abstract: For Chadwick Boseman.
lead_paragraph: Chadwick Boseman embodied a James Baldwin dictum: “History is not the past. It is the present. We carry our history with us. We are our history.” Boseman carried our history insistently, imbuing titans of the real and imagined worlds with the best parts of himself. He recognized that they, too, make metaphors out of history even as it is being rewritten with every breath. He understood how exhausting it is to be made accountable minute by minute, how small almost all of us become inside that kind of accounting.

headline: The Black Violinist Who Inspired Beethoven
abstract: George Bridgetower, the original dedicatee of the “Kreutzer” Sonata, was a charismatic prodigy but faded into history.
lead_paragraph: Six months after Beethoven contemplated suicide, confessing his despair over his increasing deafness in the 1802 document known as the Heiligenstadt Testament, he was carousing in taverns with a charismatic new comrade, George Polgreen Bridgetower. This biracial violinist had recently arrived in Vienna, and inspired one of Beethoven’s most famous and passionate pieces, the “Kreutzer” Sonata.

headline: Rescue Dog and Hopes of a Miracle Captivate Ravaged Beirut
abstract: A search squad from Chile and its dog Flash discovered what appeared to be a heartbeat underneath debris from the Aug. 4 port blast.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The sudden glimmer of hope in a devastated Beirut neighborhood came from a dog named Flash with a shaggy black coat, a white snout and red bootees to protect his paws from shattered glass.

headline: What to Cook This Weekend
abstract: Celebrate September with Marian Burros’s plum torte, or cook with whatever is good right now.
lead_paragraph: Back in 1989, the food editors at The Times made a momentous decision: after a seven-year run, this plum torte recipe (above) would no longer be reprinted every September. Our staff reporter Marian Burros, who developed it, wrote: “It is beyond understanding why fans of the recipe do not just save it from year to year.”

headline: August’s slowdown in job growth spanned many industries.
abstract: Signs of a slowing recovery were seen across industries in the jobs data released by the Labor Department on Friday. The construction sector is fewer than half a million jobs short of its level before the pandemic, but only 16,000 construction jobs were added in August.
lead_paragraph: Signs of a slowing recovery were seen across industries in the jobs data released by the Labor Department on Friday. The construction sector is fewer than half a million jobs short of its level before the pandemic, but only 16,000 construction jobs were added in August.

headline: Forget TikTok. China’s Powerhouse App Is WeChat, and Its Power Is Sweeping.

lead_paragraph: Just after the 2016 presidential election in the United States, Joanne Li realized the app that connected her to fellow Chinese immigrants had disconnected her from reality.

headline: The Service Economy Meltdown
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Service Industries', 'Building Service Employees', 'Urban Areas', 'Unemployment', 'Telecommuting', 'Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'United States Economy', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: As companies reconsider their long-term need to have employees on site, low-wage workers depending on office-based businesses stand to lose the most.
lead_paragraph: March 16 was the last day David Engelsman walked into the Jackrabbit, an acclaimed restaurant at the boutique Duniway Hotel in downtown Portland, Ore. The lead server on morning duty, Mr. Engelsman was told before his shift started that his job was no longer needed. He left early, at 10:30 a.m. The restaurant didn’t reopen the next day.

headline: After furor over golf remarks, Trump tweets an old ad of him and Arnold Palmer joking about putting.
abstract: President Trump found himself in the tall grass earlier this week when he compared police officers who shoot people to golfers who “choke” on a “three-foot putt,” but the golf-enraptured Mr. Trump was back at it on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: President Trump found himself in the tall grass earlier this week when he compared police officers who shoot people to golfers who “choke” on a “three-foot putt,” but the golf-enraptured Mr. Trump was back at it on Thursday.

headline: I Live in California. How Do I Know It’s Safe to Go Outside?
abstract: A high-tech sensor network brought me closer to the natural cycles of my environment.
lead_paragraph: Here in California, those of us lucky enough to escape the wildfires are battling smoke. We can’t always see our enemy, but we can smell it. For a while, the whole Bay Area reeked of rotting plants; experts suggested that a source was succulents burning along the Santa Cruz coastline. Some nights, there’s a rich, woodsy scent that reminds me of sitting on the beach around a campfire. But in the morning, the odor is more like stale cigarette butts. As I write this, the stench is of burning rubber and plastic.

headline: ‘Your Dad’s Not Feeling Well’
abstract: When he got sick with Covid-19, it opened a window for me to get to know him better.
lead_paragraph: I was in Brooklyn on a Zoom meeting in mid-March, when I saw my mom’s name come up on my cellphone. “Your dad’s not feeling well,” she said.

abstract: A project from the Graphics desk wanted to find out if the color in your neighborhood, as seen from above, might indicate how you voted.

headline: Salome Bey, Soulful Singer, Actress and Playwright, Dies at 86
abstract: Ms. Bey, known as “Canada’s first lady of the blues,” broke ground in her adopted country by creating opportunities for Black people in the theater.
lead_paragraph: In 1978, Salome Bey gathered Black actors and musicians together for a rehearsal of “Indigo,” a musical revue she wrote and starred in about the evolution of the blues. She started with a pep talk.

headline: At In-Person Choir Rehearsals, a Balance Between Joyful and Careful
keywords: ['Music', 'Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Coronavirus Risks and Safety Concerns', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: With the coronavirus still spreading, many choirs are gathering only online. But one London group is cautiously attempting a way forward.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — On Wednesday night in a community hall here, Matilda James kick-started a rehearsal of the Citizens of the World Choir with an unusual instruction. “Can we really keep our voices down?” she said. “We don’t need to be louder than when we talk.”

headline: N.Y.C. Parents Are Exhausted. But Will They Send Their Children to School?
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'E-Learning', 'Parenting', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Hispanic-Americans', 'Teachers and School Employees', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations', 'Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']

lead_paragraph: Adriana Aviles has been holding dress rehearsals for the first day of school. Her three children wear face masks in their Queens home all day, every other day, to practice for when they return to school buildings in a few weeks.

headline: Tomato Time
abstract: Three recipes for those enamored with perfect summer tomatoes, and two for everyone else.
lead_paragraph: Hello and welcome to Five Weeknight Dishes, Labor Day Weekend Edition — though it’s more to the point to call it the Tomato Edition, so enamored am I of the fat tomatoes at the market. Given the choice, why eat anything else? (Aside from sweet corn. Eat that too.)

headline: The Elements of Wok Hei, and How to Capture Them at Home
abstract: The elusive smoky flavors and aromas of stir-fry can be achieved in your home kitchen. J. Kenji López-Alt shows you how.
lead_paragraph: “I like the food here,” my dad would unfailingly say to me as he pulled open the aluminum-framed, oil-smudged glass door at Sun Lok Kee, a Mott Street stalwart that served beef chow fun and other Cantonese classics at any hour of the day until it burned down in 2002. “It has that nice smoky flavor.” My family moved to New York in the early ’80s, when I was 4 years old, and those stir-fries from Sun Lok Kee, with their savory char and smoky aroma, are among my first and fondest taste memories.

headline: Americans Back Tough Limits on Building in Fire and Flood Zones
abstract: A majority support outright bans on construction in disaster-prone areas, as well as paying people to move, researchers say — policies that local governments have been reluctant to adopt.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Americans support far more aggressive government regulation to fight the effects of climate change than elected officials have been willing to pursue so far, new research shows, including outright bans on building in flood- or fire-prone areas — a level of restrictiveness almost unheard-of in the United States.

headline: Comfort Viewing: 3 Reasons I Love ‘Dark Shadows’

headline: 11 of Our Best Weekend Reads
abstract: Jaguars in Argentina. Breonna Taylor. Wildfires. Chadwick Boseman. The U.S. Open. And more.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Labor Day weekend, and to the end of summer. As my friend Dan likes to say, Once we make it to the “-ber” months, it’s practically the holiday season and the year is basically over. I hope you find that notion appealing as you make your plans for the long weekend (maybe start with these seven things you can do). Whatever you do, don’t forget to make time for some great journalism.

headline: The Work Diary of 88rising’s Pan-Cultural Hitmaker
keywords: ['Rap and Hip-Hop', 'Pop and Rock Music', 'K-Pop', 'Asian-Americans', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING']
abstract: Sean Miyashiro used to drive around listening to music, pretending it was off his own label. Now it’s come true.
lead_paragraph: For this year’s Coachella festival, the music mogul Sean Miyashiro planned to produce a groundbreaking festival showcase for 88rising. His Los Angeles-based pan-Asian music company scheduled performances for Joji, a lo-fi Japanese crooner; NIKI, an Indonesian singer-songwriter; and Rich Brian, a viral Chinese-Indonesian rap star — as well as a label showcase featuring nearly 100 performers on one stage.

headline: Trump Says He Will Reverse Pentagon Plan to Close Newspaper That Informs and Speaks for Troops
keywords: ['Newspapers', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The reversal on Stars and Stripes came as President Trump was in full defensive mode over reports that he had disparaged military personnel.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump said late Friday that he planned to reverse Pentagon budget cuts that would have permanently closed Stars and Stripes, the military newspaper that has both informed and spoken for American troops over the decades.

headline: ‘Losers’ and ‘Suckers’: Trump’s Reported Remarks About Soldiers
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Police', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: “Who are the Losers? Those who would disparage military service,” a former soldier writes. Also: Police restraint of the mentally ill; the president’s new virus adviser.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: She Gave Up a Lot to Play Othello
abstract: Thrilled for the role, needing a paycheck and confident that the theater was safe, Jessika D. Williams left the actors’ union to take the part.
lead_paragraph: Jessika D. Williams has wanted to play the title role in “Othello” since she was a teenager.

headline: Review: A Pandemic ‘Othello,’ Socially and Otherwise Distant
abstract: The actors quarantined together all summer to produce Shakespeare’s tragedy safely. But they can’t overcome the remove of a camera.
lead_paragraph: I admit I have a problem with Shakespeare’s tragedies. Most are brilliant until the middle of Act III, at which point they quickly slide down a hill of blood into a heap of undifferentiated corpses. The 70 characters who are stabbed to death are not really compensated for by the two who are much more creatively baked into pies.

headline: Russians Publish Early Coronavirus Vaccine Results
abstract: The first batch of public data from the “Sputnik V” vaccine showed that it was safe and produced an immune response. No one knows yet whether it prevents coronavirus infections.
lead_paragraph: On Friday, a team of Russian scientists published the first report on their Covid-19 vaccine, which had been roundly criticized because of President Vladimir Putin’s decision last month to approve it before clinical trials had proved it safe and effective.

headline: Love Letter: The Last Full Moon of Summer
abstract: Plus: The Modern Love column is again accepting submissions.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to September.

headline: After Report That Trump Disparaged War Dead, Democrats See Chance to Win Over Military Voters
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Veterans', 'Presidential Election of 2020']
abstract: Liberal groups had already ramped up efforts to win over veterans and military families in swing states, where even a small shift could prove decisive.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Long before The Atlantic published an article on Thursday night depicting President Trump disparaging America’s war dead, liberal veterans groups had been feverishly working in battleground states to appeal to veterans and military family members, a cornerstone of President Trump’s base.

headline: A Furious Biden Calls Trump’s Reported Insults of Fallen Soldiers ‘Disgusting’
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Veterans', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States Economy', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: Responding to a report that President Trump had called soldiers killed in combat “losers,” Joe Biden used his outrage to draw a contrast with his opponent over leadership and decency.
lead_paragraph: WILMINGTON, Del. — Joseph R. Biden Jr. strained to contain his disgust with President Trump on Friday over a report that Mr. Trump had made extraordinarily disrespectful remarks about fallen soldiers.

headline: Why Facebook’s Blocking of New Political Ads May Fall Short
keywords: ['Political Advertising', 'Online Advertising', 'Social Media', 'Rumors and Misinformation', 'News and News Media', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Corporate Social Responsibility', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: There are still many ways that voter misinformation can spread on the social network, even as it moves to cut off new political ads on Oct. 27.
lead_paragraph: To limit voter misinformation ahead of November’s election, Facebook said this week that it would block new political ads from appearing on its site in the week before Election Day.

headline: The Impossible Case of a Japanese Locked-Room Mystery
abstract: Marilyn Stasio recommends two recently reissued novels by Seishi Yokomizo, as well as the latest books from Denise Mina and T. Jefferson Parker.
lead_paragraph: Forget the killer — it’s the victims who matter to Denise Mina. In THE LESS DEAD (Mulholland, 341 pp., $28), these are drug addicts, prostitutes and other people who are barely missed and rarely mourned. Margo Dunlop, a doctor who was adopted as an infant, discovers that back in 1989, her birth mother was one of nine sex workers killed in Glasgow — and becomes determined to put a face to the murderer. Lurid newspaper accounts and a popular true-crime book aren’t all that helpful to her search, and threatening letters hand-delivered in the dead of night to frighten her away from her mission lend little encouragement.

headline: Tanker Asked to Rescue Migrants Off Malta Is Denied Permission to Dock
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Ships and Shipping', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Politics and Government', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: The weekslong refusal by Malta and other nations to allow a tanker from a major global company to dock reflects an escalation in hard-line tactics against migrants.
lead_paragraph: Thirty days ago, the tanker Maersk Etienne responded to requests from Maltese authorities to help a nearby boat in distress.

headline: The Men Who Reinvented Philosophy for Turbulent Times
abstract: In “Time of the Magicians,” Wolfram Eilenberger tells the story of four philosophers — Wittgenstein, Benjamin, Cassirer and Heidegger — who altered the way we see reality.
lead_paragraph: TIME OF THE MAGICIANSWittgenstein, Benjamin, Cassirer, Heidegger, and the Decade That Reinvented PhilosophyBy Wolfram Eilenberger

headline: Jeffrey Toobin on Writing About Trump
abstract: Toobin talks about “True Crimes and Misdemeanors,” and Dayna Tortorici discusses Elena Ferrante’s “The Lying Life of Adults.”
lead_paragraph: Subscribe: iTunes | Google Play Music | How to Listen

headline: Vaping Links to Covid Risk Are Becoming Clear
abstract: Researchers are starting to home in on the ways in which the use of e-cigarettes raises the chances of catching the virus, and suffering its worst effects.
lead_paragraph: Twenty-year-old Janan Moein vaped his first pen a year ago. By late fall, he was blowing through several THC-laced cartridges a week — more, he said, than most people can handle.

headline: California Is Dangerously Hot This Weekend
abstract: Temperature records were set in parts of the Western United States. They might be followed by wind that could worsen fires in California, or storms that could bring snow in Colorado.
lead_paragraph: Brutally hot and dry weather that was forecast across much of the Western United States over the Labor Day weekend and California in particular delivered as expected on Saturday.

headline: A Coded Word From the Far Right Roils France’s Political Mainstream
abstract: Using a term that suggests the society is turning “savage,” government ministers signal a shift from the center as President Macron prepares for a new political season.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The word “ensauvagement” has been a favorite dog whistle of France’s far right in recent years, used to suggest that the nation is turning savage. With its colonial and racist overtones, it has been wielded in discussion of immigration and crime to sound alarms that France is being transformed into a dangerous, uncivilized place, stripped of its traditional values.

headline: In Louisiana, Love for a Chinese Restaurant and Its Magnetic Owner
abstract: For years, Lucky Palace has drawn fans for its intriguing wine list. Now, they come to help their dear friend Kuan Lim in his time of need.
lead_paragraph: BOSSIER CITY, La. — In late August, Kuan Lim rolled his wheelchair up to a table set for 12 at Lucky Palace, the restaurant he operates inside a budget-priced motel in northwest Louisiana. Mr. Lim is battling cancer — he lost the bottom half of his right leg to the disease — and hadn’t been to the restaurant since a Chinese New Year celebration in January.

headline: What’s in a Title?
abstract: It depends on where the author is in the creative process.

headline: While Berghain Is Closed, There’s Art on the Dance Floor
abstract: The famous Berlin techno club has been repurposed as an exhibition space during the pandemic. It’s a mixing of club culture and visual art reminiscent of the golden days of the 1990s.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — After the Berlin Wall came down, in the early 1990s, artists and D.J.s descended on this seemingly lawless city to organize exhibitions and raves in cavernous empty buildings. Or, at least, that was the (largely accurate) cliché.

headline: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome: What It Is, How to Manage It
keywords: ['Menstruation', 'Estrogen', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Tests (Medical)', 'Women and Girls', 'Obesity', 'Infertility', 'Hormones', 'Diabetes', 'Preventive Medicine', 'Insulin', 'Polycystic Ovary Syndrome']
abstract: Often misunderstood and misdiagnosed, PCOS can play havoc with your fertility. Here’s how to recognize the symptoms and take action to protect your reproductive health.
lead_paragraph: Caroline’s mother was concerned when she turned 15 and hadn’t had her first period. It finally came, but it wasn’t until three months later that she’d get her second. Her gynecologist assured her that irregular periods were common for someone her age, so Caroline’s mother didn’t worry. Then, at 18, her periods disappeared for six months. This time, her college ob-gyn said that the stress of college often causes menstrual periods to wane, and that the best treatment was hormonal therapy to make her periods regular. So she started taking birth control pills.

headline: Is Charging Your Phone All Day Really That Bad?
abstract: Worrying about your battery’s health might not be worth the hassle.
lead_paragraph: If you’re unsure whether there’s a “right” way to charge your phone — or whether charging it too long, too often or too fast can damage the battery — you’re not alone. I’m a senior staff writer at Wirecutter, and I’ve been writing about phones and tech since 2011. Before that, I was an iPhone sales specialist at an Apple Store. Even with that experience under my belt, it has never been totally clear to me whether being careful about how often I recharge my phone actually extends the life of the battery enough to make a difference, or if it’s just another hassle in a world with far too many of them.

headline: Baseball’s Iron Man Powers On Despite a Cancer Scare
abstract: With the 25th anniversary of his record-breaking 2,131st consecutive game approaching, Ripken is still a reliable presence around baseball, building another legacy at the youth level.
lead_paragraph: Twenty-five years ago, Cal Ripken Jr. made history simply by doing his job. Ripken, the Baltimore Orioles shortstop, played in his 2,131st game in a row, breaking Lou Gehrig’s hallowed record. The active leader, Whit Merrifield of the Kansas City Royals, had played in 285 consecutive games through Friday.

headline: David Graeber, Caustic Critic of Inequality, Is Dead at 59
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Income Inequality', 'Slogans and Mottoes', 'Writing and Writers', 'Books and Literature', 'ARCHAEOLOGY AND ANTHROPOLOGY']
abstract: He wrote about crushing debt, pointless jobs and the negative effects of globalization. And he played a leading role in the Occupy Wall Street movement.
lead_paragraph: David Graeber, the radical anthropologist, provocative critic of economic and social inequality and self-proclaimed anarchist who was a coiner of “We Are the 99 Percent,” the slogan of the Occupy Wall Street movement, died on Wednesday at a hospital in Venice. He was 59.

headline: Treasured Recipes From Some of Italy’s Fashion Families
abstract: As we continue to eat mostly at home, these storied designers offer some late-summer culinary inspiration.
lead_paragraph: There may be nothing better than enjoying a summer meal at home: spending long lunches at long tables with thrown-together salads and lots of cold wine, grilling corn and hot dogs at sunset after a long day at the beach, gathering around a table to crack lobsters under the stars. Right now, many of us are cooking multiple times a day and sitting down with family for almost every meal — a silver lining (usually) — and, as we enjoy the last dog days, are in desperate need of inspiration. To that end, we’ve asked some of the fashion designers who posed for our story on family-run Italian dynasties, which ran in T’s Culture issue this past spring, to share a recipe they like cooking for the ones they love. Not surprisingly, many of these light, seasonal dishes will allow you to take advantage of those crown jewels of summer, such as August tomatoes in all their purple-y red glory. Buon appetito!

headline: Life, and Other Interruptions: A Storyteller Explains ‘Why I Don’t Write’
abstract: Susan Minot’s new book is her second collection in 30 years. But that doesn’t mean she hasn’t been busy.

headline: Cathy Smith, Who Injected John Belushi With Fatal Drugs, Dies at 73
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Pop and Rock Music']
abstract: After giving an interview to The National Enquirer, she was convicted in Mr. Belushi’s overdose death and served time in prison.
lead_paragraph: A headline on the cover of The National Enquirer in June 1982 became the defining element of Cathy Smith’s life.

headline: Pentagon Sticks With Microsoft for Cloud Computing Contract
keywords: ['Cloud Computing', 'Defense Contracts', 'Government Contracts and Procurement', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Enterprise Computing', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Amazon, a rival for the $10 billion contract, has complained that President Trump interfered in the process.
lead_paragraph: The Defense Department on Friday reaffirmed its decision to award a massive cloud computing contract to Microsoft, despite protests from Amazon, which had argued that President Trump interfered to prevent it from winning the $10 billion contract.

headline: Your Thoughts on an Anxious and Uncertain Return to Classes
abstract: Newsletter readers raise their concerns about the new school year and offer some suggestions for education during the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Two weeks ago, the Canada Letter looked at the impending return to school in most provinces. Since then, the federal government and teachers’ unions have been making adjustments to the plans as they figure out how to get students back in classrooms in the middle of a pandemic.

headline: New Jersey Resumes Indoor Dining With Limits
abstract: Gov. Philip D. Murphy of New Jersey announced restaurants and bars in the state could resume indoor dining with capacity limits. Smoking inside state casinos remains prohibited.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Philip D. Murphy of New Jersey announced restaurants and bars in the state could resume indoor dining with capacity limits. Smoking inside state casinos remains prohibited.

headline: Revisiting Carol Shields and the Everywoman
abstract: In 1994, Jay Parini wrote for the Book Review about Carol Shields’s novel “The Stone Diaries,” the fictional autobiography of Daisy Goodwill Flett as she navigates marriage and motherhood.
lead_paragraph: In 1994, Jay Parini wrote for the Book Review about Carol Shields’s novel “The Stone Diaries,” the fictional autobiography of Daisy Goodwill Flett as she navigates marriage and motherhood.

headline: Reed Hastings Had Us All Staying Home Before We Had To
abstract: Netflix started with sending DVDs — remember them? — through the mail, but now the streaming pioneer sits atop a Hollywood it has thoroughly upended.
lead_paragraph: Does it feel good to be the man who killed Hollywood?

headline: Coronavirus Briefing: A Summer of Lost Opportunity
abstract: The U.S. failed to stamp out the virus before the dangerous autumn and winter months.
lead_paragraph: As summer comes to a close, the United States is averaging about 40,000 new cases a day, down from a horrifying peak in late July. But in many ways, the country is worse off now than at the beginning of the season: On Memorial Day weekend, the United States averaged 22,000 cases a day.

headline: After 6 Murder Trials and Nearly 24 Years, Charges Dropped Against Curtis Flowers
keywords: ['Black People', 'Blacks', 'Discrimination', 'Jury System', 'Prosecutorial Misconduct', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: Mr. Flowers had faced the possibility of a seventh trial in the quadruple-murder case from Mississippi.
lead_paragraph: Six times, prosecutors took Curtis Flowers, a Black Mississippi resident, to trial on the same murder case before mostly-white juries. And six times, the trials ended with convictions that were later reversed or with mistrials. But on Friday, two decades after prosecutors began pursuing murder charges against Mr. Flowers, they announced that they were dropping the case.

headline: Old Male Elephants: Don’t Count Them Out
abstract: New research challenges the assumption that bulls become redundant in elephant society after breeding.
lead_paragraph: For years, scientists assumed that when it came to elephants on the African savanna, matriarchs were the only leaders. Old males, on the other hand, were seen as solitary loners whose social contribution ended at breeding. New evidence suggests that male elephants do have social lives, and that older males may act as leaders for younger ones.

headline: Job Growth Slackens, Signaling Vulnerability of Recovery
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Unemployment', 'Unemployment Insurance', 'United States Economy', 'Recession and Depression', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Federal Aid (US)', 'Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)']
abstract: Unemployment fell to 8.4% in August, but the gain of 1.4 million jobs was the weakest in months. The end of federal aid programs is casting a shadow.
lead_paragraph: Job growth slowed further last month, the latest sign that the economy’s spring momentum has faded — and a warning that the recovery could go into reverse this fall without further government support.

headline: The 50 Best TV Shows and Movies to Watch on Disney+ Right Now
abstract: The Disney streaming platform has hundreds of movie and TV titles, drawing from its own deep reservoir classics and from Star Wars, Marvel and more. These are our favorites.
lead_paragraph: Sign up for our Watching newsletter to get recommendations on the best films and TV shows to stream and watch, delivered to your inbox.

headline: Are Influencers Responsible for the Behavior of Their Followers?
keywords: ['Social Media', 'Discrimination', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Transgender and Transsexuals', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Cyberharassment']
abstract: Fan armies are harassing gay and trans people on TikTok.
lead_paragraph: Chris smiles widely as a video of Miso Chan, a transgender creator presenting as a young woman with pink hair, plays next to him. A song with the lyrics “Now I know what’s real and what is fake,” loops in the background.

headline: Conny Nxumalo, Advocate for South Africa’s Poor, Dies at 53
abstract: Years after helping to draft legislation that reversed apartheid-era social policies, her work exposed her to the coronavirus. She died of complications of the disease.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: Labor Day Weekend, Jobs, U.S. Open: Your Friday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Stocks Slide Again as a Promising Week Turns South
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Nasdaq Composite Index', "Standard & Poor's 500-Stock Index"]
abstract: A day after the S&P 500 had its worst performance in months, stocks mostly reversed their steep early losses on Friday, but still closed the week 4.3 percent off their latest high.
lead_paragraph: The searing monthslong rally in the stock market has been a clear sign that investors expected the country’s giant tech firms to help lead the pandemic-hit economy out of the doldrums.

headline: Gary Sanchez Finally Shored Up His Defense. Then His Bat Disappeared.
abstract: Sanchez has long been praised for his slugging but criticized for his work behind the plate. A new technique is improving his catching, but he’s slumping hard on offense.
lead_paragraph: In the latest step of their yearslong refurbishing project known as Gary Sanchez, the talented-but-streaky catcher, the Yankees hired a new catching coach this off-season. Just as he had done with the Minnesota Twins, Tanner Swanson was tasked with teaching Sanchez a new one-knee catching style intended to convert more low, borderline pitches into strikes.

headline: Julia Reed, Chronicler of Politics, Food and the South, Dies at 59
abstract: In Ms. Reed’s writing for Newsweek, Vogue and other publications, her canvas included the follies of the powerful and the pleasures of Southern food.
lead_paragraph: Julia Reed, an irreverent, expansive chronicler of politics, food and Southern life, died on Aug. 28 in Newport, R.I. She was 59.

headline: The 50 Best TV Shows on Netflix Right Now
abstract: New shows come to the streaming giant all the time — too many to ever watch them all. We’re here to help.
lead_paragraph: Sign up for our Watching newsletter to get recommendations on the best films and TV shows to stream and watch, delivered to your inbox.

headline: Brazil Fires Burn World’s Largest Tropical Wetlands at ‘Unprecedented’ Scale
abstract: The blazes in Brazil, often intentionally set, have scorched a record-setting 10 percent of the Pantanal, one of the most biologically diverse habitats on the planet.
lead_paragraph: PORTO JOFRE, Brazil — A record amount of the world’s largest tropical wetland has been lost to the fires sweeping Brazil this year, scientists said, devastating a delicate ecosystem that is one of the most biologically diverse habitats on the planet.

headline: Fighting the Virus in Trump’s Plague
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Nationalism (Theory and Philosophy)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: My body is a stranger. It is out there battling the enemy within.
lead_paragraph: PARIS

headline: Daniel Prude’s Death: Police Silence and Accusations of a Cover-Up
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: The police in Rochester, N.Y., treated the death of Mr. Prude as a drug overdose. The case drew scrutiny when footage showed that he had been pinned down and hooded by officers.
lead_paragraph: In the minutes after Daniel Prude’s heart briefly stopped during a struggle with officers who had pulled a hood over his head, an unofficial police narrative took hold: He had suffered a drug overdose.

headline: My Son Knows His Father Wasn’t a ‘Loser’ or a ‘Sucker’
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Veterans', 'Children and Childhood']
abstract: Jordan lost his father in Iraq. He knows his father was a warrior and a patriot. But the words hurt nevertheless.
lead_paragraph: I struggled for the words to comfort Jordan, my 14-year-old son.
