keywords: ['Presidential Medal of Freedom', 'Awards, Decorations and Honors', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The comments came during a news conference on Friday after The Atlantic reported that the president privately referred to American soldiers killed in combat as “losers.” The article focused on statements by Mr. Trump that Mr. Kelly was privy to.
lead_paragraph: The comments came during a news conference on Friday after The Atlantic reported that the president privately referred to American soldiers killed in combat as “losers.” The article focused on statements by Mr. Trump that Mr. Kelly was privy to.

headline: In His Last Hours, Portland Murder Suspect Said He Feared Arrest
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'George Floyd Protests (2020)', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Antifa Movement (US)', 'Right-Wing Extremism and Alt-Right', 'Fringe Groups and Movements']
abstract: Law enforcement agents killed Michael Forest Reinoehl while trying to arrest him for the shooting death of a supporter of a far-right group.
lead_paragraph: Inside an apartment on a quiet suburban street near Lacey, Wash., on Thursday evening, Michael Forest Reinoehl fretted about his future. He talked about his children in a telephone call to a friend, wondering how to keep them safe should anything happen to him.

headline: Steps Toward Police Reform
keywords: ['Podcasts', 'Newsletters', 'Police Reform', 'George Floyd Protests (2020)', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: For one Black officer from Michigan, it’s the small moments that matter.
lead_paragraph: In the wake of the killing of George Floyd, there has been a lot of talk about police reform: Calls to defund and dismantle departments, or to train better and to recruit wider.

headline: John Kelly, at Center of Report on Trump Disparaging U.S. Soldiers, Keeps Silent
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2020']
abstract: The former chief of staff’s public reticence has frustrated groups that are hoping that he will publicly endorse Joseph R. Biden Jr., the Democratic presidential nominee.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — John F. Kelly left the White House barely on speaking terms with President Trump. In the months since, Mr. Kelly, a retired four-star general and former White House chief of staff, has stayed mostly silent as other senior military figures have publicly and harshly criticized the president.

headline: With More Black Women, U.S. Open Shows Serena and Venus Legacy
keywords: ['Tennis', 'United States Open (Tennis)', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Women and Girls', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: “It’s amazing to see so many girls that look like me playing in the tournament and the main draw,” said Hailey Baptiste, 18, who received a U.S. Open wild card.
lead_paragraph: The main event of the United States Open on Saturday will be Serena Williams playing Sloane Stephens: a third-round duel between Williams, the greatest women’s tennis player of her era, and Stephens, the last American to win a U.S. Open singles title.

headline: Professor Investigated for Posing as Black Won’t Teach This Term, Officials Say
abstract: George Washington University said the professor, Jessica A. Krug, will not have classes this semester after a blog post published under her name described her use of Black identities even though she is white.
lead_paragraph: [Update: Professor has resigned her position, university says.]

headline: Justice Dept. Charges 2 With Trying to Support Hamas
keywords: ['Right-Wing Extremism and Alt-Right', 'George Floyd Protests (2020)', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The men, both American citizens, were taken into custody on Thursday evening in Minneapolis. They say they are members of a far-right group called the Boogaloo Bois.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department on Friday charged two American citizens with ties to a far-right extremist group with trying to support the Palestinian terrorist group Hamas — a case that shows that extremists have sought to turn protests against racism into opportunities to commit violence, but that also runs counter to President Trump’s assertions that those extremists are predominantly on the far left.

headline: Pharma Companies Plan Joint Pledge on Vaccine Safety
abstract: The statement is meant to reassure the public that the companies will not seek a premature approval of vaccines under pressure from the Trump administration.
lead_paragraph: A group of drug companies competing with one another to be among the first to develop coronavirus vaccines are planning to pledge early next week that they will not release any vaccines that do not follow rigorous efficacy and safety standards, according to representatives of three of the companies.

headline: ‘A Glorious Thing to Be’
abstract: John Guzzetta mines the alphabet for hardworking words at just the right time of year.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — I thought I was detecting a theme where there should be none. It is Saturday, isn’t it? These days it’s hard to tell sometimes. But there is a repeated combo, “ER,” that keeps popping up at the ends of the answers here. It brings to mind those workhorses, the makers and doers: the BUTCHER, BAKER, TINKER (TINKERER?). The answers ending in “ER,” even though they don’t necessarily relate to jobs, are certainly weight-bearing words, and what better time for them than Labor Day weekend?

headline: U.S. Open Match Delayed as Health Officials Debate Virus Rules
abstract: Alexander Zverev and Adrian Mannarino waited more than two hours to play their match as officials debated whether Mannarino should play given his contact with another player who tested positive for coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: A third-round United States Open men’s singles match between Alexander Zverev and Adrian Mannarino was delayed for more than two hours on Friday as government health officials and tournament officials debated whether Mannarino should be allowed to play because of his contact with another player who tested positive for the coronavirus.

headline: International Crime Ring That Trafficked in Shark Fins Is Dismantled, U.S. Says
keywords: ['Wildlife Trade and Poaching', 'Sharks', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Money Laundering', 'Organized Crime', 'Marijuana', 'Soups']
abstract: Law enforcement agents documented the harvest of more than six tons of shark fins, officials said.
lead_paragraph: Shark fin soup, considered a delicacy in some countries, has long fueled demand for illegally harvested fins. But federal authorities in Georgia announced this week that they had dismantled at least one source for the ingredient: a multimillion-dollar organization they described as an international money laundering, drug trafficking and illegal wildlife trade ring.

headline: Trump Moves to Cancel Contracts for Government Sensitivity Training
keywords: ['Race and Ethnicity', 'George Floyd Protests (2020)', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Government Employees', 'Government Contracts and Procurement', 'News and News Media']
abstract: A memo sent to agency heads on Friday called efforts that often focus on promoting awareness of racism “divisive” and “un-American propaganda.”
lead_paragraph: President Trump has directed administration officials to make significant changes to sensitivity training sessions across the government, calling such efforts that often focus on promoting awareness of racism “divisive” and “un-American propaganda.”

headline: 2020 U.S. Open: What to Watch on Saturday
abstract: The defending doubles champions play their second-round matches, and the 2019 singles runners-up, Daniil Medvedev and Serena Williams, start off Saturday’s slate with third-round matches at Arthur Ashe Stadium.
lead_paragraph: How to watch: From 11 a.m. to 11 p.m. Eastern time on ESPN2; streaming on the ESPN app.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Last Year, Dance Class. This Year, Lessons About Justice.
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, September 5, 2020.
lead_paragraph: “For me, being a young Black woman, I’m just focused on my life. That’s really why I’m out here. I am just a Black girl trying to live.”

headline: Corrections: Sept. 5, 2020
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Sept. 5, 2020
lead_paragraph: An article on Friday about spit hoods, a device used by to prevent people from biting or spitting, misspelled the surname of a professor of police science at John Jay College of Criminal Justice. She is Maria Haberfeld, not Haberfield.

headline: The Best Part of Layshia Clarendon’s Game? ‘Fearlessness’
abstract: “It doesn’t matter if I get blocked — I’m going to go right back in the paint again,” the Liberty guard said. They bring that same tenacity to their role on the W.N.B.A. union’s executive committee.
lead_paragraph: On the court, Layshia Clarendon has become the leader of a young Liberty team coursing through a season with many unexpected challenges. As an executive committee member of the W.N.B.A.’s players’ union, Clarendon has also become a voice for social justice for the league this year.

headline: Coronavirus Crisis Shatters India’s Big Dreams
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Disease Rates', 'Quarantines', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: The country’s ambitions to become a global power, lift its poor and update its military have been set back by a sharp economic plunge, soaring infections and a widening sense of malaise.
lead_paragraph: SURAT, India — The hit that India’s dreams have taken from the coronavirus pandemic can be found in the hushed streets of Surat’s industrial zone.

headline: A Son’s Future, a Father’s Final Down
abstract: In Jacqueline Woodson’s “Before the Ever After,” a boy struggles to move forward as his pro football star father’s memory fades.
lead_paragraph: BEFORE THE EVER AFTERBy Jacqueline Woodson

headline: Two Suicidal Teens, Four Possible Paths
abstract: Aaron and Tillie are strangers, until they meet on a bridge. Bill Konigsberg’s new novel explores where four different plotlines could take them.
lead_paragraph: THE BRIDGEBy Bill Konigsberg

headline: The Latest Polls, the Great Non-Tightening: This Week in the 2020 Race
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: A wave of data this week suggested that the race was largely holding steady after the parties’ conventions. Will the uproar over President Trump’s reported remarks on the military shake things up?
lead_paragraph: [Follow our live polls tracker on Trump vs Biden.]

headline: Grisly Slabs of Gothic Horror
abstract: These books — both fiction and nonfiction — celebrate the dark corners of our world.
lead_paragraph: In the introduction to WEIRD WOMEN: Classic Supernatural Fiction by Groundbreaking Female Writers 1852-1923 (Pegasus, 384 pp., $25.95), the editors Lisa Morton and Leslie S. Klinger write that horror often seems to be a “genre bereft of female writers.” Here they set out to correct that misperception, highlighting stories by women writers whose work has fallen into obscurity.

headline: Recreational Adrenaline: Three Sizzling New Thrillers
abstract: Late summer is supposed to be a slow time for publishers, but this year there’s plenty to get your heart racing.
lead_paragraph: Late summer is supposed to be a doldrum-y time in publishing, but this year brings an enticing crop of thrillers of all kinds. Along comes Alex Pavesi’s THE EIGHTH DETECTIVE (Holt, 289 pp., $26.99), for instance, which had me at its author bio: “He enjoys puzzles, long walks and recreational lock picking.”

headline: Follow a Pandemic-Themed Path
abstract: This year a whole new vocabulary has sprung up. Find the words that have been central to reveal something essential.
lead_paragraph: For Labor Day weekend, here’s a word maze. It’s like an old-fashioned word search with a twist. The rules are fairly simple: You are looking for quarantine-related words and phrases secreted among the jumble of letters. Start at the dog-eared “C” and follow a path ending at the similarly marked “E.” You may move only horizontally or vertically, not diagonally. Letters may be visited only once, and the end of one word is always adjacent to the start of the next. If you color each square along your route with a colored pen or pencil, it will reveal a hidden image. Oh, and, as in life, avoid COVID. Download the game here and print to play.

headline: Parents Got More Time Off. Then the Backlash Started.
keywords: ['Paid Time Off', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Parenting', 'Child Care', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Workplace Environment', 'Employee Fringe Benefits', 'Work-Life Balance']
abstract: Pandemic policies at tech companies have created a rift between parents offered more benefits and resentful workers who don’t have children.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — When the coronavirus closed schools and child care centers and turned American parenthood into a multitasking nightmare, many tech companies rushed to help their employees. They used their comfortable profit margins to extend workers new benefits, including extra time off for parents to help them care for their children.

headline: When These Sea Anemones Eat, It Goes Straight to Their Arms
abstract: They’re the first animals known to turn food into extra limbs.
lead_paragraph: People have a lot of strategies for dealing with the effects of large meals — constitutionals, antacids, workouts, naps.

headline: 100 Days of Protest: A Chasm Grows Between Portland and the Rest of Oregon
keywords: ['Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Conservatism (US Politics)', 'Rural Areas', 'Firearms', 'Fringe Groups and Movements', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'George Floyd Protests (2020)']
abstract: The proximity of the left and the right in Oregon has created a dynamic of fear, mistrust and anger.
lead_paragraph: SANDY, Ore. — Trucks carrying bales of hay, horse paddocks and Christmas tree farms — drive a few miles out of Portland and the suburbs quickly give way to rural Oregon.

headline: Famous in Italy, Rodari Reaches U.S. Shores With ‘Telephone Tales’
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Politics and Government', 'Writing and Writers', 'Children and Childhood', 'Education (K-12)', 'Socialism (Theory and Philosophy)']
abstract: The children’s book writer never caught on in America, partly because of his Communist Party ties, but the English-language release of his masterpiece could change that.
lead_paragraph: EUPILIO, Italy — One of Gianni Rodari’s short stories is set in a faraway land where the authorities are so meek that, when a visitor picks a forbidden flower, a police officer demands to be slapped across the face. The visitor refuses to comply with such a strange order — if anything, he says, it’s the police who should slap him — but the reader is left wondering if reality is any less absurd.

headline: ‘Agricultural Jihad’: A Hungry Lebanon Returns to Family Farms to Feed Itself
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Politics and Government', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'Food Insecurity', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Shortages', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: With a tanking economy, and imported food costs soaring, leaders are urging the Lebanese to wage a campaign of self-sufficiency. “I never thought I’d do this in my life, but I have to survive.”
lead_paragraph: ANTELIAS, Lebanon — The falafel shop owner leaned back and listed the keys to the Lebanese kitchen — the staples that help lend this country its culinary halo:

headline: Flat Polls. Weak Ratings. Do Political Conventions Have a Future?
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Republican National Convention', 'Ratings (Audience Measurement)', 'News and News Media', 'Presidential Elections (US)', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Ratings were down and polls barely budged. Did the August conventions offer a road map for saving a flailing political institution?
lead_paragraph: After 18 hours of speeches by the candidates, testimonials from former presidents and generals, poignant appeals from voters, a cross-country nominating roll call, opera on a White House balcony and fireworks over the Washington Monument, the verdict is in on the national political conventions.

headline: How Trump Draws on Campaign Funds to Pay Legal Bills
keywords: ['Campaign Finance', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Conflicts of Interest', 'Legal Profession', 'Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'Trump-Ukraine Whistle-blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry']
abstract: As he has done with other aspects of the presidency, Donald J. Trump has redefined the practice in ways that have unsettled even some Republicans.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump was proudly litigious before his victory in 2016 and has remained so in the White House. But one big factor has changed: He has drawn on campaign donations as a piggy bank for his legal expenses to a degree far greater than any of his predecessors.

headline: Readers Share Their Best Unexpected Wedding Photos
abstract: A selection of cherished, unplanned and unscripted, wedding moments submitted by our readers.
lead_paragraph: Inspired by Alix Strauss’s article where wedding photographers shared their favorite wedding photos, we asked readers to submit their own candid, unscripted photos from their special day. Here is a selection of their cherished moments (all from weddings long before social distancing was upon us). From an explosion of laughter at the altar, to an unexpected trash the dress (and tux) session, these photos prove that the best moments are sometimes unplanned.

headline: How the Circle Drive-In ‘Found Its Niche’ in the Pandemic
abstract: With a flea market, graduations and even a livestreamed country music concert, a Pennsylvania Drive-in became a safe gathering place.
lead_paragraph: In the coronavirus pandemic, it became 15 acres of safety, 15 acres where people could lose themselves in a crowd but remain alone as they watched a movie. Or graduated from high school. Or played bingo. Or watched fireworks. Or hummed along at a concert.

headline: 11 Students on a First Day of School Like No Other
abstract: Students across the country discussed math, masks and managing anxiety as the year begins.
lead_paragraph: Lucas Fonte’s first day of virtual third grade was a virtual flop. There was no exciting wait for the school bus or morning greeting from the bus driver, Mrs. Rodriguez. Instead, the talkative eight-year-old put on his school uniform shirt, sat down next to his mother and brother at the dining room table and tried to log on to the Miami-Dade Public School district’s new online learning platform.

headline: Top Biden Advisers Preview Fall Election Strategy
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: In a wide-ranging briefing less than two months before Election Day, Joe Biden’s team said that he and Kamala Harris would be ramping up in-person activities and travel.
lead_paragraph: [Follow our daily updates on the latest presidential election polls.]

headline: Ex-F.B.I. Agent in Russia Inquiry Says Trump Is a National Security Threat
keywords: ['Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Books and Literature', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct']
abstract: Peter Strzok, who was fired for sending anti-Trump texts, played a central role in both the Hillary Clinton email and Trump-Russia investigations.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A former senior F.B.I. agent at the center of the investigations into Hillary Clinton’s email server and the Trump campaign’s ties to Russia defends the handling of the inquiries and declares President Trump a national security threat in a new memoir, while admitting that the bureau made mistakes that upended the 2016 presidential election.

headline: Explosion at Mosque, Likely Caused by Gas Leak, Kills 16 in Bangladesh
abstract: Dozens of worshipers were severely burned in the blast on Friday night just outside Dhaka.
lead_paragraph: An explosion on Friday night at a mosque near Bangladesh’s capital, believed to have been caused by a gas leak, killed at least 16 worshipers and left 21 with burns so severe that the death toll could rise further, according to a police officer and a doctor treating some of the victims.

headline: Color of Change: Tackling Systemic Racism One Strategy at a Time
keywords: ['Black People', 'Blacks', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Black Lives Matter Movement']
abstract: Rashad Robinson, president of Color of Change, talks about the online racial justice organization’s 15 years of work — and its strategies during a summer of unrest.
lead_paragraph: [Race/Related is available as a newsletter. Sign up here to get it delivered to your inbox.]

headline: Northeastern University Dismisses 11 Students for Breaking Virus Rules but Keeps Their Tuition
abstract: The U.N. warns of looming famines connected to the pandemic. Melbourne, Australia’s second-biggest city, has extended its lockdown by two weeks.
lead_paragraph: [Follow our live Covid-19 updates around the globe.]

headline: McGuire or Maguire? A Tussle Over Who Founded Labor Day
abstract: Descendants of two men with similar last names claim their great-grandfather was the true father of the holiday.
lead_paragraph: TOTOWA, N.J. — For nearly 50 years, Bill Collins, a retired history teacher, spent Labor Day not at a beach or a barbecue, but at a cemetery. He and a dozen or more relatives would gather around the tombstone of his great-grandfather to celebrate his founding of the national workers’ holiday.

headline: With Bucks Facing Elimination, Uncertainty Grows Around Giannis Antetokounmpo
abstract: For the second consecutive year, the Bucks entered the playoffs with the league’s best regular-season record. Down 3-0 against the Miami Heat, questions are swirling around the future of the team and its superstar.
lead_paragraph: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla. — Before the Milwaukee Bucks labored through a stretch of basketball that could wind up altering their future, Giannis Antetokounmpo did something that he tends to do well: He elevated for a dunk, a brief burst of explosiveness that gave the Bucks a fourth-quarter lead against the Miami Heat in Game 3 of their Eastern Conference semifinal series.

headline: A Growing Number of Catholic Schools Are Shutting Down Forever
abstract: About 150 Catholic schools have closed nationwide citing insurmountable financial pressures from the coronavirus pandemic.
lead_paragraph: In more than four decades of coaching girls’ basketball at Lebanon Catholic High School in southeastern Pennsylvania, Patti Hower had led the team to three state championships and 20 district titles. This year, with four starting players returning, there were high hopes again.

headline: Benefit From a Fall Routine
abstract: Your days don’t need to look the same every single day, but recognizing and honoring a schedule brings plenty of mental and physical benefits.
lead_paragraph: As the pandemic continues and the school year starts up, some people might be craving some regularity and structure. Having a routine not only guides you through your days, but it also brings mental and physical benefits, too, whether by adding exercise to your day, aiding in getting better sleep, helping children feel more secure or providing a sense of control during such an uncertain time.

headline: When Did the Suburbs Get so LOUD?
abstract: Several municipalities around New York have urged homeowners to limit the use of noisy landscaping equipment because their neighbors are home during the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Q: I just moved from New York City to the suburbs and assumed I’d need time to adjust to the quiet. I was wrong. The noise from the leaf blowers and lawn mowers is constant and so loud. No sooner has a landscaping crew finished eviscerating the grass at one house, than another arrives to mow the next. Does this go on all the time? How do people tolerate it? Are there no regulations about this kind of noise?

headline: Between the Pandemic and the President: Mexico City Mayor’s Balancing Act
abstract: As the first woman and Jewish person elected to lead the capital, Claudia Sheinbaum needs the president’s support. But how close can she remain to a man who has downplayed the pandemic?
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — It was a perfect portrait of the delicate relationship between the Mexican president and his protégée.

headline: Gene Norman, Who Helped Landmark Broadway Theaters, Dies at 85
abstract: As chairman of New York’s preservation commission, he also oversaw the preservation of St. Bartholomew’s Church, the Coney Island Cyclone and Ladies’ Mile.
lead_paragraph: Gene Norman, who as New York City’s unflappable official preservationist was instrumental in sparing Broadway theaters, St. Bartholomew’s Church and the Coney Island Cyclone from destruction or defacement by developers, died on Aug. 30 at his home in the Bronx. He was 85.

headline: If Summer Were a Meatball
abstract: Make Melissa Clark’s recipe, or any of the most popular recipes of the week.
lead_paragraph: The week’s most popular dishes include Melissa Clark’s skillet meatballs with peaches, basil and lime (above), Jerrelle Guy’s cherry-almond granola crisp and Hetty McKinnon’s herby tomato salad with tamarind-maple dressing. Find more recipes in the collection below.

headline: Land in Russia’s Arctic Blows ‘Like a Bottle of Champagne’
abstract: Since finding the first crater in 2014, Russian scientists have documented 16 more explosions in the Arctic caused by gas trapped in thawing permafrost.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — A natural phenomenon first observed by scientists just six years ago and now recurring with alarming frequency in Siberia is causing the ground to explode spontaneously and with tremendous force, leaving craters up to 100 feet deep.

headline: First Famines of Coronavirus Era Are at World’s Doorstep, U.N. Warns
abstract: The top U.N. relief official said parts of Yemen, South Sudan, northeast Nigeria and the Democratic Republic of Congo are at risk, “endangering the lives of millions of women, men and children.”
lead_paragraph: The first famines of the coronavirus era could soon hit four chronically food-deprived conflict areas — Yemen, South Sudan, northeast Nigeria and the Democratic Republic of Congo — the top humanitarian official of the United Nations has warned.

headline: One City. Two Neighborhoods. A 30-Year Gap in Life Expectancy.
abstract: A view of income inequality in Chicago at ground level.
lead_paragraph: A view of income inequality in Chicago at ground level.

headline: Lockdown Left My Mind and Body Flabby. Then Came Tennis Camp.
abstract: What playing doubles with a Parisian urologist taught me about how to get my life in order.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — While many Americans were cooped up at home or learning to love camping, in France (and many other places in Europe) we had an almost normal summer.

headline: Congress Should Pass a Navalny Act
keywords: ['Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations', 'Political Prisoners', 'Poisoning and Poisons', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: The latest poisoning of a Russian critic requires expanded sanctions and accountability for Kremlin leadership.
lead_paragraph: In 2012, in the face of quiet resistance from the Obama administration, Congress passed the Magnitsky Act, named for a Russian lawyer, Sergei Magnitsky, who was left to die in a Moscow prison in 2009 for blowing the whistle on a $230 million scam perpetrated by government officials.

headline: What I’ve Learned From Teaching Online
keywords: ['E-Learning', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Reading and Writing Skills (Education)', 'Education (K-12)', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Rural Areas', 'Parenting']
abstract: Roll call becomes a roster of absences. Some students write fantasies of escape. Can a new life begin when you are confined with siblings and parents?
lead_paragraph: “Let’s read,” I told the students in my writing class, trying to invoke the authority of my own high-school literature teacher. I was hoping they would unzip their backpacks, pull out the books and start reading. I had become a visiting teacher at a university in Karachi, Pakistan, a couple of years before the pandemic, and I was struggling. It felt nice to be called a professor, but I was reluctant to call my students, “my students.”

headline: The Trump Docket: A Look at the Fights Fueling Trump’s Big Legal Bills
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Trump-Ukraine Whistle-blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Legal Profession', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct']
abstract: Donor money is helping pay for a dizzying array of litigation filed by the president or against him.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Long before he moved into the White House, Donald J. Trump had cemented his reputation as a lover of lawsuits, turning to federal and state courts for battles big and small. Mr. Trump once even boasted, “I like beating my enemies to the ground.”

headline: Race for Coronavirus Vaccine Pits Spy Against Spy
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Industrial Espionage', 'Intellectual Property', 'Laboratories and Scientific Equipment', 'Cyberwarfare and Defense', 'Colleges and Universities', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The intelligence wars over vaccine research have intensified as China and Russia expand their efforts to steal American work at both research institutes and companies.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Chinese intelligence hackers were intent on stealing coronavirus vaccine data, so they looked for what they believed would be an easy target. Instead of simply going after pharmaceutical companies, they conducted digital reconnaissance on the University of North Carolina and other schools doing cutting-edge research.

headline: Variety: Split Decisions
abstract: Fred Piscop presents us with many forks in the road.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — It has been a long time since I’ve done one of Fred Piscop’s “Split Decisions” puzzles, and it shows. When I was “in practice,” the word pairs fell easily for me, but not this time. If that is not a good testimonial for solving regularly, I don’t know what is.

headline: Risks and Tradeoffs in the Covid Era
abstract: Readers discuss human nature and decisions about acceptable risks and sacrifices in response to the coronavirus.

headline: Remember Your Summer With Sun Prints
abstract: Use those shells, dried flower and other keepsakes to create beautiful white-and-blue prints.
lead_paragraph: Whether you went to the seaside or the mountains or stayed local this summer, chances are you have a pile of natural keepsakes, picked up while wandering, which now sit in a bowl or on a table in your home. Not sure what to do with them? You can use those shells, dried flowers or other mementos to make a unique and everlasting sun print.

headline: How Many of These 68,000 Deaths Could Have Been Avoided?
keywords: ['Nursing Homes', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations', 'Protective Clothing and Gear']
abstract: Nursing home residents and staff members account for around 40 percent of coronavirus-related deaths in the U.S. There’s no justifiable reason for that.
lead_paragraph: Jose Velasquez, a 79-year-old father from Bexar County, Texas, tested positive for the coronavirus on March 26 and died on April 17. During those weeks, the staff at the nursing home where he lived assured his family that he showed no symptoms of Covid-19 and, according to a lawsuit filed by his children, failed to ensure that he received proper medical care. The staff did not transfer him to a hospital as he deteriorated or even warn his family that he was sick, according to the suit. Mr. Velasquez’s family says that just hours before he died, the staff at the home reported he was “doing fine.”

headline: A Big 2020 Campaign Question: Wait, What Day Is It?

abstract: Time is marching on, toward Election Day. Somehow.
lead_paragraph: What day is it today? Is it:

headline: The First Saturday in ... September
abstract: The Kentucky Derby, the oldest continuously held sporting event in the U.S., will be run without fans for the first time. Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: The Kentucky Derby, the oldest continuously held sporting event in the U.S., will be run without fans for the first time. Here’s what you need to know.

headline: The Battle Over Biscuits and Gravy at the 11-Worth Cafe
keywords: ['Restaurants', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Discrimination', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: In “levelheaded” Omaha, a protester was killed and, in the aftermath, people demanding an end to racial injustice set their sights on police budgets — and a diner with Robert E. Lee on the menu.
lead_paragraph: Omaha’s 11-Worth Cafe served standard American breakfast fare of omelets, hash browns, bacon and eggs and, without much notice until June, a dish called the Robert E. Lee: two sausage patties smooshed between biscuits and smothered in gravy.

headline: After Cancer Treatment, Oskar Lindblom Is Back in the Fray
abstract: Lindblom, 24, suited up for the Philadelphia Flyers for the first time since December on Thursday in a postseason elimination game and could play in Game 7 on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: Oskar Lindblom had described his surgery and extensive chemotherapy treatment as “hell” earlier in the season. He had said he felt like a potential return to the ice was eons away after his first treatment for bone cancer and the ensuing push-and-pull of recovering from treatments that for months alternated between moderate and severe.

headline: The Coronavirus May Change College Admissions Forever
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Colleges and Universities', 'ADMISSIONS STANDARDS', 'SAT (College Admission Test)', 'ACT (Examination)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Coronavirus Reopenings']
abstract: A pandemic returns the focus to what matters: education.
lead_paragraph: In the context of a pandemic that has killed about 190,000 Americans and economically devastated many millions more, getting into the college of your dreams is a boutique concern. But for many teenagers who have organized their school years around that goal, it’s everything.

headline: ‘I Keep My Promises,’ Trump Said. Let’s Check.
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Here’s a report card on whether the president met his 2016 campaign pledges.
lead_paragraph: Four years ago as a candidate, President Trump made more than 280 campaign promises. Let’s see how he did:

headline: How to Pass the Time This Weekend
abstract: Things to watch, eat, read and do as summer comes to a close.
lead_paragraph: Welcome. It’s Labor Day weekend.

headline: When Learning Is Really Remote: Students Climb Trees and Travel Miles for a Cell Signal
keywords: ['E-Learning', 'Wireless Communications', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Teachers and School Employees', 'Rural Areas', 'Income Inequality', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'Quarantines']
abstract: Schools are closed in Indonesia because of the pandemic, but for the rural poor who lack internet access and smartphones, online education is particularly difficult.
lead_paragraph: On school days, the three teenage students hop on a motorbike and ride to their personal study hall: a spot along a narrow road outside the Indonesian village of Kenalan where they can get a stable cellphone signal.

headline: 4 Dead in Philadelphia House Fire
abstract: The victims were 9, 11, 17 and 35 years old, officials said.
lead_paragraph: A woman, a teenager and two children were found dead in a fire at a Philadelphia rowhouse on Saturday morning, the authorities said.

headline: Eleanor Jacobs, 91, Dies; a Force Behind the Earth Shoe Phenomenon
abstract: After discovering a pair in Copenhagen that eased her back pain, she and her husband rebranded the funny-looking shoe and sold millions in the U.S.
lead_paragraph: Eleanor Jacobs, who stumbled upon a pair of odd-looking shoes in Denmark and, with her husband, Raymond, created a short-lived phenomenon by selling them in the United States as Earth Shoes, died on Aug. 25 at her home in Litchfield, Conn. She was 91.

headline: How Many Lives Would a More Normal President Have Saved?
abstract: Trump failed to meet the Covid-19 challenge. But it’s harder to judge whether the overall response was catastrophic or merely mediocre.
lead_paragraph: All of the fears I nurtured in 2016 about Donald Trump’s unfitness for the presidency, and the dangers of putting him in the White House for the sake of judicial appointments or tax cuts or any other policy goal, have seemingly been vindicated so far in 2020. Combine Trump’s conduct throughout the Covid-19 pandemic — the month of denial, the veering messaging and policy, the rage-tweeting, the shrugging surrender to a summer spike — with the growing toll of American dead, and you have the strongest case for NeverTrumpism, distilled: Never mind his policy positions, never mind the perils of liberalism; the risk of a once-in-a-century catastrophe with this guy in charge is just too high.

headline: At Least 4 Boats Sink During ‘Trump Boat Parade’ in Texas, Officials Say
abstract: No injuries were immediately reported at the event, which was taking place on Lake Travis.
lead_paragraph: The authorities rescued numerous people from the waters of Lake Travis in Texas on Saturday after at least four boats sank at an event promoted as a Trump Boat Parade, officials said.

headline: Serena Williams Beats Sloane Stephens at U.S. Open
abstract: Williams, the No. 3 seed, won after dropping the first set to Stephens.
lead_paragraph: Another comeback victory in the books, Serena Williams waved to two of the very rare spectators at this twilight zone of a United States Open: her husband Alexis Ohanian and their daughter, Olympia, who turned 3 this week.

headline: Joseph Bartscherer, Rigorously Conceptual Photographer, Dies at 65
abstract: His work — including a project for which he collected three decades of front-page obituaries from The New York Times — often took years to complete.
lead_paragraph: Joseph Bartscherer, a fine-art photographer who created rigorously conceptual work about the constructed world, the natural world and the intersection of the two, was found dead on Aug. 13 at his home in Brooklyn Heights. He was 65.

headline: How to Both Work and School From Home
keywords: ['Content Type: Service', 'Telecommuting', 'Education (K-12)', 'E-Learning', 'Work-Life Balance', 'Parenting', 'Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)']
abstract: The hours blur together, sure, but creating distinct spaces, keeping a schedule and sharing resources can help.
lead_paragraph: In March, several days before the coronavirus pandemic brought New York to a halt, Mary Ausman, a parent and church educational coordinator, moved with her husband, their two sons and two dogs from a house in the Riverdale neighborhood of the Bronx to a 600-square-foot apartment in Hell’s Kitchen. The family wanted their younger son, Alex, 10, a student at the School of American Ballet in Midtown, to be able to walk to dance rehearsals and acting auditions, and looked forward to living in a more central location.

headline: 7 Sculpture Gardens that Merge Art With the Landscape
abstract: This fall, getting culture outdoors is even more restorative than usual. Here are some options across the country.
lead_paragraph: Many museums and galleries across the country have cautiously begun to reopen in recent weeks, offering a chance for the culture-starved to enjoy a moment of reprieve with their favorite works of art. Still, the lines can be long, and timed ticketing limits a more impulsive visit.

headline: After Accusations of Police Cover-Up, Prude Case Goes to Grand Jury
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Attorneys General']
abstract: The decision by New York’s attorney general comes more than five months after Daniel Prude died of suffocation after officers in Rochester, N.Y., placed a hood over his head.
lead_paragraph: New York’s attorney general announced on Saturday that she would set up a grand jury to consider evidence in the death of a Black man in Rochester, N.Y., who suffocated after he had been placed in a hood by police officers and pinned to the ground.

headline: Could You Repeat That Number?
abstract: David Kwong doubles down on the fun and takes us out to the old ballgame, too.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — Beware the sleight of word running through this brilliantly tortuous puzzle. David Kwong, magician, TED Talk whisperer and puzzle conjurer is back, and I couldn’t be happier.

headline: Court Approves Warrantless Surveillance Rules While Scolding F.B.I.
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods', 'Privacy', 'Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA)', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services']
abstract: The release of a newly declassified ruling follows a separate decision by an appeals court that a defunct National Security Agency program was illegal.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The nation’s surveillance court found that the F.B.I. had committed “widespread violations” of rules intended to protect Americans’ privacy when analysts search through a repository of emails gathered without a warrant, but it nevertheless signed off on another year of the program, according to a newly declassified ruling.

headline: ‘Dwarf Pride’ Was Hard Won. Will a Growth Drug Undermine It?
abstract: An experimental medication that increases height in children with the most common form of dwarfism has raised hope that it can help them lead easier lives. But some say the condition is not a problem in need of a cure.
lead_paragraph: AUCKLAND, New Zealand — It’s a question many parents of children with dwarfism have contemplated: If a medication could make them taller, would they give it to them?

headline: Authentic Wins the Kentucky Derby, Run Without Fans
abstract: The race in Louisville ran with a smaller field than usual, no spectators and in spite of nearby protests over the police killing of Breonna Taylor in the city earlier this year.
lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — No one really expected a horse race.

headline: Dorothy Parker’s Ashes Are Returned to New York
abstract: Completing a decades-long journey, the writer’s ashes were disinterred in Baltimore and taken by train to their (latest) final resting place: Woodlawn Cemetery in the Bronx.
lead_paragraph: The ashes of Dorothy Parker, the beloved writer and humorist, have been moved yet again, this time to a final resting spot in New York.

headline: Searchers Find No Sign of Survivor in Beirut Rubble
abstract: The searchers said there were no new indications that anyone was alive in the rubble of a historic house that was destroyed by the blast, despite possible signs of life reported earlier.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Rescue workers who had spent days searching for a possible survivor in a building destroyed by a huge explosion last month all but gave up hope on Saturday, saying they had no new indications that anyone was alive under the rubble.

headline: The U.S. Open Descends Into Pandemic Precaution Chaos
abstract: Yet another change in rules for players who were exposed to a player who tested positive for coronavirus caused the top women’s doubles team to be defaulted.
lead_paragraph: For two weeks, all seemed well with the plan to hold the United States Open in New York just a few months after the city had become the epicenter for the coronavirus in the Western world.

headline: The World War II You Don’t Know
keywords: ['World War II (1939-45)', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era']
abstract: To commemorate the 75th anniversary of the conflict’s end, a special section that grew out of a yearlong project brings to light overlooked stories of bravery and adversity.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: Quotation of the Day: A Hungry Country Returns to Family Farms to Feed Itself
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, September 6, 2020.
lead_paragraph: “Lebanon isn’t a poor country, it’s a looted one.”

headline: Flock to a Bird Fest or a Country Music Concert
abstract: This week, meet the feathered residents of the Pacific Northwest, remember the victims of 9/11, rock out to Margo Price and uncover the secrets of asteroids over a meal.
lead_paragraph: Here is a sampling of the week’s events and how to tune in (all times are Eastern). Note that events are subject to change after publication.

headline: Islanders Defeat Flyers and Head to Conference Finals for First Time Since 1993
abstract: The Islanders shut out the Flyers, 4-0, in Game 7 of their playoff series and now face the Tampa Bay Lightning to decide who goes to the Stanley Cup finals.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — Game 7s have a magic all their own. They are where memories are made, bringing out the kid in every N.H.L. player who dared to dream about a winner-take-all moment.

headline: 2020 U.S. Open: What to Watch on Sunday
abstract: Naomi Osaka and Novak Djokovic lead the singles fields into the round of 16 at the United States Open. Also Sunday, the doubles fields begin their quarterfinal matchups.
lead_paragraph: How to watch: From 11 a.m. to 11 p.m. Eastern time on ESPN2; streaming on the ESPN app.

headline: How, and When, to Watch the U.S. Open
abstract: Tennis has returned. Here’s what to expect for the rest of the month.
lead_paragraph: Tennis has returned. Here’s what to expect for the rest of the month.

headline: Celebrate the Jewish High Holy Days, Pandemic-Style
keywords: ['Synagogues', 'Rosh Hashana', 'Yom Kippur', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Content Type: Service', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)']
abstract: Here are ways Jewish congregations around the country are observing Rosh Hashana and Yom Kippur this year, from pretaped shofar blasts to webinars on how to make your own altars.
lead_paragraph: Unlike Passover, with its tradition of at-home Seders that translated well to Zoom in the spring, the Jewish High Holy Days have a strong emphasis on hours spent inside of a synagogue. You might be wondering — whether you belong to a synagogue year-round or scrambled each fall to find a temporary one — how you can observe Rosh Hashana (which starts the night of Sept. 18) and Yom Kippur (the night of Sept. 27) from home.

headline: ‘I Saw a Prominent Display of a Sauvignon Blanc From New Zealand’
abstract: Picking out a bottle of wine to share with friends, sturdy ivy in Queens and more reader tales of New York in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Drones, Hooks and Blood: Secrets of the Shark Fishermen of Long Island
keywords: ['Sharks', 'Endangered and Extinct Species', 'Fishing, Sport', 'Animal Abuse, Rights and Welfare']
abstract: ‘I don’t want to encourage other people to do this.’
lead_paragraph: “We’re on!” Chris Stefanou yelled as his fishing rod bent sharply, the reel screaming in the wind. A crowd began to make its way toward his stretch of Tobay Beach, on Long Island, and within minutes, an unmistakable gray dorsal fin appeared just a few feet from shore.

headline: Fighting Patriarchy, and Fearing Worse From the Taliban
abstract: A new generation of career-minded women in Afghanistan fear that all they have fought for will be swept away if the Taliban negotiate a return.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — When Gaisu Yari was 6, she was engaged to the 6-year-old son of a pro-Taliban commander in eastern Afghanistan.

headline: A New Front in America’s Pandemic: College Towns
abstract: The coronavirus is spiking around campuses from Texas to Iowa to North Carolina as students return.
lead_paragraph: IOWA CITY, Iowa — Last month, facing a budget shortfall of at least $75 million because of the pandemic, the University of Iowa welcomed thousands of students back to its campus — and into the surrounding community.

headline: Ben Simmons and Joel Embiid Are Stuck Between Star and Superstar
abstract: The Philadelphia 76ers, and their fans, are still waiting for their franchise stars to become the kinds of players, and leaders, who can win championships.
lead_paragraph: It was just two years ago when Joel Embiid, the Philadelphia 76ers’ gregarious and talented center, told reporters about an interaction he had with his gifted rookie partner, the much more subdued but still skillful Ben Simmons.

headline: The Strange Grief of Losing My Sense of Taste
abstract: Many symptoms of Covid-19 were difficult, but losing my ability to taste hurt the most.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — After I tested positive for Covid-19, I ordered panang curry. When the food arrived, I lifted the plastic lid, expecting the scent of makrut lime, lemongrass and ginger. But there was nothing. I plucked a forkful of tofu from the sauce. It was flavorless.

headline: Homes That Sold for Around $575,000
abstract: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
lead_paragraph: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.

abstract: Some residents saw the shooting of Jacob Blake as proof that the city’s policing needs a fundamental overhaul. Others spoke of getting back to normal.

headline: Democrats Belatedly Launch Operation to Share Information on Voters
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Political Action Committees', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing']
abstract: Democrats have been far behind Republicans on compiling and sharing information that can be used by campaigns, state parties and super PACs.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Hillary Clinton lost the 2016 election, she blamed Russian interference and the former F.B.I. director James Comey’s eleventh-hour resurrection of her emails for her defeat.

headline: With Adult Children Home, Now’s the Time: Talk About Your Money
keywords: ['Families and Family Life', 'Retirement', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Personal Finances', 'Living Wills and Health Care Proxies', 'Wills and Estates', 'Content Type: Service', 'Quarantines']
abstract: Riding out the pandemic with family presents the perfect chance to lay it all out: priorities, account balances, end-of-life directives.
lead_paragraph: For far too many families, financial planning is akin to scheduling dental surgery. The prospect of pain and discomfort prompts many to put it off — or not do it at all.

headline: Jenna Bush Hager, a Book Industry Insider With a New Title of Her Own
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Writing and Writers', 'Content Type: Personal Profile']
abstract: The former first daughter, a force in publishing because of her Read With Jenna book club, is the author of a new essay collection, “Everything Beautiful in Its Time.”
lead_paragraph: Let’s get this out of the way early: Jenna Bush Hager’s new book, “Everything Beautiful in Its Time,” will not be a Read With Jenna selection.

headline: Working From Home Poses Hurdles for Employees of Color
keywords: ['Telecommuting', 'Minorities', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Hiring and Promotion', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Workplace Environment', 'Discrimination', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Quarantines', 'Hispanic-Americans']
abstract: Without the networks and encounters that offices provide, companies must foster the visibility of Black and Hispanic workers, diversity experts say.
lead_paragraph: Kimberly Bryant, the founder of the nonprofit group Black Girls Code, recalls the spontaneous encounters with other people of color around the office that gave her a sense of belonging as she forged a career as an engineer. The wave in the cafeteria, the smile in the elevator, the nod in the hallway — for Ms. Bryant, “all would lead to connections that were instrumental in terms of my success.”

headline: In Final Stretch, Biden Defends Lead Against Trump’s Onslaught
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The president is attempting to overtake his Democratic challenger with a strategy of racial polarization in heavily white Midwestern states, even as Democrats make inroads in the Republican-leaning South and West.

headline: Listen Closely, and You Will Hear Coaching During U.S. Open Matches
abstract: When an umpire called out Serena Williams over coaching in the 2018 U.S. Open final, it erupted into a scene. This year, with no fans in the seats, there is chatter galore between coaches and players, even though it breaks the rules.
lead_paragraph: The prohibition against coaching during a match at the United States Open is supposed to be straightforward.

headline: Off the Shore, Finding Sharks and Freedom
abstract: Reporting on a unique group of fishermen was an adventure. Getting on the water myself was otherworldly.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: Hong Kong Police Block Protests Over Delayed Election
keywords: ['Hong Kong Protests (2019)', 'Politics and Government', 'Elections', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: Thousands of officers flooded the streets to stop a demonstration that had been planned to show public anger over the postponement and the imposition of a draconian security law.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Thousands of police officers in riot gear filled the streets of Hong Kong on Sunday, stifling efforts to protest the postponement of legislative elections and China’s imposition of a national security law that gives the authorities sweeping new powers to pursue critics.

headline: How Your Labor Day Blast Could Make Pandemic Life Worse in the Fall
keywords: ['Coronavirus Risks and Safety Concerns', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Labor Day', 'Disease Rates']
abstract: After past holiday weekends caused spikes in Covid-19 cases, public health officials are urging people to keep gatherings small, outdoors and masked.
lead_paragraph: For many Americans, Labor Day is a goodbye to summer before children go back to school and cold weather arrives. But public health experts are worried that in the midst of a pandemic, the traditional last blast of summer could translate into disaster this fall.

headline: Manhunt Underway After Stabbings in Birmingham, England
abstract: At least one person was killed in a series of attacks in the city. The police believe the victims were chosen at random, but they are not treating the rampage as terrorism.
lead_paragraph: A search was underway in Birmingham, England, on Sunday for a man who was said to have carried out a series of stabbings across the city that left at least one person dead and seven more wounded, two of them seriously, the police said.

headline: Daily Coronavirus Testing at Home? Many Experts Are Skeptical
abstract: The buzzy idea is impractical, critics said. And there isn’t yet real-world data to show it will work.
lead_paragraph: Over the past few weeks, a Harvard scientist has made headlines for a bold idea to curb the spread of the coronavirus: rolling out so-called antigen tests, a decades-old underdog in testing technology, to tens of millions of Americans for near-daily, at-home use.

headline: In Sign of Progress, Fewer Than 1% of New York’s Virus Tests Are Positive
abstract: The state’s share of positive tests has stayed below 1 percent for 30 straight days, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said, though he urged caution amid Labor Day celebrations. India surpassed Brazil to become the country with the second-highest number of cases.
lead_paragraph: [Follow our live Covid-19 updates around the globe.]

headline: Labor Day, 2020 Election, Serena Williams: Your Weekend Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: The Week in Business: Jobs Added, but at a Slower Pace
keywords: ['Stocks and Bonds', 'United States Economy', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Unemployment Insurance', 'Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)']
abstract: The United States added 1.4 million jobs in August. The stock market tumbled at the end of the week. And football season is upon us.
lead_paragraph: Happy Labor Day weekend! I hope you are enjoying some rest, even if it’s just a staycation. Here’s the business and tech news you need to know for the (short!) week ahead. — Gillian Friedman

headline: What to Cook This Week
abstract: See the summer season out with corn on the cob, or simply dressed ripe tomatoes.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. I’m back! You miss me? I sure missed you, the letters you send, the requests you have for recipes, your musings and worries and delights and disappointments. It’s a healthy, supportive community we have here at NYT Cooking, and living and cooking outside of its bubble — our virtual pod — became hard after a time, less vital and exciting. I am glad to return. And I am so thankful to Tejal Rao and Julia Moskin for covering for me while I was gone.

headline: China Freezes Credentials for Journalists at U.S. Outlets, Hinting at Expulsions
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Politics and Government', 'News and News Media', 'Freedom of the Press', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Visas']
abstract: CNN, The Wall Street Journal, Bloomberg News and Getty Images are affected. Chinese officials told journalists, who can still work, that their fate depends on what the United States does to Chinese media employees.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Chinese government has stopped renewing press credentials for foreign journalists working for American news organizations in China and has implied it will proceed with expulsions if the Trump administration takes further action against Chinese media employees in the United States, according to six journalists and U.S. officials with knowledge of the events and statements on Monday by a Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesman.

headline: Gerald Shur, Architect of Witness Protection Program, Dies at 86
abstract: As a young Justice Department lawyer investigating the mob, he realized that more witnesses might talk if they weren’t afraid of being killed.
lead_paragraph: Gerald Shur, a lawyer who realized that witnesses would be more likely to testify against organized crime figures if they weren’t afraid of being assassinated, and who used that insight to create the federal witness protection program, died on Aug. 25 at his home in Warminster, Pa., He was 86.

headline: Scenes from America's Divided Cities
abstract: Even in this crisis, our sidewalks are the essential stage of public life.
lead_paragraph: Even in this crisis, our sidewalks are the essential stage of public life.

headline: When Republicans and Unions Got Along
keywords: ['Organized Labor', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Income Inequality']
abstract: Support for unions is rising. The G.O.P. might want to be part of that.
lead_paragraph: In September 1952, Dwight D. Eisenhower spoke to a convention of labor leaders and told them that before joining the Army, he took a job at a dairy plant where “I worked 84 hours a week on the night shift from 6 to 6, seven nights a week.” Recognizing how extreme that was, Eisenhower said, in a nod to labor, “In the years since, unions, cooperating with employers, have vastly improved the lot of working men and women.”

headline: The Best Reason to Go to College
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Books and Literature', 'Religion and Belief', 'Generation Z']
abstract: It’s the same as it ever was: To learn that the world is more than the issues that divide us.
lead_paragraph: As colleges throughout the United States reopen, facing a weird new landscape of empty rooms and scattered classmates, it’s easy to wonder what these traditional places of learning still have to teach the rest of us. Long before the pandemic, campuses were in the news not so much for opening young minds as for closing down discussions and less for encouraging humanity than for promoting ideologies.

headline: N.H.L. Conference Finals Begin After Hectic Second Round
abstract: Three teams won Game 7s to advance. Dallas and Vegas start the action with Game 1 on Sunday night in Edmonton, Alberta.
lead_paragraph: Against the sizzle of late summer, the ice in Edmonton, Alberta, is being prepared to host both of the N.H.L.’s conference finals, beginning with Sunday night’s Game 1 of the Western Conference series between the Dallas Stars and Vegas Golden Knights. In the Eastern series, the Tampa Bay Lightning will clash with the Islanders, starting with Game 1 on Monday night.

headline: Helicopters Rescue About 200 Trapped in California Wildfire
abstract: “We had to splash water on our hair because our hair was catching on fire,” one evacuee said of the harrowing escape from the Creek Fire. The governor declared an emergency.
lead_paragraph: [Follow our live California Wildfires coverage.]

headline: Student Blockade Protests Viktor Orban’s Reach at a Top Arts University
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Politics and Government', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: A demonstration at the University for Theater and Film Arts in Budapest has received support from theater groups, students and faculties in Hungary and around Europe.
lead_paragraph: BUDAPEST — Nearly 100 students have occupied a key building of a prestigious Hungarian university for the past week to protest what they see as a takeover of their school by the autocratic government of Prime Minister Viktor Orban, a demonstration that has become a symbol of resistance to the country’s nationalist leadership.

headline: Venezuela’s Opposition Splits Over Taking Part in Coming Elections
abstract: Sanctions and boycotts have failed to bring down president Nicolás Maduro. Now some opposition leaders are ready to shift strategy and take him on at the ballot box, despite concerns about the vote’s fairness.
lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — Since joining forces last year, Venezuela’s fractious opposition has tried protests and strikes, and encouraged international sanctions, amnesty offers and a coup. It even considered a mercenary invasion to try to unseat President Nicolás Maduro.

headline: Japan Orders Millions to Evacuate as Typhoon Lashes Region
abstract: Typhoon Haishen, which passed Japan and made landfall in South Korea, brought down power lines and left some injured in Japan, and disrupted travel in the region.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — The Japanese authorities on Sunday ordered more than a million residents of western Japan to seek shelter as a major storm lashed the coast with high winds and threatened record-breaking flooding.

headline: A Weapon for Extortion Long Ignored in Alabama Prisons: Cellphones
keywords: ['Prisons and Prisoners', 'Cellular Telephones', 'Extortion and Blackmail', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Smuggling', 'Prison Guards and Corrections Officers', 'Smartphones']
abstract: Families say they have been threatened by call and text into sending thousands of dollars to protect loved ones on the inside. Some suffered anyway.
lead_paragraph: Families say they have been threatened by call and text into sending thousands of dollars to protect loved ones on the inside. Some suffered anyway.

headline: Review: In ‘Three Kings,’ Hot Priest Sheds His Cassock
abstract: The “Fleabag” star Andrew Scott is the entire brilliant cast of a penetrating play about toxic fathers and sons.
lead_paragraph: It’s a ridiculous result of the restrictions of livestreamed theater that one of the best performances to emerge from the new medium is also one you might never get to see.

headline: Protesters Flood Streets in Belarus but Lukashenko Refuses to Bend
abstract: The authorities sealed off streets in the capital to clamp down on demonstrations but mostly refrained from the heavy-handed violence.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Protesters on Sunday again flooded into the capital of Belarus and towns across the country, signaling the depth of popular anger at President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko, an iron-fisted leader who, fortified by strong support from Russia, has shown no sign of bending.

headline: With Some Schools Moving Outdoors, Retailers Follow
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Children and Childhood', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Parenting', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Sporting Goods and Equipment']
abstract: Some outdoor-oriented companies are starting new product lines or repurposing existing ones to capitalize on how the pandemic has changed the normal educational experience.
lead_paragraph: Amy Jackson, an early-education instructor at the Center School in Greenfield, Mass., remembers one rainy day a few years ago when she was outside with her students.

headline: Joe Biden’s China Journey
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'International Relations', 'International Trade and World Market', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: As a United States senator, he spoke of transforming China through trade. As a presidential candidate two decades later, he denounces it as a “dictatorship.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On a steamy August day along the Chinese coast, Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. stepped off a minibus at a seaside compound for a series of unusual meetings with China’s Communist Party leaders.

headline: Rwanda Hints It Tricked ‘Hotel Rwanda’ Dissident Into Coming Home
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Kidnapping and Hostages', 'Political Prisoners']
abstract: President Paul Kagame said that the arrested critic Paul Rusesabagina, now facing terrorism charges, was not kidnapped from Dubai but had been lured to Rwanda in a “flawless” operation.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — Breaking his silence on the dramatic arrest of a prominent dissident, President Paul Kagame of Rwanda insisted on Sunday that his government had not forced Paul Rusesabagina, who is famed for his portrayal in the movie “Hotel Rwanda,” to return from exile to face charges of terrorism and murder.

headline: In a Big Box-Office Test, ‘Tenet’ Grosses $20 Million
abstract: Normally, a Christopher Nolan film would bring in $50 million in North America during an opening weekend. But moviegoing is not normal these days.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Warner Bros. said on Sunday that Christopher Nolan’s hotly anticipated “Tenet” collected an estimated $20.2 million in wide release at North American theaters over the weekend and in previews. It was Hollywood’s best domestic result since mid-March, when the coronavirus pandemic forced cinemas to close.

headline: Your Monday Briefing
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)']
abstract: Hong Kong protests, India, Typhoon Haishen: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: Nearly 300 people were arrested during protests in Hong Kong on Sunday, the day when a legislative election was initially scheduled to take place. Thousands of police officers in riot gear filled the streets.

headline: Novak Djokovic Out of U.S. Open After Accidental Hit of Line Judge
abstract: Djokovic was disqualified after a lengthy discussion with officials in the latest recent misadventure for the top men’s player in tennis.
lead_paragraph: Novak Djokovic, the top men’s player in a sport with its share of meltdowns and misbehavior, became the first No. 1 disqualified from a Grand Slam singles tournament after he inadvertently struck a line judge with a ball hit in frustration at the United States Open on Sunday.

headline: DeJoy Pressured Workers to Donate to G.O.P. Candidates, Former Employees Say
keywords: ['Campaign Finance', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Conflicts of Interest']
abstract: Former employees at New Breed Logistics say they were expected to donate to candidates whom their executive, Louis DeJoy, was supporting, and would be rewarded through yearly bonuses.
lead_paragraph: Postmaster General Louis DeJoy, a major donor to President Trump and fund-raiser for the Republican Party, cultivated an environment at his former company that left employees feeling pressured to make donations to Republican candidates, and rewarded them with bonuses for doing so, according to former employees.

headline: Federal Judge Blocks, for Now, Further Winding Down of the 2020 Census
keywords: ['Census', 'Redistricting and Reapportionment', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Presidential Election of 2020']
abstract: The Census Bureau had begun ending its count in places where it considered its job done. But a lawsuit claims that stopping now will result in a flawed count.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The tortuous course of the 2020 census, first slowed by the coronavirus pandemic and then placed on a fast track by the Trump administration, took yet another twist on Friday when a federal judge temporarily blocked the administration’s order to wrap up the count a month ahead of schedule.

headline: New York Will Test the Dead More Often for Coronavirus and Flu
abstract: New regulations require a ramp-up in testing for patients with symptoms, as well as people who weren’t tested before they died.
lead_paragraph: Cough, fever, chills — with fall fast on the way, symptoms alone won’t be useful in distinguishing Covid-19 from similar-looking cases of the flu. That means routinely testing for both viruses will be crucial — even, perhaps, after some patients have already died.

headline: With Fans Barred From the U.S. Open, One Gets as Close as He Can
abstract: Giovanni Bartocci has had a 2020-type year, including enduring a fire that closed down his East Village restaurant, but he is still there to cheer the tennis player Matteo Berrettini.
lead_paragraph: If only the founders of modern tennis could have witnessed the scene outside the gates of the United States Open on Saturday. They might not have recognized the trappings of their once-genteel sport.

headline: Why Was Novak Djokovic Disqualified From the U.S. Open?
abstract: The rules on the books are not well-known to some tennis fans.
lead_paragraph: Novak Djokovic’s disqualification from the United States Open after hitting a line judge in the neck with a ball that he struck toward the back of the court in frustration is perhaps the most costly one in tennis history.

headline: Form a Tight Bond
abstract: The return of Gareth Bain.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — It has been five years since we last had a puzzle by Gareth Bain, and I, for one, am happy to see him back. No doubt he has been busy: Mr. Bain was studying to be a veterinarian when he made his New York Times Crossword debut and now he practices in South Africa.

headline: Michael Cohen’s Book Says Trump Held ‘Low Opinions of All Black Folks’
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Discrimination']
abstract: The president’s former fixer describes him as a mob boss figure who made racist insults, was driven by hatred for President Barack Obama and engaged in underhanded tactics against opponents.
lead_paragraph: President Trump routinely referred to Black leaders of foreign nations with racist insults. He had an abiding admiration for President Vladimir V. Putin’s willingness to treat Russia like a personal business. And he was consumed with hatred for President Barack Obama.

headline: Can a Person's Hands Reveal Their Job?
abstract: We use them to grip, to hold, to guide. A photo essay in honor of the American worker.
lead_paragraph: We use them to grip, to hold, to guide. A photo essay in honor of the American worker.

headline: More Than Ever, Trump Casts Himself as the Defender of White America
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'George Floyd Protests (2020)', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Discrimination', 'Whites', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Presenting himself as a warrior against identity politics, the president has increasingly made appeals to the grievances of white supporters a centerpiece of his re-election campaign.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After a summer when hundreds of thousands of people took to the streets protesting racial injustice against Black Americans, President Trump has made it clear over the last few days that, in his view, the country’s real race problem is bias against white Americans.

headline: Ashe Stadium Again Turns Into an Arena of the Absurd
abstract: The stadium has been home to thrilling tennis moments, but also to strange and unusual ones.
lead_paragraph: Since its opening in 1997, Arthur Ashe Stadium has been the site of some of the most thrilling tennis in the history of the game, matches that have gone into the small hours of the night, in front of raucous and often unruly crowds, by tennis standards.

headline: Lou Brock, Baseball Hall of Famer Known for Stealing Bases, Dies at 81
abstract: The son of sharecroppers, Brock attended a one-room schoolhouse, but was inspired by possibilities beyond the poverty and segregation of the rural South.
lead_paragraph: Lou Brock, the St. Louis Cardinals’ Hall of Fame outfielder who in a career spanning two decades became the greatest base-stealer the major leagues had ever known when he eclipsed the single-season and career records for steals, died on Sunday. He was 81.

headline: Orca That Carried Dead Calf for 17 Days Gives Birth Again
abstract: Researchers spotted the killer whale they call J35 alongside her “robust and lively” new calf on Saturday — a ray of hope for the endangered Southern Resident population off the Pacific Northwest.
lead_paragraph: An orca that once spent 17 days carrying her dead calf — a dramatic saga of apparent mourning — has become a mother once again.

headline: Heat Wave Roasts Southern California With Record of 121 Degrees
abstract: Los Angeles County set a new high temperature as a cooling sea breeze remained trapped offshore, according to the National Weather Service.
lead_paragraph: Scorching temperatures continued to bake Southern California on Sunday, with a record of 121 degrees set in Los Angeles County and at least one death, a 41-year-old hiker, suspected to be related to the heat.

headline: Journalists Aren’t the Enemy of the People. But We’re Not Your Friends.
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: President Trump will try to put the media on the ballot, and reporters face the increasing temptation to posture for those most eager to oust him.
lead_paragraph: The worst thing about being a reporter in the age of Donald Trump is, of course, the president’s concerted attacks on the free press. The second-worst thing is well-meaning readers who say things like, “Thank you for what you do.”

headline: For Aging Belarus Rockers, a Late Shot at Stardom
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Music', 'Pop and Rock Music', 'Politics and Government', 'Elections']
abstract: Forced underground in the 1990s to a life of cover gigs and guitar lessons, they are re-emerging amid the country’s political awakening.
lead_paragraph: MINSK, Belarus — Pit Pawlaw, guitar in hand, bobbed before the line of riot police guarding the presidential palace, belting out the chorus of his band’s biggest hit even as a siren blared. The protesters joined in behind him: “Hey, la-la-la-lai, don’t wait, don’t wait.”

headline: Belarus, Hong Kong Protests, U.K. Coronavirus: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.

lead_paragraph: How to watch: From 11 a.m. to 4 p.m. Eastern time on ESPN; 4 p.m. to 11 p.m. on ESPN2; and streaming on the ESPN app.

headline: What to Watch For as Harris and Pence Visit Wisconsin on Labor Day
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Vice Presidents and Vice Presidency (US)']
abstract: The vice-presidential candidates will be on opposite ends of Wisconsin, a battleground that is increasingly essential to President Trump in November.
lead_paragraph: LA CROSSE, Wis. — Labor Day is the traditional kickoff to the fall campaign season, but this year the holiday represents something more: the first time both candidates for vice president will be on the trail on the same day in the same state.

headline: It’s Patrick Mahomes’s N.F.L., but Let’s Preview All 32 Teams Anyway
abstract: Mahomes and Lamar Jackson headline an exciting new era of the N.F.L., which is on track for an on-time return to the field, just as planned.
lead_paragraph: While just about every other American sports league had to radically change its season because of the coronavirus, the N.F.L. waited patiently, insisting it would stick with its normal timeline. That confidence appears to have paid off, with the league set to kick off on Thursday, just as it said it would all along.
