headline: Jerry Lewis Telethon Will Return With Kevin Hart
abstract: Once a Labor Day weekend tradition, the telethon is coming back in October to raise money for the Muscular Dystrophy Association and its new host’s Help From the Hart charity.
lead_paragraph: For decades, the Labor Day holiday was synonymous with the weekend-long telethon hosted by Jerry Lewis, on which that comedian and filmmaker served as the M.C. for all kinds of entertainment — sometimes highly polished, other times less refined — while encouraging viewers to donate to the Muscular Dystrophy Association. But Lewis, who died in 2017, hosted his last such telethon in 2010, and despite attempts to keep the program going with other presenters, the association announced its cancellation in May 2015, before that year’s telethon could be held.

headline: An Operatic Innovator Takes On Detroit
abstract: Yuval Sharon, who has created works in cars, a park and a train station, will now lead Michigan Opera Theater.
lead_paragraph: Yuval Sharon, who has established himself as perhaps the most innovative opera director in the United States through his experimental Los Angeles company, the Industry, has been named the next artistic director of a more traditional outfit: Michigan Opera Theater in Detroit.

headline: Continue Your Life’s Education With Free Online Classes
keywords: ['Content Type: Service', 'E-Learning', 'Education', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Smartphones']
abstract: If you’re pondering a career shift, looking to learn a specific skill or just plain bored, consider a web-based class to broaden your horizons.
lead_paragraph: Have extra time at home? Want to keep your brain busy with new things to think about? Consider doing a little remote learning of your own. After all, Benjamin Franklin famously set aside an hour or two each day to study, reflect and experiment so he could fill in the gaps in his own education, and he went on to several successful careers.

headline: What You Get for $1.85 Million
abstract: An 1880 house in Provincetown, Mass.; an off-the-grid home on the Big Island of Hawaii; and a five-bedroom estate in Rabun Gap, Ga.
lead_paragraph: An 1880 house in Provincetown, Mass.; an off-the-grid home on the Big Island of Hawaii; and a five-bedroom estate in Rabun Gap, Ga.

headline: $1.85 Million Homes in Massachusetts, Hawaii and Georgia
abstract: An 1880 house in Provincetown, an off-the-grid home on the Big Island and a five-bedroom estate with two guesthouses in Rabun Gap.
lead_paragraph: Built by a Portuguese-born fisherman in the late 19th century, this house more recently belonged to an artist named Hilda Neily, who replaced the garage with a two-story painting studio. It is at the top of a hill a half-block northwest of Commercial Street, the waterside shopping thoroughfare in this picturesque town at the tip of Cape Cod. (The sellers, who bought the property in 2014, own the Canteen, a local restaurant.) Boston is about two hours northwest by car or 90 minutes by fast ferry. Flood insurance is not mandated with a mortgage.

headline: Sitting in Silence With 5,000 Fans: The New Sound of Japanese Sports
abstract: The country has welcomed spectators back to stadiums, but the highly orchestrated singing, chanting and drumming for which they are known is now strictly forbidden.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — As the players drove the ball down the field, I suddenly heard the distinct crinkle of a plastic bag a full four rows in front of me, where a man was pulling out a chicken drumstick to eat.

headline: A 19th-Century Rowhouse in Historic Old Montreal
abstract: This six-bedroom rowhouse in the historic Old Montreal neighborhood, with three commercial spaces included, is on the market for $4.8 million.
lead_paragraph: This six-bedroom rowhouse in the historic Old Montreal neighborhood, with three commercial spaces included, is on the market for $4.8 million.

headline: House Hunting in Canada: A Rowhouse in Old Montreal With Income Potential
abstract: Prices and sales volume have bounced back in Montreal since the spring quarantine, but the growing recession has the housing market on edge.
lead_paragraph: This four-story attached greystone rowhouse is in Old Montreal, the historic riverside district just east of Montreal’s downtown core. The property faces Marché Bonsecours, a restored 1847 building that once housed the city’s main public market. Behind the market building are Montreal’s Old Port and the St. Lawrence River.

headline: He Loves Pakistani Cricket. It Doesn’t Love Him Back.
abstract: “I don’t think anything prepared me for the hostility I was going to face,” the British-born Wasim Khan says of overseeing a beloved sport in a country where many see him only as a foreigner.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Wasim Khan has spent his life immersed in Pakistani cricket, even as he spent very little of that life in Pakistan. To his critics, that latter bit is precisely the problem.

headline: How to Stay Safer on Mass Transit
abstract: As traffic picks up again, on the streets and underground, what are the best strategies to stay safe while commuting and making essential trips?
lead_paragraph: As traffic picks up again, on the streets and underground, what are the best strategies to stay safe while commuting and making essential trips?

headline: Texas’ system for verifying signatures on mail-in ballots is unconstitutional, a judge ruled.
abstract: A federal judge ruled on Tuesday that Texas’ procedure for reviewing — and in some cases rejecting — mail-in ballots was unconstitutional and ordered the state to change its process before Election Day.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge ruled on Tuesday that Texas’ procedure for reviewing — and in some cases rejecting — mail-in ballots was unconstitutional and ordered the state to change its process before Election Day.

headline: Tom Brady, Florida Man in Full
abstract: After 20 years — and six Super Bowl wins — in New England, the most recognizable quarterback in the N.F.L. is working to rebrand his new home “Tompa Bay.”
lead_paragraph: Some months back, the former Buccaneers star cornerback Ronde Barber heard from an acquaintance who had just moved near him, to Tampa, Fla., and wanted to get together. They played a round at the exclusive Pelican Golf Club, where Barber raved about the climate, the culture and the city, mentioning how even with more than three million people the region still feels small, chill, manageable.

headline: Summer Jet-Setters Turned Sardinia Into a Virus Hot Spot
abstract: Silvio Berlusconi was there in August. So was his friend, the club owner Flavio Briatore. Now both are among hundreds of Covid-19 cases linked to the Italian island, a favorite of rich partygoers.
lead_paragraph: ROME — The allure of the turquoise waters, extravagant villas and exclusive dance clubs of the Emerald Coast of Sardinia proved stronger than ever in August, as Italian tourists hungry for virus-free air mingled with regulars of the international party circuit hopping across from places like the Spanish island of Ibiza and Mykonos in the Aegean Sea.

headline: Chicken! Plums! Red Onions!
abstract: Make Melissa Clark’s latest — roast chicken with plums and red onions — for Rosh Hashana, or for whenever you like.
lead_paragraph: Melissa Clark has a terrific new recipe in The Times this week, for a sheet-pan dinner of roast chicken, plums and red onions (above). She came up with it as a dish appropriate to Rosh Hashana, the Jewish New Year, which begins on Sept. 18, but it’s outstanding whatever your faith or lack thereof: a sticky, bright-flavored joy that you could pair with couscous to great effect. I hope you do.

headline: 7 People Die in West Coast Wildfires
abstract: Strong winds were likely to continue to propel the extraordinary number of fires burning in California, Oregon and Washington.
lead_paragraph: [Follow our live Oregon, California and Washington fires updates.]

headline: A Marist poll shows Biden widening his lead in Pennsylvania.
abstract: Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s lead over President Trump among likely voters in Pennsylvania has widened slightly, according to an NBC News/Marist poll released on Wednesday that shows Mr. Biden with 53 percent support to Mr. Trump’s 44.
lead_paragraph: Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s lead over President Trump among likely voters in Pennsylvania has widened slightly, according to an NBC News/Marist poll released on Wednesday that shows Mr. Biden with 53 percent support to Mr. Trump’s 44.

headline: Drag Queens Deliver Dinner and a Show in San Francisco
abstract: Oasis, a cabaret and nightclub, closed in March because of the coronavirus pandemic. Now its drag queens are bringing food and a curbside performance to people’s front doors.
lead_paragraph: Before the coronavirus, drag queens and kings lip-synced their way across the jewel-box stage at Oasis, a San Francisco cabaret, and performed parodies of shows like “Sex and the City” and “Buffy the Vampire Slayer,” to the delight of packed houses of tourists and locals.

headline: N.Y.C. Gynecologist Faces Federal Charges Over 6 Sex Abuse Accusations
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Gynecology and Gynecologists']
abstract: The former doctor, Robert A. Hadden, was charged with enticing women, including one minor, to engage in illegal sex acts.
lead_paragraph: A Manhattan gynecologist accused by the wife of former Democratic presidential candidate Andrew Yang of sexually assaulting her now faces federal charges related to the sexual abuse of women, according to a new indictment unsealed on Wednesday.

headline: Ron Gorchov, Painter Who Challenged Viewers’ Perceptions, Dies at 90
abstract: Seeking “a new kind of visual space” and using a vivid palette, he stacked multiple canvases with gently curved, round-cornered tops.
lead_paragraph: Ron Gorchov, an abstract painter widely known for vividly colored, saddle-shaped canvases that curved away from the wall and gently warped the viewer’s perception, died on Aug. 18 at his home in Red Hook, Brooklyn. He was 90.

headline: Trump’s decision to go maskless at a North Carolina rally concerns Dr. Fauci.
abstract: Dr. Anthony S. Fauci, the nation’s leading infectious diseases expert, expressed concern Wednesday morning about the example President Trump had set the night before when he held a large campaign rally in North Carolina without wearing a mask.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Anthony S. Fauci, the nation’s leading infectious diseases expert, expressed concern Wednesday morning about the example President Trump had set the night before when he held a large campaign rally in North Carolina without wearing a mask.

headline: How Are You Keeping Your Students Engaged?
abstract: Teachers: We want to hear your strategies.
lead_paragraph: Teachers, thank you for your efforts to keep our kids learning and growing. We know this year is harder than ever and presents new challenges. We’d love to know how you’re trying to make school fun. Are you finding new ways for kids to share and socialize? What are the ways you’re using technology and social distancing to your advantage?

headline: Schools Briefing: Coronavirus Dorms and Super Spreaders
abstract: Colleges are struggling to deal with outbreaks on campus.
lead_paragraph: Cases of coronavirus are spiking on university campuses, leaving administrators with two unappealing options: Quarantine students in dorms, or send them home.

headline: The ‘Straightforward’ Link Between Climate and California’s Fires
abstract: Also this week: They led the E.P.A. as Republicans. Now, they’re backing Biden.
lead_paragraph: [Follow our live California Wildfires coverage.]

headline: ‘I Knew All the Words’: Your First Favorite Musicals
abstract: Readers said “Sweeney Todd” and “Wicked,” among other classics, made them fall in love with musicals. One sheepishly confessed: “Starlight Express.”
lead_paragraph: In a recent essay, The New York Times critic Maya Phillips confessed that she discovered musicals “in a way theater die-hards might find gauche — via the widely panned film adaptation of ‘Rent.’”

headline: ‘Impossible Objects’ That Reveal a Hidden Power
keywords: ['Art', 'Photography', 'Computer Vision', 'Computer Security', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Privacy']
abstract: The artist Trevor Paglen peers into the history of photography and its relationship to state surveillance.
lead_paragraph: Tucked into a small gallery in the Carnegie Museum of Art in Pittsburgh is a plexiglass cube filled with computer parts. It’s about 16 inches on each side, reminiscent of a Donald Judd box, updated for the digital era.

headline: Refinery29 Finds Next Top Editor at Facebook
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations']
abstract: Simone Oliver, who has worked at The New York Times and Condé Nast, will inherit a workplace described as “toxic.”
lead_paragraph: Refinery29, a fashion and beauty site whose previous top editor resigned under pressure in June, has a new global editor in chief: Simone Oliver, who leads partnerships with magazines and lifestyle brands at Facebook and Instagram.

headline: The Met Hires Its First Full-Time Native American Curator
abstract: Patricia Marroquin Norby, most recently of the National Museum of the American Indian in New York, will soon join the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
lead_paragraph: For the first time in its 150-year history, the Metropolitan Museum of Art has hired a full-time Native American curator: Patricia Marroquin Norby.

headline: A Year of Heartbreak and Bloodshed at Fort Hood
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Sexual Harassment', 'Drownings', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Military Bases and Installations']
abstract: More Fort Hood soldiers have died in homicides than in battle since 2016, and officials and family members are struggling to understand why.
lead_paragraph: KILLEEN, Texas — A 20-year-old soldier from the Fort Hood Army Base in Texas was shot at a strip club and died outside a convenience store on the first of March. Thirteen days later, another Fort Hood soldier was shot and killed in a triple homicide that also left his pregnant girlfriend and a former soldier dead.

headline: No, Facebook Does Not Reflect Reality
abstract: Despite what Mark Zuckerberg says, Facebook shapes our world.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.

headline: N.Y.C. to Allow Indoor Dining, in Milestone on Recovery From Pandemic
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo announced that restaurants can open for indoor service at 25 percent capacity, starting on Sept. 30.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo announced on Wednesday that the prohibition on indoor dining in New York City would be lifted on Sept. 30, giving a boost to the city’s recovery from the pandemic and ending its status as one of the few places in the nation with a ban.

headline: Too Pop? Too Weird? A.G. Cook of PC Music Is Stepping Out on His Own
abstract: An innovative producer known for warping the line between the mainstream and the experimental is making a double debut, releasing two albums in two months.
lead_paragraph: In A.G. Cook’s music, nothing is stable. Computerized beats bounce along steadily, then suddenly skid rapidly ahead or stretch like virtual taffy. Earnest vocals get giddily pitch-shifted and skewed by distortion and effects. Tunes suddenly change key; mixes turn themselves inside out; realistic acoustic instruments begin to wow and flutter. Any semblance of predictability gets upended by human whim, as if, sooner or later, some ghost in the machine can’t resist twirling all the knobs.

headline: How Quarantine Killed the Weekend
keywords: ['Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Seasons and Months', 'Working Hours', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Leisure', 'Telecommuting']
abstract: With work changed and play curtailed, what does “time off” even mean anymore?
lead_paragraph: Tom Oling, 51, a television planner who lives in Denver, can’t remember the last time he dressed up for the weekend.

headline: ‘A Fearless Virus Hunter’ Tackles a Coronavirus Mystery in Children
keywords: ['Doctors', 'Pediatric Inflammatory Multisystem Syndrome (PIMS)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Dengue Fever', 'Kawasaki Disease', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Children and Childhood', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Genetics and Heredity', 'Hispanic-Americans', 'Parenting']
abstract: Alberto Paniz-Mondolfi treated some of the world’s most horrendous infectious diseases before fleeing Venezuela. Now that experience is helping him untangle MIS-C.
lead_paragraph: When the coronavirus arrived in the United States, it took many doctors and medical professionals by surprise. Alberto Paniz-Mondolfi was not one of them. He also wasn’t shocked when, a few months later, small numbers of infected children began exhibiting strange, widespread inflammatory symptoms. As someone who spent years fighting epidemics in South America, he learned how pathogens spread and what they can do.

headline: Trump Attacked Generals as Weak and Too Focused on Allies, Woodward’s Book Says
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: The journalist Bob Woodward’s “Rage,” which will be released next week, recounts tense conflicts between the president and his senior leaders.
lead_paragraph: President Trump denigrated senior American military officials when he told his trade adviser, Peter Navarro, during a meeting in 2017 that his top generals were weak and overly concerned with their relationships with allies, according to a new book by the journalist Bob Woodward.

headline: Pay People to Get Vaccinated
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'Consumer Behavior', 'United States Economy', 'Economics (Theory and Philosophy)']
abstract: Once a reliable vaccine exists, it won’t stop the pandemic unless most people are willing to take it. Economics provides a solution.
lead_paragraph: What’s the best way to get the economy back on track after the Covid-19 recession? Simple: Achieve herd immunity. And what’s the best way to achieve herd immunity? Again, simple: Once a vaccine is approved, pay people to take it.

headline: Kenny Ortega, Teen Whisperer
abstract: With the new Netflix series “Julie and the Phantoms,” the man behind “High School Musical” hopes to create another generation of young stars. How does he do it? By seeing teenagers for who they are.
lead_paragraph: When you are a teenager auditioning for Kenny Ortega, when he greets you in the room with his fedora, his walking staff and his whiter-than-white smile, this is what he wants to see: “The potential,” he said. “The desire, the enthusiasm.”

headline: A Cheesy Toast to Dream About
abstract: This riff on Welsh rarebit puts that wilting spinach in the fridge to use in a creamy, verdant lunch.
lead_paragraph: There’s a classic early 20th-century comic strip by Winsor McCay in which, after eating a Welsh rarebit close to bedtime, characters fall into wild, vivid dreams — often horrible, always bizarre — then wake up regretting their choice of dinner. Called “Dream of the Rarebit Fiend,” I think about it every time I make myself the cheese toast, and Tuesday was no exception.

headline: Trump Admits Downplaying the Virus Knowing It Was ‘Deadly Stuff’
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: In taped interviews with the journalist Bob Woodward, the president said as early as February that the virus was more dangerous than the flu, even as he told the country otherwise.
lead_paragraph: President Trump acknowledged to the journalist Bob Woodward that he knowingly played down the coronavirus earlier this year even though he was aware it was life-threatening and vastly more serious than the seasonal flu.

headline: British Prime Minister Bans Gatherings of More Than 6
abstract: Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain announced new coronavirus restrictions, banning gatherings larger than six people, referring to it as the “Rule of Six.”
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain announced new coronavirus restrictions, banning gatherings larger than six people, referring to it as the “Rule of Six.”

headline: A Striking Reversal: Trump’s Attacks on the Military and Defense Contractors
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Arms Trade', 'Veterans']
abstract: President Trump’s public comments this week, perhaps fueled by anger over reports of his disrespect for those who died in America’s wars, take his attack on the military to a new level.
lead_paragraph: President Trump mounted a public attack unusual even for him over the Labor Day weekend, accusing his military leadership of advocating war “so that all of those wonderful companies that make the bombs and make the planes and make everything else stay happy.”

headline: Rediscovering an Ambitious Sketch Comedy That Never Caught On
abstract: Netflix canceled “The Characters” after one season, but the 2016 series showcased a wide range of talent just now coming into their own.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes, the best gambles don’t pay off.

headline: Women on the Scottish Coast, at the Whims of Male Violence
abstract: In “The Bass Rock,” Evie Wyld’s skillful and entertaining third novel, generations of girls and women contend with the looming threat of bodily harm.
lead_paragraph: “If I were a woman I would give men a wide berth.”

headline: Theater to Stream: More Fringe and a Noël Coward ‘Party’
keywords: ['Theater', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)']
abstract: The Billie Holiday Theater offers a live performance of “12 Angry Men…and Women: The Weight of the Wait” in front of a Black Lives Matter mural.
lead_paragraph: It has now been six months since American theater turned off its lights and embarked on a quest to simply exist. Tracking the ever-mutating world of streaming theater for this column has been an education, to say the least. Play readings, for example, tended to be reserved to industry folks; now they are a big part of theater fans’ diet. All shows used to be by appointment; now we differentiate between the ones available on demand and the ones where we do have to turn up in time.

headline: How the Coronavirus Attacks the Brain
abstract: It’s not just the lungs — the pathogen may enter brain cells, causing symptoms like delirium and confusion, scientists reported.
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus targets the lungs foremost, but also the kidneys, liver and blood vessels. Still, about half of patients report neurological symptoms, including headaches, confusion and delirium, suggesting the virus may also attack the brain.

headline: Tiffany’s $16 Billion Sale Falls Apart in Face of Pandemic and Tariffs
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Jewels and Jewelry', 'Luxury Goods and Services', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Customs (Tariff)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: The luxury giant LVMH Moët Hennessy Louis Vuitton backed out of its deal to buy the jeweler.
lead_paragraph: Last November, LVMH Moët Hennessy Louis Vuitton, the world’s largest luxury goods conglomerate, announced plans to acquire Tiffany & Company, the American jeweler founded by Charles Lewis Tiffany in 1837 and famed for its robin egg blue boxes and diamond engagement rings.

headline: The Oscars’ New Diversity Rules Are Sweeping but Safe
abstract: Although the initiative is meant to encourage major changes, the best-picture qualifications aren’t as strict as they may seem.
lead_paragraph: In 2015, after the Oscars announced a set of 20 all-white acting nominees, the then-president of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences was asked whether the group had a diversity problem.

headline: Boris Johnson, Covid, Brexit and the Art of Policy Improvisation
abstract: Even by the British prime minister’s lofty standards, his reversals this week on the two dominant issues facing his country were breathtaking.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain has always taken a seat-of-the-pants approach to governing. But his reversals this week on the two most pressing issues facing the country — the pandemic and Brexit — have been breathtaking, even by Mr. Johnson’s brashly improvisational standards.

headline: Is Voting Twice a Felony?
keywords: ['Absentee Voting', 'Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Elections', 'Voter Fraud (Election Fraud)', 'Elections, Secretary of State']
abstract: President Trump suggested that North Carolina voters mail in their ballots and show up in person to test the state’s electoral system. What exactly are the consequences of voting twice?
lead_paragraph: First, President Trump suggested voters in North Carolina show up at the polls after casting an absentee ballot to test the integrity of the state’s electoral system. Then the secretary of state of Georgia said he would prosecute “to the fullest extent of the law” hundreds of cases where a voter cast an absentee ballot and also voted in person.

headline: Biden, in Michigan to Push a Jobs Plan, Tears Into Trump’s Virus Response
abstract: Before sketching out a plan to keep more jobs in the United States, the former vice president denounced his rival over revelations in a new book that the president knowingly minimized the coronavirus’s dangers.
lead_paragraph: WARREN, Mich. — Joseph R. Biden Jr. tore into President Trump on Wednesday over new revelations from a forthcoming book by the journalist Bob Woodward that the president knowingly minimized the risks of the coronavirus, arguing that Mr. Trump had lied to the American public and put lives in danger.

headline: Will You Know Me if I’m Wearing a Mask?
abstract: Readers share their experiences of being recognized in the age of Covid and not.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Serena Williams Is on Another U.S. Open Run. Is a Record Finish in Store?
abstract: Williams prevailed against Tsvetana Pironkova on Wednesday, advancing to a semifinal against Victoria Azarenka, a rival and a friend. A championship would tie Williams with Margaret Court at 24 major singles titles.
lead_paragraph: Down a set and a break to the unseeded Tsvetana Pironkova in the quarterfinals of the United States Open, Serena Williams was in danger of succumbing to a story line even better than her own.

headline: Measuring Trump’s Culpability for Covid Deaths
abstract: Readers discuss a Ross Douthat column that compared the U.S. death toll with that of other countries.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: D.H.S. Downplayed Threats From Russia and White Supremacists, Whistle-Blower Says
keywords: ['Whistle-Blowers', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'Conspiracy Theories', 'Right-Wing Extremism and Alt-Right', 'Discrimination', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Whites', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'George Floyd Protests (2020)']
abstract: Brian Murphy, the former head of the Department of Homeland Security’s intelligence division, accused senior leaders of warping the agency around President Trump’s political interests.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Top officials with the Department of Homeland Security directed agency analysts to downplay threats from violent white supremacy and Russian election interference, a Homeland Security official said in a whistle-blower complaint released on Wednesday.

headline: Amtrak Chief Pleads for Nearly $5 Billion to Survive Pandemic
keywords: ['Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Federal Aid (US)', 'Stimulus (Economic)', 'Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Railroads', 'Transit Systems', 'Transportation']
abstract: William J. Flynn, the agency’s chief executive, warned of additional cuts to Amtrak’s service and work force to “stave off bankruptcy” if Congress did not provide any additional emergency funding.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Amtrak’s chief executive, William J. Flynn, urged House lawmakers on Wednesday to provide $4.9 billion for the national passenger rail agency, warning that additional cuts to its service and work force would be needed to “stave off bankruptcy” if Congress did not provide any further emergency funding.

headline: Pandemic Has Cut Modern and Contemporary Gallery Sales 36%, Report Says
keywords: ['Art', 'Finances', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Art Basel Hong Kong', 'ART BASEL (FESTIVAL)', 'Frieze Art Fair', 'E-Commerce', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)']
abstract: The survey, by Art Basel and UBS, analyzes the effect of the coronavirus on the world’s art dealers. Sales are down, but the wealthy are still buying.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The coronavirus pandemic has reduced sales at commercial galleries specializing in modern and contemporary art by an average of 36 percent during the first half of 2020, according to a report published Wednesday by Art Basel and UBS.

headline: Gucci Heir Alleges Child Sexual Abuse
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'your-feed-fashion']
abstract: Alexandra Zarini, the great-granddaughter of Guccio Gucci, has filed a lawsuit in Los Angeles against three family members.
lead_paragraph: For the last five years, the name Gucci has been synonymous with success, with a fashion reinvention that has helped redirect the luxury industry toward inclusivity, emotion and the importance of creativity. The family that created the brand has a more complicated, darker past, one involving tax evasion, generational feuds and murder. This week, another charge will be added to that list.

headline: White House Asked Justice Dept. to Take Over Defamation Suit Against Trump, Barr Says
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'Libel and Slander', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The attorney general argued that the intervention was routine but did not say why the department waited 10 months to step in.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The White House asked the Justice Department to replace President Trump’s private lawyers to defend against a woman’s accusations that he defamed her last year in denying her claim that he sexually assaulted her a quarter-century ago, Attorney General William P. Barr said on Wednesday.

headline: White House Press Secretary Claims Trump “Never Lied” to Public on Coronavirus
abstract: The White House press secretary, Kayleigh McEnany, defended President Trump when asked whether he knowingly downplayed the threat of the coronavirus, as reported in a new book.
lead_paragraph: The White House press secretary, Kayleigh McEnany, defended President Trump when asked whether he knowingly downplayed the threat of the coronavirus, as reported in a new book.

headline: ‘The Walking Dead’ Is Set to End in 2022
abstract: The show, which is based on the popular comics by Robert Kirkman, will conclude in 2022 after 11 seasons. But some of its characters will live on in a new spinoff series.
lead_paragraph: After 11 seasons, “The Walking Dead” is finally going into the grave.

headline: George Bizos, Anti-Apartheid Lawyer Who Defended Mandela, Dies at 92
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Apartheid (Policy)', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Legal Profession']
abstract: A champion of human rights, he represented his client and friend in the so-called Rivonia trial of leaders of the African National Congress in the 1960s.
lead_paragraph: George Bizos, who fled the Nazi occupation of his native Greece at age 13 to become one of South Africa’s most prominent human rights lawyers, championing Black people who were denied those rights and devising a three-word phrase that may have shielded his client and friend Nelson Mandela from execution, died on Wednesday at his home in Johannesburg. He was 92.

headline: Steve Nash: ‘I’m Going to Be Myself’ as Nets Head Coach
abstract: Nash said he “did skip the line” by being hired, but his many years as one of the N.B.A.’s best point guards taught him valuable lessons that translate to coaching.
lead_paragraph: Steve Nash, the newly minted Nets coach, sounded all the right notes at his introductory news conference on Wednesday. He called the first coaching job of his career a “unique opportunity” and said the Nets had “an incredible roster” at an “incredible point in the history of the franchise.”

headline: I Need You to Care That Our Country Is on Fire
abstract: Would you feel more urgency about climate change if all you could see was smoke?
lead_paragraph: If you’ve never experienced a fire season before, it’s hard to explain the emotional, physical and sensory effects of having the world immolate before your eyes.

headline: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: Stranded seafarers, refugee camp fire, Boeing: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: When many countries closed their borders as the coronavirus exploded early this year, hundreds of thousands of seafarers on ships around the world suddenly had no way home.

headline: Franchise Workers Win Victory Over U.S. Effort to Curb Lawsuits
keywords: ['Workplace Hazards and Violations', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Franchises', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Fast Food Industry', 'Minimum Wage', 'Overtime']
abstract: A judge rebuffed a Labor Department move that made it harder for employees to win judgments against parent companies over pay violations.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge has struck down key portions of a Trump administration rule that made it more difficult for workers to win lawsuits against companies over violations committed by contractors and franchisees.

headline: A whistle-blower accuses top Homeland Security officials of playing down threats from Russia and white supremacists.
abstract: Top officials with the Department of Homeland Security directed agency analysts to play down the threat of violent white supremacy and of Russian election interference, according to a whistle-blower complaint filed by a top intelligence official with the department.
lead_paragraph: Top officials with the Department of Homeland Security directed agency analysts to play down the threat of violent white supremacy and of Russian election interference, according to a whistle-blower complaint filed by a top intelligence official with the department.

headline: Wildfires Blot Out Sun in the Bay Area
abstract: Across Northern California, huge plumes of smoke from a fire that blasted through the foothills of the Sierra Nevada billowed high into the atmosphere, turning day into an eerie twilight.
lead_paragraph: Hours after sunrise on Wednesday, residents of the San Francisco Bay Area waited for daylight. Instead they got only the faintest suggestion that somewhere above the smoky skies, the sun had indeed risen.

headline: Why Are Men Still Explaining Things to Women?
abstract: Mansplaining illuminates a much deeper problem than the bore of patronizing monologues. “Entitled” author Kate Manne unpacks the phenomenon.
lead_paragraph: — The girl, from “Hills Like White Elephants” (1927) by Ernest Hemingway

headline: Biden Accuses Trump of Lying to the Public About Coronavirus Threat
abstract: Joseph R. Biden Jr. accused President Trump of lying to Americans about the dangers of coronavirus, citing a forthcoming book by the journalist Bob Woodward.
lead_paragraph: Joseph R. Biden Jr. accused President Trump of lying to Americans about the dangers of coronavirus, citing a forthcoming book by the journalist Bob Woodward.

headline: Facebook May Be Ordered to Change Data Practices in Europe
keywords: ['Social Media', 'Politics and Government', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Privacy', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Irish regulators have started an inquiry into Facebook’s movement of data on European users to the United States.
lead_paragraph: Facebook is facing the prospect of not being able to move data about its European users to the United States, after European regulators raised concerns that such transfers do not adequately protect the information from American government surveillance.

headline: Professor Investigated for Posing as Black Has Resigned, University Says
abstract: A blog post published under the George Washington University professor’s name, Jessica A. Krug, described her use of Black identities even though she is white.
lead_paragraph: A George Washington University professor who was being investigated after a blog post published under her name said that she had misrepresented herself as a Black woman has resigned, the university said on Wednesday.

headline: Watch These 15 Movies Before They Leave Netflix This Month
abstract: From blockbusters to beloved indies, a lot of great movies are leaving the streaming service by the end of September. These are the ones not to miss.
lead_paragraph: At least they’re not singling anything out: This month’s exiting Netflix titles run the gamut from Oscar winners to genre specialties to blockbusters to tiny indies. That means if you load up your queue now, you might just have time to get them all in before they leave. (Dates indicate the final day a title is available.)

headline: Lady Gaga and Katy Perry, Preserving Pop’s Old Guard
abstract: Six albums into major-label careers with “Chromatica” and “Smile,” where do these two stars fit in?
lead_paragraph: Lady Gaga and Katy Perry both arrived in 2008, with major-label debut albums. Twelve years later, they’ve both released their sixth LPs, in their mid-30s. Both “Chromatica” (by Lady Gaga) and “Smile” (by Perry) have been hailed as “return to form” records that draw on the aesthetics that helped make them famous. Discussing the new work, both singers and songwriters have referenced periods of darkness that grew largely from the weight of celebrity, and the ways their personas grew detached from the artists within.

headline: Pinehurst Awarded Four More U.S. Opens

The resort’s showcase course, known as Pinehurst No. 2, was already scheduled to host the event in 2024 but will now also have the championship in 2029, 2035, 2041 and 2047.

headline: In Bob Woodward’s ‘Rage,’ a Reporter and a President From Different Universes
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: In this follow-up to “Fear,” Woodward continues applying old-school theories and lines of questioning to a deeply unorthodox administration.
lead_paragraph: What would it take at this point, amid the crush of books about the Trump White House — after the Mueller report and an impeachment trial and now the coronavirus pandemic — for a revelation about the president to be truly surprising? Would it be to learn that he hates money and harbors dreams of retiring to an ascetic, monk-like existence? That he loves to read and is intimately familiar with the works of Elena Ferrante? Readers who pick up Bob Woodward’s new book, “Rage,” and are tantalized by the promise on its dust jacket of “an utterly vivid window into Trump’s mind,” will quickly get schooled in a lesson that apartment hunters in New York often have to learn: A window can be only so vivid if it looks out onto an air shaft.

headline: In ‘Hoax,’ Brian Stelter Ventures Where No Author Has Gone Before
abstract: He’d missed his deadline and then the pandemic arrived — so CNN’s chief media correspondent wrote about it.
lead_paragraph: DOCS AND FRIENDS Aside from a vague sense that time is now divided into “before the pandemic” and “during the pandemic,” it’s hard to have perspective on the events of the past six months. Brian Stelter’s “Hoax: Donald Trump, Fox News, and the Dangerous Distortion of Truth” is among the first books to explore where we are now — and it’s certainly the first to examine how the president’s preferred news source played a role in the dissemination of misinformation about coronavirus.

headline: Montana’s Greatest Cultural Export: Inane Campaign Ads
keywords: ['Elections, House of Representatives', 'Political Advertising', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The state perfected intensely folksy political advertising, a signifiers-over-substance approach that has pervaded the nation.
lead_paragraph: Montana is a land of stunning natural variety — grassy plains and snowcapped mountains, Yellowstone and Glacier National Parks, crystal streams full of glittering trout and one of America’s largest Superfund sites — but perhaps its most abundant resource is self-awareness. I have never lived in a place where so many people’s shirts said what state we were in. Montanans live within a kind of paradox by which they regard their own home as exotic. Nicknamed the Treasure State, it is more commonly called the Last Best Place or Big Sky Country. Both epithets are constructed in the negative: “Big Sky” refers to the general absence of tall buildings, and the “Last Best Place” implies a fallen world outside its borders. It is tempting to dismiss this attitude as provincial, but it seems most popular among the many coastal expatriates who experience Montana as a respite from the lives they left behind. To native and transplant alike, Montana is the only place that isn’t everywhere else.

headline: Fleeing the Suburbs for the City? This Couple Was Ready for Some Amenities

headline: Introducing ‘Sway’ With Kara Swisher
keywords: ['Podcasts', 'Science and Technology', 'Politics and Government', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: A new podcast about power: who has it, who’s been denied it and who dares to defy it.
lead_paragraph: Times Opinion is teaming up with Kara Swisher on a new podcast about power and influence. She’s taking on C.E.O.s, senators, actors and activists — plus upstarts and gatekeepers you might not yet know but need to hear from. How did these people get power? How do they actually use it? And how does their power shape your life?

headline: Poem: The Hedgehog
abstract: A poem that widens to contain our curiosity, our fear, whatever we’re each keeping contained.
lead_paragraph: Though many like to say that poems begin with “ordinary” things, creatures and experiences, there could never be anything ordinary about a hedgehog. The way it looks, the way it looks back at you, surely the way it feels — astonishing. Lola Haskins’s endearing poem from “Asylum: Improvisations on John Clare” is possibly as straightforward as a poem could be: We’re on a walk with her, then stumble upon an unexpected rustle. What makes this poem sing is the quick instant that the hedgehog image widens to contain us all — our curiosity, our fear, whatever we’re each keeping contained. In that “rush” of empathy is our unexpected lift. Selected by Naomi Shihab Nye

headline: If You See Someone Not Wearing a Mask, Do You Say Something?
abstract: I considered whether to put on a mask at the party and, as a doctor, did so. People glanced at me hesitantly, noticing. I felt awkward.
lead_paragraph: “We’re supposed to be wearing masks,” the host said as I entered a birthday party in Pennsylvania recently. He rolled his eyes and waved his hand in the air, as if to say, “Whatever. We know we should wear them, but we know we’re all OK.”

headline: Buying Wedding Insurance During the Pandemic
abstract: Some insurance carriers have made changes to their coverage since the coronavirus outbreak began.
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus pandemic foiled many couple’s wedding plans this year, but at the same time, it has helped raised awareness of wedding insurance.

headline: I Watched Months of Bolsonaro’s Broadcasts. It Was Wild.
abstract: After watching the president for so many days, I finally understood that happiness is a matter of choice.
lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — On Aug. 29, my country crossed the threshold of 120,000 people killed by Covid-19. With around 900 new deaths a day, we’re yet to see a downward trend in the outbreak. I wanted to understand why many Brazilians seem unperturbed by this, so I decided to take a desperate measure: I started watching President Jair Bolsonaro’s weekly live broadcasts on YouTube and Facebook.

headline: What’s Your Favorite H.B.C.U. Homecoming Memory?
keywords: ['Historically Black Colleges and Universities', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)']
abstract: Did you attend a historically Black college or university? Or are you a current H.B.C.U. student? If so, we want to hear about your most memorable homecoming experience.
lead_paragraph: For students and graduates of historically Black colleges and universities, homecoming is more than just a football game. It’s an expression of pride, culture, food, music and fashion that attracts tens of thousands of students, graduates, celebrities, supporters and fans each year.

headline: I Used to Go Out. Now I Go to The Home Depot.
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Home Repairs and Improvements', 'Gardens and Gardening', 'Flowers and Plants', 'Lawns']
abstract: How the coronavirus turned me into a Lawn Dad.
lead_paragraph: I’ve spent the spring and summer becoming a verified Lawn Dad: the sort of person who fills their time fine-tuning sprinkler patterns and surveying their handiwork each morning with a cup of coffee in hand. I spent a May afternoon hacking away an ancient juniper, an entire day pruning an unruly lilac. Piles of bark were spread. A patio was redone. An entire deck was sanded and re-stained.

headline: Sam Hunt’s Latest Country Hit: A 1950s Honky-Tonk Classic + a Hip-Hop Beat
abstract: The Nashville boundary-pusher and five all-star collaborators built “Hard to Forget” around a sample of Webb Pierce’s “There Stands the Glass.” See how they made it sound modern in the latest Diary of a Song.
lead_paragraph: Webb Pierce, Hank Williams, Buck Owens, Garth Brooks … Kanye West?

headline: That Person Floating Over the East River Is Riding a $12,000 Water Toy
abstract: A cross between a surfboard and a Jet Ski, the eFoil can go as fast as 25 miles per hour — but only for 90 minutes at a time.
lead_paragraph: Two years ago, Brian Sheehy saw something crazy on the internet: Videos of people who looked like they were flying over water on futuristic contraptions called eFoils.

headline: A Court Just Slammed the Guantánamo Gate Shut
abstract: Does the public care about the 40 remaining inmates with no obvious end to their imprisonment?
lead_paragraph: It’s more than 12 years since the Supreme Court cracked open the prison gates at Guantánamo Bay, ruling that the prisoners held there, the living embodiments of the post-9/11 war on terror, had the constitutional right to petition the federal courts for release.

headline: Is Staying Home Harming Your Child’s Immune System?
keywords: ['Coronavirus Risks and Safety Concerns', 'Immune System', 'Respiratory Diseases', 'Child Care', 'Children and Childhood', 'Parenting', 'Respiratory Syncytial Virus (RSV)', 'Cytomegalovirus']
abstract: Why exposure to other germy kids might matter.
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus pandemic has come with a few silver linings. The clear winner for me has been the delightful dearth of snot: My kids haven’t had a cold since March, and neither have I, and I haven’t missed those crusty red noses one little bit.

headline: Musicians on How to Bring Racial Equity to Auditions
keywords: ['Classical Music', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Hiring and Promotion', 'Careers and Professions', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Minorities']
abstract: Conductors, players and administrators don’t necessarily want to abandon blind auditions. But they say the lack of diversity in American orchestras is more complicated than that.
lead_paragraph: Anthony Tommasini, The New York Times’s chief classical music critic, recently wrote an essay arguing that blind auditions — long seen as an equalizer in American orchestras — were no longer tenable. The screen had been transformative for gender representation, he said, but not for racial diversity.

headline: A Deep U.S. Open Run Becomes a Pitch For College Tennis
abstract: For years, college tennis was seen as a dead end for aspiring pros. Jennifer Brady, a semifinalist at the U.S. Open, is the latest player to show it does not have to be.
lead_paragraph: The most stunning thing about Jennifer Brady’s stunning run to the semifinals of the United States Open is that it included a stop in college, at the University of California, Los Angeles.

headline: On the Packing List This Year: Masks, Sanitizer and a Very Good Boy
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Road Trips', 'Dogs', 'Pets', 'Summer (Season)', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: Neither house sitters nor jetting off for the weekend are possibilities for most dog owners who want to travel right now. So these furry friends are increasingly curled up in the back (or front) seat, enjoying the ride.
lead_paragraph: In mid-March, three days after canceling their April wedding in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, because of the pandemic, Dana Bakich and Daniel Snyder consoled themselves by bringing home a new puppy: a curly-haired, black-and-white Labradoodle chosen for his sweet disposition and little-to-no likelihood of shedding. Three months later, with the pandemic raging on and hoping to live closer to their families, the couple packed up their home in Los Angeles and drove eastward toward the Atlanta suburbs with Malo — named for the French port city of Saint-Malo, where his “parents” got engaged — in tow.

headline: In Encounters With Black Leaders, Trump Has Chosen Photo Ops Over Substance
keywords: ['Black People', 'Blacks', 'Discrimination', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The president claims he is a champion of Black Americans. But those who have tried to work with him tell a different story.
lead_paragraph: On Martin Luther King’s Birthday in January 2017, Donald J. Trump, then the president-elect, welcomed a group of civil rights leaders, led by Dr. King’s eldest son, into his office in Trump Tower.

headline: In a Year Like No Other, a ‘Historic Crisis’ of Need
abstract: When Times readers heard the call of The Neediest Cases Fund’s annual campaign, they gave. And when a pandemic took hold, they gave again.
lead_paragraph: Ms. Gonzalez Gil was among those profiled in the 108th annual campaign of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, which ran from October to January. Since Ms. Gonzalez Gil was featured in The Times, she has enrolled in the College of Mount Saint Vincent in the Bronx and is on track to study nursing with a full scholarship.

headline: Automated Judging Changed the U.S. Open. Except at a Crucial Moment.
abstract: A new system meant no line judges on all but two courts, including the one where Novak Djokovic was playing when he hit a judge with a ball.
lead_paragraph: An experiment in automation that could change tennis has been well received at this year’s United States Open, but it might have been a bigger hit if Novak Djokovic had lost his cool on a court that was included in the trial run.

headline: What Will N.F.L. Games Sound Like?
abstract: N.F.L. teams have spent years trying to create over-the-top entertainment for fans inside stadiums. This year, they’ll just be trying to cover up echoes from empty seats.
lead_paragraph: N.F.L. games have become high-tech circuses. Players run through flames as they enter the field, pyrotechnics are blasted after touchdowns and heart-pounding music shakes the rafters, all in an effort to get the home crowd to be as loud as possible.

headline: Will Trump Win Pennsylvania Again?
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Rural Areas']
abstract: Rural counties voted for him in a landslide in 2016. Will this time be different?
lead_paragraph: Rick Ainey lives on the northern tier of Pennsylvania, near the New York border in a region known as the Endless Mountains. The area is scenic, deeply rural and so reliably Republican that the last time it has given a majority of its votes to a Democratic presidential candidate was in 1964, when Lyndon Johnson crushed Barry Goldwater just about everywhere. The time before that was 1852, when the two major parties were the Democrats and the Whigs.

headline: ‘They Call Me a Criminal’: Nursing Home Workers Who May Spread the Virus
abstract: As states struggle to keep the coronavirus out of nursing homes, employees who work at multiple facilities are thought to be behind some of the continuing spread.
lead_paragraph: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla. — In late May, Jean-Junior Vertu and Marie Julceus, two employees at a long-term care facility near West Palm Beach, Fla., took a routine test for the coronavirus and then went about their workday. They felt fine. Mr. Vertu, a dietary aide, pureed food for the residents while listening to Haitian dance music. Ms. Julceus, a nurse, helped them eat.

headline: London Offices Aren’t Refilling Fast Enough for Shops Relying on Them
keywords: ['Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Small Business', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Quarantines', 'Telecommuting']
abstract: The British government and business lobby want workers to return to support surrounding businesses, but some city offices are only 15 percent full.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Schroders, a big asset management firm, wants more of its workers to return to its office in the City of London. Over the summer, it encouraged people to come in for a day to test their commute and so the firm could demonstrate the new safety measures in place, including an app to order food from the canteen.

headline: A Photographer Works to the Sound of Falling Trees
abstract: Fire tore through Big Basin Redwoods State Park. I went to see what it left behind.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: How to Save Restaurants
keywords: ['Restaurants', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations', 'Tips and Tipping']
abstract: Rebuilding the restaurant business requires a new model for its labor.
lead_paragraph: When the pandemic hit America’s restaurants, it was as if an anvil dropped — on a bubble.

headline: A Freshly Killed Chicken Is Mightier Than the Coronavirus
keywords: ['Wildlife Trade and Poaching', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'SARS (Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome)', 'Restaurants', 'Chickens', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Rabies', 'Hygiene and Cleanliness', 'Avian Influenza', 'Epidemics', 'Plague', 'Food', 'Tables', 'Smallpox', 'Chopsticks', 'Bubonic Plague', 'Influenza']
abstract: How Hong Kong’s food culture has adapted to epidemic after epidemic, fending off disease while saving its favorite dishes, and its soul.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The other day, craving a bowl of fish ball noodle soup, I went to eat lunch at On Lee, a famous 54-year-old hole-in-the-wall on Hong Kong Island. I hadn’t been there since the start of the pandemic.

headline: After Backlash, Homeless Men Will Move Out of the Upper West Side
abstract: Some residents complained that the new neighbors were diminishing the quality of life in the area. Others felt that characterization was unfair.
lead_paragraph: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]

headline: Coronavirus Can Be Deadly for Young Adults, Too, Study Finds
abstract: India set another record for new infections, adding more than 96,000. The Senate did not approve a Republican proposal for more virus aid.
lead_paragraph: [Follow our live Covid-19 updates around the globe.]

headline: Mothers for QAnon
keywords: ['QAnon', 'Conspiracy Theories', 'Fringe Groups and Movements', 'Right-Wing Extremism and Alt-Right', 'Women and Girls', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Sex Crimes', 'Social Media', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: In the testosterone-filled world of Trump-adjacent online conspiracy, the newest theory stands out. Why are so many women falling for Q?
lead_paragraph: On Aug. 22, I attended a “Freedom for the Children” rally in London, one of hundreds around the world organized by believers in the complicated conspiracy theory known as QAnon. Looking around, it was impossible not to notice a fact that at first glance surprised me: The rally was composed mostly of women, many with young children.

headline: The Killing of Breonna Taylor, Part 2
keywords: ['Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: What thousands of pages of documents tell us about the night the 26-year-old was killed and whether the officers involved will ever be charged.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher

headline: These Changes Are Needed Amid Worsening Wildfires, Experts Say
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Environment', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Wildfires', 'Land Use Policies', 'Building (Construction)', 'Forests and Forestry']
abstract: The blazes scorching the West highlight the urgency of rethinking fire management policies, as climate change threatens to make things worse.
lead_paragraph: Wildfires are ravaging the West — in California alone, five of the largest blazes on record have all struck in just the past four years — offering a deadly reminder that the nation is far behind in adopting policies widely known to protect lives and property, even though worsening fires have become a predictable consequence of climate change.

headline: Business owners fret that jobless benefits deter workers, but studies show otherwise.
abstract: The $600-a-week jobless benefit supplement that Congress approved in March as part of the CARES Act has been widely credited by economists with keeping the economy functioning through the coronavirus pandemic.
lead_paragraph: The $600-a-week jobless benefit supplement that Congress approved in March as part of the CARES Act has been widely credited by economists with keeping the economy functioning through the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: London’s offices are largely empty, like the tills in nearby shops.
abstract: Britain’s sparsely populated offices have put the economy in a quandary. The dry cleaners, coffee shops, lunch places and clothing retailers specializing in suits that serve areas packed with offices are starved of their customers.
lead_paragraph: Britain’s sparsely populated offices have put the economy in a quandary. The dry cleaners, coffee shops, lunch places and clothing retailers specializing in suits that serve areas packed with offices are starved of their customers.

headline: Safety Review Underway of AstraZeneca’s Vaccine Trial
abstract: A participant in the company’s late-stage coronavirus vaccine trial reportedly developed severe neurological symptoms. Now experts must assess whether the vaccine was responsible.
lead_paragraph: Scientists on Wednesday praised the decision by AstraZeneca to suspend its late-stage coronavirus vaccine trials and begin a safety review after learning that a participant had developed a serious neurological condition. Dr. Francis Collins, the director of the National Institutes of Health, testifying at a Senate hearing on Wednesday, said the step “ought to be reassuring.”

headline: A Director Turns an Immigrant Into a Modern-Day Jesus
keywords: ['Movies', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Bible', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Foreign Workers', 'Venice International Film Festival']
abstract: Milo Rau has retold the Passion of Christ through the story of migrant workers in Italy fighting for rights and citizenship.
lead_paragraph: VENICE — In his celebrated 2018 manifesto on how theaters should be run, the Swiss theater director Milo Rau wrote that a stage work isn’t about the final product: What counts is the “production process.”

headline: The West, Ablaze
abstract: And what else you need to know today.
lead_paragraph: In Oregon, wildfires have incinerated several communities this week, and thousands of people have evacuated their homes. In Washington State, a fire hit the town of Malden so quickly that deputies drove through the streets screaming for residents to leave. In Colorado, a 100,000-acre blaze was slowed only by a rare September snowstorm.

headline: What Milton Friedman Missed About Social Inequality
abstract: Since the economist wrote his influential essay on capitalism, the “haves” have gained much — and everyone else has missed out.
lead_paragraph: Fifty years ago, the economist Milton Friedman warned in his seminal essay, “The Social Responsibility of Business Is to Increase Its Profits,” that corporate executives would undermine the “basis of a free society” if they acted as if “business has a ‘social conscience’ and takes seriously its responsibilities for providing employment, eliminating discrimination, avoiding pollution and whatever else may be the watchwords of the contemporary crop of reformers.”

headline: ‘Red, White & Wasted’ Review: Dirty Driving
keywords: ['Documentary Films and Programs', 'Trucks and Trucking', 'Sports Utility Vehicles and Light Trucks', 'Whites', 'Alcohol Abuse', 'Fringe Groups and Movements']
abstract: A beloved swampland subculture is under threat in this raucous yet melancholy documentary.
lead_paragraph: Like a nature documentary ogling the strange habits of an endangered species, “Red, White & Wasted” takes us to Orlando, Fla., where the revered pastime known as mudding is in danger of becoming extinct.

headline: ‘Sibyl’ Review: Diagnosing Problems, and Creating More
abstract: A troubled psychotherapist becomes unhealthily embroiled in a patient’s life in this unhinged melodrama.
lead_paragraph: Whether psychological drama or sexual farce — and, really, there’s no way to tell — “Sibyl” is a soapy mess. That goes double for its title character, an alcoholic therapist whose license should probably be revoked, and for at least two other addled souls in this bonkers brew of memory and erotic obsession.

headline: ‘Unpregnant’ Review: Friendship Is a Long and Winding Road
abstract: Former besties reunite for a road trip in this teen buddy comedy, which is the second movie this year to feature young women crossing state lines to obtain an abortion.
lead_paragraph: “Unpregnant” is the second film this year, after “Never Rarely Sometimes Always,” to feature a pair of teenage women crossing state lines to obtain an abortion. In both movies, as in real life, the characters’ home states mandate parental consent for minors. But in contrast to that earlier, quietly distressing story, “Unpregnant” takes this real-world issue as the premise for an energetic buddy comedy.

headline: ‘Rent-A-Pal’ Review: You Don’t Want to Borrow This VHS Tape
abstract: Set in the 1990s, this thriller features Wil Wheaton — on a videotape — as a bearded, sweater-vest wearing “friend” to a lonely man.
lead_paragraph: This thriller, the debut feature from Jon Stevenson — who not only wrote, produced and directed it, but was also the editor — does a lot of things well. Or almost well. But finally, not well enough.

headline: ‘Our Time Machine’ Review: A Picture of the Past
abstract: In this documentary, the Chinese artist Maleonn enlists his aging parents, both artists themselves, in an ambitious memory play.
lead_paragraph: The Chinese artist who goes by the name Maleonn (his work encompasses puppetry, theater, photography, machine engineering and more) is himself the product of a rich artistic heritage. His mother, Zheng Wei Tong, was an actor, and his father, Ma Ke, directed both the Beijing Opera and the Shanghai Opera.

headline: ‘Jimmy Carter Rock & Roll President’ Review: A Musically Enlightened Commander in Chief
keywords: ['Documentary Films and Programs', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Bob Dylan, Rosanne Cash, Willie Nelson, Garth Brooks and more celebrate the 39th U.S. president in this documentary.
lead_paragraph: Of all the cases you could make on behalf of the 39th American president, Jimmy Carter, the one put forward by this film’s title — “Jimmy Carter Rock & Roll President” — is not necessarily the first that springs to mind, unless you’re of a certain age and have a strong memory. But the filmmaker Mary Wharton (with a script from veteran music writer Bill Flanagan) makes good on her hook in this engaging documentary.

headline: ‘Suspension’ Review: Roads to Nowhere
abstract: This documentary looks at a stretch of road in Colombia known as “the springboard of death.”
lead_paragraph: “Suspension” tells a tale of two roads. The first connects the town of San Francisco and the city of Mocoa in Putumayo, Colombia, locations that as the bird flies are less than 20 miles apart. But the route itself, encompassing a stretch called “El Trampolín de la Muerte” (“the springboard of death”), has a reputation as one of the world’s most dangerous, as a single, unpaved lane snakes through the Andean-Amazon piedmont. Even the most careful drivers can be crushed by falling rocks.

headline: ‘Space Dogs’ Review: No Dogs Go to Heaven
abstract: This documentary uses the lives and legends of Moscow’s street dogs to present a brutal vision of humanity and nature.
lead_paragraph: The otherworldly documentary “Space Dogs” begins fittingly with a story of oblivion. A narrator recounts the pioneering flight of Laika, the Muscovite street dog who orbited the Earth when the Soviets launched her into space in 1957. The camera seems to recreate her journey, floating around glowing blue. But this peacefulness derails as the narrator details Laika’s cruel demise and the image begins to distort, as if the camera were making a forced re-entry.

headline: The Woodward Revelations
abstract: In March, Trump admitted he was downplaying the coronavirus: This is your morning tip sheet.
lead_paragraph: Woodward’s revelations prompt an admission from Trump: “I’m a cheerleader.” It’s Thursday, and this is your politics tip sheet. Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.

headline: New Fire Erupts in Beirut Port, Just Weeks After Devastating Blast
abstract: Orange flames and a plume of black smoke rose over the city, terrifying residents still recovering from last month’s explosion.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT — A large fire erupted in Beirut’s port on Thursday, sending up orange flames and a huge plume of black smoke that terrified residents still recovering from the horrific port explosion that devastated entire neighborhoods last month.

headline: The Case of the LVMH Letter
abstract: Can a French government intervention excuse the luxury conglomerate from its $16.2 billion deal with Tiffany? It depends on what counts as an order.
lead_paragraph: We are holding a DealBook Debrief call today as part of The Times’s special project for the 50th anniversary of a seminal Milton Friedman essay that changed the course of capitalism. R.S.V.P. here for the call at 11 a.m. Eastern and see below for more details about our special guests.

headline: In Berlin Theaters, the Curtain Rises on a ‘Corona Season’
abstract: Some of the city’s major playhouses are presenting pandemic-delayed premieres in sparsely populated auditoriums, with much of the seating removed.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — People in Berlin know the drill by now: Wear masks, wash hands, give details for contact tracing and keep a distance from other audience members.

headline: The president is holding frequent rallies again, though the virus has caused snags.
abstract: With hyperbole and falsehoods, the president has increased stops at airports that resemble campaign rallies, his favorite type of politicking. But Nevada said the events violated health restrictions and canceled two rallies there.
lead_paragraph: With cheering crowds, inflated claims, and inflammatory partisan rhetoric, President Trump has resumed the mode of politicking he enjoys most: entertaining his supporters at campaign-style rallies.

headline: Trump’s Supreme Court list comes as he seeks a political boost.
abstract: The president, who views his commitment to a conservative federal judiciary as critical to his 2016 victory, added 20 more names to earlier lists.
lead_paragraph: President Trump, who counts his two Supreme Court appointments as among his greatest successes, issued a new list on Wednesday of 20 potential nominees to the court, reviving an issue he believes was a key to his victory four years ago as he faces a difficult re-election fight.

headline: Many ask if Woodward should have revealed Trump’s comments sooner, and Trump weighs in.
abstract: Should Bob Woodward have withheld until now a February quotation from President Trump, who privately told him the coronavirus was “deadly stuff” even as he publicly minimized its severity? Could Mr. Woodward have helped save lives by releasing the information sooner?
lead_paragraph: Should Bob Woodward have withheld until now a February quotation from President Trump, who privately told him the coronavirus was “deadly stuff” even as he publicly minimized its severity? Could Mr. Woodward have helped save lives by releasing the information sooner?

headline: Biden says his rival ‘failed to do his job on purpose’ as the virus ravaged the country.
abstract: Before sketching out a plan to keep more jobs in the United States, the former vice president denounced his rival over revelations in a new book that the president knowingly minimized the coronavirus’s dangers.
lead_paragraph: WARREN, Mich. — Joseph R. Biden Jr. tore into President Trump on Wednesday over new revelations from a forthcoming book by the journalist Bob Woodward that the president knowingly minimized the risks of the coronavirus, arguing that Mr. Trump had lied to the American public and put lives in danger.

headline: Pelosi and Schumer advise Americans to vote early, warning of possible election interference.
abstract: Democratic congressional leaders sent a letter to colleagues on Wednesday pleading with them to urge their constituents to vote as early as possible, citing concerns that President Trump, with the help of Postmaster General Louis DeJoy, is working to kneecap the Postal Service to ensure his own re-election.
lead_paragraph: Democratic congressional leaders sent a letter to colleagues on Wednesday pleading with them to urge their constituents to vote as early as possible, citing concerns that President Trump, with the help of Postmaster General Louis DeJoy, is working to kneecap the Postal Service to ensure his own re-election.

headline: Trump will head to Michigan amid multiple controversies.
abstract: The forecast for President Trump’s scheduled campaign stop today in Freeland, Mich., is cloudy, appropriately enough.
lead_paragraph: The forecast for President Trump’s scheduled campaign stop today in Freeland, Mich., is cloudy, appropriately enough.

headline: Even Big Pharma Is Turning on Trump
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The president is the coronavirus vaccine’s worst hype man.
lead_paragraph: President Trump has become so shameless about subverting the public interest to his political self-interest that Big Pharma — not generally regarded as the most civic-minded of entities — is now scrambling to control the damage.

headline: Even With 190,000 Dead, There’s a Lot That Voters Don’t Know
abstract: People often engage in “projection,” assuming a preferred candidate shares their view, even on a key issue like masks during a pandemic.
lead_paragraph: President Trump mocked Joe Biden for his mask wearing at a campaign rally last week, saying, “Did you ever see a man who likes a mask as much as him?”

headline: For Survivors at Charlie Hebdo Trial, Wounds Are Still Raw
abstract: Victims of the 2015 attack on the satirical weekly took the stand this week with vivid accounts of how their colleagues were killed — and how their own lives were suddenly overturned.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — One by one, the witnesses told a hushed court how their lives were brutally upended on a cold January morning in 2015, when two brothers wielding assault rifles burst onto a quiet Parisian street looking for the newsroom of Charlie Hebdo, the satirical weekly.

headline: Tucker Carlson blames Trump’s 18 interviews with Bob Woodward on Lindsey Graham.
abstract: Tucker Carlson on Fox News, one of President Trump’s most devoted defenders, is pointing a finger at another Trump wingman — Senator Lindsey Graham of South Carolina — for selling the president on a sit-down with Bob Woodward for his new book.
lead_paragraph: Tucker Carlson on Fox News, one of President Trump’s most devoted defenders, is pointing a finger at another Trump wingman — Senator Lindsey Graham of South Carolina — for selling the president on a sit-down with Bob Woodward for his new book.

headline: Citigroup’s Fraser to Be First Woman to Lead a Big Wall Street Bank
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Jane Fraser, Citigroup’s president, will replace Michael Corbat as chief executive in February as he retires after eight years.
lead_paragraph: Booms and busts and scams and panics have changed Wall Street in many ways over the decades, but one thing has stubbornly remained the same: The top jobs have always gone to men. Now, that last citadel is about to fall.

headline: How Do I Tell My Friend to Stop Paying for His Son’s Lifestyle?
abstract: A reader wants his golfing buddy to stop complaining about his over-age dependent.
lead_paragraph: My friend’s son is a deadbeat. He’s 35, still lives at home, has never kept a job for longer than a year, buys things he can’t afford, and now his pregnant girlfriend is moving in. He has a million excuses for everything that goes wrong. It’s never his fault! The problem: My friend and I play golf three times a week, and I can’t tolerate listening to him complain about his son anymore. How do I tell him to wise up and stop supporting him? I don’t want to hurt my friend, but he needs to hear the truth.

headline: ‘Coastal Elites’ Review: Confined Confessions
abstract: This collection of monologues written by Paul Rudnick initially for the stage, has been adapted for the screen.
lead_paragraph: Legend has it that shortly after Shakespeare premiered “Macbeth,” London’s theaters were shuttered by plague. Four centuries later, the playwright and screenwriter Paul Rudnick’s “Coastal Elites,” arriving on HBO Sept. 12, has embraced the soliloquy as the defining art form of the era of social distance, where we poor players strut and fret our hours on the webcam.

headline: ‘Black Boys’ Review: Young Lives in the Balance
keywords: ['Documentary Films and Programs', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Men and Boys']
abstract: This documentary addresses the dehumanization of Black boys by attempting the reverse: reconstructing them to show they are worth the care they are denied.
lead_paragraph: When does the eye of the documentarian obscure the sight? The Peacock film “Black Boys” examines the beauty of Black boys but suffers from a failure to police its own gaze.

headline: Cleaners Demand Harassment Safeguards From the Booking Service Handy
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Sexual Harassment', 'Domestic Service', 'Freelancing, Self-Employment and Independent Contracting', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations']
abstract: Workers for a home services company say they face sexual harassment and unfair fees. A civil rights group is asking California regulators to step in.
lead_paragraph: BERKELEY, Calif. — It was supposed to be just another routine job for Patti Cris, who in early 2018 was a contract worker for the home services booking site Handy. She got the key for the San Jose apartment she was scheduled to clean while its occupant was gone, and remembers knocking twice and announcing herself, just to make sure.

keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Mortgages', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']

lead_paragraph: The coronavirus pandemic has thrown yearly buying and selling patterns out of whack, with a big reduction in inventory and an increase in asking prices in many of the country’s biggest markets.

headline: What to Know About the Wildfires
abstract: Thursday: Taking a step back to answer questions.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: ‘Buoyancy’ Review: Enduring Horrors on the Sea, and Struggling to Survive
abstract: In this sobering, moving drama, a Cambodian teenager runs away from home and is sold into slavery on a Thai fishing boat.
lead_paragraph: The hollow-eyed man on the fishing boat calls the water “the sea of the dead.” It’s an apt name for this stretch of blue more properly known as the Gulf of Thailand. The water is usually calm in “Buoyancy,” save for the thrash of fish and the churn of the engine. There’s far more turbulence onboard, where the hollow-eyed man and a handful of others rise before the sun and work into the night, though work is too dignified a word to describe this hell.

headline: 10 Dead in California as Wildfires Spread on West Coast
abstract: More than three million acres have burned in California, and officials said one of the most damaging fires in Oregon may have been deliberately set.
lead_paragraph: [Follow our live Oregon, California and Washington fires updates.]

abstract: “I like reading in graveyards leaning against old gravestones, though I haven’t had many opportunities of late.”
