headline: Violent Protests Erupt in Colombia After a Man Dies in Police Custody
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: A video showed officers pinning down Javier Ordóñez and shocking him with a stun gun as he begged them to stop.
lead_paragraph: The video circulating on social media showed a man pinned to the ground by Colombian police officers, who shocked him repeatedly with a stun gun for more than two minutes. “Please, no more,” he begged.

headline: Studio Museum in Harlem Names Artists in Residence
abstract: The museum adds a midcareer component to a program known for anointing new talent.
lead_paragraph: The artist-in-residence program at the Studio Museum in Harlem is an institution — an early-career incubator whose alumni list, in annual cohorts of three, reads like a canon of a half-century of Black American art.

headline: With ‘We Are Who We Are,’ Luca Guadagnino Wants You to Question Yourself
abstract: The “Call Me By Your Name” director’s new HBO series follows teens who are exploring their gender and sexual identity. Its shoot was just as unconventional.
lead_paragraph: “What does it mean to be a provocateur?” Luca Guadagnino asked over Zoom. “We should talk about that for a moment.”

headline: A poll finds most Americans are worried the Trump administration will rush a virus vaccine.
abstract: A clear majority of American adults worry that political pressure from the Trump administration will lead the Food and Drug Administration to rush through a coronavirus vaccine without making sure it is safe and effective, according to a poll released Thursday by the Kaiser Family Foundation.
lead_paragraph: A clear majority of American adults worry that political pressure from the Trump administration will lead the Food and Drug Administration to rush through a coronavirus vaccine without making sure it is safe and effective, according to a poll released Thursday by the Kaiser Family Foundation.

headline: What We Know About the Death of Rayshard Brooks
keywords: ['George Floyd Protests (2020)', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: Killed by an Atlanta police officer just weeks after George Floyd’s death touched off nationwide protests, Mr. Brooks became a potent symbol.
lead_paragraph: Less than three weeks after George Floyd’s death in police custody, fuel was added to the nationwide protests against police brutality when an Atlanta officer fatally shot Rayshard Brooks on June 12 in the parking lot of a Wendy’s restaurant.

headline: The T List: Five Things We Recommend This Week
abstract: Walter Price paintings, three-legged chairs — and more.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the T List, a newsletter from the editors of T Magazine. Each week, we’re sharing things we’re eating, wearing, listening to or coveting now. Sign up here to find us in your inbox every Wednesday. You can always reach us at tlist@nytimes.com.

headline: Record Wildfires Ravage Three States
abstract: Wildfires in California, Oregon and Washington State have killed at least seven people, and there are growing fears more have died in towns that have been destroyed.
lead_paragraph: Wildfires in California, Oregon and Washington State have killed at least seven people, and there are growing fears more have died in towns that have been destroyed.

headline: Diana Rigg, Stylish Emma Peel of ‘The Avengers,’ Dies at 82
abstract: Ms. Rigg also played many classic roles onstage in both New York and London and, late in her career, found new fans on “Game of Thrones.”
lead_paragraph: Diana Rigg, the British actress who enthralled London and New York theater audiences with her performances in classic roles for more than a half-century but remained best known as the quintessential new woman of the 1960s — sexy, confident, witty and karate-adept — on the television series “The Avengers,” died on Thursday at her home in London. She was 82.

headline: ‘I Am Woman’ Review: Singing Against Sexism
abstract: Unjoo Moon’s film is a superficial hustle through the career of Helen Reddy and the recording of her most famous song.
lead_paragraph: “I Am Woman,” a pleasant, yet disappointingly trite biopic of the singer Helen Reddy, has a flatness that’s difficult to ascribe to any one element. As Reddy, Tilda Cobham-Hervey has warmth and gumption; the 1960s-80s production design is impeccable; and the cinematography, by the celebrated Dion Beebe (the partner of the director, Unjoo Moon), is richly textured.

headline: American Ballet Theater Promotes Dancers Despite Pandemic Slump
abstract: The six new principal dancers include Calvin Royal III, who is just the third Black dancer to be elevated to that role.
lead_paragraph: American Ballet Theater on Thursday announced promotions for six soloists, elevating them to the role of principal dancer despite an empty live performance schedule for the fall and a difficult financial situation because of the pandemic.

headline: What We Know About the Shooting of Jacob Blake
keywords: ['George Floyd Protests (2020)', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Civil Rights and Liberties']
abstract: The police shooting of Mr. Blake ignited protests in Kenosha, Wis., including one in which the authorities said a teenager fatally shot two demonstrators.
lead_paragraph: Jacob Blake, a 29-year-old Black man, was left partly paralyzed after a white police officer shot him seven times in the back outside an apartment complex in Kenosha, Wis., on Aug. 23.

headline: The Braves Scored 29 Runs. Their Player of the Game? Everyone.
abstract: The Braves’ run total against the Marlins was a National League record, and all 10 men they sent to the plate got at least one hit.
lead_paragraph: There was an expectation that this most unusual baseball season would produce some most unusual results. How about this one? Braves 29, Marlins 9.

headline: Pandemic Collides With Europe’s Migrant Crisis to Set Off a Calamity in Greece
keywords: ['Fires and Firefighters', 'ARSON', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Politics and Government', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Asylum, Right of', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Quarantines']
abstract: Frustrated asylum seekers lit fires this week in protest over lockdowns that worsened cramped and squalid conditions on Lesbos. Now 12,000 migrants are homeless.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — The thousands of asylum seekers crammed into Europe’s largest refugee camp, on the Greek island of Lesbos, had for years bridled at their squalid conditions and the endless delays in resolving their fates. Then came the coronavirus and its strict containment measures, which compounded their misery.

headline: The Native Artists Showing Us What’s Happening in Indigenous America
abstract: We spoke with Wendy Red Star about what it was like to curate, edit and feature a wide range of Native artists for the Fall issue of Aperture.
lead_paragraph: Wendy Red Star is a visual artist who grew up on the Apsáalooke (Crow) reservation in Montana and now lives in Portland, Ore. She recently was asked to guest edit the Fall issue of Aperture, a quarterly magazine, which focuses on Indigenous lives through photography.

headline: A Chef’s Childhood in Iran Shaped His Cooking in the Pandemic
keywords: ['Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Flowers and Plants', 'Cooking and Cookbooks']
abstract: In times of crisis, the California chef Hanif Sadr learned to forage and preserve food, and use it to heal.
lead_paragraph: A FOREST IN THE BAY AREA, CALIF. — Moments after walking into a verdant forest in San Francisco’s East Bay, the chef Hanif Sadr nibbled on the vegetation he found there — canary yellow mustard flowers, then spicy wild radish flowers, streaked with white and purple. He tasted potently cool chocolate mint, and sniffed leaves from an intensely aromatic California bay laurel.

headline: A Black Venture Capitalist Sees Challenges as an Investing Edge
keywords: ['Venture Capital', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Discrimination', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Entrepreneurship', 'Start-ups']
abstract: “Black Founders Matter” started out as a T-shirt design. Now, a once-jilted start-up founder is trying to turn it into a moneymaking strategy.
lead_paragraph: Marceau Michel’s idea for a new on-demand staffing company, Werkhorse, was good enough to win a start-up pitch competition and a coveted spot in a tech incubator in Portland, Ore., two years ago. But no matter what he did, Mr. Michel could not seem to land the funding he needed.

headline: Dress code for tonight’s Michigan rally: the only acceptable campaign gear is Trump’s.
abstract: Trump supporters heading to the president’s rally in Freeland, Mich., Thursday night were given some unusual notes on how to prepare.
lead_paragraph: Trump supporters heading to the president’s rally in Freeland, Mich., Thursday night were given some unusual notes on how to prepare.

headline: After 43 Years, the Wine Sentinel of the River Café Stands Down
abstract: Joseph DeLissio, “a blue-collar kid in a white-collar job,” saw the rise of American wine culture and put together an ever-changing, world-class list.
lead_paragraph: Joseph DeLissio never felt called to become a master sommelier. He didn’t post Instagram photos of himself posing with cult wines. He didn’t try to make his own wine, start an import company or initiate a podcast, all standard activities for 21st-century sommeliers.

headline: The Causes of Estrangement, and How Families Heal
keywords: ['Content Type: Service', 'Families and Family Life', 'Children and Childhood', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Parenting']
abstract: For those who reconcile with estranged relatives, the key is “letting go of the attempt to have the other person see the past as they saw it,” the author of a new book says.
lead_paragraph: A 21-year-old college student who hasn’t spoken to her mother since high school.

headline: Mom Shaming Is Running Rampant During the Pandemic
abstract: With myriad back-to-school options to choose from, moms’ groups have hit judgment overload.
lead_paragraph: “So you can’t play with us anymore,” she said. She’s not a 4-year-old schoolyard bully, but a 34-year-old women’s studies professor and my new mom friend who lives down the street. Ours is a familiar tale: We met in the park, discussed how old our girls were and whether they sleep through the night, and exchanged phone numbers to coordinate play dates. Soon our kids were friends too, digging in the sandbox while we drank coffee in the shade. Then the coronavirus arrived.

headline: Accused of Ruining Popcorn, Cass Sunstein Wants to Repent
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Labeling and Labels (Product)']
abstract: In “Too Much Information,” President Obama’s onetime regulatory chief takes another look at whether disclosing information — including calorie counts — is always a good thing.

abstract: How is Covid-19 affecting where you live? What do you notice and wonder about these two maps?
lead_paragraph: The New York Times reports that in the United States there have been more than 6.3 million Covid-19 cases and more than 190,000 deaths.

headline: The racial justice movement is motivating young Latinos to vote, a poll finds.
abstract: Protests against racial injustice and the widespread impact of the coronavirus are helping to drive young Latinos to vote this year, according to a new national survey of Latino voters between the ages 18 and 34.
lead_paragraph: Protests against racial injustice and the widespread impact of the coronavirus are helping to drive young Latinos to vote this year, according to a new national survey of Latino voters between the ages 18 and 34.

headline: Trump’s Deliberate Coronavirus Deception
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Rumors and Misinformation', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Polls and Public Opinion']

headline: The Fire Compounding Misery at the Lesbos Camp, in Photos
abstract: Thousands were displaced by fires at Europe’s largest refugee camp on the Greek island of Lesbos this week.
lead_paragraph: The skeletal metal tent frames, their coverings and contents reduced to ash, poked out of the landscape. A twisted and blackened fan hung from what was once a ceiling. And everywhere, there were people, clinging to small bags of belongings or setting up makeshift beds on the side of the road, uncertain where to turn next.

headline: Social Media Shaming Your College
abstract: Students are using apps to shame their schools into better coronavirus plans.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.

headline: In encounters with Black leaders, Trump has chosen photo ops over substance.
abstract: The president claims he is a champion of Black Americans. But those who have tried to work with him tell a different story.
lead_paragraph: President Trump likes to make the far-fetched claim that he has done more for Black Americans than any president since Abraham Lincoln. But many Black leaders who have tried to work with him tell a different story — that he is more interested in photo ops than substantive interactions.

headline: 7 Things to Do This Weekend
keywords: ['Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Art', 'Music', 'Theater', 'Pop and Rock Music', 'Rosh Hashana', 'Opera', 'Dancing', 'Country Music', 'Classical Music', 'Children and Childhood', 'Festivals']
abstract: How can you get your cultural fix when many arts institutions remain closed? Our writers offer suggestions for what to listen to and watch, as well as see in person at a gallery.
lead_paragraph: When the playwright Krista Knight received the news that her play “Crush” would no longer be produced because of the pandemic, she imagined a version she could stage in the 500-square-foot home studio in the East Village she shares with her collaborator, Barry Brinegar.

headline: ‘Saturday Night Live’ to Return Oct. 3 With New Live Episodes
abstract: NBC said “S.N.L.” will air its first live episode since the coronavirus pandemic halted its traditional production in March.
lead_paragraph: “Saturday Night Live” is set to return this fall with its first new live episode since the coronavirus pandemic started.

headline: Trading the Ice for New York City Pavement
abstract: Under the summer sun, Ice Theater of New York finds its way back to gliding. “I go wherever my wheels take me,” one skater says.
lead_paragraph: A sheet of ice, a metal blade and speed. With each stroke of a blade, the surface melts away, leaving a canvas of etchings. At the same time, a skater experiences that treasured sensation: the ability to glide.

headline: How Three Artists Are Exploring Mythology and Race
keywords: ['Black People', 'Blacks', 'Art', 'Women and Girls', 'Myths and Mythical Creatures', 'Greek Civilization', 'Water', 'Religion and Belief']
abstract: In re-examining historical narratives and classical stories, these artists are creating images that speak on multiple levels to the experiences of being Black and female.
lead_paragraph: Whether or not you believe in a literal Garden of Eden, the biblical story in which it appears has fed opinions about the nature of gender relationships, human sin and the consequences of disobedience. “The Odyssey” has lessons about life’s journey, weathering storms, heeding warnings and returning home. Odin, the one-eyed Norse god of war and death, is a symbol of self-sacrifice for wisdom.

headline: 3 Art Gallery Shows to See Right Now
abstract: Frank Jones’s fanciful drawings; Lyles & King’s inaugural exhibition in its new space; and Serena Stevens’s haunting paintings.
lead_paragraph: Frank Jones, who was born in Clarksville, Texas, in 1900, spent much of his life in and out of that state’s prisons, possibly for crimes he did not commit, and died in one in 1969. During his last decade, Jones made around 500 drawings, usually on found paper, signed with his name and inmate number, 114591. He worked with the stubs of colored pencils discarded by the prison’s accountants. He was partial to red and blue, but also used combinations of purple, orange and green.

headline: Afghan Peace Talks Begin This Week. Here’s What to Know.
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Politics and Government', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'International Relations', 'Peace Process']
abstract: The Afghan government and the Taliban are to meet on Saturday to open negotiations about power sharing after years of relentless war. The differences on major issues are vast.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Peace talks between the Taliban and the Afghan government are expected to begin on Saturday in Doha, Qatar, officials announced on Thursday, in a historic negotiation between the two sides after nearly two decades of bitter war.

headline: Democrats are sending a truck to Trump’s Michigan rally to play audio of his coronavirus comments.
abstract: Ahead of President Trump’s rally in Michigan on Thursday night, Democrats are planning to use his own words to skewer him.
lead_paragraph: Ahead of President Trump’s rally in Michigan on Thursday night, Democrats are planning to use his own words to skewer him.

headline: For New York City Ballet, Another Digital Season
abstract: Live performances in the theater are still on hold, but the company will present an online season, culminating in five new dances.
lead_paragraph: New York City Ballet will not be returning to the David H. Koch Theater this fall, but the company’s coming digital season will culminate with performances of new dances by Pam Tanowitz, Jamar Roberts, Justin Peck, Sidra Bell and Andrea Miller. The commissioned ballets will be recorded outdoors in New York City and shared with audiences, one each night, from Oct. 27 to Oct. 31.

headline: Pulitzers to Consider Canceled Plays and Streamed Productions for 2021 Prize
keywords: ['Theater', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Pulitzer Prizes', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Videophones and Videoconferencing']
abstract: The coronavirus pandemic has prevented most in-person theater this year, so the prize board is changing the eligibility rules for its annual drama honor.
lead_paragraph: The Pulitzer Prize in drama is ordinarily given to work that is performed onstage. But this year, because of the coronavirus pandemic, that will change.

headline: Return of the King: Ninja, a Video Game Star, Goes Back to Twitch
keywords: ['Computer and Video Games', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: After months of speculation, one of the world’s most famous video gamers announced his next move.
lead_paragraph: BERKELEY, Calif. — In 2010, LeBron James made “The Decision,” leaving his hometown Cleveland Cavaliers for the Miami Heat and upending the N.B.A.

headline: When the Otters Vanished, Everything Else Started to Crumble
keywords: ['Otters (Animals)', 'ALGAE', 'Seaweed', 'Reefs', 'Fish and Other Marine Life', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Global Warming', 'Carbon Dioxide', 'Research', 'your-feed-science', 'your-feed-animals']
abstract: Against the backdrop of climate change, the delicate underwater ecology of Alaska’s Aleutian Islands is hurting from declines in otters.
lead_paragraph: In 1970, Jim Estes made his first trek up to Alaska’s Aleutian Islands. He was greeted by an ocean filled with furry faces.

headline: Killings Reignite Racial Tensions in Guyana
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: The South American country, already deeply split by a presidential election and an oil windfall, is tested again as three teenagers are slain.
lead_paragraph: COTTON TREE, Guyana — The gruesome murders of two teenagers and the apparent reprisal killing of a third have plunged Guyana into its worst racial unrest in years, coming just weeks after the nation emerged from a disputed election that had deeply divided its two dominant groups over the country’s newfound oil wealth.

headline: Ethiopian Region Holds Local Elections in Defiance of Prime Minister
abstract: The government of Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed postponed elections this year because of the coronavirus, but the restive northern region of Tigray went ahead and held a vote anyway, escalating tensions.
lead_paragraph: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia — When Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed came to power in 2018, he introduced a raft of reforms aimed at helping Ethiopia transition from an authoritarian state to an inclusive democracy, actions that helped win him the Nobel Peace Prize in 2019.

headline: In Quarantine, Kids Pick Up Parents’ Mother Tongues
abstract: For some families, the pandemic has meant a return to their native languages.
lead_paragraph: A few days into the lockdown here in London, I noticed a surprising side-effect of the pandemic: My 3-year-old son was speaking more German.

headline: When the Audience Is Stuck at Home, the Play Is in the Mail
abstract: That package in your hallway may be an exciting new theatrical experience. Or maybe not.
lead_paragraph: During the first few months of the pandemic pause, between Zoom readings and Instagram monologues, I often found myself pondering the question of genre: What’s a play and what isn’t? Usually my answer was that if it’s made by theater people and I like it, it’s a play. But if I’m watching an actor on a small screen instead of a big stage, isn’t it actually television?

headline: The Defamation Suit Against Trump
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Cyberwarfare and Defense', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']

headline: Chevy’s Little Engine That Could
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Antique and Classic Cars', 'Engines', 'Engineering and Engineers', 'Automobile Racing']
abstract: For six decades, a small-block Chevy has powered the dreams of hot-rodders and Corvettes, and plenty of other cars, even a Ford Mustang.
lead_paragraph: In the great rivalry between Chevrolet and Ford, Jason Carlisle, a former mechanic and current hobbyist racer, took sides decades ago. “Cut me: I bleed Ford blue,” he said. But when it came time to replace the engine in his Mustang racecar, he did the unthinkable. He installed a small-block Chevy engine.

headline: Historic Wildfires Rage in Western States
abstract: Photographs from California, Oregon and Washington, where hundreds of thousands were under evacuation orders.
lead_paragraph: Wildfires across the West Coast have consumed roughly five million acres of land in California and Oregon and destroyed entire towns in Washington, and they continued to spread on Thursday.

headline: Marcia Sasser, Who Smiled Through Chronic Pain, Dies at 75
abstract: Despite suffering from rheumatoid arthritis for decades, she traveled frequently and became the star of her SilverSneakers exercise class in Georgia.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: Jets and Giants Coaches Aim for Wins Using Different Approaches
abstract: Joe Judge, the Giants’ first-year coach, hopes to energize a team entering a new era, while the Jets’ Adam Gase wants to build consistency for Sam Darnold.
lead_paragraph: The Giants and the Jets have struggled with the injuries, internal dissent and, to put it plainly, winning in recent seasons.

headline: Justice Dept. Announces Dozens of Fraud Charges in Small-Business Aid Program
keywords: ['Small Business', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Federal Aid (US)', 'Stimulus (Economic)', 'Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: Fifty-seven people were charged with trying to steal more than $175 million from the Paycheck Protection Program, law enforcement officials said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department said on Thursday that it had charged 57 people with trying to steal more than $175 million from the Paycheck Protection Program to help small businesses during the coronavirus pandemic as questions swirled about how its funds were disbursed.

headline: What’s the Post Office Good For? Everything
abstract: The check (and the book, and the sandals, and everything else) is in the mail.
lead_paragraph: The check (and the book, and the sandals, and everything else) is in the mail.

headline: New York’s Reopened Museums: Where to Go and What to See
abstract: What you need to know before venturing back out to see art, from safety precautions to the exhibitions still on view.
lead_paragraph: For New Yorkers who regard their local cultural institutions as unofficial civic symbols, the museum openings that began at the end of August are a welcome sign that the city’s spirit is starting to re-emerge after months of disruption and uncertainty. Broadway theaters remain shuttered, and it’s still impossible to see a movie on the big screen or eat indoors at restaurants, but the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Museum of Modern Art are finally back.

headline: Biden Campaign Lashes Trump Over Concealing the Danger of the Virus
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Rumors and Misinformation']

headline: Netanyahu Apology to Bedouins Is Taken as an Affront
keywords: ['Bedouins', 'Bribery and Kickbacks', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Apologies', 'Nomadic People']
abstract: Critics and outraged officials accused the Israeli prime minister, on trial for corruption, of exploiting a tragic episode to discredit his own law enforcement agencies.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — It took nearly four years for the Israeli government to apologize to a Bedouin family from the Negev desert after a relative whose car had fatally run over a police officer, and who was killed by police fire, was hastily and wrongly labeled a terrorist.

headline: Brexit Talks Hit Crisis as Boris Johnson Rejects Ultimatum
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)']
abstract: Europe has demanded the quick withdrawal of draft Brexit legislation that breaks international law. Britain has refused.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Britain and the European Union were on a collision course Thursday, after Brussels demanded the speedy withdrawal of proposed Brexit legislation that the government of Prime Minister Boris Johnson has admitted would breach international law.

headline: Are Gender Reveals Cursed?
abstract: Several parties, meant to mark a milestone in the journey of pregnancy, have resulted in devastation. Is it time to temper the spectacle, or embrace the celebratory spirit?
lead_paragraph: This week, after a “smoke-generating pyrotechnic device” used at a gender-reveal party set off a devastating wildfire that scorched thousands of acres east of Los Angeles, many internet pundits decided enough was enough.

headline: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: Indonesia hospitals, election hacking, Afghan peace talks: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: Officials in the Indonesian capital will reimpose a partial shutdown on Monday as hospitals near capacity. The measures include a work-from-home requirement, a ban on large gatherings and restrictions on houses of worship.

headline: Joan Feynman, Who Shined Light on the Aurora Borealis, Dies at 93
abstract: Her mother told her that women’s brains “can’t do science.” She would prove her mother very wrong.
lead_paragraph: Joan Feynman grew up in the shadow of her older brother, the brilliant scientist and Nobel laureate Richard Feynman. When she expressed interest in following in his footsteps, her mother crushed the impulse.

headline: U.S. Imposes Sanctions on Ukrainian With Ties to Russia, Citing Election Interference
keywords: ['Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'Trump-Ukraine Whistle-blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry', 'Elections']
abstract: Andriy Derkach has released information intended to hurt former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., which President Trump has promoted.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration imposed sanctions on a Ukrainian lawmaker Thursday for waging “a covert influence campaign” to undermine the presidential election after he disseminated information intended to hurt former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

headline: Century 21, Fabled New York Bargain Destination, Is Closing
abstract: The retailer, famous for offering designer goods at discount prices, said it had failed to receive $175 million from its insurers and would close its 13 locations.
lead_paragraph: Century 21, the famous New York discount store chain, became the latest retailer felled during the pandemic, saying on Thursday that it had been forced to file for bankruptcy and would close all 13 of its locations after failing to receive money from its insurers.

headline: M.L.B. Set to Hold Postseason at Neutral Sites
abstract: The league plans to hold games at four stadiums in Southern California and Texas, with the World Series held at the Texas Rangers’ new ballpark.
lead_paragraph: Major League Baseball will play most of its postseason at neutral sites for the first time, with the World Series to be held this October at the Texas Rangers’ new ballpark in Arlington, Texas. While the league is still working out details of the plan with the players’ union, the concept and location of postseason bubbles have been decided.

headline: ‘Science Versus Politics’: School District Defies Governor’s Reopening Order
keywords: ['Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Education (K-12)', 'E-Learning', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Politics and Government', 'Disease Rates', 'Quarantines', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations', 'Teachers and School Employees']
abstract: In one of the nation’s sharpest clashes over school reopening, officials in Des Moines say Iowa’s Republican governor is pushing them to risk public safety.
lead_paragraph: No matter how much tension has surrounded the reopening of schools during the coronavirus pandemic, most state and local officials have found a way to arrive at some sort of plan by the first day of classes.

headline: Four Houston Police Officers Are Fired Over Fatal Shooting
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'George Floyd Protests (2020)']
abstract: Nicolas Chavez, 27, was killed by the police in southeast Houston in April, during a confrontation that was partly recorded by a bystander’s cellphone.
lead_paragraph: The Houston Police Department on Thursday fired four officers involved in the fatal shooting of a 27-year-old man in April and released body camera footage of the confrontation, after months of scrutiny by investigators and calls for transparency from protesters.

headline: La Niña May Worsen Southwest Drought This Winter
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Environment', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Weather', 'El Nino Southern Oscillation', 'Winter (Season)', 'Oceans and Seas']
abstract: Climate forecasters said the pattern would affect weather across the globe.
lead_paragraph: Climate forecasters said Thursday that the world had entered La Niña, the opposite phase of the climate pattern that also brings El Niño and affects weather across the globe. Among other impacts, La Niña has the potential this winter to worsen what are already severe drought conditions in the American Southwest.

headline: The Ugly Side of New York’s Outdoor Dining Renaissance
abstract: When sidewalk cafes collide with the city’s inadequate response to homelessness.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday afternoon, at the height of the lunch hour, Nick Accardi sat in one of his three Hell’s Kitchen restaurants, Tavola, on Ninth Avenue, and looked out toward the empty tables that lined the street, with a sense of grievance and envy. It was not as though the other restaurants nearby were doing better. They were not. But this situation was an anomaly amid the city’s vibrant outdoor dining renaissance. Even later, in the no-man’s dining hour of 3 p.m., tables in the West Village and TriBeCa were lively and full.

headline: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
abstract: A recovery bill sinks, and teachers pay a heavy toll.
lead_paragraph: Don’t expect any new virus stimulus before Election Day. That seems to be the takeaway after Senate Republicans today failed to advance their scaled-back plan, in the face of opposition from Democrats, who called it inadequate.

headline: ‘I Didn’t Lie,’ Trump Claims on Downplaying Coronavirus Threat
abstract: During a news conference, President Trump defended his interviews with the veteran journalist Bob Woodward.
lead_paragraph: During a news conference, President Trump defended his interviews with the veteran journalist Bob Woodward.

headline: A University Had a Great Coronavirus Plan, but Students Partied On
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Fraternities and Sororities', 'Tests (Medical)', 'Parties (Social)', 'Physics', 'Disease Rates', 'Coronavirus Reopenings']
abstract: An unexpected upswing in positive tests at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign showed how even the most comprehensive approaches to limiting the virus’s spread can break down.
lead_paragraph: At the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, more than 40,000 students take tests twice a week for the coronavirus. They cannot enter campus buildings unless an app vouches that their test has come back negative. Everyone has to wear masks.

headline: 9 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: Our recommended books this week are evenly balanced between questions of race and space. First, the cosmos: In “The Sirens of Mars,” the planetary scientist Sarah Stewart Johnson evokes the wonders of her work looking for life on other worlds; in “The End of Everything,” the theoretical cosmologist Katie Mack asks what science can teach us about the likely end of the universe; and in “The Smallest Lights in the Universe,” the astrophysicist Sara Seager balances an account of her scientific career with a memoir of grief and young widowhood. On the subject of race, Seyward Darby (“Sisters in Hate”) and Edward Ball (“Life of a Klansman”) both probe America’s troubled legacy of white supremacy, while Martha S. Jones (“Vanguard”) celebrates the Black women who have persevered in the cause of equal justice.

headline: Advertisers Flock to N.F.L. Broadcasts as a ‘Safe Haven’
abstract: Ad spending has slumped in the pandemic, in part over uncertainty about how sports seasons would proceed. With an on-time start, football is poised to capture “a greater share of a smaller pie.”
lead_paragraph: The N.F.L. season kickoff is giving the advertising industry reason to rejoice after months of disruption related to the pandemic and civil unrest.

headline: Stimulus Bill, Wildfires, N.F.L.: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Ronald Khalis Bell of Kool & the Gang Dies at 68
abstract: He was the chief force behind the feel-good song “Celebration” and wrote or co-wrote many of the group’s other hits.
lead_paragraph: Ronald Khalis Bell, who with his brother and neighborhood friends formed the jazz-funk-R&B band that became Kool & the Gang, and who was the lead writer on its biggest hit, the omnipresent feel-good song “Celebration,” died on Wednesday at his home in the Virgin Islands. He was 68.

headline: Joshua Bellamy, Ex-Jet, Fraudulently Took $1.2 Million in Covid-19 Aid, U.S. Says
keywords: ['Frauds and Swindling', 'Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)']
abstract: Federal prosecutors said that Mr. Bellamy, 31, who was cut from the team on Tuesday, used the proceeds from a Paycheck Protection Program loan to buy luxury goods from Gucci and Dior.
lead_paragraph: A wide receiver who was cut from the New York Jets on Tuesday has been charged with fraudulently obtaining a $1.2 million loan from the Paycheck Protection Program and using the proceeds to buy luxury goods, prosecutors said on Thursday.

headline: 150 Big Businesses Warn Mayor of ‘Widespread Anxiety’ Over N.Y.C.’s Future
abstract: Leaders of companies like Goldman Sachs and JetBlue implored Mayor Bill de Blasio to take more decisive action to halt the city’s decline.
lead_paragraph: More than 150 business leaders in New York City joined together on Thursday to warn Mayor Bill de Blasio that he needed to take more decisive action to address crime and other quality-of-life issues that they said were jeopardizing the city’s economic recovery.

headline: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
abstract: Our critic recommends a poignant documentary about a singular moment in pop culture, along with a stunning ballet adaptation and a thoughtful CBS sitcom.
lead_paragraph: Every Monday, Wednesday and Friday, Margaret offers hyper-specific viewing recommendations in our Watching newsletter. Read her latest picks below, and sign up for the Watching newsletter here.

headline: How to Help Prepare Your Home Against the Threat of Wildfires
abstract: There are measures you can take to help protect your property from wildfires, but you must evacuate if ordered to do so.
lead_paragraph: Wildfires are spreading across California, Washington and Oregon at an astonishing rate, leaving thousands of scorched homes and businesses in their wake.

headline: What if We Have to Wait Years for a Coronavirus Vaccine?
abstract: A silver-bullet vaccine is far from guaranteed. But it’s also not the only way out of the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it on Tuesdays and Thursdays.

headline: Unemployment Claims Send Another Worrisome Note
keywords: ['Unemployment Insurance', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Unemployment', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'United States Economy', 'Frauds and Swindling']
abstract: Filings for benefits reflect continued layoffs and a sluggish recovery. “The numbers are going in the wrong direction,” one economist said.
lead_paragraph: Despite some signs of economic revival, the outlook for American workers remains treacherous, with layoffs continuing to claim hundreds of thousands of jobs a week.

headline: A Climate Reckoning in Fire-Stricken California
keywords: ['Wildfires', 'Global Warming', 'Water Pollution', 'Air Pollution', 'Power Failures and Blackouts']
abstract: If climate change was a somewhat abstract notion a decade ago, today it is all too real for Californians fleeing wildfires and smothered in a blanket of smoke, the worst year of fires on record.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Multiple mega fires burning more than three million acres. Millions of residents smothered in toxic air. Rolling blackouts and triple-digit heat waves. Climate change, in the words of one scientist, is smacking California in the face.

headline: As Clock Ticks, Trump Engulfs Himself in Chaotic News Cycles
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Books and Literature', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Political Advertising']
abstract: With early voting about to begin in some states, the days President Trump can afford to be consumed by crises of his own making are dwindling. But he has spent the last week in reaction mode.
lead_paragraph: President Trump is running out the clock on his own re-election campaign.

headline: Now We Know What the President Knew
abstract: The revelations in Bob Woodward’s book about President Trump also showed us something about the state of the Washington establishment.
lead_paragraph: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your guide to the day in national politics. I’m Lisa Lerer, your host.

headline: When a Heart Is Empty
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2020']
abstract: The consequences of Donald Trump’s inability to feel.
lead_paragraph: On Dec. 26, 2004, the French author Emmanuel Carrère, his girlfriend and their respective sons were vacationing at a cliff-top hotel in Sri Lanka. Their relationship was dying and, feeling out of sorts, they decided not to go down to the beachfront scuba diving lesson they’d signed up for. It was a consequential decision, for that was the morning the tsunami hit.

headline: Trump’s Coronavirus Response Was Beyond Incompetent
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct']
abstract: He wasn’t oblivious to the danger. He just didn’t care.
lead_paragraph: Most cases in which cars kill pedestrians surely reflect negligence: drivers who were too busy talking on their cellphones or thinking about their golf games to notice the senior citizen crossing the street in front of them. A handful are acts of murder, like when a man killed a woman by plowing his car into counterprotesters at a neo-Nazi rally in Charlottesville, Va.

headline: Support the Brave Protesters of Belarus
keywords: ['Elections', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Politics and Government', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'Poisoning and Poisons']
abstract: America and Europe must make clear that they stand behind the Belarusian people’s demand for fair elections.
lead_paragraph: The monthlong crackdown on peaceful protests over a blatantly fixed election in Belarus is an affront to everyone who cherishes democracy and elemental fairness. The question is how to respond.

headline: Federal Court Rejects Trump’s Order to Exclude Undocumented From Census
keywords: ['Census', 'Population', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Redistricting and Reapportionment', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Executive Orders and Memorandums']
abstract: A three-judge panel unanimously said President Trump lacked the authority to remove noncitizens from census counts used to allot House seats.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A federal court on Thursday rejected President Trump’s order to exclude unauthorized immigrants from population counts that will be used next year to reallocate seats in the House of Representatives, ruling that it was so obviously illegal that a lawsuit challenging the order need not go to a trial.

headline: F.D.A. Regulators Publish Rare Self-Defense Amid Rising Vaccine Pressure
abstract: A group of career scientists at the Food and Drug Administration vowed that their work would continue unimpeded and independent of political influence.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As President Trump continues to suggest a coronavirus vaccine could be ready before Election Day, top regulators at the Food and Drug Administration issued an unusual statement on Thursday promising to uphold the scientific integrity of their work and defend the agency’s independence.

headline: Ronald Harwood, Oscar-Winning Screenwriter, Is Dead at 85
abstract: A prolific writer of books and plays as well as screenplays, he won an Academy Award in 2003 for “The Pianist.”
lead_paragraph: Ronald Harwood, a British author, playwright and screenwriter who earned three Oscar nominations and won for best adapted screenplay in 2003 for “The Pianist,” died on Tuesday at his home in Sussex, England. He was 85.

headline: States Are in Desperate Search for Help Battling Record Wildfires
abstract: With millions of acres ablaze across the West Coast, states are having a tough time finding available fire crews. California resorted to calling in a team of firefighters from Israel.
lead_paragraph: MOLALLA, Ore. — As wildfires began consuming communities across Oregon this week, leaders at the state emergency management office fired off an email to counterparts around the country, pleading for 10 firefighting strike teams that could bring 50 extra engines to the region.

headline: Investigation of Medicare Chief Exposes Underside of Washington
keywords: ['Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'Government Contracts and Procurement', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Consultants', 'Public Relations and Publicity', 'News and News Media']
abstract: A yearlong investigation into Seema Verma, the head of the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services, showed the cozy relations that fuel the nation’s capital at taxpayer expense.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A girls’ night at the Georgetown home of a prominent journalist, a lobbying push for soft-focus features in glossy magazines, a professional makeup artist and invitations to awards dinners and prestige panels.

headline: For a President Who ‘Needs to Touch the Flame,’ Bob Woodward Was Irresistible
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'News and News Media', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2020']
abstract: President Trump gave 18 interviews to the famed Watergate journalist, gambling that he could control the narrative. Instead, he undermined himself shortly before an election.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Presidents over the decades thought they could manage Bob Woodward and many, as Karl Rove put it this week, came to regret it. Then came Donald J. Trump, who being Donald J. Trump thought so much of his powers of persuasion that he opened up to Mr. Woodward not once or twice but an astonishing 18 times.

headline: Hopes Dim for More Stimulus as Democrats Block Narrow G.O.P. Plan
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Stimulus (Economic)', 'Federal Aid (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)', 'United States Economy']
abstract: A show vote in the Senate reflected a continuing partisan divide that appears increasingly likely to scuttle any recovery package to address the toll of the pandemic before the November election.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Prospects for any additional stimulus to address the coronavirus pandemic’s devastating toll before the election darkened considerably on Thursday, when a whittled-down Republican plan failed in the Senate on a partisan vote.

headline: Police Chief Cheated to Get His Job, and Officers Helped, U.S. Says
abstract: Armando J. Perez, the police chief of Bridgeport, Conn., and another official were charged with conspiring to rig the hiring process to ensure Mr. Perez got the top job.
lead_paragraph: Bridgeport, Connecticut’s biggest city, has experienced its share of government corruption in the recent past, including a scandal that sent the current mayor to federal prison for seven years before his triumphant return to City Hall.

headline: N.F.L. Season Kicks Off With Players’ Protesting Racism
abstract: After an off-season of social turmoil, the Houston Texans chose not to be on the field for the playing of “Lift Every Voice and Sing” and “The Star-Spangled Banner” before the league’s season opener in Kansas City, Mo.
lead_paragraph: After an off-season of social and political turmoil, N.F.L. players made it clear on the night of the season opener that they will continue to shine a light on social injustice and police brutality against African Americans.

headline: Victoria Azarenka Beats Serena Williams in Comeback to Reach U.S. Open Final
abstract: Williams was hurt in the third set of a tight match. Azarenka will face Naomi Osaka in the final.
lead_paragraph: Victoria Azarenka and Naomi Osaka will meet in the United States Open final on Saturday in a nearly empty, cavernous stadium in Queens — and what a shame that will be for fans.

headline: For the Men’s Doubles Champs, One Constant Holds: ‘A Grand Slam Is a Grand Slam’
abstract: In a United States Open with a reduced field and protocols that discouraged players from high-fiving, Mate Pavic and Bruno Soares won their first major title together in straight sets.
lead_paragraph: The United States Open men’s doubles final lacked drama, but the victors’ celebrations were enthusiastic: Mate Pavic collapsed to the ground on his back as Bruno Soares screamed his name. When Pavic rose, the two hugged enthusiastically before embracing each other and shaking hands with their opponents across the net.

headline: What I Learned From My Instagram Crush
abstract: Can anything good come from obsessing over a South Korean bodybuilder on social media?
lead_paragraph: It took two hours and three buses to reach his gym. I was working a split shift at an English language academy in Seoul, leaving me a gap of five hours for taking a nap or traveling to his gym, where, given the long commute, I would barely have enough time to break a sweat.

headline: Rapes of Woman and 5-Year-Old Fuel Outrage in Pakistan
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Sex Crimes', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: The girl’s burned body was found two days later. The woman was dragged from her car. The two cases have focused the country’s attention on its handling of sexual abuse.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — A 5-year-old girl in southern Pakistan was raped, hit on the head and set on fire. Five days later, a woman in the country’s east was dragged from her car and sexually assaulted on a highway in front of her children.

headline: New in Paperback: ‘Nothing to See Here’ and ‘Red at the Bone’
abstract: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
lead_paragraph: FASHIONOPOLIS: Why What We Wear Matters, by Dana Thomas. (Penguin, 320 pp., $18.) After faulting “fast fashion” (discount brands’ accelerated production of runway-show knockoffs) for economic, human rights and climate crises worldwide, a veteran style writer introduces us to the visionaries who are attempting to transform the industry “from an urban nightmare,” as our reviewer, Tatiana Schlossberg, put it, “into a shining city on a hill.”

headline: How I Finally Got to Know My Father by Asking About His Past
abstract: Well into adulthood, I felt that I could never make up for the father-time I’d missed as a child. But it turned out that I could. And I did.
lead_paragraph: I adored my father. He’s the parent I felt an affinity with, the one I thought understood me. But when I was growing up in Brooklyn in the late ’40s and early ’50s, he was rarely home. He worked overtime as a cutter in the garment district, late into the evening during the week and all day Saturday. Most Sundays he was busy “being active,” as we called it, in New York’s Liberal Party, in recompense for which he was promised a political appointment that would allow him to escape the factory.

headline: A Relationship Built on Resiliency
abstract: Dr. Lisa Jacobs fell in love with Mark Kerstens’s sense of adventure, which took them from San Francisco to Amsterdam and back again.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Lisa Jacobs had low expectations for online dating. So low in fact, that after matching on Tinder in December 2017 with Marinus Kerstens, who goes by Mark, she made sure to eat dinner before their first date, thinking it would be for only a drink. Mr. Kerstens showed up ready for a full meal.

abstract: Damon Dickinson and Neil Alpert bonded over a love of travel, cooking, the television sitcom “Golden Girls,” and Christmas.
lead_paragraph: Despite the fact that Damon Dickinson and Neil Alpert are Jewish, the couple have celebrated Christmas with Mr. Dickinson’s family each of the last four years.

headline: 20 Theater Figures on How to ‘Revolutionize’ Their World
abstract: End unpaid internships. Set term limits for leaders. Get real about inclusion. Take performances to the streets. Say yes to joy, and no to couch plays.
lead_paragraph: Whoopi Goldberg had a suggestion: Stop calling Broadway “The Great White Way,” she proposed on “The View” in June, and nickname it “The Great Bright Way” instead.

headline: The Towering Lies of President Trump
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'Rumors and Misinformation', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: It’s simple. Everything that benefits Mr. Trump is true and everything that inconveniences him is false.
lead_paragraph: President Trump’s taped admission to Bob Woodward that he deliberately misled Americans about the danger of the coronavirus makes him morally culpable in the ensuing tragedy. But Mr. Trump actually forfeited the battle against the pandemic long before it erupted in Wuhan, China, in the first place. His tragic failures are a result of a systematic skepticism — an opportunistic cynicism — whose orienting principle is that everything that benefits Mr. Trump is true and everything that inconveniences him is false.

headline: New York City Marks 9/11 at a Time of Harrowing Loss
abstract: As they memorialize a past tragedy, New Yorkers face another profound and deadly crisis that is not yet over.
lead_paragraph: The mourners entering the plaza wore face masks, and the teary, intimate hugs of years past were replaced by awkwardly choreographed fist bumps. When the bells tolled at 8:46 a.m., marking the moment the first jet smashed into the north tower 19 years ago, those gathered stood at somber attention, trying to draw comfort from neighbors required to stand six feet apart.

headline: She Helped Put ‘Black Lives Matter’ on N.B.A. Courts
keywords: ['Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Basketball', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Black People', 'Blacks']
abstract: Michele Roberts grew up in the South Bronx and made her way to the pinnacle of the legal world before becoming the head of the players’ union.

headline: Missed Vaccines, Skipped Colonoscopies: Preventive Care Plummets
abstract: Nonurgent medical procedures have seemed worth postponing in a pandemic. This could pose long-term risks, health officials fear.
lead_paragraph: When the coronavirus pandemic hit, Americans vastly scaled back their preventive health care, and there is little sign that this deferred care will be made up.

headline: California’s Air Quality Is Poor. Here’s How to Protect Yourself.
abstract: Wildfire smoke spreads misery, including health problems, far beyond fire zones. We have key facts and tips.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Jennifer Krasner’s 4-year-old daughter had been coughing for days. Ms. Krasner and her family live 20 minutes north of San Francisco, in Mill Valley, Calif., not close to any fire but wreathed in smoke nonetheless, with her house and car dusted with ash.

headline: The Perfect Mix: Politics and Comedy
abstract: Chelsea Connor and Will Carey met at a comedy club in June 2014, but didn’t begin to date to date until a month later, after the New York Democratic primary.
lead_paragraph: When Chelsea Connor first saw Will Carey, all 6 feet 7 inches of him, in June 2014, he was onstage at the comedy club Caroline’s on Broadway, discussing the gentrification of the chopped cheese sandwich.

headline: One Question Left on the Board
abstract: Lina-Marie Mano and Andrew Silvestri played 20 questions while they were dating as a way to learn more about each other.
lead_paragraph: Shortly after they began dating, Lina-Marie Mano and Andrew Silvestri started playing a game called 20 questions.

headline: Always on Each Other’s Mind
abstract: Caitlin Nicholson and Emily Reeves got to know each other at a Dartmouth sorority party, and hit it off right away.
lead_paragraph: When Dr. Caitlin Nicholson and Emily Reeves were introduced in 2011 at Dartmouth College, there was, Dr. Nicholson will assure you, a sorority house basement and a variety of the pong drinking games that involved beer. The venue was customary for both of them, as they were students at the college in Hanover, N.H.

headline: I’ve Never Seen the American West in Such Deep Distress
abstract: We’re choking on smoke and staring out at Martian-red skies in a world becoming uninhabitable.
lead_paragraph: The open road in the Big Empty part of the American West has always been therapeutic. Vacant skies, horizons that stretch to infinity, country without clutter. The soul needs to roam, too.

headline: Can Empathy Be Taught? Should Schools Try to Help Us Feel One Another’s Pain?
abstract: We can never perfectly inhabit another person’s experience, but should we still try?
lead_paragraph: Do you consider yourself to be an empathetic person? Do you try to understand how others are feeling? Is empathy is an important skill for all of us to have? Why, or why not?

headline: A Day 1 Prediction on the Beach
abstract: Jordan Eller and Philipp Leiminger met on an island in Thailand. Their connection was immediate.
lead_paragraph: In November 2018, Jordan Eller got out her backpack, one of her favorite possessions, and traveled with a few friends to Koh Phi Phi, an island in Thailand. Ms. Eller, 25, lives in Denver and is a transportation-engineer-in-training at HDR, an engineering and architectural firm where she helps design a variety of structures like highway bridges and wheelchair accessible trails in the wilderness.

headline: After the After-Parties, Act 1, Scene 1
abstract: Shauna Perlman and Julie Oh went from party to party after the Tony Awards ceremony in 2014, and then gingerly entered into a relationship.
lead_paragraph: Shauna Lauren Perlman and Julie Sujin Oh were on familiar turf as they went from party to party after the 2014 Tony Awards ceremony at Radio City Music Hall in Manhattan.

headline: Is There a Black Hole in Our Backyard?
keywords: ['Space and Astronomy', 'Stars and Galaxies', 'Black Holes (Space)', 'Solar System', 'Telescopes and Observatories', 'Gravitation and Gravity', 'Physics', 'Large Synoptic Survey Telescope', 'your-feed-science']
abstract: Astrophysicists have recently begun hatching plans to find out just how weird Planet Nine might be.
lead_paragraph: What is an astrophysicist to do during a pandemic, except maybe daydream about having a private black hole?

headline: Larry Wilmore Doesn’t Miss Late Night, but He’s Back Anyway
abstract: Four years after the abrupt end of “The Nightly Show,” Wilmore has a new topical comedy series on Peacock.
lead_paragraph: Back when Larry Wilmore was about to introduce “The Nightly Show,” his short-lived late-night series on Comedy Central, he saw a tweet from an angry prospective viewer who wished failure on the host and his lousy show, which at that point had not yet aired a single episode.

headline: The Pandemic in Six-Word Memoirs
abstract: “The world has never felt smaller.”
lead_paragraph: Since 2006, I’ve been challenging people to describe their lives in six words, a form I call the six-word memoir — a personal twist on the legendary six-word story attributed to Ernest Hemingway: “For sale: baby shoes, never worn.”

headline: How to Birth a New American Theater
keywords: ['Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Theater', 'Unemployment', 'Income Inequality', 'Web-Original Programming', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: Six months dark. Thousands of artists out of work. Could this disaster have a surprise ending? Five critics on what must change, onstage and off.
lead_paragraph: When New York City shut down on March 12, its theaters were preparing for a busy spring season: big names on Broadway, Tony Awards mania, millions of dollars in sales and of course a smattering of thoughtful, important plays on smaller stages.

headline: Bonding After a Broken Arm
abstract: When Amanda Augustine and Michael Mayer faced the prospect of a long-distance relationship, they decided to split up. A fateful dodge-ball game changed things.
lead_paragraph: Amanda A. Augustine and Michael R. Mayer had maintained a long-distance relationship for years when, in 2017, they finally settled in the same city.

headline: Chiefs Fans, Used to Chops and Cheers, React to N.F.L.’s New Climate
abstract: Kansas City’s fans are among the loudest in pro football. But the celebratory start to their season silenced game rituals and drew mixed opinions on players’ protests of racial injustice.
lead_paragraph: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — Kent Gaines stepped out of his car on Thursday evening, a red mask swinging from his finger, and took in the scene around him in the parking lot of Arrowhead Stadium. It was just before the Kansas City Chiefs and the Houston Texans kicked off to start an N.F.L. season unlike any he had ever experienced as a season-ticket holder.

headline: The Secret History of America’s Only WWII Refugee Camp
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'World War II (1939-45)', 'Jews and Judaism', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: At the height of the war, 982 refugees fleeing the Nazis were invited by President Roosevelt to a converted military base in upstate New York.
lead_paragraph: Elfi Strauber was 11 years old when she boarded the U.S.S. Henry Gibbins in Naples, Italy. It was the summer of 1944, and she was traveling with her parents and sister, hundreds of wounded soldiers and close to a thousand other Jewish war refugees. The overcrowded troop ship was heading to New York, escorted by a convoy of warships and two transport vessels carrying Nazi prisoners of war — protection against German attack.

headline: The Last Islanders Team to Advance This Far Sees a Little of Itself
abstract: As happened in 1993, the timely help of role players lifted the franchise to the conference finals. But behind in the series, 2-0, to Tampa Bay, these Islanders risk suffering the same fate.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — No one should be surprised that the Islanders advanced to the conference finals for the first time in 27 seasons.

headline: For Hotels, Cleaning Is Key. But Cleaners Say Their Jobs Are Under Assault.
keywords: ['Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Building Service Employees', 'Cleaning Services', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations', 'Coronavirus Risks and Safety Concerns', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Organized Labor']
abstract: The hotel industry says doing away with daily room cleanings keeps guests and staff safe. But housekeepers say it is a step toward cutting earnings and job security.
lead_paragraph: In the past four months, nearly every major hotel brand in the world has announced a cleaning program highlighting new disinfecting and sterilizing procedures. Many companies are consulting with medical organizations; some are using robots; all say they are cleaning more than ever before. Their messaging is clear: Hotels are very clean.

headline: How Paul Rudnick, Humorist, Spends His Sundays
keywords: ['Writing and Writers', 'Comedy and Humor', 'Television', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)']
abstract: In his new socially distanced HBO satire, “Coastal Elites,” five New Yorkers and Angelenos handle the curveballs of 2020.
lead_paragraph: In 1993, Paul Rudnick made his mark as a comedic writer who took on serious issues with “Jeffrey,” a play that captured the strained social tenor of AIDS-ravaged Manhattan. At first, producers refused to stage the production, but it eventually became an award-winning Off Broadway hit, followed by a movie version, starring Patrick Stewart.

headline: A Free Market Manifesto That Changed the World, Reconsidered
keywords: ['Corporate Social Responsibility', 'United States Economy', 'Capitalism (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Economics (Theory and Philosophy)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Conservatism (US Politics)']
abstract: Milton Friedman’s libertarian economics influenced presidents and inspired “greed is good.” So what did Friedman get right — and wrong? Today’s business leaders and economists weigh in.
lead_paragraph: Sept. 13 is the 50th anniversary of a seminal moment in the world of business: the publication of Milton Friedman’s essay in The New York Times Magazine entitled “The Social Responsibility of Business Is to Increase Its Profits.”

headline: We Need to Recruit More Black Americans in Vaccine Trials
keywords: ['Black People', 'Blacks', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Clinical Trials', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Vaccination and Immunization']
abstract: Pharmaceutical companies and the government must step up their efforts to enroll a diverse group of volunteers.
lead_paragraph: The global race is on for a vaccine to combat the coronavirus, but the question is: Who will be included?

headline: This Island Has No Bridges. Can It Survive With No Ferries?
abstract: On Shelter Island, private ferries are the only way to reach the mainland. With a greatly reduced tourist season, they might be out of business soon.
lead_paragraph: Unless you have a kayak, there are only two ways on and off Shelter Island. As they have since the 19th century, the full-time residents on the small island at the very tip of Long Island rely exclusively on the North Ferry and the South Ferry.

headline: Back to School With Tan France
abstract: The “Queer Eye” star has a lot to teach us about dressing.
lead_paragraph: Three years ago at an Embassy Suites in Glendale, Calif., Antoni Porowski spotted his soon-to-be co-star Tan France in the hotel’s gym. Mr. France was wearing tailored gym shorts and a crisp Nike shirt tucked neatly into his waistband. His hair was perfectly coifed and he was smiling as he StairMastered without breaking a sweat.

headline: See How N.Y.’s Caribbean Community Kept Carnival Vividly Alive
abstract: This year, the official West Indian American Day celebrations were canceled — but the Carnival spirit came through.
lead_paragraph: Not celebrating wasn’t an option. When Sandra Morris Bell learned that this year’s West Indian American Day celebrations had been canceled in New York City, she found a way to keep the tradition alive.

headline: The Other Way Covid Will Kill: Hunger
keywords: ['Food Insecurity', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Shortages', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Third World and Developing Countries', 'Children and Childhood', 'Malnutrition']
abstract: Worldwide, the population facing life-threatening levels of food insecurity is expected to double, to more than a quarter of a billion people.
lead_paragraph: Long before the pandemic swept into her village in the rugged southeast of Afghanistan, Halima Bibi knew the gnawing fear of hunger. It was an omnipresent force, an unrelenting source of anxiety as she struggled to nourish her four children.

headline: In New Development, Buyers Favor the Boroughs
abstract: Yes, some buyers are leaving Manhattan. But others are doubling down on Brooklyn and Queens.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to new development, buyers who are choosing to stay in New York — and have the means to stay — are choosing Brooklyn and Queens.

headline: The Coronavirus Is Mutating, and That’s Fine (So Far)
abstract: SARS-CoV-2 has been slowly changing in small ways, without getting more dangerous.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — No doubt you have read the recent headlines about patients who recovered from Covid-19 only to be infected with SARS-CoV-2 again later — purportedly by a different “strain” of the virus.

headline: Black Police Chiefs, Feeling Squeezed, Face Criticism on All Sides
keywords: ['Black People', 'Blacks', 'Police Reform', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'George Floyd Protests (2020)', 'Black Lives Matter Movement']
abstract: As police departments are scrutinized for racist policing practices, African-American chiefs find themselves caught between skeptical residents and officers.
lead_paragraph: Sitting in a church service several years back, listening to his pastor speak of the obligation to confront what is wrong in society, Branville G. Bard Jr. thought about being a Black man and a top police official too.

headline: A Biden Win Won’t Cure My Trump-Era Depression
keywords: ['Depression (Mental)', 'Anxiety and Stress', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: I find hope and relief from my misery in things that have nothing to do with the election.

headline: Serena’s Rivals Are Emboldened. But She Still Has the Fire and the Game.
abstract: On Thursday, Serena Williams’s quest for a 24th Grand Slam singles title was thwarted once more. Maybe it doesn’t really matter.

headline: Saying Goodbye to Australia
abstract: With an upcoming departure from Sydney, one Australian reporter reflects on the experience of home and the country’s culture of simple pleasures.
lead_paragraph: It was the slow pace that struck me most when I returned to my hometown, Sydney, three years ago from Washington, D.C.

headline: N.Y.C. Remembers 9/11 Amid a Pandemic
keywords: ['September 11 (2001)', 'Coronavirus Risks and Safety Concerns', 'World Trade Center (Manhattan, NY)', 'Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)']

keywords: ['your-feed-science', 'Rumors and Misinformation', 'News and News Media', 'E-Learning', 'Social Media', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Elderly', 'your-feed-health']

headline: The Virus Is a Marathon
abstract: And what else you need to know today.
lead_paragraph: Last week’s newsletter comparing the U.S. coronavirus death toll to the global average helped spark a continuing debate: What’s the fairest expectation of how bad the pandemic should have been in this country?

headline: Corrections: Sept. 11, 2020
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, Sept. 11, 2020.
lead_paragraph: An article on Thursday about a reassurance from health officials that a coronavirus vaccine will meet safety standards before approval included incorrect information on school requirements for vaccination. Schools no longer require smallpox vaccinations, and many schools require skin testing, not vaccination, for tuberculosis.

headline: Has Business Left Milton Friedman Behind?
abstract: The economist taught a generation of corporate leaders that profit should be their main motive. A new group of C.E.O.s begs to differ.
lead_paragraph: On September 13, 1970, the New York Times Magazine published an essay by the economist Milton Friedman titled “The Social Responsibility of Business is to Increase Its Profits.” It laid out what came to be known as the Friedman Doctrine — a call to arms for American free-market capitalism and arguably the most consequential economic idea, for better or worse, of the latter part of the 20th century.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Disastrous Wave of Climate Events Slams California
abstract: Quotation of the Day of Friday, September 11, 2020.
lead_paragraph: “People are always asking, ‘Is this the new normal?’ I always say no. It’s going to get worse.”

headline: From Miner’s Grandson to Lord Darroch of Kew, With a Touch of Irony
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The former British ambassador to Washington was undone by a leak of cables giving his unvarnished opinion of President Trump. No, he is not embittered.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — For Kim Darroch, Britain’s former ambassador to the United States, the latest jaw-dropping revelations about President Trump’s private comments about the military and the pandemic could easily be a source of vindication or bitterness.

headline: Hunger is a growing scourge in the pandemic.
abstract: As the global economy absorbs the most punishing reversal of fortunes since the Great Depression, hunger is on the rise.
lead_paragraph: As the global economy absorbs the most punishing reversal of fortunes since the Great Depression, hunger is on the rise.

headline: How China is using promises of a vaccine as a diplomatic carrot.
abstract: With pledges of a coronavirus vaccine, China is on a charm offensive to repair strained diplomatic ties and bolster engagement with other countries.
lead_paragraph: China is still most likely months away from mass producing a vaccine that is safe for public use. But the country is using the prospect of the drug’s discovery in a charm offensive aimed at repairing damaged ties and bringing friends closer in regions China deems vital to its interests.

headline: Democrats Gained These Voters in 2018, and Biden Needs to Keep Them Now
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Midterm Elections (2018)', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: An authoritative new study on 2018 midterm voters shows how despite his strong position, Joe Biden is lagging behind the rates at which some key demographics broke for the Democrats two years ago.

headline: Who’s the Next Woman to Take Over on Wall Street?
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']

lead_paragraph: Want this delivered to your inbox each day? Sign up here.

headline: The Never Boring Rockets May Have Met Their Match

lead_paragraph: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla. — The Houston Rockets managed to make things interesting in the fourth quarter, which is one thing the Rockets do well: make things interesting. They reinvent offensive schemes and engineer big trades and offer nightly rebukes to conventional wisdom. Houston’s style may be polarizing, but the Rockets are not a boring franchise.

headline: A Sitcom for Families With ‘Funny Shapes’

headline: The clock is ticking, and Trump keeps engulfing himself in chaotic news cycles.
abstract: With early voting about to begin in some states, the days President Trump can afford to be consumed by crises of his own making are dwindling. But he has spent the last week in reaction mode.
lead_paragraph: President Trump is running out the clock on his own re-election campaign.

headline: The U.S. imposed sanctions on a Ukrainian with ties to Russia, citing election interference.
abstract: The Trump administration imposed sanctions on a Ukrainian lawmaker Thursday for waging “a covert influence campaign” to undermine the presidential election after he disseminated information intended to hurt Joseph R. Biden Jr.
lead_paragraph: The Trump administration imposed sanctions on a Ukrainian lawmaker Thursday for waging “a covert influence campaign” to undermine the presidential election after he disseminated information intended to hurt Joseph R. Biden Jr.

headline: Protecting Your Property From Wildfires
abstract: There are measures you can take to protect your home ahead of wildfires, but you must evacuate if ordered to do so.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: The Fluid Morality of Soccer’s Transfer Market
abstract: Only a few months ago, as Europe’s biggest clubs faced suspended seasons and financial ruin, owners pressed their players to take pay cuts. So why are they now spending as if nothing has changed?
lead_paragraph: At the height of it, during those long weeks in March and April when the future was nothing but fog, Europe’s soccer players were left in no doubt at all. The message was passed down from the top — from team executives and owners, from the sport’s major leagues themselves and even from lawmakers — through interminable video calls with club captains, and it was clear.

headline: Travis Scott Meets McDonald’s (It’s Lit!)
keywords: ['Fast Food Industry', 'Rap and Hip-Hop', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Fashion and Apparel']
abstract: A partnership between the rapper and the fast-food chain is a melding of the merchandising minds.
lead_paragraph: During my childhood years, my family’s kitchen cabinets used to be lousy with the sorts of commemorative glassware you’d get at Burger King or McDonald’s — a Luke Skywalker here, a Snoopy there. These were part of huge global marketing pushes for creative projects being milked for every last ounce of intellectual property, but also savvy positioning by the restaurants. Fast-food companies have long attempted to stave off disposability by piggybacking on broader cultural moments, hoping to extend their reach beyond the comestible into the permanently tangible.

headline: That Roof Deck Makes for a Nice One-Room Schoolhouse
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Education (K-12)', 'Children and Childhood', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Condominiums']
abstract: Some luxury apartment buildings are offering up outdoor and indoor common spaces for at-home learning pods.
lead_paragraph: Vanessa Phillips was sold on a two-bedroom apartment at One Hundred Barclay, a luxury condo conversion in TriBeCa, because of the enviable amenity space she saw when she visited the building in February. The Ralph Walker-designed Art Deco tower has two landscaped terraces, a media room, music rooms, a wine lounge, a billiards room and a fitness center with two pools, all of which were closed during the pandemic, but are now in the process of reopening.

headline: How to Network From Home
keywords: ['Content Type: Service', 'Careers and Professions', 'Hiring and Promotion', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Social Media', 'Telecommuting', 'Videophones and Videoconferencing']
abstract: While team meetings and industry conventions have moved online, the pandemic has opened as many doors as it has closed.
lead_paragraph: Maybe you were never comfortable networking at the office or striking up a conversation over a boxed lunch at a convention, but after half a year working inside your own four walls, oh, the chance to meet new people!

headline: Four Questions to Help Demystify Your Relationship With Money
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Personal Finances', 'High Net Worth Individuals']
abstract: An author seeks to prompt critical thinking about money and the status and power that are accrued from it. Several experts offered their own take.

While working there, she met her husband, David, who had more stock options than she did. He later left to work for Amazon when it was still just selling books and got even more valuable options there.

abstract: What are architects and urban planners foreseeing as people cautiously gather? Streets “curated” for various uses and dynamic cityscapes that both advance wellness and knit communities together.
