headline: Even the Threat of a Tougher Rule on Financial Advice Has Helped Investors
keywords: ['Financial Brokers', 'Financial Planners', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Consumer Protection', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Conflicts of Interest']
abstract: The Obama administration’s efforts to require firms to truly work in the interests of investors has already given people better choices, a new study says.
lead_paragraph: A battle over exactly how investors should be treated when they get financial advice has been underway for years. The Obama administration pushed for stricter investor protections, while the Trump administration has been putting looser rules into effect.

headline: What to Cook This Weekend
abstract: Make Tejal Rao’s latest, a vegetarian kofta, inspired by one of her favorite grandfather’s specialties.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Nineteen years ago today, I stared at the empty bluebird sky from a patch of grass next to a stretch of open, sparkly water, a week-old baby in a carrier beside me, grief everywhere in the sun, unsure of what we’d done, to bring a child into such a world. I sat that way a long time. Later I cooked as if it could do something, a roast chicken to feed a new family, a scent to counter smoke, a balm against reality’s angry rash. It did not help much, but it helped.

headline: Bruce Springsteen’s Classic E Street Tune, and 11 More New Songs

headline: Six Questions Looming Over Soccer’s New Season
abstract: The sport’s new calculus must account for infection rates, empty stadiums and a compressed schedule certain to exhaust everyone involved.
lead_paragraph: An hour or so after the fireworks had finished, long after the smoke had cleared and the lights had dimmed, a handful of Bayern Munich players returned to the field at the Stadium of Light in Lisbon. In near darkness, Serge Gnabry, Joshua Kimmich and David Alaba sat down on the turf. At last, the strangest season was over. Now was the time to rest and to reflect.

headline: In Oregon, a Year of Political Tumult Extends to Devastating Wildfires
abstract: A tumultuous summer of protests has become a complication in the wildfires raging around Portland.
lead_paragraph: MOLALLA, Ore. — Ralph Mitchell’s neighbors were fleeing. Ash rained from the sky. And outside Mr. Mitchell’s natural-medicine business, a police cruiser announced on loudspeaker: “This has been declared a life-threatening fire emergency. You need to evacuate the city.”

headline: Palestinians Rejected Tax Money to Slap Israel. It’s Not Israel That’s Hurting.
abstract: Palestinian families are suffering intensely as their government’s tax protest continues, even though the cause — Israel’s push to annex the West Bank — has been suspended.
lead_paragraph: RAMALLAH, West Bank — Furious that Israel was about to annex large swaths of the West Bank, the Palestinian Authority president, Mahmoud Abbas, took the painful step in June of refusing to accept taxes collected by Israel that account for more than 60 percent of the authority’s budget.

headline: Recipes for Right Now
abstract: These dishes embrace summer produce, and honor those fall cravings.
lead_paragraph: Hello and welcome to Five Weeknight Dishes. Celestially speaking, we are still in summer, but as soon as we pass Labor Day, I start thinking of roast chicken, squash and apple cakes. (This may have something to do with the fact that your hard-working NYT Cooking staff is currently preparing for Thanksgiving.)

headline: 11 of Our Best Weekend Reads
abstract: Wildfires. Jacob Blake. Diana Rigg. London’s bridges. Tilda Swinton. And more.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the weekend. As we start to get into fall, you may feel like the pandemic and the nonstop news cycle have killed the concept of the weekend for you. You’re not alone: “It feels like perpetual Thursday,” one woman said. If it does seem like you’re living in the movie “Groundhog Day,” there are still ways to enjoy the time off you do have, even if it’s just by making this cheesy toast. Whatever you do, be sure to make time for some great journalism.

headline: On the Anniversary of 9/11, Lincoln Center Awakens With Hope
abstract: “Table of Silence” was adapted this year to look back at one moment of crisis in New York City history against the backdrop of another.
lead_paragraph: On Friday morning, as the call of conch shells summoned dancers to the fountain of Lincoln Center’s plaza, the sun’s softly circular glow broke through clouds that lingered from a passing storm.

headline: Comfort Viewing: 3 Reasons I Love ‘Three’s Company’
abstract: Amid the stress of 2020, the writer finds solace in this classic sitcom’s disco-era innuendos and excess.
lead_paragraph: During a yearlong, semi-melodramatic existential crisis in my early 20s, I waited tables all day, panicked about the future at night, watched TV (while panicking) and did it all again the next day. One night, I flipped through channels and landed on “Three’s Company” to see Jack Tripper (John Ritter), Janet Wood (Joyce DeWitt) and Chrissy Snow (Suzanne Somers) pratfalling around their plant-filled 1970s apartment.

headline: In New York, rivals cross paths, and bump elbows.
abstract: Vice President Mike Pence traded an elbow bump with the Democratic nominee for president, Joseph R. Biden Jr., Friday morning when the two attended a ceremony in Lower Manhattan marking the Sept. 11 attacks.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Mike Pence traded an elbow bump with the Democratic nominee for president, Joseph R. Biden Jr., Friday morning when the two attended a ceremony in Lower Manhattan marking the Sept. 11 attacks.

headline: The Orioles Looked Done. Now They’re Threatening the Yankees’ Playoff Plans.
abstract: “We’re young and I think a lot of people underestimated us, and that’s kind of fun,” said Baltimore’s Pat Valaika. Even more fun for the Orioles would be taking the Yankees’ playoff spot.
lead_paragraph: When the Miami Marlins needed pitching help after their coronavirus outbreak this summer, they turned to the Baltimore Orioles. A few weeks later, when the Atlanta Braves wanted a starter, they also made a deal with the Orioles. The Mets and the Colorado Rockies got relievers from Baltimore, too.

headline: Stories of Then That Still Hold Up Now
abstract: Margaret Atwood, Héctor Tobar, Thomas Mallon and Brenda Wineapple on older political novels they admire that have a lot to say about the world today.
lead_paragraph: Inevitably, 2020 has been a year filled to the brim with books about politics — and not just in nonfiction. Novelists are as focused on the state of the world as any journalist or Washington insider. We decided to ask four accomplished writers to revisit a favorite political novel from the past — telling us why they admire it, and why it remains relevant and timely (or timeless, if you prefer). — John Williams

headline: Covering Ebola Didn’t Prepare Me for This: I Volunteered for the Covid-19 Vaccine Trial
keywords: ['Vaccination and Immunization', 'Content Type: Service', 'Placebos', 'Immune System', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'RNA (Ribonucleic Acid)', 'Clinical Trials']
abstract: George Washington University invited me to participate in Moderna’s vaccine trial because I am triple-risk: a Black woman, a Type 1 diabetic and asthmatic.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The unfamiliar voice on my cellphone three weeks ago had the “You have been selected” greeting that usually signals someone trying to sell you something. But this was no telemarketer.

headline: Bahrain Will Normalize Relations With Israel, in Deal Brokered by Trump
keywords: ['Palestinians', 'International Relations', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The island kingdom in the Persian Gulf becomes the second Arab nation in a month to more openly embrace Israel, dismissing Palestinian objections.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump announced on Friday that Bahrain would establish full diplomatic relations with Israel, following the United Arab Emirates, in another sign of shifting Middle East dynamics that are bringing Arab nations closer to Israel.

headline: Gig Work Is Risky for Apps, Too
keywords: ['Mobile Applications', 'Freelancing, Self-Employment and Independent Contracting', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: New and proposed laws and regulatory challenges threaten the business model of apps like Uber and Handy.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.

headline: Let the Flavors Do the Work
abstract: Farmers’ market produce is at its peak, and David Tanis thinks you should simply let it shine on its own in this dinner.
lead_paragraph: Here we are again at summer’s end, and, if ever there is a time of year to enjoy fresh produce in its glorious prime, it is now. Farmers’ markets are full of gorgeous summer fruits and vegetables — fragrant, ripe and sweet.

headline: Family Members, Politicians Pay Tribute to 9/11 Victims
abstract: Politicians gathered at the Sept. 11 memorial in Lower Manhattan to remember a national crisis on the 19th anniversary of the terrorist attacks.
lead_paragraph: Politicians gathered at the Sept. 11 memorial in Lower Manhattan to remember a national crisis on the 19th anniversary of the terrorist attacks.

headline: ‘#Alive’ Review: From Great Graphics, to Graphic
abstract: A laid back gamer is homebound with no food, no weapons, and zombies knocking at the door in this spirited Korean twist on siege movies.
lead_paragraph: No food, no weapons, minimal practical skills: What’s a doofus gamer to do when facing murderous opponents he can’t kill with a joystick? Oh Joon-wo, the protagonist of “#Alive,” hunkers down in his apartment and tries to wait things out. This can only work for so long — the single-minded attackers are undead and have all the time in the world.

headline: Review: A Family Gropes for Words in ‘Incidental Moments’
keywords: ['Theater', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)']
abstract: Richard Nelson’s profound conclusion to his Zoom-format trilogy about the Apple siblings examines the perils of conversation in 2020.
lead_paragraph: There is so much they all want — no need — to say. They have always been a family for whom conversation is as essential as oxygen, a means of defining and confirming their own identities in relation to one another and to the wide, heaving world that keeps shifting beyond and beneath them.

headline: Love Letter: Ever Obsessed Over an Instagram Crush?
abstract: Plus: 20 questions that led to love.
lead_paragraph: If you’ve been admiring a certain someone from afar, social media has made it incredibly easy to find out almost anything about them. After just a few minutes of scrolling, an expert-level lurker can dig up everything from their crush’s favorite food to the details of their last relationship.

headline: Trump’s Payroll Tax ‘Cut’ Fizzles
keywords: ['Payroll Tax', 'Corporations', 'Stimulus (Economic)', 'Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)', 'Social Security (US)', 'Executive Orders and Memorandums', 'United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Big companies say the president’s directive to delay collection of the tax that funds Social Security is more trouble than it is worth. Federal employees are upset they are stuck with it.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With congressional negotiations stalled over a new round of pandemic aid, President Trump has floated the idea of once acting alone to stimulate the economy before the November election.

headline: France to Smooth Snarled Testing Process as Virus Pressure Grows
abstract: The country is now carrying out over one million tests weekly, but critics say getting results takes too long as cases surge and hospitalizations increase.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — France is facing a worrying surge of the coronavirus crisis, the government said on Friday, warning that the number of new cases was rapidly increasing and that hospitals were seeing an uptick in admissions.

headline: Cancer Projects to Diversify Genetic Research Receive New Grants
keywords: ['Race and Ethnicity', 'Colon and Colorectal Cancer', 'Pancreatic Cancer', 'Bladder Cancer', 'Breast Cancer', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Genetics and Heredity', 'Cancer', 'your-feed-science']
abstract: Because much cancer research and clinical trials have been based on white populations, efforts to explore the ways race and ethnicity influence disease are underway.
lead_paragraph: The New York Genome Center awarded six cancer research grants this week as part of an initiative examining the role of race and ethnicity in major types of cancer.

headline: A Book About Nature That Is So Much More
abstract: In “World of Wonders” the poet Aimee Nezhukumatathil tells stories of her life through the natural world that surrounded her and gave her solace.
lead_paragraph: WORLD OF WONDERSIn Praise of Fireflies, Whale Sharks, and Other AstonishmentsBy Aimee Nezhukumatathil

headline: How Liberals Opened the Door to Libertarian Economics
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Libertarianism (US Politics)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Income Inequality', 'Economics (Theory and Philosophy)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues']
abstract: Milton Friedman’s free-market ideas found favor in a free-love era and helped redirect the country toward the right. The aftershocks of his radical arguments are still being felt today.
lead_paragraph: On September 13th, 1970, the New York Times Magazine published an essay by Milton Friedman entitled “The Social Responsibility of Business Is to Increase Its Profits,” which turned out to be one of the most influential economic arguments of the century.

headline: For These Shows, Take a Hike
abstract: If you participate in a sound walk and no one is there to applaud, does it count as theater? Our critic argues that it does. Or at least that it can.
lead_paragraph: There’s a moment late in “Cairns,” a lovely, peaceable sound walk created by the singer and scholar Gelsey Bell and presented by Here, in which Bell will ask you to do something drastic: Take out your earbuds. Maybe that doesn’t seem so extreme, but when was the last time you put away your phone, shut your eyes, stilled the mental whirl of worries, statistics and undone errands, and just listened?

headline: How Colleges Became the New Covid Hot Spots
abstract: Like meatpacking plants and nursing homes early in the pandemic, campuses across the country are experiencing outbreaks.
lead_paragraph: It began last month with a trickle of coronavirus infections as college students arrived for the fall semester. Soon that trickle became a stream, with campuses reporting dozens, and sometimes hundreds, of new cases each day.

headline: Cooking Class | Beth Bugdaycay
abstract: The co-founder and designer of the New York jewelry brand Foundrae makes a version of Turkish green beans that her mother-in-law taught her, and that Bugdaycay now teaches us.
lead_paragraph: The co-founder and designer of the New York jewelry brand Foundrae makes a version of Turkish green beans that her mother-in-law taught her, and that Bugdaycay now teaches us.

headline: A Jewelry Designer’s Prized Family Vegetable Recipe
abstract: When Beth Bugdaycay serves her favorite green beans, she is not only feeding her own family but paying tribute to her husband’s Turkish heritage.
lead_paragraph: When, at 22, the jewelry designer Beth Bugdaycay traveled to Istanbul to meet her new mother-in-law, she arrived with a request: that her husband’s mother teach her a few family dishes. “I think sharing a family recipe with another person is very personal,” says Beth, now 47, who co-founded the jewelry company Foundrae with her husband, Murat, in 2015, and lives with him and their two children above their TriBeCa store. “Learning hers was a way to show that I respected her family and her culture, and that I was committed to keeping those traditions alive with her son in New York.”

headline: Veterans Fortify the Ranks of Militias Aligned With Trump’s Views
keywords: ['Veterans', 'Right-Wing Extremism and Alt-Right', 'Fringe Groups and Movements', 'Whites', 'Neo Nazi Groups', 'Antifa Movement (US)', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The vast majority of veterans do not join militias, but some fast-growing militias have many veterans among their ranks.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Emboldened by President Trump’s campaign platform of law and order, militia groups have bolstered their strength before Election Day by attracting military veterans who bring weapons and tactical skills viewed as important to the organizations.

headline: Ken Robinson, Who Preached Creativity in Teaching, Dies at 70
abstract: Dance, he said, is just as important as math. He was knighted for his work, and his TED Talk on schools and the arts was the most viewed of all time.
lead_paragraph: Ken Robinson, a dynamic, influential proponent of stimulating the creativity of students that has too often been squelched by schools in the service of conformity, died on Aug. 21 at his home in London. He was 70.

headline: Whistle-Blower’s Complaint Ignites a Smoldering Homeland Security Agency
keywords: ['Whistle-Blowers', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Whites', 'Right-Wing Extremism and Alt-Right']
abstract: The agency created to share information across governments is accused of distorting its intelligence to play down the threats posed by Russia and white supremacists.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Well before his move to the Department of Homeland Security, Brian Murphy had become known as an ambitious counterterrorism investigator at the F.B.I., determined and relentless. At times, though, colleagues chafed at what some saw as an overzealous disregard for bureaucratic rules.

headline: Fauci Says It Could Be a Year Before Theater Without Masks Feels Normal
abstract: Dr. Anthony Fauci said a vaccine would need to exist for nearly a year before people might feel comfortable returning to theaters unmasked, which he said would likely be mid- to late 2021.
lead_paragraph: As theaters look to see how they might reopen with safety accommodations including mask use, Dr. Anthony Fauci says it will likely be more than a year before people feel comfortable returning to theaters without masks.

headline: Santa Fe Board Crushes George R.R. Martin’s Plan for ‘Medieval Castle’
abstract: An architect proposed a seven-sided tower called the “Water Garden Keep.” Neighbors feared it would attract Mr. Martin’s fans, and a review board said it did not fit Santa Fe’s Southwestern style.
lead_paragraph: It was not quite as dramatic as Daenerys mounting her last living dragon to destroy a rival kingdom.

headline: 2 Young Girls Killed and Former V.P. Missing in Paraguay Guerrilla Conflict
abstract: A military operation targeting a small insurgent group has led to accusations of a government cover-up in the deaths of two young girls from Argentina.
lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — Paraguay’s president hailed a raid last week on a guerrilla camp as a successful operation that killed two militants.

headline: The Best Movies and Shows on Hulu Right Now
abstract: We’ve handpicked the finest movies and television shows currently streaming on Hulu in the United States. Take a look.
lead_paragraph: Sign up for our Watching newsletter to get recommendations on the best films and TV shows to stream and watch, delivered to your inbox.

headline: French Prime Minister Announces No New Restrictions Despite Surge
abstract: Amid an increasing number of coronavirus cases in France, Prime Minister Jean Castex said the government was not planning a nationwide lockdown.
lead_paragraph: Amid an increasing number of coronavirus cases in France, Prime Minister Jean Castex said the government was not planning a nationwide lockdown.

headline: Europe Feels Squeeze as Tech Competition Heats Up Between U.S. and China
keywords: ['Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'United States International Relations', 'Social Media', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Facial Recognition Software', 'Artificial Intelligence', 'Privacy']
abstract: As the rapid pace of change mixes with national security issues, Europe’s role as a global regulator is increasingly tested — and may not be enough.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Lacking a powerful technology sector of its own, the European Union has instead tried to carve out a space in the digital economy as the world’s regulatory superpower, leading the charge on privacy rights and data protection by leveraging its enormous single market against Goliaths like Google and Facebook.

headline: A Spiritual Study in Blue
abstract: Betye Saar’s new work is a collection of found objects, including a sarcophagus from Egypt and wood pieces from a local craft store.
lead_paragraph: In each installment of The Artists, T highlights a recent or little-shown work by a Black artist, along with a few words from that artist putting the work into context. This week, we’re looking at a new piece by Betye Saar, known for her legendary work in assemblage, and whose solo show “Call and Response” opens Sept. 12 at the Morgan Library and Museum in New York City.

headline: Keep Track of the Tiny Details
abstract: They’ll unlock a cascade of memory in the future.
lead_paragraph: Welcome. I like to get up while it’s dark, before anyone else has begun to stir, walking through the apartment on tiptoe with the world on mute. I fix my coffee in the dark and wake up slowly. There are fewer variables, minimal stimuli. At 5 a.m., New York’s famed sleeplessness is repudiated.

headline: How to Tell if Distance Learning Is Working for Your Kid
abstract: Measuring skills, not test scores, is key.
lead_paragraph: Most parents never expected they’d be in grade school again, and yet, here we are: the alphabet, the multiplication tables, the order of colors in a rainbow …

headline: How to Avoid ‘Mask Breath’
keywords: ['Teeth and Dentistry', 'Tongue', 'Bacteria', 'Toothbrushes and Toothpaste', 'Content Type: Service']
abstract: Treat the real culprit, a buildup of oral bacteria.
lead_paragraph: Treat the real culprit, a buildup of oral bacteria.

abstract: A look at education in America as many students go back to school amid the pandemic.

abstract: Readers urge action on climate change, worry about the economic impact on Napa wineries and praise police officers helping with evacuations.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

abstract: Stelter talks about “Hoax: Donald Trump, Fox News and the Dangerous Distortion of Truth” and Reed Hastings discusses “No Rules Rules: Netflix and the Culture of Reinvention.”
lead_paragraph: Subscribe: iTunes | Google Play Music | How to Listen

headline: Bodies of Evidence
abstract: In her new Crime column, Marilyn Stasio ranges from an Alpine chalet to the sunny streets of Los Angeles to the venerable British city of Bath.
lead_paragraph: What’s a wobble? you ask. In Victorian England, it was a grueling, six-day speedwalking race, a fad that also became popular in America. This eccentric sport inspired Peter Lovesey’s first murder mystery, “Wobble to Death,” originally published in 1970.

headline: He Calls Baseball Games by Ear. Without Fans, His Job Is a Lot Harder.
abstract: Enrique Oliu, a blind radio broadcaster for the Tampa Bay Rays, relies on crowd noise and on-field sounds to do his job. This season, he’s had to adjust more than anyone.
lead_paragraph: The soundtrack of the 2020 baseball season, played amid a pandemic, is undoubtedly different. The pop of the catcher’s mitt, the thwack of the bat and the fervor from the dugouts sound louder without the buffer of tens of thousands of cheering fans.

headline: The Vaccine Challenge: ‘Not Putting All Our Eggs in One Basket’
keywords: ['Vaccination and Immunization', 'Politics and Government', 'Government Contracts and Procurement', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: Anita Anand is out shopping for millions of doses of a coronavirus vaccine that isn’t yet approved to make sure Canada is ready when it finally is.
lead_paragraph: Unless the military is buying a large quantity of something that flies and is very expensive, Canadians don’t pay a lot of attention to the minister of public services and procurement. But the current holder of the job, Anita Anand, is firmly in the national spotlight now, as the leader of the government’s efforts to secure a supply of coronavirus vaccine for Canadians.

headline: Russian Attack Jets Back Mercenaries Fighting in Libya
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Mercenaries and Private Military Contractors']
abstract: An American military official said the warplanes were conducting combat missions in support of Kremlin-backed private security forces, and extending Moscow’s influence in Africa.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — More than a dozen attack jets that Russia sent to Libya this year are conducting ground strikes and other combat missions in support of Russian mercenaries fighting alongside a beleaguered commander in his campaign to oust the government from Tripoli, the capital, a top American military official said on Friday.

headline: Remembering One Tragedy in the Shadow of Another
abstract: This year’s 9/11 ceremony captured not just a city still grieving those lost nearly two decades ago, but one enduring a pandemic that has claimed many more lives.
lead_paragraph: This year’s 9/11 ceremony captured not just a city still grieving those lost nearly two decades ago, but one enduring a pandemic that has claimed many more lives.

headline: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
abstract: Architects think outside the six-foot bubble.
lead_paragraph: Crises, both natural and man-made, have long driven change in architecture and urban planning. In the coronavirus era, when indoor spaces have become danger zones, architects have been tasked with figuring out how to make social gatherings and community activities possible again. The Times recently asked several how they’re thinking outside the six-foot bubble.

headline: Finding a Place for Third-Culture Kids in the Culture
abstract: In his new HBO series, the filmmaker Luca Guadagnino revisits a timeless yet timely question: What does it mean to be from everywhere and nowhere at once?
lead_paragraph: On a blanched, sun-baked afternoon, two teenagers, a boy and a girl, wander into a grocery store to pick up lunch. Fraser is a recent transplant from New York, and Britney a new friend who has lived her life evenly between South Korea, Germany and Italy, though you’d never know it by her American drawl or the pop music she blares through her headphones. To the viewer, the scene presents like quotidian life in the United States — but for the fact that it takes place in Veneto, Italy, on a military base where families work and attend school, their children running off every evening to dance and drink by the cerulean sea alongside their friends from town with whom they scheme and share secrets, whispered in fluent Italian. In a few years, many of them will ready themselves for a move — to another home on another military base in another country, with a supermarket configured to look exactly like this one. “They look the same so you don’t feel lost,” Britney tells Fraser. “Do you ever feel lost?” he asks. She shrugs.

headline: Investigating the Killing of Breonna Taylor
keywords: ['Podcasts', 'Newsletters', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Theater', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)']
abstract: Piecing together new details of her life and death through audio.
lead_paragraph: Listen to ‘The Killing of Breonna Taylor’: Part 1 and Part 2

headline: The Woman Taking Over TikTok at the Toughest Time
keywords: ['Social Media', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Mobile Applications', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: Vanessa Pappas is keeping a focus on the app’s community of creators and users as it deals with pressure from President Trump, Beijing and a possible sale.
lead_paragraph: Six weeks ago, as TikTok grappled with escalating tensions between the United States and China, the social media app’s top executives huddled together to figure out their next steps.

headline: Are You Lying More in the Pandemic? Some Certainly Are
abstract: The rate at which people are lying during the pandemic has increased, experts suggest, perhaps because health-related matters are particularly difficult to share.
lead_paragraph: As much of the United States moves toward reopening in phases, some people are enjoying little bites of pre-pandemic life, such as dining in restaurants, exercising in gyms and learning in classrooms. With the gradual return comes a set of intrusive health questions: Are you experiencing any symptoms? Have you been exposed to anyone who has tested positive for the coronavirus? Answering those questions is where it gets tricky.

headline: George Floyd’s Family Lawyer Pushes Back on Police Claims
keywords: ['Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: The family of George Floyd and their lawyer, Benjamin Crump, rebuked claims from police officers’ defense lawyers that Mr. Floyd died of an overdose.
lead_paragraph: The family of George Floyd and their lawyer, Benjamin Crump, rebuked claims from police officers’ defense lawyers that Mr. Floyd died of an overdose.

headline: Protecting Brazil’s Uncontacted Tribes for 30 Years, Then Killed by an Arrow
abstract: Rieli Franciscato, an expert on the Amazon’s isolated tribes, had been frantically trying to keep safe a group that had ventured out of the forest. He was mistakenly perceived as a threat.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Sightings of the isolated tribes that Rieli Franciscato devoted his career to protecting are rare and fraught with danger.

headline: ‘Covid Will Not Win’: Meet the Force Powering Brooklyn Hospital Center
abstract: During the surge of Covid-19 cases this spring that filled Brooklyn Hospital with the critically ill and the dying, the staff went in day after day, trying to save as many lives as they could. Now they are bracing for a second wave.

headline: Wildfires, Sept. 11, ‘Queer Eye’: Your Friday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Shere Hite, Who Challenged Myths of Female Sexuality, Dies at 77
abstract: Her 1976 book, ‘The Hite Report,’ touched off ‘a revolution in the bedroom’ and has sold tens of millions of copies. But harsh criticism drove her to self-exile in Europe.
lead_paragraph: Shere Hite, who startled the world in the 1970s with her groundbreaking reports on female sexuality and her conclusion that women did not need conventional sexual intercourse — or men, for that matter — to achieve sexual satisfaction, died on Wednesday at her home in London. She was 77.

headline: Top Aide in Review of Russia Inquiry Resigns From Justice Dept.
keywords: ['Special Prosecutors (Independent Counsel)', 'Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'United States Attorneys', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The resignation came amid increasing expectations that the department may disclose partial results from the review before it is completed but ahead of the presidential election.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A top aide to the criminal prosecutor whom Attorney General William P. Barr assigned to scrutinize the Trump-Russia investigation has resigned unexpectedly from the Justice Department, a spokesman said Friday.

headline: Catch the N.F.L.’s Big Return
abstract: For many fans, sports weren’t really back until football kicked off. Well, that moment has arrived.
lead_paragraph: For many fans, sports weren’t really back until football kicked off. Well, that moment has arrived.

headline: A Lifeline to the Jobless Has Problems With Fraud, and With Math
keywords: ['Unemployment Insurance', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Identity Theft', 'Freelancing, Self-Employment and Independent Contracting', 'Unemployment', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Part-Time Employment', 'Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)', 'States (US)']
abstract: An emergency federal program faces growing issues with spurious claims, and the flood of applicants may have led to overcounting the unemployed.
lead_paragraph: Two weeks ago, shortly after she advertised an apartment for rent in the Bay Area, Barbara Lamb found five envelopes from the state’s unemployment office in the building’s communal mail slot. They kept coming, day after day, until a stack of more than 30 piled up, bulging with notices of benefit approvals, questionnaires about job status — and debit cards with money.

headline: Remembering the Presidency of Donald Trump
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: I wish it were a fever dream in my Covid-clouded mind. But, no, our president believes empathy, like patriotic sacrifice, is for suckers.
lead_paragraph: After two weeks of battling Covid-19 — thank you, dear readers, for all the good wishes — I can report that the droning discomfort has passed, some energy has returned, I can taste again, and, for better or worse, I am recovering my personality from whoever hijacked it. I can also certify that the virus is a devilish addition to life on earth. Do not mess with it.

headline: Police Veteran Charged in George Floyd Killing Had Used Neck Restraints Before
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: Derek Chauvin, the officer who is charged with second-degree murder in Mr. Floyd’s death, is expected to go to trial next year.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — The former Minneapolis police officer charged with murder after pressing his knee into the neck of George Floyd for more than eight minutes had used neck and upper body restraints during at least seven previous arrests, prosecutors said in court documents filed this week.

headline: Ex-Felons in Florida Must Pay Fines Before Voting, Appeals Court Rules
abstract: In a reversal, a court said Floridians who had completed sentences for felonies must pay fines and fees before voting. The State Constitution was amended in 2018 to restore their rights.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Four months after a federal judge ruled that it was akin to an unconstitutional poll tax for Florida to require that people with serious criminal convictions pay court fines and fees before they can register to vote, an appeals court narrowly overturned that decision on Friday.

headline: A Fact-Checked List of Trump Accomplishments
abstract: It’s been circulating on social media for months. Here’s what I found when I looked into these claims.
lead_paragraph: This list of President Trump’s accomplishments has been circulating on social media for months and has most likely been viewed by millions of people. I examined each claim to the best of my ability, reaching out to people and institutions who had special insight to see if they considered the claims accurate.

headline: James Jackson, Who Changed the Study of Black America, Dies at 76
abstract: Rather than focus on interracial comparisons, his National Survey of Black Americans explored the complexities within the Black population.
lead_paragraph: James S. Jackson, who changed the way scholars examined Black life in the United States, leading to new insights on health, social support systems and more when he founded the Program for Research on Black Americans at the University of Michigan in 1976, died on Sept. 1 at his home in Ann Arbor, Mich. He was 76.

headline: What I Learned From a List of Trump Accomplishments
keywords: ['Rumors and Misinformation', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Facts are vital. But they are not sufficient.
lead_paragraph: Don’t ask me why, but I’ve spent the past week fact-checking a list of Donald Trump’s accomplishments, as compiled by one of his loyal supporters. OK, if you must know: A friend asked me to because she didn’t believe this list could be true, and she was upset that someone she respected had posted it.

headline: Peru Launches Impeachment Hearings Against President
abstract: A country with the world’s highest death toll per capita from the coronavirus is now also in political crisis, as lawmakers seek to oust President Martín Vizcarra over allegations of obstruction of justice.
lead_paragraph: LIMA, Peru — Peru’s congress voted on Friday to begin impeachment hearings against President Martín Vizcarra over allegations of obstruction of justice, a move that could result in his swift removal from office just as the country faces one of the world’s worst coronavirus outbreaks.

headline: I Take Back Everything I Said About Southwest Louisiana

headline: Dominic Thiem and Alexander Zverev Give U.S. Open a New Look for Final

lead_paragraph: Dominic Thiem has certainly paid his dues in the long-running era of the Big Three. And on Sunday, with Novak Djokovic, Rafael Nadal and Roger Federer all out of the picture, Thiem will get his next and best chance to win his first Grand Slam singles title.

headline: Rockets’ Danuel House Leaves N.B.A. Bubble After Violation

keywords: ['DNA (Deoxyribonucleic Acid)', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Sex Crimes', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Forensic Science']
abstract: Using DNA evidence, the authorities in Rochester, N.Y., said that they had charged Timothy L. Williams of Melbourne, Fla., with murdering Wendy Jerome on Thanksgiving Day in 1984.
lead_paragraph: The last time Wendy Jerome was seen alive she was leaving her home in Rochester, N.Y., to deliver a birthday card to a friend who lived nearby. It was around 7 p.m. on Thanksgiving and Wendy, who was 14, had to be home by an 8 p.m. curfew.

headline: Flip
abstract: Ryan McCarty’s puzzle spins us about a bit.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Time will tell if Ryan McCarty becomes one of these mad scientists who crafts puzzles with ever diminishing numbers of clues — there are 60 today, which go with the pinwheel geometry. Chunky grids indicate low word counts, which makes sense (the pithiest ones, which contain as few as 50 words, start to look very similar). The challenge of low word count goes with themeless puzzles, a more subtle “constructor’s” constraint, if you will, and tends to make for a tough solve.

headline: Films Hit Festivals Trying to Create Buzz Without a Crowd

headline: Toots Hibbert, a Father of Reggae, Is Dead

headline: Why Are We in the West So Weird? A Theory

headline: In This Woodpecker Kingdom, War Is a Spectator Sport
abstract: When prime habitat is up for grabs, acorn woodpeckers travel from all around to see who will win.
lead_paragraph: Acorn woodpeckers are renowned food hoarders. Every fall they stash as many as thousands of acorns in holes drilled into dead tree stumps in preparation for winter. Guarding these “granary trees” against acorn theft is a fierce, familial affair. But all hell breaks loose when there are deaths in a family and newly vacant spots in prime habitat are up for grabs.

headline: In Oregon, a New Climate Menace: Fires Raging Where They Don’t Usually Burn
abstract: The northwest part of the state, usually much wetter, has dried out this year, enabling flames driven by powerful winds to “just explode down these canyons.”

lead_paragraph: The night before her wedding, Maya Posey-Pierre crouched on the living room floor of her Brooklyn apartment watching YouTube tutorials on floral design. She neatly laid out rows of orange and white roses, which she bought in bulk from Trader Joe’s. Armed with floral shears and sheer determination, she got to work.

headline: Who Is Paris Hilton, Really?
abstract: The heiress and proto-influencer says that she spent nearly two decades playing a character. Now she’s ready to be herself.

There were none of the affectations that have defined her public image for two decades: the flat baby voice, the tiny, shimmering outfits, the faux ditziness, the stance that everything cool was “hot.”

But as she was parking her white Toyota Tacoma, she found herself surrounded by several armed men. “What happened? What did I do?” Ms. Flores recalled asking them.

headline: As Both Sides Dig In, What’s the Endgame for Belarus?

keywords: ['Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Coronavirus Risks and Safety Concerns', 'Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Children and Childhood', 'Anxiety and Stress', 'Protective Clothing and Gear', 'Education (K-12)', 'Medicine and Health', 'Parenting', 'Hygiene and Cleanliness']
abstract: Face mask? Check. Hand sanitizer? Got it. Here’s how you can help kids ease back into school this fall.
lead_paragraph: Ever since schools closed last spring, many kids across the country have been excited to get back into the classroom. For some, in-person instruction has already begun — albeit with new precautions: In Vermont, for example, class might take place in the open air, under a tent, while in South Carolina, some students might find their desks separated from their neighbors’ by plexiglass dividers. Elsewhere, cities like New York and Providence, R.I., have delayed the start of the term to better prepare their teachers and facilities for students returning to campus.

The cats wander into my garden, defecating on my plants and attacking the birds and chipmunks. One of them got into my garage and sprayed. How can I get my neighbor to stop feeding these cats? And how can I get them to stop breeding?

headline: Mandela, Gorbachev, Trump? A Disruptive President Plays Peacemaker
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: President Trump seems exceedingly unlikely to receive a call from the Nobel Committee, but all the talk of peace prizes spotlights what has become a core foreign policy message in recent weeks.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Even before President Trump announced a diplomatic breakthrough between Israel and Bahrain on Friday, he had been nominated twice this week alone for the Nobel Peace Prize. The nominations, each from a right-wing Scandinavian politician, were met around the world with a mixture of amusement and dismissal: Much like submitting art or writing for a prize, such a designation doesn’t mean much in itself.

headline: Variety: Acrostic
abstract: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon prepare us for shorter days and longer nights.
lead_paragraph: ACROSTIC — This is one of those public service announcement acrostic puzzles, which I love because they provide scientific evidence that gives credibility to some (usually) human foible that I’ve always wondered about. The excerpt today is from a book called “The Alchemy of Us: How Humans and Matter Transformed One Another,” by Ainissa Ramirez, that covers eight inventions. Clocks and light bulbs are among them, both disrupters of darkness and sleep, and the excerpt concerns an interesting pre-technology sleeping pattern that I had never known of before but which sounds like part of human nature. Isn’t it curious to consider that all those times you woke up a few hours into sleep, raring to finish a task or get a snack, you might have just been following evolutionary orders?

headline: Terence Conran, Designer and Retail Magnate, Is Dead at 88

He was 88.

headline: Another Gulf State Recognizes Israel. Here’s Why It Matters.

headline: A Young Core Carries the Celtics Past the Raptors. But There’s More Work to Do.
abstract: Jayson Tatum, Jaylen Brown and Marcus Smart played like veterans in dethroning the Toronto Raptors.
lead_paragraph: The last time Jayson Tatum, Jaylen Brown and Marcus Smart were in a Game 7, they were up-and-coming youngsters on a 2018 Boston Celtics team that was full of potential going up against LeBron James and the Cleveland Cavaliers. Tatum even famously dunked on James in the fourth quarter of a losing effort — a small taste of his growth to come.

headline: Make a Cube, Then Make a Bigger Cube
abstract: Using modular origami you can turn newspaper into a cube, then create an intricate mathematical puzzle.
lead_paragraph: Sonobe modules follow the rules of traditional modular origami, beginning with a flat square of paper and then combining pieces into structures without tape or glue. The cube that you can make from this simple start is particularly elegant and appealing. It is the same on all six sides and very stable, and it can be combined to make other structures.

headline: Smoke Cloaks Oregon as Wildfires Continue to Spread
abstract: More than a million acres have burned in the state, destroying entire towns and filling the air with dangerous smoke.
lead_paragraph: More than a million acres have burned in the state, destroying entire towns and filling the air with dangerous smoke.

headline: Gene Budig, Last President of the American League, Dies at 81
abstract: After a distinguished academic career, he brought his love of baseball to a position that he considered a dream job — but that was eliminated five years later.
lead_paragraph: Gene Budig, the soft-spoken former chancellor of the University of Kansas who in 1994 became the final president of baseball’s American League, died on Tuesday at his home in Charleston, S.C. He was 81.

headline: What Isn’t Trump’s Fault
abstract: The coronavirus stories that get lost when we focus only on presidential failure.
lead_paragraph: Last weekend, I wrote a column arguing that the blundering of the Trump administration, while real and deadly, may not be responsible for the bulk of America’s coronavirus fatalities. A few days later, courtesy of Bob Woodward’s omniscient tape recorder, we received a reminder of the president’s culpable failures in the pandemic’s early days — which offered ammunition to readers who found my column to be implausible, pro-Trump special pleading or just obtuse.

headline: Why Does Trump Want an Inaccurate Census?
keywords: ['Census', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Redistricting and Reapportionment', 'Executive Orders and Memorandums']
abstract: His effort to stop the census count early, in the middle of a pandemic, is in line with his campaign of exclusion.
lead_paragraph: It’s hard to overstate the importance of the census to everyday life in the United States. The vast amount of demographic information it gathers determines who gets how much political power in Congress and the states; it steers more than a trillion dollars in federal funding for health care and other critical services; it guides long-term economic decisions by governments, corporations and mom-and-pop stores; it helps determine the location of highways and schools, hospitals and housing, police and fire stations.

headline: How Did the ‘Best-Prepared Country’ Become a Horror Story?
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Masks', 'Contact Tracing (Public Health)', 'Tests (Medical)', 'Rationing and Allocation of Resources', 'States (US)', 'Shortages']
abstract: President Trump resisted masks and sidelined experts, with disastrous results.
lead_paragraph: What would America be like today if President Trump had acted decisively in January to tackle the coronavirus, as soon as he was briefed on the danger?

headline: Colorado Official Sues Postal Service Over Election Mailer She Says Misleads Voters
keywords: ['Postal Service and Post Offices', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2020']
abstract: The suit comes as the Postal Service has drawn scrutiny for a mail delivery slowdown that Democrats have charged are part of an effort by President Trump to hobble mail-in voting to bolster his re-election.
lead_paragraph: Colorado’s top election official filed a federal lawsuit on Saturday against the postmaster general and other Postal Service leaders, claiming that a mailer sent to voters in the state was an attempt to disenfranchise them by offering misleading information about how to vote by mail.

headline: SoftBank Said to Be Near Deal to Sell British Chip Designer Arm
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Computer Chips', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues']
abstract: A sale to Nvidia for more than $40 billion would net billions of dollars for the Japanese tech investor and create a powerhouse in the semiconductor industry.
lead_paragraph: SoftBank is near a deal to sell the British chip designer Arm to Nvidia, two people briefed on the matter said on Saturday, which would raise billions for the Japanese technology investor and create a powerhouse in the semiconductor industry.

headline: ‘Nomadland’ Wins Top Prize at the Venice Film Festival
abstract: The first major international movie event since the coronavirus pandemic began drew to a close and handed out its biggest award.
lead_paragraph: “Nomadland,” a film written and directed by Chloé Zhao, won this year’s Golden Lion, the top prize, at the 77th edition of the Venice Film Festival.

headline: Confederate Statue Near Site of White Nationalist Rally in Charlottesville Is Removed
keywords: ['Monuments and Memorials (Structures)', 'Charlottesville, Va, Violence (August, 2017)', 'Right-Wing Extremism and Alt-Right']
abstract: The 111-year-old monument, “At Ready,” includes two cannons and cannonballs. It was near the site of a violent white supremacist rally in 2017 that killed one and injured dozens more.
lead_paragraph: With yellow bands and rope wrapped around its legs, waist and ankles, a Confederate statue in Charlottesville, Va., the site of a violent white supremacist rally in 2017, was removed on Saturday morning from its pedestal at the Albemarle County courthouse after 111 years.

headline: Political Appointees Meddled in C.D.C.’s ‘Holiest of the Holy’ Health Reports
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Research', 'Medicine and Health', 'Academic and Scientific Journals', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Trump loyalists at the Health and Human Services Department have been exerting influence on the Centers for Disease Control’s weekly reports on all disease outbreaks, the coronavirus and beyond.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Political appointees at the Department of Health and Human Services have repeatedly asked the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention to revise, delay and even scuttle weekly reports on the coronavirus that they believed were unflattering to President Trump.

headline: Kevin Dobson, ‘Kojak’ and ‘Knots Landing’ Actor, Dies at 77
abstract: Starting out by working odd jobs while auditioning, he found his greatest success on television playing a detective and a lawyer.
lead_paragraph: Kevin Dobson, the actor best known for playing Telly Savalas’s protégé on “Kojak” and Michelle Lee’s love interest on the prime-time soap opera “Knots Landing,” died on Sept. 6 at a hospital in French Camp, Calif. He was 77.

headline: How to Revisit Your First Date
keywords: ['Dating and Relationships', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Content Type: Service']
abstract: Your relationship might be sorely in need of attention. Why not recreate the special day that sparked it, with an enhancement or three?
lead_paragraph: For many people, the monotony of the last 160-plus days has depleted just about everything. You aren’t alone if you barely recognize yourself, let alone your partner and the special qualities that attracted you to him or her in the first place. Stress and worries over health or financial hardship might have increased, and romance and excitement in your daily life may have disappeared.

headline: Feed a Craving for Eggplants or Italian Film
abstract: This week, take a quick cooking class, stream “Caesar Must Die” and pull back the curtain on an opera company.
lead_paragraph: Here is a sampling of the week’s events and how to tune in (all times are Eastern). Note that events are subject to change after publication.

headline: Sanders Urging Biden to Do More to Excite Progressives
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Bernie Sanders has been sounding more direct notes of caution to the Biden campaign, saying the centrist former vice president should work harder to appeal to young voters and Latinos.
lead_paragraph: Follow our latest coverage of the Biden vs. Trump 2020 election here.

headline: ‘Cuties’ Sparks a Firestorm, Again, After Its Netflix Release
abstract: Several members of Congress have weighed in on the award-winning film, including to call for its removal from Netflix or a Justice Department investigation.
lead_paragraph: Netflix is facing renewed backlash from subscribers and members of Congress after it released the award-winning French film “Cuties” on its platform this week.

headline: Final Offer
abstract: I’m going to bet that MaryEllen Uthlaut’s puzzle gets a laugh or two.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — This is MaryEllen Uthlaut’s third New York Times puzzle, but it’s her Sunday debut and it has been years since those first two grids, so if she was a new name to you then you can sit with me. According to Will Shortz’s print intro, she slipped on a banana peel in the library and caught her balance on a book about puzzles. (Not exactly — she found the book on a random shelf while researching another topic. Still, a funny story for a funny constructor.)

headline: Confederate Statue Removed to Cheers in Charlottesville
abstract: The “At Ready” monument was removed on Saturday by county workers in Charlottesville, Va. It was located near the site of the white supremacist rally in 2017 that killed one and injured dozens.
lead_paragraph: The “At Ready” monument was removed on Saturday by county workers in Charlottesville, Va. It was located near the site of the white supremacist rally in 2017 that killed one and injured dozens.

headline: Trump to Visit California After Criticism Over Silence on Wildfires
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Wildfires', 'Fires and Firefighters']
abstract: The announcement came after the president acknowledged a wildfire season that so far has claimed at least 20 lives and destroyed millions of acres of land in California, Oregon and Washington.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After weeks of public silence about the wildfires devastating the West Coast, President Trump scheduled a visit to California on Monday, where he will join local and federal fire and emergency officials for a briefing on the crisis.

headline: Naomi Osaka, While Rallying for Social Justice, Wins U.S. Open Title
abstract: “The point is to make people start talking,” said Osaka, who wore masks to the court in each of her seven victories bearing the names of Black people who were victims of violence.
lead_paragraph: Naomi Osaka had just come back to secure her second United States Open singles title. She had tapped rackets with Victoria Azarenka, thanked the chair umpire and consulted with a WTA Tour media official about the commitments to come.

headline: AstraZeneca Partly Resumes Coronavirus Vaccine Trial After Halting It for Safety
abstract: The company said tests of its vaccine would start up again in Britain while remaining suspended in the U.S. and other countries. Pfizer, a competitor, announced an expansion of its trials.
lead_paragraph: The pharmaceutical company AstraZeneca said Saturday that it had resumed its coronavirus vaccine trial in Britain after suspending it six days ago over potential safety issues but that its trials in the United States and other countries were still on hold.

headline: For Victoria Azarenka, Disappointment Again, but Plenty of Hope
abstract: Unseeded coming into the U.S. Open and far removed from a time when she was at the top of the women’s game, Azarenka showed how dangerous she could be. Will it stick?
lead_paragraph: For Victoria Azarenka, a surprise United States Open run began to unravel in the seventh game of the second set, the 14th game of a Saturday afternoon final that had been nearly perfect for her from the start.

headline: Stars Are One Win Away From Winning the West
abstract: Anton Khudobin made 32 saves, including stops during a 5-on-3 penalty kill in the third period, in Dallas’s 2-1 win over the Vegas Golden Knights.
lead_paragraph: EDMONTON — Unlike many of the behemoth goaltenders in the modern N.H.L., the Dallas Stars’ Anton Khudobin checks in at just 5 feet 11 inches and 195 pounds. But the 34-year-old has stood tall between the pipes this summer.

headline: California Deputies Shot in Ambush Are Expected to Recover, Authorities Say
keywords: ['Attacks on Police', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: The Los Angeles County deputies were critically injured after being fired upon in their car outside a Metro station in Compton. The gunman remained at large, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: Two deputy sheriffs who were shot multiple times as they sat in a parked patrol car in Los Angeles County on Saturday evening are expected to recover from their injuries, the authorities said Sunday.

headline: 2020 U.S. Open: Men’s Final Preview
abstract: Dominic Thiem and Alexander Zverev will play in the men’s singles final of the United States Open on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: How to watch: Starting at 4 p.m. Eastern time on ESPN in the United States; and streaming on the ESPN app.

headline: Shinzo Abe Vowed Japan Would Help Women ‘Shine.’ They’re Still Waiting.
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Part-Time Employment', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Politics and Government', 'Child Care', 'Hiring and Promotion']
abstract: Female workers remain largely shut out of management jobs, and many take part-time work because of overwhelming family responsibilities, despite policies that Mr. Abe said would elevate their standing in society.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — This was supposed to be the era when Japan finally stepped beyond its centuries of patriarchal dominance and empowered women in the workplace. Prime Minister Shinzo Abe said the country’s prosperity depended on it, and promised policies to help women “shine.” He even gave the push a name: womenomics.

headline: It Was 50 Years Ago Today, the Marathon Came to New York to Stay
abstract: There won’t be a New York City Marathon this year, but we can celebrate the anniversary of the first one, held on Sept. 13, 1970.
lead_paragraph: Many sports fans assume the New York City Marathon has always occurred in October or early November, and always run through the five boroughs. That’s not the case. Indeed, the first New York City Marathon took place entirely within Central Park, and it happened 50 years ago, on Sunday, Sept. 13, 1970.

headline: 4 Podcasts to Help Heal Your Mind
abstract: Use this playlist to learn more about mental health and to understand your own better.
lead_paragraph: In trying times, sorting through your thoughts and emotions can be hard. If you are looking for help, there is no substitute for professional treatment and medical intervention. A self-care podcast may provide supplemental support. There are many programs that guide audiences through meditations, take them into psychologists’ offices or share conversations with experts on mental well-being. These four shows might help you reflect on your feelings or simply provide insights about mental health and the human psyche you didn’t know before.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Mandela. Dalai Lama. Gorbachev. Now Trump?
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, September 13, 2020.
lead_paragraph: “First of all, icicles in hell come to mind. Ain’t gonna happen.”

headline: Corrections: Sunday, Sept. 13, 2020
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Sept. 13, 2020
lead_paragraph: The Markets Last Week chart last Sunday misstated the percentage decline of the price of Apple Inc. stock over the previous week, and erroneously included Apple on a list of that period’s worst-performing stocks. The shares fell 3.1 percent — not 75.8 percent, a figure that failed to take into account the company’s four-to-one stock split.

headline: ‘I Was Enjoying Dinner Alone on My Favorite Boulder in St. Nicholas Park’
abstract: A quiet place on a summer evening, a taste of wine and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: How Kamala Harris’s Immigrant Parents Found a Home, and Each Other, in a Black Study Group
keywords: ['Black People', 'Blacks', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Donald Harris and Shyamala Gopalan grew up under British colonial rule on different sides of the planet. They were each drawn to Berkeley, and became part of an intellectual circle that shaped the rest of their lives.
lead_paragraph: At an off-campus space at the University of California at Berkeley in the fall of 1962, a tall, thin Jamaican Ph.D. student addressed a small crowd, drawing parallels between his native country and the United States.

headline: U.S. Marine Pardoned for Killing Transgender Woman Is Deported From Philippines
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations', 'Transgender and Transsexuals']
abstract: Lance Cpl. Joseph Scott Pemberton was formally deported and flown out on a U.S. military plane. His pardon by President Rodrigo Duterte has drawn anger from activists.
lead_paragraph: MANILA — A U.S. Marine who received a pardon from President Rodrigo Duterte for the killing of a transgender woman was deported from the Philippines on Sunday.

headline: Wildfires, 2020 Election, N.F.L. Sunday: Your Weekend Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: A New Look at the Often Barely United States
abstract: Richard Kreitner talks about “Break It Up,” his new book about deep divisions and secessionist movements throughout American history.
lead_paragraph: In “Break It Up,” his new book about the history of deep divisions and secessionist movements in the United States, Richard Kreitner recalls Hillary Clinton’s concession speech in 2016, when she said that the country must be “more deeply divided than we thought.”

headline: New Cases Have Reached Record Levels in the Midwest
abstract: As new coronavirus cases have dropped nationally, infections have soared in the Midwest.
lead_paragraph: As new coronavirus cases have dropped nationally, infections have soared in the Midwest.

headline: How My 2-Year-Old Planted a Coronavirus Story Idea
keywords: ['Tests (Medical)', 'Children and Childhood', 'Coronavirus Risks and Safety Concerns', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Day Care Centers', 'Parenting']
abstract: After another child at my son’s day care tested positive, I ran into obstacle after obstacle trying to get him a test. I quickly learned I wasn’t alone among concerned parents of young children.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: Homes That Sold for Under $500,000
abstract: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
lead_paragraph: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.

headline: Fever Checks Are No Safeguard Against Covid-19
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Restaurants', 'Coronavirus Risks and Safety Concerns', 'Masks', 'Fever', 'Medicine and Health', 'your-feed-healthcare']
abstract: The practice of taking temperatures is becoming de rigueur in many workplaces and restaurants, even though federal health officials say they are of limited value.
lead_paragraph: In recent weeks, a new cadre of gatekeepers armed with thermometer guns has appeared at the entrances of hospitals, office buildings and manufacturing plants to screen out feverish individuals who may carry the coronavirus.

headline: As Fires Disrupt Schools, ‘the Pandemic Has Actually Helped’
abstract: After wildfires consumed an entire town, students and teachers who had planned for remote classes found some comfort in staying connected amid the chaos.
lead_paragraph: Ash fell from an apocalyptic orange sky as Jennifer Willin drove home last week from the only school in tiny Berry Creek, Calif., where she had picked up a pair of Wi-Fi hot spots for her daughters’ remote classes. Hours later, her cellphone erupted with an emergency alert: Evacuate immediately.

headline: Big Voting Decisions in Florida, Wisconsin, Texas: What They Mean for November
keywords: ['Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Absentee Voting', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Ex-Convicts']
abstract: Less than two months before the election, both parties are waging legal battles around the country over who gets to vote and how.
lead_paragraph: As Democrats and Republicans prepare to fight for votes in the fall general election, recent court decisions in three battleground states illustrate how each side is maneuvering for the best possible legal position to achieve its goals — with Democrats hoping to expand voting to as many citizens as possible and Republicans working to limit it.

headline: Minnesota Seemed Ripe for a Trump Breakout. It Has Not Arrived.
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Voting and Voters', 'George Floyd Protests (2020)']
abstract: Minnesota was a near miss for Donald Trump in 2016. But new polling shows him well behind where he finished four years ago in a state he views as a prime pickup opportunity.
lead_paragraph: DULUTH, Minn. — For a campaign event featuring Donald Trump Jr., the brash-talking, liberal-dunking namesake of the president, it was all rather mundane.

headline: How Old Is This Ancient Vision of the Stars?
keywords: ['Arts and Antiquities Looting', 'ARCHAEOLOGY AND ANTHROPOLOGY', 'Bronze Age', 'Research', 'Space and Astronomy', 'your-feed-science']
abstract: It’s a tale of bronze, iron, looting and archaeological conflict.
lead_paragraph: The Nebra sky disk has been hailed as the oldest known representation of the cosmos. Uncovered by looters in 1999 and then recovered in a sting by archaeologists and law enforcement a few years later, the ancient bronze artifact, inlaid with gold decorations of the night sky, has provoked heated debates.

headline: At U.S.A.I.D., Juggling Political Priorities and Pandemic Response
keywords: ['Humanitarian Aid', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Disasters and Emergencies', 'Ventilators (Medical)']
abstract: Aggressive oversight of the aid agency by political appointees at the White House and the State Department has delayed humanitarian aid when the world needs it most.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The coronavirus was spreading around the world, and officials at the United States Agency for International Development were anxious to rush humanitarian aid to nations in need. But first, they had to settle a debate over American branding and whether it should be displayed on assistance headed to conflict zones.

headline: Dozens Feared Dead as Nepal Landslides Wipe Out Homes
abstract: Many in the region had only just rebuilt homes that were damaged by a powerful 2015 earthquake. The country is also facing an economic crisis brought on by the coronavirus pandemic.
lead_paragraph: KATHMANDU, Nepal — Landslides set off by heavy rainfall this weekend killed at least 11 people and left many more missing in a hilly region of Nepal that borders Tibet, officials said, bringing a renewed crisis to an area that was hit hard by a devastating 2015 earthquake.

headline: Greed Is Good. Except When It’s Bad.
abstract: Fifty years ago today, Milton Friedman published a seminal essay that is still hotly debated in business and policy circles.
lead_paragraph: Sept. 13 is an important date in the world of business. Fifty years ago on that day — today — Milton Friedman published a seminal essay in The New York Times Magazine that is still hotly debated in business and policy circles. DealBook teamed up with The Times Magazine to revisit the legacy of the so-called Friedman Doctrine in a special issue out today in print. This newsletter runs through some of the highlights, along with bonus material and other features to mark the occasion.

headline: The Week in Business: Let’s Call the Whole Thing Off
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)', 'Stimulus (Economic)']
abstract: In a bad week for deals, a new aid bill fizzled in Congress and Tiffany’s sale fell apart.
lead_paragraph: Hi everyone. Here’s your quick catch-up on the latest news in business and tech, plus what you need to know for the week ahead. — Charlotte Cowles

headline: Trial Is Postponed of British-Iranian Woman Held in Iran
abstract: Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe is already serving time after being accused of plotting to overthrow Iran’s government. The case has further strained fraught ties between Britain and Iran.
lead_paragraph: A new trial in Iran to present fresh charges against a British-Iranian woman who has been held in the country since 2016 was postponed at the last minute on Sunday, her husband said.

headline: Review: ‘We Are Who We Are’ Captures Not-So-Innocents Abroad
abstract: Luca Guadagnino’s HBO series is a heady teen drama of hormones and self-discovery on a U.S. Army base in Italy.
lead_paragraph: The supermarket at the U.S. Army base in Chioggia, Italy, looks as if it could be anywhere in the world. That’s exactly the point. As Britney (Francesca Scorsese), a teen living on base, explains it to new kid Fraser (Jack Dylan Grazer), all the military stores like it are precisely alike, down to the same items in the same places in the same aisles. “So we don’t get lost,” she says.

headline: Trump Holds Indoor Rally as White House Officials Try to Defend His Virus Response
abstract: Infections in Britain have spiked back up to levels not seen in months. After a fire razed a refugee camp in Greece, homeless migrants fear what’s next.
lead_paragraph: [Follow our live Covid-19 updates around the globe.]

headline: 50 Years Ago, They Did Something Rare in Gospel: Tied Music to Protest
abstract: The Voices of East Harlem went from community stages to the Isle of Wight Festival, blending the soul-cleansing power of Christian songs with R&B, funk and rock on “Right On Be Free.”
lead_paragraph: The graphic video montage of violence against people of color that accompanies Isaac Cates & Ordained’s sobering neo-spiritual “Hold On” brought the hosts of the 2020 online music festival Vox Virtual nearly to tears. Lydia Salett Dudley commissioned a clip with similarly vivid imagery for “Whatcha Gonna Say?,” a funky song released this summer that commands listeners to speak out about inequality or face the consequences of inaction today and in the afterlife.

headline: The Sunday Read: ‘The Children in the Shadows’
abstract: More than 100,000 of New York City’s public school students lack permanent housing. They are caught in bureaucratic limbo that often seems like a trap.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher

headline: ‘It Is Apocalyptic’: Fear and Destruction Grip the West Coast
abstract: President Trump will fly to California on Monday to assess the wildfires that have killed at least 24 people. In hard-hit Oregon, officials have warned that the death toll could climb.
lead_paragraph: [Follow our live Oregon, California and Washington fires updates.]

headline: What to Cook This Week
abstract: The weather is just starting to turn in some parts of the country. It’s time for the most comforting of stews.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. The weather’s turning where I stay, the close, soft mornings giving way to a little bite, low-pressure fog lingering longer over the bays. Not for me the morning orange and cold glass of coffee I used to love, not these days. My taste runs to eggs, fried soft on a warm tortilla, a steaming cup of tea beside it. It’s time to bulk up. Autumn’s coming, and winter hard behind it.

headline: N.F.L. Week 1: Live Updates From Opening Sunday
abstract: The Saints won the Brees-Brady showdown; the Patriots won their first game with Cam Newton at quarterback; and the 49ers lost a tight battle with the Cardinals.
lead_paragraph: The 49ers quarterback Jimmy Garoppolo ended the last N.F.L. season missing Emmanuel Sanders on a deep throw over the middle in the Super Bowl. He began this one operating an impotent offense that scored 10 points across its final nine possessions and converted 2 of 11 third-down chances.

headline: West Coast Wildfires Burn More Than 4 Million Acres
abstract: More than 20 people have died in massive fires spreading through parts of California, Oregon and Washington.
lead_paragraph: More than 20 people have died in massive fires spreading through parts of California, Oregon and Washington.

headline: Should the SALT Cap on Deductions Be Repealed?
abstract: Readers discuss who benefits and who is harmed by the $10,000 cap on deductions for state and local taxes, and whether progressives should back the repeal.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Decoupling From China: There’s Precedent
abstract: A former U.S. trade negotiator says Japan, India and Australia have already taken steps. Also: Kenosha, my hometown; making the switch to metric.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Empty Seats, Slowly Filled With Energy
abstract: A photographer’s account of covering a U.S. Open unlike any that had come before it.
lead_paragraph: It was depressing. My first United States Open match this year was the men’s doubles final, with Mate Pavic and Bruno Soares playing Wesley Koolhof and Nikola Mektic at Arthur Ashe Stadium. It was supposed to rain, so the roof of the stadium was covered. It was humid, dark, and the resonating noise of machines never stopped. But most of all, the seats were largely empty.

headline: 2 Killed, 6 Injured in Shooting Near Rutgers University
abstract: Video obtained by The New York Times shows four men arriving at the scene in a car and shooting into the area.
lead_paragraph: Two people were killed and six others wounded in a shooting early on Sunday morning that took place blocks away from the Rutgers University campus in New Brunswick, N.J., the authorities said.

headline: Conflicting Virus Data in Texas Raises Distrust of the Government
abstract: Delays, discrepancies and abrupt leaps in coronavirus case and death counts in Texas have baffled residents and frustrated local officials. Here is what has gone awry.
lead_paragraph: Inconsistencies and problems with Covid-19 data collection in Texas have clouded the picture of the pandemic’s trajectory in the state, to the point that some residents and officials say they cannot rely on the numbers to tell them what is really going on.

headline: Review: Four Intimate Screen Encounters (One From Far Away)
abstract: The second grouping of these excellent “Here We Are” monologues includes a raucous report from outer space and a small gem from Lynn Nottage.
lead_paragraph: On the night I watched several of the short plays that make up “Here We Are,” I was at my laptop in the living room while one roommate cooked dinner in the kitchen, just a few feet away, and my other roommate shuffled in and out, doing laundry. Behind me, on the other side of our bay windows, the sounds of Brooklyn wafted in from the street: people chatting, cars going by, dogs barking.

headline: In New Orleans, Recovering From One Storm and Preparing For Another
abstract: Tropical Storm Sally is the latest Gulf storm that seems likely to hit Louisiana as a hurricane this week.

headline: Florence Howe, ‘Mother of Women’s Studies,’ Dies at 91
abstract: In 1970, she helped found the Feminist Press. It was hailed for making available “a legacy of writings by and about women.”
lead_paragraph: Florence Howe, a key architect of the women’s studies movement and a founder of the Feminist Press, a literary nonprofit dedicated to promoting social justice and amplifying overlooked voices, died on Saturday in Manhattan. She was 91.

headline: A Violinist Lost His Seat and His Job. He Blames China.
keywords: ['Classical Music', 'Emojis and Emoticons', 'Social Media', 'Chinese-Americans', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Discrimination']
abstract: In a lawsuit filed in New Jersey, a former member of the well-known Shanghai Quartet said he had been dumped after a remark he made on social media was misinterpreted as an ethnic slur.
lead_paragraph: Yi-Wen Jiang, a violinist who was, until recently, billed as a member of the Shanghai Quartet, an internationally known chamber group with roots in China, says he didn’t give the pig emoji a second thought.

headline: N.F.L. Kicks Off Season With Nods to Unrest and Focus on Anthem

headline: Faces in a Nursing Home
abstract: As I helped feed these residents, I understood how our common humanity makes us ‘infinitely responsible’ to others.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Twenty-five years ago, the philosopher Emmanuel Levinas died in Paris. Born in Lithuania and naturalized in France, Levinas had led weekly Torah readings until shortly before his death just shy of his 90th birthday. I often thought about his age this spring as I worked as a volunteer in a nursing home. Not only was Levinas as old as several of the residents who I helped to feed, but he was engaged in an activity — being with others — denied to the residents since the pandemic burst into their lives. In both his person and his principles, Levinas offers a guide for the crises that now threaten nursing homes.

headline: Don’t Let the Pandemic End a 100-Year-Old Soccer Legacy
abstract: My league played through World War II and 9/11. Why do we have to stop now?
lead_paragraph: Soccer was once the sport of immigrants in a city of immigrants. Now, it’s everyone’s game. The Cosmopolitan Soccer League, one of the oldest continually operating soccer leagues in the country, began life as the German-American Soccer League in 1923. Some of those teams are still around, joined by more than 100 others of all varieties, such as Astoria United, Manhattan Kickers Football Club, Greek-American Atlas Astoria, Williamsburg International and N.Y.P.D. Finest.

There were mixed and confusing messages back at the beginning of the pandemic, then political discussion that got in the way of sane public health decision-making, as well as circulating disinformation, anger, and a certain amount of shaming and finger-pointing, by those who wanted masks and by those who didn’t. But evidence keeps accumulating that masks help keep us all safer.

headline: The Outrage Diet
