headline: House Hunting in Austria: Skiing Heaven in the Austrian Alps for $1.5 Million
abstract: In the Salzburg area, low supply and a revived seller’s market are keeping the inventory moving.
lead_paragraph: This four-bedroom penthouse sits on a plateau at the foot of the Grossvenediger, an 11,700-foot glacier-topped mountain that looms over the village of Neukirchen am Grossvenediger, in the Austrian Alps.

headline: A Republican inquiry into Hunter Biden and Ukraine finds no evidence of wrongdoing by his father.
abstract: An election-year investigation by Senate Republicans into corruption allegations against Joseph R. Biden Jr., the Democratic presidential nominee, and his son, Hunter, involving Ukraine found no evidence of improper influence or wrongdoing by the former vice president, bringing to a close a highly politicized inquiry they hoped would tarnish President Trump’s rival.

Biden Jr., the Democratic presidential nominee, and his son, Hunter, involving Ukraine found no evidence of improper influence or wrongdoing by the former vice president, bringing to a close a highly politicized inquiry they hoped would tarnish President Trump’s rival.

headline: Theater to Stream: Catty Birthdays and ‘Lessons in Survival’
abstract: In a fall season without many live shows, everything is up for grabs. That includes the canon of classics — and where Bill Irwin might be performing.
lead_paragraph: Every September, stages around the country spring back to life after the summer slowdown. This year, however, all usual bets are off as theaters ponder not just their fall seasons, but what exactly constitutes a season — as opposed to an assemblage of ad hoc programming.

headline: Gale Sayers Dies; Elusive Hall of Fame Running Back Was 77
abstract: Though his career was cut short by injuries, he was regarded as one of the N.F.L.’s greatest players. The movie “Brian’s Song” spread his name beyond the sports world.
lead_paragraph: Gale Sayers, the will-o’-the-wisp running back who in a short but brilliant career with the Chicago Bears left opponents, as they used to say, clutching at air, died early on Wednesday at his home in Wakarusa, Ind. He was 77.

headline: How Lenny Kravitz Keeps His Cool
keywords: ['Pop and Rock Music', 'Books and Literature', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Content Type: Personal Profile']
abstract: In a new memoir, the rock musician breaks down the first 25 years of his life, when he found his sound, his voice and his commitment to love and nonviolence.
lead_paragraph: In “Let Love Rule,” his new memoir, Lenny Kravitz recounts the first 25 years of his life, ending with the release of his debut album in 1989. The story he tells isn’t about stardom (that will come next, he says), but about the influences that inspired his distinctive musical hybrid of soul and classic rock.

headline: Come to Vote, Stay for the Art
keywords: ['Art', 'Museums', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Murals', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: In California, the Institute of Contemporary Art San José will open for voting, with a mural by Amir H. Fallah on display.
lead_paragraph: While many California museums are still shuttered because of the coronavirus, and others are opening slowly at limited capacity, the Institute of Contemporary Art San José has come up with an ingenious solution to open the museum, legally, for four days.

headline: We’ll Have to Learn to Live With Smoke. Here’s Why.
abstract: There’s a huge fire debt in the West that must be paid off, experts say, either through controlled burns or out-of-control blazes. Either way, that means smoke.
lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Ore. — For a full week this month, my family did not leave our house here in this famously outdoorsy city. At times, smoke from the state’s huge wildfires made it hard to see to the end of the block. Sometimes, we could barely see across the street.

headline: 356 Elephants Dropped Dead. Did This Bacteria Poison Them?
keywords: ['Elephants', 'Wildlife Die-Offs', 'ALGAE', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances', 'Conservation of Resources', 'Laboratories and Scientific Equipment', 'your-feed-science', 'your-feed-animals']
abstract: Some conservationists accepted the explanation provided by Botswana’s government, but others raised doubts.
lead_paragraph: In May and June, conservationists discovered the carcasses of 356 elephants in Botswana’s Okavango Panhandle. Some of the animals appeared to have collapsed and died suddenly, while walking or running. Others seemed disoriented, walking in circles before they died.

headline: 10 Unusual Streaming Movies for Unusual Times
abstract: Looking for a few fresh and different streaming options? We offer some assistance.
lead_paragraph: In normal times, the shift into fall would mean film festivals jockeying for marquee premieres and prestige Oscar hopefuls filling the multiplexes and art houses. Instead, we’re still watching movies from home, and while this month’s crop of out-of-the-box streaming service picks may not have any festival laurels, there’s plenty of blood-soaked vengeance and uncorked sexuality to dig into instead.

headline: Three Cheers for Melissa Clark
abstract: Back in March, she began a column specific to the pandemic. Now it’s time to end it.
lead_paragraph: Back in March, when everyone was freaking out about having enough flour and beans to last through quarantine, Melissa Clark started writing From the Pantry, a series of articles meant to ease readers of The New York Times through the business of cooking more regularly and more flexibly, using what ingredients they had to hand. She did this every day, for weeks, then regularly thereafter, 60-odd recipes developed on the fly, a brilliant run of creativity.

headline: Ron Cobb, a Pioneer in Science Fiction Design, Dies at 83

lead_paragraph: Ron Cobb, the artist and movie production designer known for his work on the spaceship in “Alien,” the DeLorean in “Back to the Future,” and some tipsy aliens in “Star Wars,” died on Sept. 21 in Sydney, Australia. He was 83.

headline: United States is the richest country in the world, and it has the biggest wealth gap.

lead_paragraph: The United States led the world in growth of financial assets last year thanks to tax cuts and booming stock markets, but its distribution of wealth was more unequal than in any other country, according to a study published Wednesday.

headline: Democrats, You Can’t Count On the Hispanic Vote
keywords: ['Hispanic-Americans', 'Minorities', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: President Trump’s standing is as strong as it has ever been.
lead_paragraph: Democrats are counting on Hispanics to help them win the White House on Nov. 3, but they may be in for a surprise. Though I’ve been a conservative most of my life, I didn’t vote for Donald Trump in 2016 and won’t this year either. But I understand why his brand of populism and appeal to religious voters has struck a chord not just with white voters and evangelicals but also with Hispanics, who will likely make up 13 percent of voters in November.

headline: The Nose Needed for This Coronavirus Test Isn’t Yours. It’s a Dog’s.
abstract: Several animals now working on a trial at Helsinki’s airport have been trained to detect the virus by scent on arriving passengers.
lead_paragraph: Travelers arriving at Helsinki’s airport are being offered a voluntary coronavirus test that takes 10 seconds with no uncomfortable nasal swab needed. And the test is done by a dog.

headline: The Metropolitan Opera Won’t Reopen for Another Year
abstract: The nation’s largest performing arts organization, shut by the coronavirus pandemic, sends a chilling signal that American cultural life is still far from resuming.
lead_paragraph: The Metropolitan Opera announced Wednesday that the still-untamed coronavirus pandemic has forced it to cancel its entire 2020-21 season, prolonging one of the gravest crises it has faced in its 137-year history and keeping it dark until next September.

headline: Capturing How Ruth Bader Ginsburg Was Honored in Washington
abstract: The justice was mourned and celebrated at the Supreme Court and the Capitol over three days.
lead_paragraph: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg lay in state at the Capitol on Friday, the first woman and the first Jewish American to be given the honor. The justice, who died on Friday at 87, was honored with a private ceremony in Statuary Hall, where lawmakers and other dignitaries later took turns paying their respects. The women of Congress lined the steps of the Capitol as her coffin was carried out one final time.

headline: Jackie Stallone, Celebrity Astrologer and Sylvester’s Mother, Dies at 98
abstract: After running away with the circus, she promoted women’s wrestling and fitness before seeing signs of the future in a most unusual spot. (Hint: it’s not the palm.)
lead_paragraph: Jackie Stallone, the matriarch of a celebrity family who became something of a celebrity in her own right as an astrologer, died on Monday at her home in Los Angeles. She was 98.

headline: Getting Climate Into the Presidential Debates
abstract: Also this week, learning to live with smoke. And, climate experts talk about the future.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the Climate Fwd: newsletter, and thanks to everyone who made the latest Netting Zero, our series of virtual events looking ahead to key international climate negotiations next year, a big success! The panel focused on cities trying to become carbon-neutral. If you missed it, don’t despair. You can watch a recording here.

headline: ‘A Wilderness of Error’ Review: Errol Morris in the Fog of Murder
abstract: The famous documentary maker sits on the other side of the camera to offer his own take on the Jeffrey R. MacDonald murder case.
lead_paragraph: “A Wilderness of Error” is not, technically, a new Errol Morris documentary. But the five-part FX series (premiering with three episodes on Friday) begins with a clapperboard in front of Morris’s face, and he’s the star of the show, as well as its secondary subject and, perhaps, slightly guilty conscience.

headline: A Kids’ Vaccine Isn’t Coming Anytime Soon

lead_paragraph: Walmart’s planned investment in TikTok is being called “transformative.” Another analyst predicted the deal could “redefine retail” across the industry. “It is a bigger-picture opportunity,” said Oliver Chen, a retail analyst at Cowen.

headline: Gillian Flynn Takes Her Paranoia to Television
abstract: With “Utopia,” the best-selling novelist makes her debut as a TV showrunner. But anyone who knows her from “Gone Girl” or “Sharp Objects” might be surprised by what they see.
lead_paragraph: Gillian Flynn grew up surrounded by comics. Her father, a film professor and an avid comic book collector, would spend weekends taking her to flea markets and garage sales, explaining the various eras and artists she should know, which strip was loosely based on a Ray Bradbury story, and so on.

headline: 2 Officers Shot in Louisville Protests Over Breonna Taylor Charging Decision
keywords: ['Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']

headline: How Trump’s Race-Baiting Lets Liberals Off the Hook
abstract: It’s easy to condemn the president’s rhetoric about the suburbs. But white progressives play their own roles in keeping communities segregated.
lead_paragraph: On the last day of August, the Fox News host Laura Ingraham interviewed President Trump on her show, “The Ingraham Angle.” Five weeks earlier, Trump endured a half-hour interview with the Axios political reporter Jonathan Swan, who grilled Trump about Covid-19 with the kind of disdain economics professors reserve for a graduate student who botches the calculation. Ingraham was the anti-Swan, fawning and pat. Leaning forward in her chair with a warm expression, she tossed softballs and gently guided the president back on track when he veered into politically risky territory.

headline: M.L.B. Awards: In a Short Season, Veterans Are Standing Out
abstract: The top contenders for baseball’s annual awards include two 30-somethings who could take home the Most Valuable Player Awards.
lead_paragraph: A typical baseball schedule is merciless — six weeks of spring training followed by six months of games, with few days off and many thousands of air miles. The advantage for younger players shows up in the list of Most Valuable Player Award winners; it has been 13 years since anyone started a season in his 30s and won the M.V.P.

headline: Progressives Defeat Brooklyn Project That Promised 20,000 Jobs
abstract: The developers behind Industry City abandoned a rezoning proposal after left-leaning Democrats raised concerns about gentrification.
lead_paragraph: It was slated to be one of the biggest real estate projects in New York City in years, a major expansion of the Industry City complex on the Brooklyn waterfront that could have created as many as 20,000 jobs at a time when local unemployment has soared because of the pandemic.

headline: Saudi King, in First U.N. Speech, Assails Longtime Nemesis Iran
abstract: King Salman of Saudi Arabia used his speech to brand Iran as a force for chaos in the Middle East, but he addressed none of his country’s own controversies.
lead_paragraph: At the United Nations General Assembly’s week of speeches this year, the diplomatic forum has felt more like a film playing to a largely empty theater.

headline: M.L.B.’s Unusual Postseason: 16 Teams, Neutral Sites and No Days Off
abstract: This will be one of the most unusual Octobers in memory for Major League Baseball. Here’s a primer to all the changes to the playoff format.
lead_paragraph: This is not your grandfather’s postseason. In the 1950s, when the teams with the best record in each league advanced directly to the World Series, baseball staged only 61 postseason games over the entire decade. This fall alone, there could be as many as 65.

headline: Heat and Drought Team Up More Frequently, With Disastrous Results
abstract: A new study finds that what used to be a rare weather double whammy has been occurring more frequently in recent decades because of climate change.
lead_paragraph: The combination of drought conditions and heat waves, which can make wildfires more likely, is becoming increasingly common in the American West, according to a new study. The results may be predictably disastrous.

headline: We Want to Hear From You: How Would You Change the Supreme Court?
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: We invite readers to offer ideas about the nomination process and the composition of the court.
lead_paragraph: What do you think about the way Supreme Court justices are now chosen, and how the court functions? What changes, if any, would you like to see? Would you prefer term limits for justices, for instance, or do you think the size of the court should be increased?

headline: The Home Schoolfluencers
abstract: You don’t need Google Classroom, says Ainsley Arment, the founder of Wild + Free, a home-schooling community. Just nature, literature and a community of patient “mamas.”
lead_paragraph: Many home-schoolers feel misunderstood. People assume they’re religious adherents, hippies or anti-technologists who distrust institutions, when, in fact, they have a wide range of backgrounds and motives.

abstract: Dispatches from around the country as a grim milestone is reached.

headline: Judge Orders Eric Trump to Testify in N.Y. Fraud Inquiry

headline: E.P.A. Rejects Its Own Findings That a Pesticide Harms Children’s Brains
keywords: ['Environment', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances', 'Pesticides', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Children and Childhood', 'Babies and Infants']
abstract: The agency’s new assessment directly contradicts federal scientists’ conclusions five years ago that chlorpyrifos can stunt brain development in young children.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration has rejected scientific evidence linking the pesticide chlorpyrifos to serious health problems, directly contradicting federal scientists’ conclusions five years ago that it can stunt brain development in children.

headline: Experts Warn a Rare Pediatric Condition May Re-emerge This Fall
keywords: ['Acute Flaccid Myelitis', 'Content Type: Service', 'Fever', 'Parenting', 'Enterovirus 68', 'Therapy and Rehabilitation', 'Physical Therapy', 'Brain', 'Children and Childhood']
abstract: There’s no cure for acute flaccid myelitis, or A.F.M., but early detection is key for better outcomes.
lead_paragraph: In the fall of 2018, all three of Mallory Bradley’s kids became sick. Her sons, aged 8 and 2, ran low fevers for a couple of days, but were soon back to normal, running around their new house in Norfolk, Virginia. Then Ryleigh, Bradley’s 3-year-old daughter, spiked a high fever, and oddly, seemed floppy and unsteady. A kid that usually ran with confidence was suddenly listing and weaving across the playroom — Bradley knew something was wrong.

headline: How Memes and a Good Laugh Can Help People in Recovery
keywords: ['Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Alcohol Abuse', 'Comedy and Humor', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Social Media', 'Content Type: Service', 'your-feed-selfcare']
abstract: Meme accounts like @dankrecovery and @brutalrecovery use dark humor to help those struggling with addiction.
lead_paragraph: Timothy Kavanagh, 36, a recovering heroin addict and addictions counselor, was in his second year of sobriety when his brother was killed in a drunk-driving accident. “I went into an overwhelming state of depression,” he said. “Finding recovery memes helped me get through it.”

headline: Biden Could Be Our Second Catholic President. Does It Matter?
keywords: ['Liberalism (US Politics)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Discrimination', 'ABORTION', 'Presidential Election of 2020']
abstract: With John F. Kennedy in 1960, Catholic America achieved a long-sought victory and lost something in return.
lead_paragraph: As Election Day approached 60 years ago, Catholics across the country followed the news with a nervous thrill of anticipation. For them, the final stage of a long struggle was at hand: An Irish Catholic was poised to become president of the United States, ending the historic Protestant monopoly on the White House — and on mainstream, middle-class respectability.

headline: Justice Dept. Urges Congress to Limit Tech’s Legal Shield
keywords: ['Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Law and Legislation', 'Computers and the Internet', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Social Media', 'Censorship']

lead_paragraph: Johnson & Johnson has begun the final stage of clinical trials for a coronavirus vaccine that could have a big advantage over its competitors: It would require just one shot instead of two.

headline: U.S. Rationale for Military Aid to Saudis in Yemen War Is Fraying
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Civilian Casualties', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Arms Trade', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The Trump administration argues that its partnership with Saudi Arabia helps reduce civilian killings in Yemen. But State Department investigators and other U.S. officials say the efforts are flawed.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When challenged over why the United States has continued to assist Saudi Arabia and other Gulf Arab nations in a bombing campaign that has killed thousands of civilians in Yemen, Trump administration officials have often responded that American involvement is helping to hold down unnecessary casualties by advising the Saudis and their allies on targeting and rules of engagement.

headline: Naomi Biden writes a personal tribute to her father, Hunter, after politicized Senate report.
abstract: Hours after the release on Wednesday of a Republican inquiry into corruption allegations regarding Hunter Biden, which found no evidence of wrongdoing, his daughter Naomi posted a series of heartfelt messages on Twitter attempting to show a more personal side of her father.
lead_paragraph: Hours after the release on Wednesday of a Republican inquiry into corruption allegations regarding Hunter Biden, which found no evidence of wrongdoing, his daughter Naomi posted a series of heartfelt messages on Twitter attempting to show a more personal side of her father.

headline: Secrets of the Most Thankless N.B.A. Job: Referee
abstract: A 17-year veteran N.B.A. referee discusses blown calls, player beefs and the timeless question: Do superstars get special treatment?
lead_paragraph: The referee Zach Zarba had spent, by his count, roughly 23 nights a month away from home during the N.B.A.’s regular season for the past 17 years. Then the coronavirus pandemic hit, and the league suspended its season in March.

headline: Museum Fires Curator Who It Says Sexually Harassed Student Researcher
abstract: The American Museum of Natural History acted after investigators it hired reviewed a complaint filed against an expert on invertebrate zoology.
lead_paragraph: A scientist who is a leading expert on leeches was fired this month from his curator’s post at the American Museum of Natural History after the museum found that he had sexually harassed and bullied a graduate student who was doing research under his supervision.

headline: California Plans to Ban Sales of New Gas-Powered Cars in 15 Years
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Automobiles', 'Fuel Emissions (Transportation)', 'Electric and Hybrid Vehicles', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Executive Orders and Memorandums']
abstract: The proposal would speed up the state’s efforts to fight global warming at a time when California is being battered by wildfires, heat waves and other consequences of climate change.
lead_paragraph: California plans to ban the sale of new gasoline-powered cars statewide by 2035, Gov. Gavin Newsom said Wednesday, in a sweeping move aimed at accelerating the state’s efforts to combat global warming amid a deadly and record-breaking wildfire season.

headline: Maybe the Best Home School Is … on a Boat?

headline: Listening Closely to the Birds
abstract: What comprises the soundscape where you are?
lead_paragraph: Welcome. Pre-dawn, the sounds in the house are few and predictable: the refrigerator lurching to a hum, then off again; the steam knocking in the pipes. This morning, however, the pigeons, delirious with the expanse of dark that was all theirs, thrashed against the windows, landed with thuds on the A/C units. On purpose? By accident? I imagine them sleepy and clumsy, or else showing off to one another, their morning calisthenics.

headline: Poem: About the Dead Man’s Recent Dreams
abstract: The "dead man poems" Marvin Bell has been writing for more than a quarter century take on a collective shadow presence when read during a pandemic.
lead_paragraph: The poet Marvin Bell has been writing “dead man poems” for more than a quarter century, beginning at age 53. His recent generous volume, “Incarnate: The Collected Dead Man Poems,” brings together four previous collections and adds 26 new poems. In one poem, the dead man is described as “perspective itself, the universal fixed to a pinpoint. …” Elsewhere Bell has written that these poems are for those “who know they are living in the pre-posthumous.” Read during a pandemic, they take on a collective shadow presence: Could be us. May be us. How many we never knew are now gone from our communities, but how much light still radiates? While the Zen admonition — Live as if you were already dead — may embody a lively challenge, these poems, too, tip their hats with greatest respect and fanciful care for the living mystery that holds us all. Selected by Naomi Shihab Nye

headline: I Am Not a Housewife. I’m a Prepper.
abstract: Survivalism can be less about guns and ammo, and more about homemaking and community resilience.
lead_paragraph: Before the pandemic, I was working on a book about doomsday preppers — people who are actively preparing for the end of the world, or at least major disruptions to our comfortable daily lives. Starting out, my idea of prepping matched the stereotype I’d so often seen: the prepper as a rural, military-minded dude who gathers canned food, guns and ammo, and heads to the hills to wait out the zombie apocalypse.

headline: A Manly Response to Disease
abstract: A conventional model of masculinity inhibits some men from expressing their emotional responses to assaults on the body.
lead_paragraph: While learning this spring that the coronavirus was taking a disproportionate toll on men, I was reading David Lehman’s account of his bladder cancer, a disease that also disproportionately afflicts men. His brilliantly circumspect 2019 memoir, “One Hundred Autobiographies,” reminded me that a conventional model of masculinity inhibits some men from expressing their emotional responses to assaults on the body.

headline: David Chang’s Memoir, ‘Eat a Peach,’ Provides Food for Thought
abstract: The restaurateur, television personality and podcast host lays his life on the table with bracing candor.
lead_paragraph: FROM SOUP TO GUTS In 2004, the chef David Chang put himself on the culinary map when he opened his first restaurant, Momofuku Noodle Bar, in Manhattan’s East Village. Epicureans flocked there to feast on what was described in the Times as Americanized ramen, “served with a generous helping of impossibly tender braised pork, peas, bamboo shoots, a poached egg — a vast improvement on the traditional hard-boiled egg — and, of course, noodles.”

headline: Gavin Newsom: ‘We Decided to Pull the Band-Aid Off’
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Executive Orders and Memorandums', 'Electric and Hybrid Vehicles', 'Fuel Emissions (Transportation)', 'Automobiles', 'Federal-State Relations (US)', 'Wildfires', 'Forests and Forestry', 'Relocation of Business']
abstract: Twenty months into his term, California’s governor faces a pandemic and an environmental crisis. He speaks to Kara Swisher about his plan to save the “state of resistance.”
lead_paragraph: On this episode of “Sway,” Kara Swisher speaks to Gavin Newsom, a governor who is, by some measures, running a country. California is the world’s fifth-largest economy. And now, the state has joined the ranks of Britain, Denmark and Germany with an ambitious environmental order banning the sale of new gasoline-powered cars by 2035.

headline: Accustomed to Helping Others, They Now Find Themselves in Need
abstract: In pandemic’s grip, concerns about food insecurity are compounded for older Americans.
lead_paragraph: Until March, Gabriel and Constancia Merrill had both worked to provide food to seniors, she preparing the meals and he delivering them.

headline: This Is the Casual Racism That I Face at My Elite High School
abstract: Unexpectedly, the school did something about it.
lead_paragraph: Starting senior year in the middle of a pandemic has brought on more challenges than ever: Navigating college applications and maintaining my G.P.A. while dealing with Zoom burnout and no physical connection to my friends.

headline: Even When They Lost Their Jobs, Immigrants Sent Money Home
abstract: Predictions were that immigrants would stop sending money home when the coronavirus took their jobs. But that did not take into account how determined foreign workers were to help their families.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Jesus Perlera’s pay from hauling shipping containers to and from the port of Oakland, Calif., plummeted in the spring as the coronavirus pandemic ravaged business. But, through the shaky months, the self-employed trucker never stopped sending money to his mother in El Salvador. “If I don’t support her,” he said, “how will she eat?”

headline: The Ugly (and Glorious) Truth About American Supermarkets
abstract: In his new book, “The Secret Life of Groceries,” Benjamin Lorr argues that the kale chips and shade-grown coffee sold at supermarkets define who we are.
lead_paragraph: “On the one hand, the supermarket is the most banal, mundane place,” said Benjamin Lorr, the author of the new book, “The Secret Life of Groceries: The Dark Miracle of the American Supermarket,” standing in the produce aisle of a Trader Joe’s in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, a short stroll from his apartment.

headline: Whole Foods Founder: ‘The Whole World Is Getting Fat’
keywords: ['Supermarkets and Grocery Stores', 'Capitalism (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Food', 'Executives and Management (Theory)', 'Corporate Social Responsibility']
abstract: John Mackey, who espouses a high-minded version of capitalism, sold his upscale grocery chain to Amazon.
lead_paragraph: For the better part of the past decade, the Whole Foods founder John Mackey, a libertarian and health food enthusiast, has been preaching the redemptive power of what he calls “conscious capitalism.” As he tells it, when businesses find their true purpose and serve not just investors, but all stakeholders, everyone wins.

headline: Breonna Taylor Deserved Justice
keywords: ['Black People', 'Blacks', 'Discrimination', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: No police officer will have to answer for her death. This never gets easier.
lead_paragraph: Kentucky’s attorney general, Daniel Cameron, announced Wednesday that one police officer would be charged, not in the shooting death of Breonna Taylor, but with endangering her neighbors with reckless gunfire. “If we simply act on emotion or outrage, there is no justice. Mob justice is not justice,” Mr. Cameron said, in an apparent attempt to explain the lack of more serious charges relating to the 26-year-old’s killing. “Justice sought by violence is not justice. It just becomes revenge.”

headline: Beyond the Pandemic, Libraries Look Toward a New Era
keywords: ['Libraries and Librarians', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Books and Literature', 'Computers and the Internet', 'E-Books and Readers', 'ARCHITECTURE', 'Book Trade and Publishing']
abstract: With a shift to online resources well underway, “the most trusted civic institutions” are in a good position to deal with the changing future.
lead_paragraph: Many companies and public institutions were unprepared for the pandemic and the ensuing lockdown. There was one notable, perhaps even surprising, exception: the nation’s public libraries.

headline: The Future of Airbnb
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Coronavirus Reopenings']
abstract: Home-sharing’s challenges aren’t only about social distancing and hygiene. Overtourism, racial bias, fee transparency and controlling the party crowd are also in the mix.
lead_paragraph: In the travel wreckage caused by the pandemic, home-sharing has emerged as battered, but with a steady pulse, as rental houses became social-distancing refuges for the travel-starved.

headline: U.S. Prepares to Take Sudan Off List of States That Support Terrorism
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Terrorism', 'Cole (USS)', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates']
abstract: Coming before the election, the move would give President Trump another chance to broker diplomacy on Israel’s behalf. But it could be at the cost of compensation for terrorism victims.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration is preparing to remove Sudan from a list of states that sponsor terrorism, seeking another foreign policy victory before the election but putting at risk the compensation for victims of terrorist attacks that American courts have concluded were carried out with Khartoum’s support.

headline: A Quadriplegic, a Specialty Van and a Lifetime of Adventures
abstract: A biking accident left Kirk Williams paralyzed, but he has traveled widely and inspired others to follow in his tire tracks.
lead_paragraph: Kirk Williams loved racing mountain bikes and “enjoyed playing on anything that had a motor,” he said.

headline: Trump Says He Will ‘Always’ Protect Those With Pre-Existing Conditions. He Hasn’t.
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Executive Orders and Memorandums', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The president’s promises on health care stand in stark contrast with his legislative, regulatory and legal record.
lead_paragraph: In speeches, in tweets, in media interviews, President Trump keeps promising that he will preserve protections for Americans with pre-existing health conditions. He recently signed an executive order committing to the notion. It’s a crowd-pleaser of a policy, but one entirely at odds with his administration’s legislative, regulatory and legal record to date.

headline: Few Police Officers Who Cause Deaths Are Charged or Convicted
abstract: A wide gulf remains between the public perception of police violence and how it is treated in court.
lead_paragraph: Since Breonna Taylor was awakened in the night and shot to death by the police in her own home, Louisville has banned no-knock warrants. A police chief was fired, and so was an officer who was on the scene. But despite demands from across the country, no one was charged in Ms. Taylor’s death.

headline: In Politically Charged Inquiry, Durham Sought Details About Scrutiny of Clintons
keywords: ['Special Prosecutors (Independent Counsel)', 'Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods', 'Cyberwarfare and Defense', 'Corruption (Institutional)']
abstract: John Durham’s team has sought information about the F.B.I.’s handling of the Clinton Foundation investigation, raising questions about the scope of the prosecutor’s review.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — From the beginning, John H. Durham’s inquiry into the Russia investigation has been politically charged. President Trump promoted it as certain to uncover a “deep state” plot against him, Attorney General William P. Barr rebuked the investigators under scrutiny, and he and Mr. Durham publicly second-guessed an independent inspector general and traveled the globe to chase down conspiracy theories.

headline: Trump Faces Challenges Even in Red States, Poll Shows, as Women Favor Biden
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Voting and Voters', 'Women and Girls', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Close races in Georgia, Iowa and Texas show President Trump’s vulnerability and suggest that Joseph Biden has assembled a formidable coalition, according to a New York Times/Siena College poll.
lead_paragraph: President Trump is on the defensive in three red states he carried in 2016, narrowly trailing Joseph R. Biden Jr. in Iowa and battling to stay ahead of him in Georgia and Texas, as Mr. Trump continues to face a wall of opposition from women that has also endangered his party’s control of the Senate, according to a poll conducted by The New York Times and Siena College.

headline: 17 New Books to Watch For in October
abstract: New biographies shed light on Malcolm X, Sylvia Plath and the Beatles, plus the latest fiction from Tana French, Martin Amis, Sayaka Murata and more.
lead_paragraph: After it was founded in 2010, WeWork seemed poised to change work culture around the world, attracting interest from high-profile investors and expanding at a breakneck pace. The company’s flaws have been well-reported, and ultimately, it’s a story of 21st-century boom and bust. Wiedeman, a contributing editor at New York magazine, has written a satisfying ticktock of the company’s rapid rise and crash, culminating in its disastrous I.P.O. in 2019 and Neumann’s ouster.

headline: What Will It Take to Vote in Milwaukee?
keywords: ['Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Absentee Voting', 'Content Type: Service', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Hispanic-Americans']
abstract: The coronavirus has added strain to Wisconsin voters already facing challenges to ballot access.
lead_paragraph: MILWAUKEE — For 15 years, Johnny Miller worked the polls at a church on Milwaukee’s North Side. He was born in Mississippi, where, he said, his family was terrorized by the Ku Klux Klan for attempting to cast ballots. This background makes him feel “a deep historical tie with trying to get people to vote.”

headline: Times Square, Grand Central and the Laws That Build the City
keywords: ['Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Land Use Policies', 'Eminent Domain', 'Area Planning and Renewal', 'ARCHITECTURE', 'Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Privately Owned Public Spaces', 'Parks and Other Recreation Areas', 'Zoning']
abstract: A virtual tour looks at the legal battles and innovations behind 42nd Street. Our critic chats with the Harvard professor Jerold S. Kayden.
lead_paragraph: Designers design buildings. Engineers engineer them. But the law is New York’s foundational architect and building block.

headline: Home Sales Surge in Brooklyn
abstract: Six months into the pandemic, inventory is up in Manhattan while buyers are heading to Brooklyn for more space and lower prices.
lead_paragraph: While Manhattan’s real estate market continued to reel in August, Brooklyn had a near-record number of contract signings, spurred by bargain hunting New Yorkers and pent-up demand from months under quarantine.

headline: China Has a New Plan to Tame Tibet
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Forced Labor', 'Minorities', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'Nomadic People', 'Han Chinese (Ethnic Group)', 'Religion and Belief', 'Chinese Language']
abstract: It failed to coax cultural assimilation with economic incentives. Now it’s going for coerced labor and micromanaging people’s very lifestyles.
lead_paragraph: Before Xinjiang, there was Tibet. Repressive policies tested there between 2012 and 2016 were then applied to the Uighurs and other ethnic minorities in northwestern China: entire cities covered in surveillance cameras, ubiquitous neighborhood police stations, residents made to report on one another.

headline: Harold Evans Dies at 92; Crusading Newspaperman With a Second Act
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'News and News Media', 'Newspapers', 'Book Trade and Publishing', 'Magazines']
abstract: In Britain, he helped redefine high-quality newspapers and challenged legal restrictions on the press. In America, he brought new scope and glitz to book publishing as the head of Random House.
lead_paragraph: Harold Evans, the crusading British newspaperman who was forced out as editor of The Times of London by Rupert Murdoch in 1982 and reinvented himself in the United States as a publisher, author and literary luminary, died on Wednesday night in New York City. He was 92.

headline: Industry City: Here’s What Happened
abstract: After a long battle to rezone the business hub in Brooklyn, developers abandoned the plan, eliminating a possible 20,000 new jobs.
lead_paragraph: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]

headline: Stalled Talks Over Covid-19 Stimulus in the U.S. Show Signs of Life
abstract: It was far from clear that Republican and Democratic negotiators would be able to reach a deal. Rio de Janeiro’s annual Carnival parade will be delayed for the first time in decades.
lead_paragraph: [Live Trump tests positive for Covid-19 updates and news.]

headline: Solo Plays for Anxious Times
abstract: The Bridge theater in London has resumed performances after the coronavirus shutdown with a series of monologues by David Hare and Alan Bennett.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Can we get his doctor’s number?

headline: As Virus Cases Surge in Europe, Hospitalizations Lag. But for How Long?
abstract: For now, countries are betting they can suppress hospital admissions and deaths without imposing more lockdowns, even as case numbers approach peak levels from last spring.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In Munich, normally brimming with boisterous crowds for Oktoberfest this month, the authorities just banned gatherings of more than five people. In Marseille, France, all bars and restaurants will be closed next Monday. And in London, where the government spent weeks urging workers to return to the city’s empty skyscrapers, it is now asking them to work from home.

headline: YouTube Tries Again to Amplify Accurate Voting Information
keywords: ['Rumors and Misinformation', 'Absentee Voting', 'Social Media', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Presidential Election of 2020']
abstract: Tech platforms have struggled to keep false and misleading information about mail-in ballots off their services.
lead_paragraph: No issue this election season is generating more misinformation online than voting by mail, even though some of the major tech platforms have made combating false information about voting a top priority.

headline: On the Ground in Louisville
keywords: ['Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Attacks on Police', 'Black People', 'Blacks']
abstract: Unrest has again rocked the city after a grand jury in Kentucky declined to bring charges against the two officers who shot Breonna Taylor.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher

headline: 40 Days to Nov. 3
abstract: And what else you need to know today.
lead_paragraph: Election Day is 40 days away, but voting is already underway in several states. To help you vote during this unusual year — in a country where voting is already more difficult than in most other democracies — we have put together a step-by-step guide.

headline: ‘The Artist’s Wife’ Review: Strife on Canvas
abstract: Lena Olin and Bruce Dern play married artists whose lives are abruptly reconfigured when one receives a diagnosis of dementia.
lead_paragraph: The best, perhaps the only reason to see “The Artist’s Wife” is Lena Olin, an actor incapable of giving a so-so performance. As Claire, though, the devoted spouse of the title, even Olin is unable to salvage this pulpy portrait of a onetime artist who has laid aside her own talents to enable those of her husband.

headline: ‘Kajillionaire’ Review: California Scheming
abstract: Miranda July’s third feature follows a family of small-scale swindlers in a deceptively sunny Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: Before watching the oddly titled “Kajillionaire,” I had thought myself immune to the appeal of Miranda July’s strange and excessively whimsical movies. Suffused with coyness and childlike characters, bizarre visuals and eccentric behavior, her two previous features — her 2005 debut, “Me and You and Everyone We Know,” and “The Future” in 2011 — had left me more irked than entertained.

headline: ‘Secret Society of Second-Born Royals’ Review: A Princess With Powers
abstract: Streaming on Disney+, Anna Mastro’s incoherent origin story follows a rebellious princess who learns she’s even more special than she thought.
lead_paragraph: The most polished superpower on display in the defiantly unexciting “Secret Society of Second-Born Royals” is the ability to say its title without spitting. Taking privilege to a whole new level, Anna Mastro’s brainless addition to the superhero genre drops us in a fictional European country where Sam (Peyton Elizabeth Lee), 15, is second in line to the throne.

headline: ‘Bird Island’ Review: Avian Therapy
abstract: This compact, whimsical film about a bird rehabilitation center in Switzerland is perched wryly between fiction and documentary.
lead_paragraph: In the very first spoken exchange in “Bird Island,” Antonin, a young new recruit at an ornithological rehab center in Geneva, asks the jaded rat-and-mouse breeder Paul: “What’s that smell?”

headline: ‘The Last Shift’ Review: Passing the Fast-Food Torch
abstract: Richard Jenkins gets a starring role as a man training his replacement at a job he’s worked at for nearly 40 years.
lead_paragraph: Richard Jenkins is one of this country’s great character actors. The near-hangdog, generally unprepossessing appearance and bearing he cultivates in many of his roles is unimpeachably effective when he’s portraying a kindly, sympathetic Everyman, as in the 2014 mini-series “Olive Kitteridge.” And it’s equally convincing when he’s incarnating a hardheaded organization man in mainstream fare like the 2012 action picture “Jack Reacher,” or getting played for a chump in an idiosyncratic black comedy like 2008’s “Burn After Reading.”

headline: ‘Ottolenghi and the Cakes of Versailles’ Review: Pastries of the Gilded Age, Made Modern
abstract: This documentary follows the star chef Yotam Ottolenghi as he assembles a crack team to make sweets for an event at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
lead_paragraph: Did you know that drinkable chocolate predated the chocolate bar? It’s one of the many historical tidbits dropped for your delectation in “Ottolenghi and the Cakes of Versailles,” a fun documentary directed by Laura Gabbert.

headline: ‘Myth of a Colorblind France’ Review: Artistry Abroad
abstract: The documentary focuses on the history of African-American expatriates in France and the writings, paintings and music they made there.
lead_paragraph: The documentary “Myth of a Colorblind France” presents a history of eminent African-Americans who have lived in France, interweaving the thoughts of Black artists residing there today with the stories of historical figures who traveled to the country beginning in the 19th century. At times, the title might seem like a misnomer, since a central point of this documentary is that many expatriates faced less discrimination in France than in the United States.

headline: ‘Public Trust’ Review: Saving National Lands
keywords: ['Wilderness Areas', 'Federal Lands', 'Land Use Policies', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Mines and Mining', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline']
abstract: This documentary follows individuals pushing back against political forces that want to privatize federal lands.
lead_paragraph: Federal land ownership isn’t a topic that leaps off the page in a news article, but “Public Trust,” a documentary that shows viewers the scenic beauty of those lands, doesn’t have the same problem.

headline: To Fight Apple and Google, Smaller App Rivals Organize a Coalition
keywords: ['Mobile Applications', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Mobile Commerce and Payments', 'Software', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Computer and Video Games', 'Smartphones']
abstract: Spotify, Match Group, Epic Games and others have created a nonprofit alliance that they hope will amplify a protest against the power of the giants.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — For months, complaints from tech companies against Apple’s and Google’s power have grown louder.

headline: The Race for Iowa, Georgia and Texas
abstract: A Times poll shows Biden and Trump neck and neck in three states: This is your morning tip sheet.
lead_paragraph: House Democrats (and Bernie Sanders) want to stop Trumpism from becoming the new normal. But first they’ll have to get him to give up power — and he’s not making any promises. It’s Thursday, and this is your politics tip sheet. Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.

headline: Civil Conversation Challenge for Teenagers, Forum 3: The Fight for Racial Justice
abstract: To what extent is the legacy of slavery and racism still present in America in 2020? In what ways has progress been made? What work remains to be done?
lead_paragraph: Update, Oct. 26: We are inviting students and teachers who participated in this Challenge and would like to reflect on the experience to tell us here.

headline: Hong Kong Police Arrest Activist for Violating 2019 Mask Ban
abstract: Joshua Wong, one of Hong Kong’s most visible pro-democracy activists, suggested that the authorities had political motives for charging him, at a time when the coronavirus has made mask-wearing ubiquitous.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Joshua Wong, one of Hong Kong’s most visible pro-democracy activists, has been arrested multiple times for taking part in antigovernment protests that erupted over the past year and roiled the city for months before the coronavirus pandemic hit.

headline: Another Big Investment in Racial Justice
abstract: Square plans to put $100 million into programs to bolster Black communities, joining the likes of Netflix and others.
lead_paragraph: Want this delivered to your inbox each day? Sign up here.

headline: Batsheva Makes a Top (or a Dress!) From a Pillowcase
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Sewing', 'Do It Yourself', 'Content Type: Service']
abstract: The Designer D.I.Y. series returns with a sleeveless look for the last stretches of summer, from the pioneer woman of modern prairie dresses.
lead_paragraph: Batsheva Hay has kept busy these last six months, creating quarantine-friendly fashion via face masks and house dresses in her signature ironic Amish patterns. At some point, she also acquired a collection of old patterned pillowcases from her mother, and they reminded Ms. Hay of one of the first garments she learned to make.

headline: Biden gives cautious answers on Breonna Taylor and the Supreme Court.
abstract: Asked by reporters about two issues of deep importance to Democrats, the party’s nominee was circumspect. The Biden campaign later released a fuller statement about Ms. Taylor.
lead_paragraph: Joseph R. Biden Jr. on Wednesday shied away from two major issues of deep importance to Democrats, giving cautious responses to reporters’ questions about the police shooting of Breonna Taylor and President Trump’s imminent nomination for the Supreme Court.

headline: 2 Republicans resign from the North Carolina elections board over a mail ballot extension.
abstract: The two Republicans on the North Carolina Board of Elections resigned in protest late Wednesday, after elections officials on Tuesday agreed to extend the deadline for receiving mail ballots in North Carolina by six days.
lead_paragraph: The two Republicans on the North Carolina Board of Elections resigned in protest late Wednesday, after elections officials on Tuesday agreed to extend the deadline for receiving mail ballots in North Carolina by six days.

headline: What will it take to vote in Milwaukee?
abstract: MILWAUKEE — For 15 years, Johnny Miller worked the polls at a church on Milwaukee’s North Side. He was born in Mississippi, where, he said, his family was terrorized by the Ku Klux Klan for attempting to cast ballots. This background makes him feel “a deep historical tie with trying to get people to vote.”
lead_paragraph: MILWAUKEE — For 15 years, Johnny Miller worked the polls at a church on Milwaukee’s North Side. He was born in Mississippi, where, he said, his family was terrorized by the Ku Klux Klan for attempting to cast ballots. This background makes him feel “a deep historical tie with trying to get people to vote.”

headline: Andrea Campbell, the first Black woman to serve as Boston’s City Council president, jumps into the mayor’s race.
abstract: Boston’s 2021 mayoral race heated up further on Thursday with the announcement that Andrea Campbell, the first Black woman to serve as City Council president, will enter the race, presumably challenging the city’s popular incumbent and a fellow Democrat, Mayor Marty Walsh.
lead_paragraph: Boston’s 2021 mayoral race heated up further on Thursday with the announcement that Andrea Campbell, the first Black woman to serve as City Council president, will enter the race, presumably challenging the city’s popular incumbent and a fellow Democrat, Mayor Marty Walsh.

headline: Trump shifts the 2020 focus by again threatening to undermine the democratic process.
abstract: President Trump’s refusal on Wednesday to commit to a peaceful transfer of power enraged Democrats and again put Republicans in a difficult position as their party leader continued to make remarks aimed at delegitimizing the election.
lead_paragraph: President Trump’s refusal on Wednesday to commit to a peaceful transfer of power enraged Democrats and again put Republicans in a difficult position as their party leader continued to make remarks aimed at delegitimizing the election.

headline: Suspect Is Charged in Shooting of 2 Louisville Police Officers
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Attacks on Police']
abstract: Demonstrators marched downtown without police intervention a day after a grand jury decided not to charge the officers who fatally shot Ms. Taylor. After curfew, protesters took refuge at a church.
lead_paragraph: The authorities in Louisville, Ky., have charged Larynzo Johnson, 26, with 14 counts of wanton endangerment and two counts of assault on a police officer after two officers were shot during protests in the city, according to the Louisville Metro Department of Corrections.

headline: A $300 unemployment supplement remains elusive for many.
abstract: A key source of federal aid to the unemployed is running out — again.
lead_paragraph: A key source of federal aid to the unemployed is running out — again.

headline: Furloughed, then laid off, a cruise worker may soon leave New York.
abstract: Tyler Lindsay worked as an event sales manager at Hornblower Cruises for four years before he was furloughed on March 17, when the pandemic hit and cruise operations ground to a halt. He was permanently laid off on Aug. 17, after the cruise line decided to suspend New York operations at least through the spring.
lead_paragraph: Tyler Lindsay worked as an event sales manager at Hornblower Cruises for four years before he was furloughed on March 17, when the pandemic hit and cruise operations ground to a halt. He was permanently laid off on Aug. 17, after the cruise line decided to suspend New York operations at least through the spring.

headline: How Did a Young, Unknown Lawyer Change the World?
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: Ruth Bader Ginsburg took on the obstacles to women’s equality incrementally, but she was powered by a larger vision.
lead_paragraph: I’ve been asked repeatedly in recent days to explain Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg’s accomplishment: How did she, a young unknown lawyer, starting basically from scratch, persuade the nine men of the Supreme Court to join her in constructing a new jurisprudence of sex equality?

headline: Trump will hold a rally in Florida tonight as Pence travels to Minneapolis.
abstract: Here are the daily schedules of the presidential and vice-presidential candidates for Thursday, Sept. 24. All times are Eastern time.
lead_paragraph: Here are the daily schedules of the presidential and vice-presidential candidates for Thursday, Sept. 24. All times are Eastern time.

headline: Mom, Can’t We Speak English Here?
abstract: A reader is bothered by her mother’s insistence on speaking Hungarian at home, which isolates her husband.
lead_paragraph: When we visit my mother, she speaks to me in Hungarian, her native language, in front of my husband who doesn’t understand a word of it. He told me he feels excluded by this because he can’t participate in our conversations. I’ve told my mother her behavior is rude, but she persists, saying, “I am Hungarian, and this is my house.” She is fluent in English, so she could honor our request if she wanted to. Also, she and I speak on the phone frequently. If she had something private to say to me, she could do it then. Otherwise, she’s nice to my husband. Any advice?

headline: Whole Foods and Trader Joe’s Downstairs, Higher Rent Upstairs
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Supermarkets and Grocery Stores']
abstract: High-end grocery stores at the ground level of rental buildings have been shown to produce higher rents, greater rent increases and faster leasing.
lead_paragraph: The appearance of a new Whole Foods Market or Trader Joe’s can be a contentious thing — a welcome neighborhood amenity to some, a sure sign of gentrification to others. The question is: Does the presence of a high-end grocer directly cause rent increases?

headline: The T List: Five Things We Recommend This Week
abstract: A Croatian monastery turned hotel, a new show at the SculptureCenter — and more.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the T List, a newsletter from the editors of T Magazine. Each week, we’re sharing things we’re eating, wearing, listening to or coveting now. Sign up here to find us in your inbox every Wednesday. You can always reach us at tlist@nytimes.com.

Biden Jr. has piled up endorsements from officials who would likely have backed almost any Republican not named Donald Trump, but one name leaps from the lengthy list of 489 national security experts who announced their support for Mr. Biden on Thursday: Gen. headline: ‘Misbehaviour’ Review: Pretty Women, Some Pretty Angry
abstract: This British comedy about a feminist protest against the 1970 Miss World contest stars Keira Knightley and Gugu Mbatha-Raw.
lead_paragraph: The cheerfully one-dimensional “Misbehaviour” puts a smiley face on female rage. A comedy flecked with seriousness, it revisits a 1970 feminist protest against the Miss World pageant in London. Bright and insistently upbeat, the movie has period polish, some swinging detail and a sympathetic cast headed by Keira Knightley, Gugu Mbatha-Raw and Jessie Buckley. Like most commercial movies about feminist history, though, it also has a toothless vision of protest and empowerment that’s doomed to fail its subject because its makers don’t (can’t) risk making the audience uncomfortable.

headline: Losing Your Hair Can Be Another Consequence of the Pandemic
abstract: Doctors are seeing a huge increase in patients who have been shedding abnormal amounts of hair, and they believe it is related to stress associated with the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: Annrene Rowe was getting ready to celebrate her 10th wedding anniversary this summer when she noticed a bald spot on her scalp. In the following days, her thick shoulder-length hair started falling out in clumps, bunching up in the shower drain.

headline: Making Art When ‘Lockdown’ Means Prison
abstract: The harshness of life behind bars is designed to crush inmates’ individuality. But a stirring exhibition at MoMA PS1 shows the prison-industrial complex can’t stifle the artistic impulse.
lead_paragraph: We’re living in a post-fact time, but that doesn’t mean there are no facts. Here are some. The United States has the largest population of captive human beings on earth, around 2.4 million, and an outsized percentage of them are Black. Since the 1980s, prison life sentences have quadrupled; the minimum age for imprisonment has dropped; the use of solitary confinement, sometimes referred to as “no-touch torture,” has grown.

headline: Luchita Hurtado: The Elusive Artist Portrays Herself

headline: How to Deal With a Friendship ‘Quiet Season’
abstract: You might emerge from 2020 with fewer friendships, and that’s OK.
lead_paragraph: Friendships need four elements to grow, according to Kat Vellos, an author and connection coach: close physical proximity, regular interactions, a compatible outlook on life and a shared commitment to being there for each other. In her book, “We Should Get Together: The Secret to Cultivating Better Friendships,” she calls these factors “seeds of connection,” because when they are all present, a healthy friendship can bloom. However, if any of these components are lacking “due to circumstance or not being actively nurtured, the greater your likelihood of failure,” she wrote.

lead_paragraph: For this week’s roundup of student comments on our writing prompts, we asked teenagers to reflect on the legacy of Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, who died on Sept. 19. Justice Ginsburg was the second woman to serve on the Supreme Court and a pioneering advocate for women’s rights. So we wondered: To what extent do young people think we have achieved equality of the sexes?

headline: I Was Bullied for Being Arab. Nine Inch Nails Threw Me a Lifeline.
abstract: As a teenage girl paralyzed with fear, one of the darkest albums of the 1990s, “The Downward Spiral,” gave me the guts to rebel against my tormentors.
lead_paragraph: During my first week of school in Kentucky, in 5th grade, at the very beginning of the first Gulf War, a boy drew a picture and hung it on the classroom wall. On one side was an illustration of me; on the other, the rest of my classmates and teacher. Above my head, in marker, the words “Saddam Salam.” The teacher came in, examined it, peeled it off and never said a thing. I’ve since joked that I was the “literal poster child for bullying,” but it’s not so funny.

headline: Looking to Brighten a Room? Try Painting a Lampshade
keywords: ['Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Art', 'Lamps and Lampshades', 'Handicrafts', 'Content Type: Service']
abstract: The British designer Cressida Bell offers a step-by-step guide on how to recreate one of her signature motifs.
lead_paragraph: Although the vast majority of the changes brought on by the pandemic have been difficult if not heartbreaking, some slivers of sunlight have made this unnerving period rewarding in small ways. When we have less to do in the outside world, our interior world can become richer: We can develop skills we’ve always wanted to explore. And we can meditate within a task engaging enough to make the news of the day fall away for an hour or two — a balm for the mind and for the soul. Taking time to do something with one’s hands, in particular, seems to alleviate stress. By the end of May, my dining-room table was covered with dozens of small rocks that I’d painted to (vaguely) resemble seals, whales, fish, seaweed, jellyfish, birds and more; I’d used my children’s watercolor set each evening (often accompanied by an adult beverage) after they’d gone to bed and the house was still. With this in mind, we present the first installment of Crafting With T, a new series of crafty how-tos, for which we call upon expert makers in the hopes of providing not only instruction but a temporary respite from the noise of the world.

headline: Prince’s Vault Reveals a Brilliant Trove With ‘Sign o’ the Times’
abstract: The reissue of his 1987 masterpiece unveils dozens of unheard songs.
lead_paragraph: “Sign o’ the Times,” Prince’s 1987 masterpiece, moves from bleak realism through partying and carnal pleasures to true love, steadfast faith and ecstatic communion. It starts with the gaunt, minimal funk of its title track — with lyrics about AIDS, drugs and gangs — and traverses R&B, jazz, rock, synth-pop, gospel and more. The album’s ambition was amplified by its playfulness, its casual mastery, its willingness to tease and please while ignoring — and transcending — boundaries. And Prince, as always, had recorded far more material than the original double LP could hold.

headline: Donald Kendall, Pepsi’s Chief During the Cola Wars, Dies at 99
abstract: He faced off against Coke, wooed a ‘Pepsi generation’ and bought Frito-Lay and fast food chains. Ever loyal, he downed a Pepsi for breakfast.
lead_paragraph: Donald M. Kendall, a former soda salesman who as the head of Pepsi challenged Coke in a worldwide cola war and personally promoted his brand as the first American consumer product made and marketed in the Soviet Union, died on Saturday at his home in Greenwich, Conn. He was 99.

headline: New York Will Review Virus Vaccines, Citing Politicization of Process

lead_paragraph: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo announced on Thursday that New York would review coronavirus vaccines that are approved by the federal government, giving the state a potentially contentious new role in the process a day after President Trump raised doubts about tougher F.D.A. guidelines.

headline: France Doubles Paid Paternity Leave to 28 Days, One of Europe’s Most Generous Plans
abstract: “When a baby arrives in the world, there is no reason it should be just the mother who takes care of it,” President Emmanuel Macron said in announcing the extension.
lead_paragraph: Paid paternity leave in France will be doubled from 14 to 28 days starting next summer, and fathers will be required to take at least a week off work after their babies are born, President Emmanuel Macron announced this week, offering one of the more generous plans in Europe.

headline: ‘Fargo’ Review: Kansas City, Here We Come
abstract: FX’s mannered Midwestern noir returns after three years with a new setting, a social conscience and Chris Rock.
lead_paragraph: “Fargo” returns to FX on Sunday night, slipping back onto television after a three-year absence like one of its Midwestern lowlifes suddenly drifting back into town. Some of the delay was pandemic-related — production on the fourth season was shut down temporarily in March — but most of it probably had to do with the workload of the show’s creator and primary writer, Noah Hawley, who oversaw several seasons of his superhero series “Legion” in the meantime.

headline: 10 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: The natural world and its intersections with human culture lie at the heart of a few books we recommend this week. In “Owls of the Eastern Ice,” the wildlife biologist Jonathan Slaght writes about his mission to document and preserve the world’s largest owls in the Russian Far East. In “Fathoms,” the Australian environmental writer Rebecca Giggs considers whales and their hold on the human imagination. And in “Soul Full of Coal Dust,” Chris Hamby looks at the vexing collision of geology and industry and politics, through the story of Appalachian coal miners and the terrible health problems they face.

headline: Britain Introduces a Scaled-Back Wage Support Plan
keywords: ['Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: As the country faces a second wave of coronavirus infections, the government doesn’t want to support jobs propped up solely by fiscal stimulus.
lead_paragraph: The British government, battling a second wave of coronavirus cases, on Thursday announced a slew of new and extended economic measures to support jobs and businesses. But the centerpiece, a wage-support program, is less generous to workers and employers than the furlough program it is replacing, which expires next month.

headline: Life in ‘Anarchist’ New York City
abstract: I saw a woman drinking iced coffee in 57 degree weather. OK, chaos agent!
lead_paragraph: Right after I learned that the Department of Justice this week designated New York City an “anarchist jurisdiction,” alongside Portland, Ore., and Seattle, I took a walk around my Brooklyn neighborhood with freshly fearful eyes. There was an older man in a plaid shirt leaning against the fence of a basketball court, eyes closed, face turned up toward the autumn sunlight. Perhaps he was enjoying a moment of solace with nature before winter, when we will surely be driven back indoors by the coronavirus. Or was he gathering strength before smashing up the local Victoria’s Secret and bringing home the lacy loot to his wife, most likely another senior citizen demented by lawlessness?

headline: How to Move Back Home
keywords: ['Content Type: Service', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Families and Family Life', 'E-Learning']
abstract: Be creative about space. Communicate early and often. Don’t let your family dynamic regress.
lead_paragraph: “You have to be creative about space,” says Lindsay Veros, a 23-year-old master’s student in college counseling and student development at North Carolina State University in Raleigh. In March, when Veros’s classes went online, she moved back home with her mother and her mother’s boyfriend. Within a week, they received word that Veros’s 25-year-old brother had lost his job at a ski resort in Colorado and was headed home, too, which meant four people, two dogs and two cats in a two-bedroom home. A generous, adaptable mind-set is beneficial when it comes to divvying up space. “Who gets the couch? Who gets the bed?” says Veros, who eventually moved into her mother’s 28-foot travel trailer parked in the driveway, where she had Wi-Fi and electricity but no running water. “I was brushing my teeth with bottled water in the yard,” she says.

headline: ‘The Trial of the Chicago 7’ Review: They Fought the Law
abstract: Aaron Sorkin and an all-star cast re-enact a real-life ’60s courtroom drama with present-day implications.
lead_paragraph: Anyone who has been paying attention to the news recently might conclude that Karl Marx was wrong. History doesn’t repeat itself, and it’s usually tragedy and farce at the same time.

headline: Force Feed
abstract: Rachel Fabi’s debut puzzle breaks the internet.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — This is Rachel Fabi’s very welcome New York Times crossword debut, but if you ever dip your toes into other puzzle pools then her name might ring a bell — she has constructed for USA Today, independent venues like Inkubator, and other spots. For those of us hornswoggled by the science and technology clues, well, this constructor is a bioethics scholar; for those of us bemused by the trivia, she won on Jeopardy last year. I have no explanation for the extremely clever clusters of related clues, but that aspect of this grid made it a standout for this solver.

Fremont’s previous memoir, revealing that her parents were Jewish rather than Catholic, led her father, who has since died, to update his will and declare her dead. He “metaphorically killed her for it,” our reviewer, Alexandra Styron, reasoned. What’s a writer to do but write another memoir to “understand why”?

headline: From All-Star Flop to Astute Satire in Just 50 Years
abstract: “The Rise and Rise of Michael Rimmer” involved major names like John Cleese and Harold Pinter and anticipated U.S. and British politics. Why didn’t it catch on?
lead_paragraph: If you scan the roster of British stage and screen luminaries who created “The Rise and Rise of Michael Rimmer,” you might wonder why you’ve never heard of this vicious 1970 satire starring Peter Cook as an amoral ad man who manipulates polling data to ascend to the heights of political power. In addition to Cook, the cast includes the Monty Python founders Graham Chapman and John Cleese. Denholm Elliott plays an unctuous pollster, and the playwright Harold Pinter gives a memorably nasty performance as a talk-show host.
